DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Banana Workers End Strike Against Chiquita Brands
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of workers returned to their jobs Monday after ending a 7-week-old strike against U.S. banana giant Chiquita Brands that caused an estimated $60 million in losses to the Honduran economy. Threatened with dismissal after the government sent in troops to end the strike, the banana workers accepted a 25 percent pay hike Sunday and agreed to return to work. The strikers had earlier demanded a 60 percent raise. Activity in the fields and installations owned by Cincinnati-based Chiquita Brands International Inc. appeared normal Monday morning for the first time since 10,000 banana workers walked out on June 25. ``We did not achieve our demands, but we are satisfied,'' union president Rene Ayestas said. Hundreds of troops and police remained at Chiquita's facilities in the city of La Lima, 180 miles north of the capital, Tegucigalpa. Government spokesman Martin Baide Urmeneta said the army will stay in La Lima ``until the situation is normal.'' Police said five people, including two workers and three security policemen, were injured when troops and police moved in Saturday to dislodge 4,000 strikers who were occupying company property in La Lima. On Sunday, the strikers announced they had accepted ``without any conditions'' a proposal by President Rafael Leonardo Callejas that would raise the minimum monthly salary from $246 to $308.50. Callejas had proposed the settlement on July 28, but it was rejected by the union. The company rejected the union's counter-proposal, and the impasse led Callejas to send in the troops. Ayestas said Callejas' measures to end the strike were ``drastic and incorrect.'' Callejas, in a nationwide radio and television address Sunday, said the strikers had ``dragged the country toward social and economic destabilization'' and ``threatened to destroy the democratic process in Honduras.'' ``There are no winners or losers,'' Callejas said. ``The situation was overcome so that we can face the enormous problems that afflict the nation.'' Chiquita produces and exports 60 percent of Honduras' banana crop, the country's main source of foreign exchange, and preliminary government estimates said the strike caused $60 million in losses.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Graham Says He Never Influenced Bank Regulators in CenTrust Seizure
DOC.TEXT: A former aide in Sen. Bob Graham's office said Monday he had arranged a meeting between bank regulators and Centrust Bank, which later failed causing the biggest bailout of the savings and loan crisis. NBC News reported Monday that the aide, Steve Josias, had used his position as a special counsel in Graham's office to bring pressure on bank regulators looking into the thrift's finances. But Josias denied the report and Graham's office said the Democratic senator had had no knowledge of the meeting. Josias' Fort Lauderdale firm had handled some real estate matters for CenTrust before the 1987 meeting with officials from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said Ken Klein, Graham's spokesman. The day after the meeting, Graham's office manager met with Josias to tell him such a meeting was against the senator's policy, Klein said. Graham himself did not learn of the meeting until earlier in 1990 and characterized it as poor judgment, Klein said. ``We do not seek to intervene with regulators on specific cases,'' Klein said. Graham, a member of the Senate banking committee, said in an interview from his Washington, D.C., office he had done nothing to delay the seizure of the Miami-based thrift by the government. The CenTrust bailout will cost taxpayers $1.7 billion. ``I would say categorically (my office) did not have any effect on any action by federal regulators that would have affected their decisions,'' Graham said. Josias told The Associated Press that NBC's report was ``ludicrous.'' He described himself as ``merely a convener'' of the 30-minute meeting. CenTrust officials called it because they felt federal officials were failing to respond to questions on regulatory procedures, he said. Josias worked in Graham's office for six months as special counsel, providing legal expertise, Klein said. ``When lawyers called (Graham's office), they were given to the lawyer,'' Josias said, when asked about the CenTrust call that led to the meeting. ``I should have said then that I know CenTrust and my legal firm did work for them.'' When regulators seized CenTrust in February, they blamed its failure on speculative investing, including purchase of more than $1 billion in junk bonds. They also cited the lavish spending of the institution's chairman, David L. Paul, who spent millions of dollars of deposits on a museum-quality art collection kept at his home; a company yacht, limousines, a corporate jet and gold-plated toilets in the executive washrooms. Paul has declined comment about CenTrust and its seizure. A ``fraud squad'' of investigators is examining the legality of $328,000 in political contributions by Paul. Graham said he has never received political contributions from Paul or any CenTrust political action committees.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Filed Against Hanford Contractors
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit filed Monday against 13 contractors at the Hanford nuclear reservation claims people working at and living around the plant were hurt by the reckless release of radiation and toxic chemicals. The class-action suit filed in U.S. District Court seeks unspecified damages for health threats and reduced property values, said Tom Foulds, who heads a team of lawyers on the project. Twenty-one people were named as plaintiffs, but the number of people affected could eventually reach 5,000, according to the suit. It claims that exposure to high doses of radiation and toxic chemicals and hazardous storage conditions have caused death, disease, disfigurement, miscarriages, birth defects and infertility and sterility. ``The thrust of the suit is for recovery for personal injuries and other bodily damage that already has been done,'' Foulds said. ``But the subclasses mention damage to property arising out of the possibility of explosion and continuing operations. We are trying to get the hazards abated and removed.'' The suit seeks an abatement order against the companies, requiring them to remove and clean up any continuing contamination, underground storage tanks, radioactive sediments in the Columbia River and to establish a fund for monitoring health effects. Two federal studies are attempting to determine the health effects of Hanford operations and the state and two federal agencies have signed a 30-year, $57 billion cleanup pact. The partial results of a study released last month indicated a potential for increased thyroid diseases among people living downwind of the 560-square-mile government plutonium-production facility. ``This lawsuit came to a head when the dose reconstruction report was made,'' Foulds said `` ... Once that came out, it seemed to verify a lot of very strong indications I had already received during my research.'' The suit does not name the government agencies that contracted Hanford operations _ the Department of Energy and its predecessor, the Atomic Energy Commission _ because the government's immunity from tort claims would make it difficult to win, Foulds said. ``It was clear to us we should try to go after the contractors that ran this. They don't enjoy the same immunity unless they can show they complied with all the applicable government regulations,'' Foulds said. ``I don't think they can prove that. There is a clear pattern of failure and violations.'' Bill Whiting, a spokesman for Westinghouse Hanford Co., the reservation's current prime contractor, said company attorneys had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment. Attempts to reach attorneys for other corporations after normal business hours were unsuccessful. The lawsuit accuses past and present Hanford contractors ``carelessly, intentionally, recklessly and unlawfully'' allowed the releases of radioactive and non-radioactive materials. The Hanford reservation was begun in top secrecy as part of the Manhattan Project that produced nuclear materials for the atomic bombs that ended World War II. The lawsuit was filed on the 45th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, which killed at least 140,000 people. Documents released since 1986 show a pattern of intentional and accidental releases of large amounts of radiation and hazardous wastes into the air, soil and water from Hanford operations.

DOC.HEAD: Catch-22 of Homelessness: More Can Mean Less Public Sympathy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For two years, a city within a city lived and grew in the shadow of City Hall. Then one morning in July, buses pulled up to Civic Center Plaza to take away the homeless people who camped under knobby-branched olive trees amid mildewed mattresses, tattered blankets and shopping carts heaped with the eclectic possessions of modern nomads. The homeless and their advocates decried the city's insensitivity. ``It's not that they care about these people not having homes,'' said Jill, 28, who had been bouncing in and out of welfare hotels with her boyfriend, Ron, for six months. ``They just don't want them to be seen.'' But Mayor Art Agnos said he does care. That's why he allowed the homeless to live in the park while he arranged a ``humane alternative'': two full-service shelters equipped with everything from job training to drug counseling, facilities designed to ease people off the street for good. In cities across the nation, city officials and advocates for the homeless talk about how public emotion _ hostility and compassion, frustration and sympathy _ has escalated as the ranks of the homeless swell. ``People are frustrated it's not over. We're into quick fixes,'' said Mary Ann Gleason, director of the Denver Healthcare for the Homeless Clinic, which serves about 6,500 people a year. ``There are hundreds of thousands of people we've gotten off the streets, but there are more falling in behind them.'' No one knows how many Americans are homeless. Estimates range from 300,000 to 3 million. But no one disputes the fact that the number is increasing, and greater numbers mean greater visibility. ``It's a common perception that at least among some parts of society, there's not only less compassion but more organized hostility'' toward the homeless, said Gary Blasi, president of the National Coalition for the Homeless and a Legal Aid Foundation attorney in Los Angeles, a city with a homeless population estimated at more than 150,000. ``A large part of the source of the hostility is that it's not great to have a lot of homeless people around when you're a tourist city,'' Blasi said. ``It's not just the cable cars and the Golden Gate anymore.'' What passes for heartlessness often is case of empty municipal pockets, with compassionate programs succumbing to financial pressures. The city council in Washington, faced with a $95 million budget deficit, voted in June to gut its policy of guaranteeing overnight shelter to anyone who requested it. That ordinance was championed by the late homeless activist Mitch Snyder and passed six years ago by more than 70 percent of the vote. In Philadelphia, 80 members of the Mayor's Public-Private Task Force on Homelessness resigned in July to protest massive cuts in the city's budget for homeless services after the amount dropped from $34 million to $10 million in two years. At the same time, the city plans to spend $1 million closing off spaces under train platforms in a downtown station where people like to sleep. ``I see no abatement whatsoever in people's concern, people calling, people coming in, people of all ages making an effort and reaching out,'' said Phyllis Ryan, director of the Philadelphia Committee for the Homeless and one of the former task force members. ``The government resources have just not been sufficient. I think they just looked out there and decided who's a voter and who isn't.'' In some places, voters aggravated by the homeless problem are using their electoral clout to protest. Residents in Santa Monica, Calif., have collected thousands of signatures to place a proposition on the November ballot to make the city attorney's office an elected one. The current city attorney, Robert Myers, has refused to prosecute people for sleeping outdoors. ``I think there's an increasing feeling of helplessness,'' said Barbara Stinchfield, Santa Monica's community development manager. ``We get proposals weekly ... on how to solve the homeless problem. It's frustrating, it's troubling, it's unsettling, it's not getting better. But most people are not reacting in a really destructive way.'' Citizens in Santa Cruz, Calif., took their anger to the streets. When 200 homeless activists rallied outside the Santa Cruz County Courthouse demanding an end to the city's camping ban, they were outnumbered by 600 counterdemonstrators who said they were tired of giving ``bums'' and ``squatters'' a free ride in the seaside town about 75 miles south of San Francisco. ``I think what happened in Santa Cruz and San Francisco has to do with something much bigger than homelessness,'' Gleason said. The American public, she believes, feels angry but helpless over things like the HUD scandal and the savings-and-loan bailout: ``I think people are feeling so frustrated from being bamboozled and taken advantage of on every front, homelessness gets lumped in with the rest of it. It's very easy to take your anger out on the poor.'' It's more difficult to find effective solutions to the problem, but citizens in Seattle are trying, said Martha Dilts, executive director of Seattle Emergency Housing Service. Seattle residents are trying to raise $1 million for transitional housing for homeless families, and a local real estate company's agents are donating part of their commissions to fight homelessness. ``I see people starting to realize that homelessness is affecting more people, that it could happen to your family or your neighbor. There's a feeling of community and a sense of `We can do it,''' said Dilts, a member of the governor's homeless task force. Advocates agree that homelessness will persist until society deals with the lack of affordable housing, access to drug treatment and mental health facilities and absence of affordable childcare and other support services for the working poor. Meanwhile, cities are eing forced to expand and improve shelter facilities, something many communities are loathe to do. Although Washington has been under court order to expand its shelter system, council members say neighborhoods will not accept one without a fight. In one area, a homeless man's arrest on murder charges galvanized the neighbors; they held bake sales to finance their effort to close the shelter in which he lived. In a suburban Westchester County, N.Y., community, neighbors have filed five lawsuits to try to stop construction of a 108-unit complex for homeless women and children. In a San Jose, Calif., neighborhood, residents are fighting a homeless shelter they believe is responsible for a 120 percent increase in felonies in their area. ``If there was a shred of sympathy in me before,'' one resident said, ``after seeing this, I have lost all compassion.'' Sometimes, however, neighbors find the cure far less painful than they had anticipated. A project to help mentally ill homeless women in Denver was welcomed into a neighborhood after residents' fears were allayed by the project's planners. The house has been a smashing, problem-free success: 78 percent of those who passed through there in the first year now have homes, and neighbors now drop by to donate lawn chairs and tomato plants. ``I don't think the American public knows what's going on in homeless services today,'' Gleason said. ``Part of it is misinformation, part of it is honest-to-God displaced anger. When people understand both what the homeless reality is, and what we're trying to do about it, it paints a whole different picture.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Transcript of President Bush's remarks upon his arrival at the White House from Camp David on Sunday: BUSH: Well, I just wanted to fill you all in on the diplomatic activity that is taking place, intensive diplomatic activity around the world. I've got to go in now; I'm getting another call from President Ozal of Turkey, with whom I have been in previous conversation. Yesterday, I talked to him. I talked this morning to Prime Minister Kaifu, and I applaud Japan's stance, cracking down on the imports from Iraq. I just hung up, up there in Camp David, talking with Prime Minister Mulroney. We're all in the same accord, he and President Mitterrand, with whom I've spoken, Chancellor Kohl, Margaret Thatcher. And I think the Alliance, the NATO Alliance, is thinking exactly the same way on this. I also talked yesterday to Kuwait's Emir and gave him certain assurances. What's emerging is nobody is _ seems to be showing up as willing to accept anything less than total withdrawal from Iraq _ from Kuwait of the Iraqi forces and no puppet regime. We've been down that road, and there will be no puppet regime that will be accepted by any countries that I'm familiar with. And there seems to be a united front out there that says Iraq, having committed brutal, naked aggression, ought to get out and that the _ this concept of their installing some puppet leaving behind will not be acceptable. So, we're pushing forward on diplomacy. We've gotten _ tomorrow I will meet here in Washington with the Secretary General of the United Nations _ I mean the Secretary General of NATO _ and Margaret Thatcher will be coming in here tomorrow, and I will be continuing this diplomatic effort. And I'm sure you know of the meeting I had in Camp David with some of our top military people, and I will continue that kind of consultation as well. Question: How are you going to _ how are you going to keep the puppet government from being accepted and installed? And are you going to. ... BUSH: There is no intention on the part of any of these countries to accept a puppet government, and that signal is going out loud and clear to Iraq. And I will not discuss with you what my options are or might be, but they're wide open, I can assure you of that. Question: The Saudi Arabians and the Turks, have they _ have you talked to Saudi Arabia and the Turks about turning off the oil pipelines through their countries? And are they. ... BUSH: All options are open and there is a strong feeling on the part of the NATO countries to whom I've talked, Turkey being one of them, that we must have concerted, and I'd say, well, concerted action to isolate Iraq economically. And you can ... you can just assume from there that those matters are being considered. Question: Are the Saudis inclined to cut off the pipeline, Mr. President? BUSH: I can't tell you the state of play. I've discussed this with King Fahd and I _ whether I'll be talking to him again today, I don't know. But I'm not going to characterize their position on this. Let them speak for themselves. Yeah? Question: Mr. President, what is the situation on the ground? Do the Iraqis appear to be dug in or are they readying. ... BUSH: Iraq lied once again. They said they were going to start moving out today and we have no evidence that they're moving out. Question: Do we have evidence that there's 18 divisions, new divisions coming in. ... BUSH: I'm not going to discuss the intelligence situation on the ground right now, but I've not heard a figure of 18 new divisions going in. Question: Have you given any. ... BUSH: Just a minute. Anne? Question: Are Americans in danger in Kuwait or other areas down there? And can you. ... BUSH: I wouldn't want to say they're in danger, but I _ you know how I feel about the protection of American life and willingness to do whatever is necessary to protect it. But I don't have the feeling that they're in imminent danger right now. Question: And the people who are now in control in Kuwait are saying they may close some of the embassies in Kuwait City, that they will regard any reaction against them as _ ``You should take care if you have your nationals in our country.'' Isn't that a threat? BUSH: I'm not trying to characterize threats. The threat is the vicious aggression against Kuwait. And that speaks for itself. And anything collaterally is just simply more indication that these are outlaws _ international outlaws and renegades. And I want to see the United Nations move soon with Chapter VII sanctions. And I want to see the rest of the world join us, as they are in overwhelming numbers, to isolate Saddam Hussein. Question: Mr. President, how can you and other world leaders prevent the installation of what you've termed a ``puppet'' government? BUSH: Just wait. Watch and learn. Yeah? Question: Mr. President, have you, in fact, tried to reach Saddam Hussein since you're calling all these other people? BUSH: No. No, I have not. Question: King Hussein has embraced him. Question: Mr. President, have we asked the Saudi Arabians for the use of their military bases? BUSH: Hmm? Question: Have we asked the Saudi Arabians. ... BUSH: I'm not going to discuss what I'm talking to the Saudis about. I'm not going to discuss anything to do about military options at all. Yeah? Question: Mr. President, have you talked to King Hussein of Jordan since he indicated his support. ... BUSH: I talked to him once and that's all. Question: Are you disappointed in what he said? Question: But he's embraced Saddam Hussein. He went to Baghdad and embraced. ... BUSH: What's your question? I can read. Question: Are you disappointed in what King Hussein said? BUSH: I want to see the Arab states join the rest of the world in condemning this outrage and doing what they can to get Saddam Hussein out. Now, he was talking _ King Hussein _ about an Arab solution, but I am disappointed to find any comment by anyone that apologizes or appears to condone what's taken place. Question: Is Secretary Cheney going to Saudi Arabia? BUSH: I'm not going to comment on anything that we're doing of that nature. Question: Mr. President, are you disappointed in the failure of the Arab _ other Arab nations to make more progress toward resolving the situation? BUSH: Well, I was told by one leader that I respect enormously _ I believe this was back on Friday _ that they needed 48 hours to find what was called ``an Arab solution.'' That obviously has failed. And of course I'm disappointed that the matter hasn't been resolved before now. This is a very serious matter. I'll take one more and then I've got to go to work over here. Question: Have you already taken steps to protect Americans over there? Have you moved. ... BUSH: I am not going to discuss what we're doing in terms of moving of forces, anything of that nature. But I view it very seriously, not just that but any threat to any other countries as well as I view very seriously our determination to reverse out this aggression. And please believe me, there are an awful lot of countries that are in total accord with what I've just said. And I salute them. They are staunch friends and allies. And we will be working with them all for collective action. This will not stand. This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait. I've got to go. I have to go to work. I've got to go to work.

DOC.HEAD: From Slurs to Skinheads, East Germany Grapples With Racial Tension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese man is thrown from a moving train, a factory fires foreigners to trim its payroll, young toughs club a Kurd unconcious. Racism is increasing in East Germany. Blessed with new freedom and German pride, but plagued by a crashing economy and competition for scarce jobs, East Germans have become openly hostile to foreign minorities. ``I am ashamed of the behavior of the East German people,'' said Horst Kinitz, chief of the nation's employment agency. Organized bands of neo-Nazi skinheads _ radical youths with shaved heads and aggressive attitudes _ have attacked Asians and Africans, who make up the bulk of East Germany's foreign workers. About 80,000 Vietnamese, Angolans, Mozambicans and Cubans have been working in East Germany under arrangements made with those countries by the former Communist government. ``I'm very afraid,'' said Ngo Manh Long, a Vietnamese worker in an East Berlin textile factory. ``The gangs make problems for us. The German people are angry we are here.'' Few such incidents were apparent under the Communists, who maintained order with a suffocating internal security system. Rapid economic and social upheaval, and East Germany's emergence as a Central European crossroads, have left its people dizzy with change after four decades of isolationism. Lt. Joachim Crannich of the national police said the agency recorded 32 cases of violence against foreigners in the first half of 1990, but added the actual count probably was much higher. ``You have to see it in the context of our social changes,'' he said. ``With the move toward democracy and introduction of the free market, many people are anxious. If you're an East German and you lose your job, but you see a foreigner keep his job, that creates a certain frustation.'' Among the incidents this year: _Skinheads attacked a grooup of Vietnamese on a train from Eisenach to Berlin. _A Vietnamese was pushed off a train and seriously injured in Wittenburg. _In Leipzig, skinheads attacked African students, shouting racial epithets and ``Foreigners out!'' _A dozen skinheads covered a Vietnamese man with spray paint in Rudolstadt. An Iraqi Kurd said young toughs jumped him, pulled his jacket over his head and beat him unconcious. ``I felt like a Jew during the Third Reich,'' he said. Many people blame organized radical right-wing groups, such as the National Alternative, for such attacks. The group denies it. Juergen Helfricht, spokesman for the Interior Ministry, said there was no proof the National Alternative was involved in anything illegal, so police had no grounds to move against it. Experts say the skinheads, despite the attention they draw, are only the violent fringe of a broader problem. ``The sensitivity in the East German population about racism is abominably low,'' said Annetta Kahane, the East Berlin city official who deals with foreigners' concerns. ``It's going to take a long time until it reaches the same level as West Germany, and it's not very good in West Germany.'' Factories have become bastions of racism. East Germany switched to a free market and merged its economy with West Germany's on July 1, a prelude to reunification in December. Unemployment is growing and there are numerous reports of foreign workers being fired first as businesses trim payrolls. Volker Daehne, deputy chief of the East German employment authority, said he had 296 documented cases since July 1 of foreign workers being fired illegally. ``It's shameful to bring foreigners into this country and then fire them at will,'' he said. Manh, the Vietnamese worker, is employed by an East Berlin maker of men's clothing called Becon Classic, a former state concern now operating independently. He said there is open hostility in the plant. A complaint filed with the East Berlin government by Vietnamese workers says rents have tripled in housing supplied by Becon and two other factories. East Germans are protected from extreme rent increases. Manh said he and eight other Vietnamese were living in a one-room apartment and had paid the equivalent of $19 a month each, but the rent more than tripled in July. Veronika Arendt-Rojah, a West Berlin lawyer representing Vietnamese at Becon Classic, said she would file suit to block the increases. Plant spokesman Wolfgang Boerner said there were no plans to fire foreigners. He said rents had to be raised because subsidizing them was a burden on the company.

DOC.HEAD: Election Winners in Burma Still Waiting to Govern
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Two months after winning an overwhelming mandate to govern, Burma's democratic opposition is being kept out of office by a military administration that shows no signs of stepping aside. The ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council has added new conditions that could indefinitely delay a transfer of power to the National League for Democracy, which swept the May 27 parliamentary election. ``The scene is set for a confrontation and the feeling is now that, unless the NLD stands up to be counted, the (military rulers) will prevail,'' said a senior Western diplomat reached in Rangoon, capital of Burma. ``The NLD may have scored a major election victory, but the (military rulers) are the still the ones with the guns,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Anti-government street protests have increased despite prohibitions under martial law. Diplomats said demonstrations by young people in Rangoon and Mandalay, to the north, were the largest in months. A cartoon in an exile newsletter expressed the feelings of many Burmese. A mean-looking soldier points a revolver at the face of a ragged civilian and snarls: ``Idiot! I said I'd give you elections _ I didn't say I'd hand over power!'' On July 29, More than 1,000 supporters of the National League for Democracy waited outside a Rangoon conference hall where party officials adopted a resolution demanding Parliament be convened in September. Other demands in the resolution included dialogue with the government, democratic rights and the release of party leaders. They include Aung San Suu Kyi, an outspoken critic of military rule who remains under house arrest although her one-year sentence expired July 19. Police and soldiers surrounded the hall throughout the two-day meeting. Gen. Saw Maung's government promised the election, the first in 30 years of authoritarian rule, after taking power in September 1988. His soldiers killed thousands of civilians who demonstrated for democracy. Western diplomats said the government probably was astonished by the magnitude of its loss. The National League took 392 of 485 parliamentary seats, and most of the rest went to groups close to it. After it came to power, Saw Maung's government suspended the constitution and said the parliament to be chosen in the promised elections must approve a new one before power could be transferred. On March 27, the general said political parties could follow their own programs after the election. ``Some are saying an interim government will be first formed and power transferred under an interim constitution and they will take time in drafting a constitution,'' he said. ``They can do what they want.'' Before the vote, the government spokesmen also said the new parliament could adopt a constitution based on the charter of 1947, the one that replaced it in 1974, or entirely new. Following their victory, National League officials said they wanted to adopt the 1947 constitution temporarily and revise it. On July 13, the powerful chief of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, said the 1947 constitution no longer was appropriate and a totally new one was needed. He added more conditions July 27, saying the government would convene a national conference to provide guidelines for drafting a charter, which then must be approved by referendum. ``Drafting of an interim constitution to obtain state power will not be accepted in any way, and if it is done, effective action will be taken according to the law,'' he declared. ``A political organization does not automatically obtain the three sovereign powers of legislative, administrative and judiciary power by the emergence of a people's assembly,'' he said. The new parliament's function was merely to draw up a constitution, he said. The National League disagreed, and declared at its conference that the parliament was not merely a constituent assembly. ``It is against political nature that the NLD, which has overwhelmingly won enough seats ... to form a government, itself has been prohibited from the minimum of democratic rights,'' the declaration said. ``It is shameful in the eyes of the people and the international community.'' Party leaders had drafted a provisional constitution that would be refined by the parliament, the statement said. A Western diplomat said the declaration was a direct challenge to the military, but that the National League was treading carefully. Resentment of military rule remains strong and widespread, but diplomats doubt the huge demonstrations of 1988 will be repeated. ``The army has constantly reminded people that it is quite willing to take the same action as it did in 1988,'' one said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Jack Nicholson says TV interviews destroy an actor's credibility, but he wouldn't mind acting on the tube. Nicholson gives interviews to the print media only. ``You can say anything in the printed word and both sides admit that it's open to interpretation,'' he said in the Aug. 11 issue of TV Guide. Nicholson said of TV interviews: ``There is no way you can get people to believe you on screen if they know who you really are through television.'' The actor's latest movie, ``The Two Jakes,'' a sequel to ``Chinatown,'' opens Friday. He said he would have liked working on the CBS miniseries ``Lonesome Dove'' and might want to turn to television for a long-cherished project about Napoleon. ``Maybe I made a mistake not doing television,'' Nicholson said. ``Now it might tempt me.''

Spanish director Pedro Almodovar says lingering American puritanism is to blame for the uproar over his latest film, ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' ``Everybody talks about this growing puritanism, which is true,'' Almodovar said in the Aug. 13 issue of Newsweek. ``People say it's the result of AIDS. But in fact it's a result of this conservative nature inherent in American culture.'' Almodovar, best known for last year's hit ``Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,'' lost a fight over an X rating assigned to his new film and decided to release it without a rating rather than re-edit the movie. The film is about a former porn star who falls in love with a man who keeps her tied up. Feminists who criticize the film are treating women ``as if they were dumb animals,'' Almodovar said.

Jane Pauley says she feels some responsibility for a 17 percent drop in the ratings of ``Today.'' Pauley left the NBC morning program last December and said in the Aug. 13 issue of People magazine she feels guilty about the ratings slump. Guilty, she said, ``to the degree that any of it was my doing.'' Pauley was succeeded on ``Today'' after 13 years by Deborah Norville.

Three robbers made off with $260,000 in cash from souvenir sales at a New Kids on the Block concert, police said. Police spokesman Jacques Morrisseau said the robbers, armed Sunday with revolvers and a bogus hand grenade, entered a room in Olympic Stadium where 12 employees were counting money after a show by the teen-age pop group. The robbers handcuffed the employees and placed the fake grenade near a door, warning that the device would explode if someone tried to open the door.

Rue McClanahan and Casey Kasem criticized the judge in a trial over a monkey trainer's defamation complaint against an animal rights group. The two spoke to reporters Saturday and criticized state District Judge Myron Leavitt's participation in the case brought by Bobby Berosini. McClanahan, who appears on NBC's ``Golden Girls,'' Kasem of radio's ``American Top 40'' and actress Peggy McCay, all animal rights activists, said Leavitt had taken contributions from the Stardust Hotel, where Berosini performs. The hotel is not involved in the trial between Berosini and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. Berosini is suing PETA for $80 million, claiming the organization slandered him by releasing a videotape showing him disciplining orangutans used in his show. Defense attorneys did not object to Leavitt hearing the case and did not seek to move the case to another court.

DOC.HEAD: Spreading Blazes Scorch Italy From North to South
DOC.TEXT: Forest fires, fed by wind and months of drought, have scorched tens of thousands of acres across Italy, disrupting train and highway travel and force evacuation of hill towns in the path of the flames. Tuscany and Liguria in northcentral and eastern Italy were hardest hit, but blazes were also reported Sunday in the hills outside small towns near Rome, in the central mountainous Abruzzo region and in the southern region whose principal city is Naples. A major state highway running to Leghorn, a Tuscan port city, was closed near the city for a second day on Sunday. The rail line linking Leghorn to Genoa, further up on the Tyrrhenian coast, was periodically closed. No major injuries were reported, but several homes were reported destroyed in the evacuated hamlet of Castellaccio, in the hills outside Leghorn. Planes sprayed flame-retardant chemicals on the blazes, which burned for a fourth day through the hills outside Leghorn. Two French chemical-spraying aircraft were dispatched from Corsica to help, state television said. Rainfall has been 40 percent below normal this year, creating tinder-like conditions in the woods.

DOC.HEAD: Long, Hot Summer for Cable Mogul Ted Turner
DOC.TEXT: It's been a long, hot summer for Ted Turner. Mediocre ratings and a loss of up to $26 million plagued his Goodwill Games, his Cable News Network got a new president and his relationship with Jane Fonda burned up the gossip columns. The fiery entrepreneur from Atlanta kept his chin up Saturday when he spoke to reporters the day before the Goodwill Games concluded. Speculation was rampant that the games, founded by Turner in 1986, may no longer be sponsored by Turner Broadcasting System Inc. Turner said he expected a decision from the TBS board of directors within six weeks on whether to continue the network's participation. ``Yes, we did lose some money _ the exact amount will not be known until later _ but in my opinion it's a reasonable down payment to an event that will grow in stature and at some point break even,'' Turner said. The Seattle games, which lasted 17 days, received an overall rating on TBS of 3.2. A rating of 5.0 was anticipated. One A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings point is equal to 921,000 homes. ``Yes, the ratings did not meet our estimates, but the Winter and Summer Olympics did not meet the estimates of ABC and NBC,'' Turner said. Last month, Turner hired an outsider, Tom Johnson, to be president of CNN. Johnson, a former publisher of the Los Angeles Times, left his job as vice chairman of the newspaper's parent Times Mirror Co. to work at Turner's 24-hour, all-news network. Turner found time this summer to play his ``Mouth of the South'' role when he insulted religious groups by saying Christianity is ``for losers.'' He later appeared at a Woodstock, Ga., church to apologize. All the while, Turner and Fonda have been burning up the gossip circuit. An Atlanta magazine lampooned their relationship by superimposing Turner's head on a photograph of a muscleman for a cover story. Turner, chairman and president of TBS, disclosed last month during the TBS annual shareholders meeting that the Goodwill Games would lose as much as $26 million, twice what had been projected. He has maintained since 1986 that the games were not designed to make money but to foster good will between nations and showcase the world's best athletes. But some observers feel Turner may have trouble convincing the TBS board of directors the altruistic benefits of the games justify costs. Hank Whittemore, whose book ``CNN: The Inside Story'' was published earlier this year and chronicles the network's first 10 years, said he couldn't predict whether Turner would stick with the Goodwill Games, but suggested there are some parallels between the games and the early days of CNN. ``CNN lost $77 million in five years and people said when is Turner going to sell out and go back to being what he was _ the owner of another network (the TBS SuperStation) and a bunch of sports teams,'' Whittemore said. Turner officials in charge of the Goodwill Games are cautious when discussing the future. Terence F. McGuirk, TBS vice president in charge of sports, said financial losses aside, the Goodwill Games were a success. The goal of the '90 Games was to build the credibility of the event in the athletic world, which was accomplished, he said. Still, McGuirk added, ``We are not in a position today to tell you definitely that the company is ready to commit to a certain involvement with the Goodwill Games in the future.'' It is conceivable, McGuirk said, that TBS will remain with the Games but in a different role. He would not speculate about what that role might be.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rice Exports By Vietnam Cause Price Jumps at Home
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam has been exporting so much rice that domestic prices for the staple have doubled in Ho Chi Minh City and some provinces in the last month, Radio Hanoi reports. Exporters ``have rushed to the city to buy up all the rice available,'' Vietnam's official radio said. ``This has given the people the impression that there is a scarcity of rice, thus prompting many families to buy rice to keep in reserve.'' Domestic rice prices have almost doubled in other provinces as well, said the report, which gave no price figures. A text of last week's broadcast was seen in Bangkok today. Officials were trying to control rice prices by banning sales to unauthorized exporters and placing one agency in charge of buying and selling grain within Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, the radio report said. The government also plans to buy grain for reserve stocks, the report said. Vietnam exported 1.15 million tons of rice in the first six months of 1990, double its exports for the same period last year. Analysts predict the Communist country will export a record 2 to 2.4 million tons this year. Vietnam went from widespread food shortages in 1988 to become the world's third-largest rice exporter last year. Economic reforms have given farmers incentives by allowing them to keep more profits.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Ask Wyoming to Elect a GOP Woman Governor
DOC.TEXT: Republicans are putting Wyoming's nickname as the Equality State to the test this year, asking residents to elect their second woman governor in state history. Two women are vying for the GOP nomination in the state's Aug. 21 primary, hoping for a shot at first-term Democrat Mike Sullivan, who is one of the most popular politicians in heavily Republican Wyoming. ``Wyoming touts the slogan that this is the Equality State. I'll have to run on that premise,'' Nyla Murphy, one of the GOP contenders, says. ``We had the first woman governor in our nation's history, I see no reason why we couldn't have another woman governor.'' Her GOP rival is Mary Mead, who says her life on a ranch has more than prepared her for the governor's office. ``I pull a calf at 4 a.m., cook for men for breakfast, go to a bank meeting at 9 a.m., move cows, try to get my damn snowmobile to run to check heifers, work outside all day and then have a dinner party,'' she said. ``That's not untypical for any ranch woman.'' But Wyoming historian T.A. Larson think it will take more than a nickname to get Murphy or Mead elected this year. Larson said Wyoming has been ``mighty slow'' in living up to its Equality State tag. ``I think there has been a little more male chauvinism in Wyoming than many other states, so I think this election will be a really substantial test,'' Larson said. Sullivan surprised many people four years ago when he left his law practice to run for governor and handily defeated Republican Pete Simpson, the brother of U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson. This time around, some Republicans who had considered running for the office pulled out early, saying Sullivan would be too hard to beat. The governor has been criticized by his challengers as lacking leadership to bring about a strong economic recovery to the mineral-dependent state. While the campaigns have been focusing on the need for economic expansion, neither Murphy nor Mead has offered specific plans on how to bring it about. Sullivan said he's hopeful voters will cast their ballots based on the issues, not gender, but acknowledges: ``I don't think you can overlook the fact that you have a woman who is a challenger and you have to at least be sensitive to that fact.'' Mead agrees gender should not be the deciding factor. ``I don't think it should make a difference whether it's a man or a woman,'' she said. ``I would hope Wyoming people are very discerning people. They are so capable and quick to size 'em up.'' Mead had all but sewn up the GOP nomination earlier this year after a half-dozen competitors dropped out of the race. The disappearances led to charges that powerful Republicans, including Mead's father, former Gov. Cliff Hansen, were playing ``queen makers'' and had effectively discouraged all others from the race. That rankled Murphy, a 12-year veteran of the state House, who entered the race in June. ``I call them king makers,'' she said at the time. ``I guess I should say queen makers. But I think that there's a small group of the party ... money powers, money brokers, behind the opponent's candidacy.'' The gender issue has popped up from time to time on the campaign trail. During one campaign stop, the governor remarked that he considered Mead a ``pretty woman from a nice family.'' While his statement was widely publicized, the question that prompted it wasn't. ``The question to me was, `Governor ... Mary Mead and the Republicans say you're a nice man with a nice family. What is your response?'' Sullivan said. ``And flippantly I said, `Mary's a pretty woman from a nice family.''' For her part, Mead joked during an interview that she was so busy on the campaign trail that she didn't have time to iron her clothes and perhaps she could borrow the governor's wife, Jane. Mead also initially rejected proposals to debate Murphy, saying it wouldn't be proper for two women to debate one another. Wyoming's one and only woman governor was Nellie Tayloe Ross, who was elected 66 years ago to fill the unexpired two-year term of her late husband. She was not re-elected.

DOC.HEAD: Trinidad Coup Attempt Underscores Caribbean Vulnerabilty
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Behind the sun, sand and carefree islanders of the tourist brochures lies another Caribbean of hardship and frustration that is a breeding ground for radicalism. It became visible when Moslem extremists tried to overthrow the government of Trinidad. ``Trinidad was a ticking time bomb, but it is only one of a number of such situations in the Caribbean,'' said Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs in Washington. Economic decay throughout the region provides fertile ground for civil unrest, analysts say. ``Economic prosperity solves a broad range of societal problems, and economic despair breeds them,'' Birns said. Abu Bakr, leader of Jamaat-al-Muslimeen, said he and his followers seized Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and 54 other hostages on July 27 because of the poverty that has replaced Trinidad's oil bonanza of the 1970s. Most of the Caribbean's two dozen islands have similar problems because of shrinking world markets for bauxite, oil, bananas, sugar and other traditional exports. Unemployment in the region averages 22 percent, foreign debt in the billions drains tax revenues, inflation erodes buying power and living standards fall. Foreign investment, trade agreements like the Reagan administration's Caribbean Basin Initiative and expansion of tourism have not stopped the decline. ``Unfortunately, the United States thinks in terms of hundreds of thousands of dollars to solve Caribbean problems when it's going to take hundreds of millions of dollars,'' said Birns, whose organization often criticizes U.S. policy in the region. Bakr, a former policeman who converted to Islam, demanded Robinson's resignation and blamed him for the country's economic plight. Most of Bakr's support came from poor blacks. Robinson won a landslide election victory in 1986, but Birns said the prime minister had become a ``political pariah,'' largely because of austerity measures dictated by the International Monetary Fund as a condition for new loans. Consumer price increases, layoffs and reduced spending on schools and hospitals demanded by the IMF have provoked riots in Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and Guyana, as well as several Latin American countries. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi stepped into this picture, analysts say, with handouts for Bakr and radical political parties with potential to destabilize governments. ``It's a well-known fact that Libya has funded leftist activities in Dominica, Antigua and St. Lucia and separatists organizations in Martinique and Guadeloupe,'' said John Collins, Caribbean advisor to the Puerto Rican government. ``The left-of-center parties in these small islands use support from Gadhafi to exploit the economic underdevelopment which exists in their countries to mount opposition to the right-of-center parties that are pro-U.S.'' The six-day hostage siege in Trinidad, which prompted widespread looting and claimed at least 38 lives, has prompted Caribbean leaders to review regional security measures. ``Our determination that this must not happen again must be given explicit effect,'' Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford of Barbados said at last week's annual meeting of the 13-member Caribbean Economic Community, or Caricom, in Kingston, Jamaica. Prime Minister Eugenia Charles of Dominica said a regional security agreement dating to the 1983 U.S. invasion of Grenada should be expanded to allow Caricom armies to intervene when an elected government is threatened. In Trinidad's case, Caricom sent a multinational force of 150 on Friday, two days after the siege ended, to aid the army and police. Guyana's independent Stabroek News said in an editorial that the attempted coup was ``an affront to the aspiration of the region's people.'' ``We know the shock waves have reverberated throughout the Caribbean, where many governments face a difficult economic situation, and we imagine this will spur them all to greater and more purposeful efforts to define a democratic future for Caribbean peoples,'' it said. Anthony Maingot, a native of Trinidad who teaches sociology at Florida International University in Miami, acknowledged the region's vulnerability, but said democracy was firmly entrenced. ``This is the largest gathering of Third World democracies in the world,'' Maingot said. He noted that in Trinidad Prime Minister Robinson ``is still there, the elected government is still there and parliamentary democracy is still intact. This is the silver lining of the cloud.''

DOC.HEAD: Industry Claims It's Being Sacrificed in Trade Discussions
DOC.TEXT: The domestic textile industry and its workers are portraying themselves as sacrificial lambs in the administration's jockeying to reduce foreign trade barriers to U.S. exports. Casting itself as a victim is nothing new for an industry that has lost 30 percent of the American textile and clothing market and about 400,000 jobs to foreigners in the 1980s alone. In the past decade, the foreign share of the U.S. fiber and apparel market has climbed from 28 percent to 60 percent. As a result, 1,500 domestic plants have been closed and U.S. employment in the industry has dropped 25 percent. The industry blames a wide variety of economic and political forces: _Ideological free traders in the Reagan and Bush administrations. _The government's desire to maintain U.S. influence abroad in the face of a shrinking ability to provide direct foreign aid. _The development of export-oriented textile, apparel and shoe industries in less-developed countries so they'll have cash to pay back loans from American banks. ``There is a belief that many of the debtor (less-developed) countries must be allowed to ship textiles and apparel to the U.S. in order to earn foreign exchange,'' said Daniel Frierson, past president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute. ``And in some instances we now see where these debts are being forgiven in return for barter for textiles.'' Frierson, chairman of Dixie Yarns Inc. of Chattanooga, Tenn., heads an industry coalition that is behind the Senate's passage earlier this month of a bill to limit further growth of textile, apparel and footwear imports to 1 percent a year. Opponents of the proposed new quotas contend they will raise the price of apparel, other textile products and shoes to U.S. consumers by $25 billion to $27 billion a year. ``You do not notice it much,'' said Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore. ``Just 50 cents a shirt here, a dollar ... two dollars a pair of shoes there. But add that up by 250 million consumers in this country; that is a lot of money.'' The bill has cleared the House Ways and Means Committee and _ with 243 sponsors _ passage seems virtually assured when representatives return from recess in September. Whether it can survive Bush's expected veto is another question. Nearly identical legislation was approved by Congress in 1985 and 1988 but was vetoed by Reagan. Bush has vowed to do the same should it reach his desk. The administration contends the bill would undermine U.S. efforts to lower foreign barriers to American farm and computer exports, banks and other investors. ``If this textile legislation is passed into law, then other nations will take off the negotiating table matters that are extremely important to us,'' said Ronald J. Sorini, the chief U.S. negotiator in the 100-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks going on in Geneva. Sorini and other U.S. officials contend they will support quotas on textiles and apparel in some form for another 10 years. But industry leaders fear they will only open the door to more imports. ``The U.S. government has two bargaining chips to use to obtain its GATT goals _ agriculture and textiles,'' said Jay Mazur, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. ``With few signs that agreement will be reached on agriculture, only apparel and textiles remain as giveaways,'' he said. ``And there is every indication that the administration is prepared to give them away.''

DOC.HEAD: Roseanne's Husband Clashes With Photographers
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr's husband, Tom Arnold, clashed with paparazzi at Los Angeles International Airport, and three photographers accused him of assault, police said. No injuries were reported, and no arrests were made. Arnold and Miss Barr, star of ABC's ``Roseanne,'' had arrived on a flight Sunday from Minnesota when Arnold tangled with four or five photographers, said airport police Sgt. Allen Chu. Three photographers, Gary Aloian, 38, Robert Scott, 39, and Ralph Dominguez, 43, filed police reports accusing Arnold of striking them several times and damaging their cameras, said city police Sgt. Michael Apodaca. The reports did not say where the photographers worked. ``Our detectives will look at it and determine the merits of the case,'' Apodaca said. ``They may hand the case over to the city attorney, who again will evaluate it and make a decision whether to file.'' Miss Barr last month caused a stir by screeching the national anthem at a San Diego Padres baseball game. George Freeman, a spokesman for Miss Barr, did not immediately return a call Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Addicts, Homeless Trained as Print Shop Workers
DOC.TEXT: Sammie Harkless rose quickly in the print shop of an investment banking firm, and he and his pregnant wife live comfortably in a suburban New Jersey apartment. Four years ago, he was a homeless drug addict. In between his time on the streets and his arrival at Morgan Stanley & Co., Harkless discovered Binding Together Inc., a copy shop that does more than duplicate resumes. It takes recovering drug addicts and teaches them the printing trade. ``Four years ago, I thought there was no hope for me,'' said Harkless, 32. ``I was living on the streets using drugs. Really I was bankrupt spiritually.'' Binding Together gave him the chance he needed to change, he said. ``All I have to do now is just maintain this.'' Students at Binding Together are referred by drug treatment centers. They read, on average, at a seventh-grade level and often need tutoring to handle copy-shop paperwork. The program provides six months of instruction in binding, shipping and receiving and operating state-of-the-art printing machines. Graduates get $2,000 each. Most use the money to get an apartment and buy clothes for work. The program has 82 graduates ranging is age from 22 to 40 since it started two years ago. Thirteen people didn't finish the course and 30 are in training now. ``Right now in the graphic arts industry there is a shortage of trained people,'' said Michael Lamberti, a spokesman for Morgan Stanley. The company started Harkless as a clerk in its in-house print shop, promoted him to a machine operator and then to a shift supervisor within 19 months. ``It's all because he can do the job,'' Lamberti said. ``He came to us trained.'' All Binding Together graduates are placed in jobs that pay at least $7 an hour. Surveys taken four months after graduates left found 85 percent were still at work. More than half of Binding Together's annual $650,000 budget comes from sales the business makes of printing services to corporate clients such as Equitable and Time Warner. The rest comes from private foundations, corporations and public agencies, including the state Division of Substance Abuse Services, which came up with the idea of opening a business that could pay some of its own bills while teaching people a skill. Binding Together was one of 17 job training programs honored in March with presidential citations. ``It's a well thought-out program,'' said Yvonne DeGaetano, deputy commissioner for the city Department of Employment, which also provides money for Binding Together. ``The staff is incredibly good. It's not just a job. They believe in what they're doing. People become family and become connected with each other, and particularly with this population you need to do that.'' Bruce Sims, 29, a recent graduate, agreed. ``I didn't really have faith in myself. When I was ready to give up, the staff encouraged me,'' he said. Sims is a high school dropout and said he would treasure the certificate he got from Binding Together. ``I'm going to hang this up on my wall and look at it every night and morning,'' he said. Binding Together is run by Phil Calderella, 40, a retired police officer who also worked for four years in the printing business. ``Some people are in a situation where they have hit rock bottom,'' he said. ``When you come across somebody like that, you have to put forth the extra effort. Given the right tools to help them re-enter society, they're going to change.''

DOC.HEAD: Cruising Takes a Bruising; Teen-Agers Fighting Back
DOC.TEXT: An effort to ban cruising in Milwaukee and three suburbs has escalated into a legal battle with teen-agers claiming a right to free travel. The laws prohibit cars from passing a given point more than twice in two hours. Police keep track by recording license plate numbers on laptop computers. ``It's a ridiculous law. I think Checkpoint Charlie was taken down in Europe and put up here,'' said Diane Brandmiller, 25, the first person arrested in May under the ordinance in West Allis. The American Civil Liberties Union last week sued on behalf of Ms. Brandmiller and hundreds of teen-age drivers. The lawsuit, filed against Milwaukee, West Allis, Hales Corner and Greenfield, contends the bans trample on drivers' rights to travel freely. Ms. Brandmiller, who pleaded innocent to the charges, said she is not a ``cruiser by nature'' but supports the challenge. ``It's a Milwaukee tradition,'' she said. ``I expect my parents were cruisers.'' Greenfield Police Capt. Phil Hall said that on two streets, young drivers cruising around were constantly ``screeching tires, throwing bottles, urinating and (playing) boom boxes.'' ``It was the volume of traffic where emergency vehicles couldn't even move on the street. They had to use the sidewalks. The people in the area were complaining about losing business,'' Hall said. Fines for violating the ordinances range from $50 to $200, depending on the number of violations. West Allis police have made only 10 arrests since the ban was enacted but report a dramatic decrease in the volume of traffic on main streets. Other departments have reported similar experiences. ``The streets are back to normal, back to the way they should be. They're so you can drive on them again,'' said Lt. Ronald Hensel, of the West Allis Police Department. Jerome Buting, an attorney for the ACLU, said the lawsuit seeks to have the laws declared unconstitutional. The ACLU fears that the cities have gone so far to ``deal with a perceived problem'' that they have enacted laws that ``hurt more than cruisers,'' he said. Greenfield Mayor James M. Besson disagreed, arguing that police won't go after drivers who don't appear to be cruisers. Protesters angry over the bans picketed in Milwaukee in June. ``You should be able to go where you want to when you want to. Mostly, cruisers are driving around and talking,'' said one picket, Eric Nelson, 19. ``There's a few cruisers around looking for fights, but they're a small percentage.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Heads for Summer Recess
DOC.TEXT: Congress is on summer recess after a weekend marathon that produced a Pentagon spending blueprint in the Senate, campaign finance overhaul in the House and final passage of emergency relief to cities hard hit by AIDS. Left hanging after the burst of legislative activity were the delicate _ and politically testy _ negotiations between Congress and the White House on a deficit-reduction plan to avert mandatory, across-the-board budget cuts. Also awaiting action when the House and Senate return after Labor Day are conference talks on the first major clean air bill in more than 13 years, a measure to boost aid for child care and a possible new fight over family leave legislation that President Bush vetoed earlier this year. Lawmakers also face the usual election-year deadline pressures of trying to complete the major spending bills in time to hit the campaign trail as early in October as possible. The Senate and House face particularly acute differences over the defense bill. These include policy divisions on how much to spend on B-2 stealth bomber production and the future of the Strategic Defense Initiative, once the glittering cornerstone of Reagan administration defense policy but now dimmed by warming U.S.-Soviet relations. In approving a $289 billion defense bill on Saturday, the Senate left intact Bush's proposal to build two B-2 bombers in the 1991 fiscal year starting Oct. 1. But the Senate cut $1 billion from his Star Wars request, leaving $3.7 billion. While the Senate pegged total defense spending at $18 billion less than the $307 billion Bush sought, the House favors even steeper cuts of $24 billion. But even though the Senate version represents the likely high-water mark in defense spending in Congress this year, the White House said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is likely to recommend a veto. Cheney objects to the reduction in the Star Wars program and to the Senate's call for a 100,000 reduction in U.S. military personnel. The Senate also voted to eliminate $1.6 billion in procurement money for the MX rail-mobile missile program. In their rush to leave the city's August heat behind, the House and Senate approved a number of measures, including a campaign finance package backed by the House Democratic leadership making a number of changes and limiting House campaign spending to $715,000 a candidate. The House bill _ which seeks to curb contributions by ``fat cat'' corporate political action committees _ must be reconciled with a differing Senate version. The AIDS measure would provide more than $4 billion over five years to help U.S. cities hardest hit by the disease. The bill authorizes nearly $900 million per year in AIDS spending for five years, with $275 million authorized to be divided among the cities in fiscal 1991 and fiscal 1992 and ``such sums as may be necessary'' through fiscal 1995. A similar amount would be authorized for distribution to the states for improving quality and availability of care for people with the AIDS-causing HIV virus. A major portion of the money for the cities would be earmarked to help provide health and social services. The first half of the money, about $137 million, would be divided among the 16 areas singled out for special assistance. The other half would be redistributed in fiscal 1992 based on the number of AIDS cases at that time. The cities authorized to receive the assistance are Atlanta, $3.8 million; Boston, $3 million; Chicago, $4.2 million; Dallas, $3 million; Fort Lauderdale, Fla., $2.7 million; Houston, $5.6 million; Jersey City, $2.8 million; Los Angeles, $13 million; Miami, 5.3 million; New York, $51.3 million; Newark, $6.3 million; Philadelphia, $3.6 million; San Diego, $2.4 million; San Francisco, $20.4 million; San Juan, P.R., $4.1 million and the District of Columbia, $5.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: A City Remembers The Bomb That Struck 45 Years Ago
LaserPhoto HIR6
DOC.TEXT: Hiroshima came to a halt for a moment today in observance of the world's first atom bomb attack, which leveled this bustling coastal city 45 years ago. For an eery moment, the city fell silent, automobiles stopped and people throughout this industrial center of one million residents joined in a moment of prayer to comfort the souls of the 140,000 people who died from the bomb. ``I pay my deep respects to the citizens of Hiroshima who have built this city of international peace from the ashes,'' Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said in an address to a crowd of 55,000 at a commemoration ceremony. ``As the only country in the world to have experienced an atom bomb attack, Japan has resolved not to let it be repeated with our three non-nuclear principles and our calls for total nuclear disarmament and everlasting peace.'' The United States dropped the atom bomb on Hiroshima, a major military center, during World War II, on August 6, 1945. The bomb wiped out nearly half the 300,000 people who lived in the city, killing most immediately. Many others died within months from radiation, burns and other afflictions. Some 70,000 buildings were destroyed, including most of the city's hospitals. In his annual peace declaration, Hiroshima Mayor Takeshi Araki called pledges by the United States and the Soviet Union to reduce their nuclear arsenals the best hope for the future. He called for the banishment of all nuclear tests and nuclear weapons worldwide. By early today, a wide plaza in front of the cenotaph, the central monument to atom bomb victims, was filled with mourners and flowers wilting in the heat. Dignitaries, Hiroshima residents and foreign guests bowed their heads in a moment of silent prayer at 8:15 a.m., the moment the bomb exploded in a blinding flash of light 45 years earlier. Hiroshima has been honoring the dead each year for 43 years. Movies, museum exhibits, monuments and victims' testimony describe the bombing that reduced Hiroshima to rubble and left its seven rivers choked with dead. Each year, 1.5 million people visit the city's Peace Memorial Museum, where several graphic exhibits refer to the attack as genocide and point out that it was carried out against innocent civilians. Not all Hiroshima residents can face the memories. Retired school teacher Minako Tanabe said her husband has never attended the annual peace ceremony. ``My husband won't come here because it's too sad. So many of his friends died that day,'' she said. At the ceremony, 5,551 names of victims exposed to the bomb who died in the past year were added to the names enshrined in the cenotaph. Although it is difficult to determine which deaths are directly related to the bomb, researchers believe the risk of death from leukemia and lung, bone and breast cancer is much greater for those exposed. Three days after the attack on Hiroshima, the United States dropped a second atom bomb on the city of Nagasaki, killing another 70,000 civilians. Japan surrendered on August 15, 1945, ending the war.

DOC.HEAD: `Public Enemy No. 1' Acquitted in ABA Mock Trial
DOC.TEXT: Al Capone was sent up the river in 1931 on a federal income tax rap. But the mobster who ruled the Chicago underworld would be untouchable today if the jury's verdict at a mock trial is any indication. Public Enemy No. 1 seemed sure of the outcome of the fantasy trial as he strode with a smile on his face and confidence in his step into a makeshift courtroom Sunday. Capone actually was Joe Guastaferro, an actor hired by the American Bar Association, which sought to demonstrate modern courtroom tactics at its annual meeting here. All bets seemed to be on Capone, who ran Chicago's gambling and booze rackets in the 1920s with a gang of tommy gun-toting toughs. Thanks to a stable of fine ``mouthpieces'' and favorable changes in tax laws, Capone was acquitted on all 12 counts of money laundering, willingly failing to file taxes and conspiracy to defraud the United States. The verdict did not surprise Indianapolis attorney Linda Pence, who played a government lawyer at the trial. ``The problem we had was that we were trying to summarize 11 days of testimony in three witnesses,'' she said. ``Usually a jury hears evidence over and over again from several witnesses, and we didn't have that. ``And the law has changed a bit. When the Capone case was first tried there were very few guidelines about what you could do.'' Ms. Pence did express some mock concern at the mock acquittal, however. ``I just hope the jury doesn't let him off so easily next time. It worries me a little bit that Al Capone is roaming the streets of Chicago again,'' she said. The bar association enlisted a real federal judge and jury and lawyers who studied transcripts and evidence from the trial 59 years ago. Sunday's trial was held in the ballroom of a Chicago hotel. ``We are going to prove to you that he has exhibited an arrogance uncommon to the average American taxpayer,'' Ms. Pence told the jury. ``While living like a king, he never filed taxes, never filed a return.'' U.S. District Judge Prentice Marshall, who presided over the trial, praised the defense lawyers for their apparently successful efforts to discredit the prosecution's key witness. At the original trial, defense attorneys did not attack the credibility of Capone bookkeeper Fred Ries, a two-time convict. But the defense this time said the government coerced Ries into singing like a canary by sticking him in a cell with a colony of cockroaches. ``It was torture, wasn't it?'' asked the defense attorney, played by Terence MacCarthy, executive director of the federal defender program in Chicago. ``It was not an enjoyable experience,'' Ries replied. ``And after five days, you decided to, quote, `play ball,''' MacCarthy responded. ``You said, `I'll tell them whatever they want to know.''' The Rev. Patrick Smith, a boyhood friend of Ries and defense witness, later said the bookkeeper was known as someone who couldn't be trusted. ``I'm afraid if you had a choice between shaking hands with the devil and with Frank Ries, you'd shake hands with the devil every time,'' Smith testified. In 1931, Capone was convicted on five counts of evading income taxes and failing to file tax returns. He was sentenced to 11 years in prison and served almost seven years. Capone died of syphilis in 1947 at his Florida home.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Rural Development Tainted By Money Shortage
DOC.TEXT: Rural development efforts by the federal government are tainted by money shortages and poor management of the limited funds that are available, a study says. The yearlong project, financed by the Ford Foundation, focused on the Farmers Home Administration, an agency of the Agriculture Department. The FmHA handles a variety of farm, housing and community programs. A report was released Sunday by the Center for Community Change, a non-profit advocacy group for low-income rural people. ``Federal support for rural development was cut by nearly 70 percent during the Reagan administration,'' said Robert Rapoza, who directed the study. ``Yet the majority of the remaining funds failed to reach the neediest rural communities. The federal response to these communities has been plainly inadequate.'' Joe O'Neill, a spokesman for the FmHA, said the agency had not had the opportunity to study the report. But he said, ``We're always pleased to get these kinds of studies ... and they can be very useful.'' The report said rural problems include: _Unemployment, adjusted to include underemployment, is one-third higher than in the cities. _Rural Americans are more likely to be poor. One-third more rural people than urban residents are below the poverty line. _Ninety-seven percent of the nation's rural residents rely on ground water for drinking. Yet, a 1984 survey by the Environmental Protection Agency found two-thirds of the wells were contaminated. _Almost 2 million rural residents live in substandard housing, usually lacking adequate plumbing. _Maternal and infant mortality rates are substantially higher than in urban areas and are rising at faster rates. ``Rural residents are, as a group, less educated, less healthy and less skilled than their urban counterparts,'' the report said. ``They operate in a comparatively static, more conservative business environment, and they receive less help from Washington.'' The report criticized the FmHA _ which has its roots in the Great Depression era of the 1930s _ for not targeting more of its resources to poor communities to help build water and sewer systems, health centers, fire houses and businesses. These programs add up to about $900 million this year. According to the report, poverty-level communities got only 2 percent to 3 percent of total FmHA loans and grants for water and sewer facilities between 1985 and 1988. The report said one reason for not targeting on the poorest communities is the way FmHA uses poverty data. While the agency adjusts the poverty line upward each year, it uses 1980 census numbers to determine the average income of individual communities, it said. Thus, some communities whose average income exceeded the poverty level in 1980 now fall under today's higher poverty line. The effect, according to the report, is that those communities qualify for FmHA assistance, even though others are much poorer. Programs operated by the EPA also were criticized for failing to provide more help for rural areas to meet federal water standards. ``EPA figures indicate that two-third of rural water supplies violate agency drinking water standards,'' said Maureen Kennedy, principal author of the report. ``Given this need, it is disturbing that the EPA has not provided more support to rural areas.'' Despite the need, the report said, EPA spends ``a very small and diminishing amount on wastewater projects'' in rural areas. Figures for EPA construction grants between 1981 and 1987 declined by 91 percent in real terms, after adjustments for inflation, the report said. The report hedged on recommending a vast reorganization of federal rural development programs, such as blending them all into one super agency. But it did propose some administrative changes within USDA's hierarchy. Also, it said many communities lack the know-how for getting access to federal programs that might help them develop. Further, the report said most FmHA staff people come from agricultural backgrounds ``despite the fact that these programs demand training in finance, civil engineering and organizing.'' Consequently, ``FmHA should strengthen its substantive training programs, but more importantly, the agency should focus its recruiting efforts on those with backgrounds appropriate to the changing needs of the agency,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,599.53, down 916.23 points, or 3.10 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Crisis Seen Unlikely to Create Oil Shortage
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The oil war between Iraq and Kuwait jeopardizes an important lifeline for the world economy, and Americans already are seeing the results at the gasoline pump. Here are some questions and answers to help explain the economic stakes in the gulf crisis. Q. Can't we get by without Iraq's oil? A. Yes, and apparently we will, since President Bush has ordered a total cutoff of imports from Iraq. The United States, Japan, Canada and the European Community announced embargoes on Iraqi oil after Iraq's invasion Thursday of Kuwait. Q. If we don't need Iraq's oil, why would prices go up? A. Often the price of oil is influenced more by fear than logic. If oil companies and brokers decide there's a chance that the Persian Gulf crisis could worsen, they are likely to bid for the first available barrel rather than use one already in storage. The more the bidding, the higher the price goes. Some critics say the oil companies take advantage of this uncertainty by jacking up their prices at the gasoline pump, although the industry hotly disputes this. Q. Does this mean I'll be paying more at the pump? A. Almost surely. The American Automobile Association says its survey of gasoline stations showed prices rose by 4 to 14 cents a gallon in just the first two days after the Iraqi invasion. Edward Rothschild of Citizen Action, a Washington-based consumer group, thinks prices will jump 15 to 20 cents a gallon by the end of the month, but the Bush administration says it sees no risk of a big rise. Q. Wouldn't it help if American oil companies pumped more crude? A. Probably, but there's no chance of that. In fact it's the lack of spare production capacity, in part, that makes the U.S. consumer vulnerable to price increases caused by foreign wars. U.S. oil companies have been shutting down wells since 1986 when a collapse of crude prices made many smaller wells uneconomic. Domestic oil production is down 20 percent since 1985, and the number of oil and natural gas operators in this country has plunged from 13,000 to 4,500 since 1985, according to the Independent Petroleum Association of America, a trade group. Q. If more oil supply is the answer to keeping down prices, why is Bush boycotting Iraq? A. The embargo is mainly a diplomatic tool. The president himself said Friday he couldn't assure the American public that the pressure tactic would pay off. In fact, the administration may not be anxious for it to work too well. If every nation refused to buy Iraq's oil, the world would suddenly find itself short of oil, at least for a short time. ``If we were truly successful on the embargo we would throw ourselves into a serious recession,'' said Rep. Philip R. Sharp, D-Ind., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on energy and power. Q. Doesn't the United States have emergency oil reserved for crises like this? A. Yes, there is a large reserve, but no, it apparently won't be used under the current circumstances. Known as the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the system is a series of salt caverns in Louisiana and Texas that holds nearly 590 million barrels of oil, or enough to replace more than one-third of U.S. imports for 170 days.
