The reserve, which was started in 1975 in response to the 1973 Arab oil embargo, has never been used, and the administration says it sees no need for tapping it now.

DOC.HEAD: Liberia-At-A-Glance
With PM-US-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Liberia:

THE LAND: The West African nation is bordered by Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone and covers 42,900 square miles _ about the size of Ohio. The coastal plain gives way to rocky cliffs, and strong tides make access to the Atlantic Ocean difficult. The highest elevations are in the northern highlands, which rise up to 4,500 feet. The capital is Monrovia.

THE PEOPLE: The population is estimated at about 2.5 million, including 16 principal tribal groups and about 50,000 descendants of freed American slaves who founded the country. English is the official language. The vast majority of the country practices traditional African religions.

THE ECONOMY: Even before the rebel insurgency began, the economy was near collapse, although Liberia possesses some of the richest iron ore in the world. The country has been unable to pay its foreign debt, and it has been suspended by the International Monetary Fund. Mining has earned more than 64 percent of Liberia's foreign exchange but agriculture has remained the main employer.

THE HISTORY: In 1822, freed American slaves visited Liberia and began settlements. They declared Liberia an independent republic in 1847. Descendants of the freed slaves, called Americo-Liberians, dominated the country until then-Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe led a military coup on April 12, 1979. He was popular with the majority of Liberians, who resented the dominance of the Americo-Liberians. Doe headed a military government until October 1985, when elections were held. He claimed victory, but opposition parties and independent observers said the vote was rigged. On Dec. 24, 1989, former Doe aide Charles Taylor invaded with a small band of men from Ivory Coast. Taylor said he intended to topple Doe's government. Another rebel leader, Prince Johnson, split with Taylor and now controls much of Monrovia.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Liberian Unrest Since December Uprising
With PM-US-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: December 24 _ Two groups of rebels led by Charles Taylor cross the border from the Ivory Coast. One attacks a customs station in eastern Nimba County and the other heads toward the capital of Monrovia. January 3 _ President Samuel K. Doe fires his internal affairs minister, Col. Edward Sackor, and Stephen Daniels, superintendent of Nimba County, for mishandling reports of the rebel invasion. January 5 _ Fighting between Liberian forces and rebels opposed to Doe destroys two towns in northeastern Liberia and sends thousands fleeing across the border. May 7 _ Doe calls for negotiations with rebel forces on ending their four-month insurgency. May 29 _ Doe asks the legislature to call early elections after rebel forces move within 35 miles of the capital and take control of most of the country's major economic enterprises. June 1 _ Doe announces he will not run for re-election, and asks the United States and other nations to help end the civil war. June 5 _ State Department officials say the American military has ``no role to play'' in Liberia's internal conflict even though more than 2,000 Marines are poised offshore to help evacuate U.S. citizens from the African nation. June 8 _ The government says it is willing to accept a cease-fire and begin negotiating with a rebel army. June 10 _ Rebels win control of Liberia's international airport. June 12 _ A delegation of Liberian rebels arrives for talks with government officials aimed at ending the fighting. June 16 _ The Liberian government proposes a 30-day cease-fire. June 25 _ Liberian rebels break off peace talks with the government, announce plans to attack Monrovia. July 7 _ Liberia's shattered government announces cease-fire on a makeshift radio station and appeals to shops to open and government workers to return to their offices. July 12 _ Peace talks begin in Sierra Leone. July 19 _ Foreign Minister J. Rudolph Johnson and other prominent Liberians appeal to the United States for a temporary U.S. peacekeeping force to help prevent further bloodshed. July 21 _ Doe expels the U.S. military attache. A government communique accuses the head of the U.S. mission, Col. David Staley, of providing support to the rebels and urging government forces to defect. July 23 _ In a surprise attack, fighters from a splinter rebel group led by Prince Johnson wade across a swamp to shoot their way into the capital's center. July 30 _ Government troops kill up to 600 people sheltered in a refugee compound in Monrovia. Saturday _ Johnson says he is ordering the arrest of all foreigners in Monrovia beginning today in hope of provoking foreign intervention. Sunday _ U.S. Marines rescue 59 Americans from the U.S. Embassy compound without firing shots or encountering resistance. Rebel leader Taylor calls on civilians and soldiers to mobilize, asking all Liberians to defend their country and oppose foreign intervention.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 1:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
States Raised Taxes by $7.6 Billion
DOC.TEXT: States increased taxes by an estimated $7.6 billion during 1990 legislative sessions, pushed by higher costs for schools, prisons and health care, a study released today said. In its annual survey of state budgets, the National Conference of State Legislatures said it expected state finances to continue to deteriorate in the coming year. ``State balances fell throughout fiscal 1990 and for most states _ including all the larger states _ are now dangerously low,'' the group said. ``The national average balance fell from 4.5 percent of expenditures at the end of fiscal 1989 to 4 percent at the end of fiscal 1990, and is expected to fall to 2.3 percent by the end of fiscal 1991,'' it said. Those balances are considered indicators of state fiscal conditions, and many states try to maintain a balance of 5 percent of general fund spending. The balance is considered a cushion against emergencies for states required by law or constitution to have balanced budgets. The NCSL released its report at its annual meeting, being held this week in Nashville, Tenn. The report said many state fiscal conditions weakened during the last year. Northeast and New England states were the hardest hit. Tax increases were passed in 23 states. Those tax increases are expected to increase revenue by $7.6 billion in fiscal 1991, an increase of 2.6 percent of state tax collections. The study said spending for Medicaid, education and corrections grew faster than general state revenue. Medicaid spending grew at a 25 percent annual rate, putting pressure on state budgets. Of the three major types of taxes, 10 states increased personal income taxes, the report said. Ten raised corporate income taxes and 17 raised sales and use taxes. The biggest tax increases were in New Jersey, Massachusetts, Florida, New York, Kentucky and Texas. Other states raising taxes were: Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Vermont, Delaware, Ohio, Kansas, Nebraska, Alabama, Louisiana, Tennessee, Virginia, Arizona, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Washington. New Jersey's increase totaled $2.2 billion, or 21 percent of 1989 revenue, the report said. Massachusetts' increase was $1.16 billion, or 12.8 percent, and Florida's was $1.09 billion, or 8.7 percent, the report said. States listed as lowering taxes were: Indiana, Iowa, Minnesota, South Carolina, Utah and Hawaii. All of the decreases were small, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Chest-Beating on Iraq's Invasion of Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Within 24 hours of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the House was ready to roar with its condemnation. It was chest-beating time. A resolution calling for an embargo against Iraq arrived for a vote so quickly that few in the chamber had read it. Rep. Bob Walker, R-Pa., asked for a few hours' delay. He was ignored. As lawmakers streamed in, Rep. Bob Mrazek, D-N.Y., stood in an aisle urging his colleagues to support the measure. ``End the war, end the war, please vote yes,'' he said loudly. ``They're pulling out as we speak, because they never expected us to do this.'' Not surprisingly, the measure passed with breathtaking speed and with no opposition. Mrazek's dry humor reflects something most lawmakers readily acknowledge but like to pretend isn't true: Congress' role is very limited when it comes to fast-moving world events. The House bill called for something President Bush already was doing on his own _ retaliating economically against Iraq with an embargo. To understand why Congress acted so quickly, the bill must be put in context. Congress is a frustratingly slow and complex place to work, and laced with political traps. At the same time, lawmakers are desperately eager to get involved, vent their frustrations and cast their votes in a politically popular way. In foreign affairs _ as in the domestic arena _ Congress' power is in the control of the purse. But the House and Senate foreign affairs committees are largely ineffective in this crucial area. So for the committees and for Congress as a whole, these foreign affairs resolutions provide welcome relief. As Mrazek implied, few expected the resolution to have any effect on Iraq or its president, Saddam Hussein. ``It would be very foolish to think that a resolution of sanctions by the United States would have deterred an otherwise reckless, irresponsible, illegal and dangerous action,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``I think it is a matter of expressing our strong disapproval and concern.'' ``Break Hussein's arm,'' said Rep. William S. Broomfield, R-Mich., senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``President Bush has a fistful of hard-hitting options. He should choose one, and choose one now.'' The House beat the Senate to the punch in this case, but it doesn't always. In fact, the Senate quickly passes resolutions on most noteworthy international events _ and, according to Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., sometimes without enough regard for what they mean. It's a well-worn cliche that Congress consists of 535 secretaries of state, but it's more like 535 imitation secretaries of state. Few lawmakers have any true expertise in international affairs. And their votes on matters affecting other nations are filtered through the one area in which nearly everyone on Capitol Hill is truly expert: getting re-elected. Since the direct affect on constituents of any foreign affairs resolution is minimal, it doesn't take long to decide how to vote. ``Most of the time it doesn't matter,'' Dole said in a recent speech on the Senate floor. But sometimes, he said, it does. On a trip to the Middle East, Dole found that a Senate resolution on Jerusalem _ passed without controversy by lawmakers wanting to show support for Israel and to maintain their own support in the Jewish community _ was causing consternation there at a critical juncture in the peace process. ``They believe there is still some sense in the Senate, in what we do and say,'' he said. ``And they despair ... when they see that sometimes, too often, what we really deal in is the nonsense of the Senate.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: House Armed Services Chairman Outlines Military Choices
DOC.TEXT: Here are the United States' military options, as outlined by House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., should Iraq invade Saudi Arabia. Aspin discussed the choices on the CBS news program ``Face the Nation'' on Sunday. Asked if the United States would launch an attack in the event of an invasion, Aspin said: ``I think that the question _ the answer is yes. I think that's almost inevitable. Those Saudi oil fields are so important to the national security of the United States, and I'm assuming that when the invasion comes that Saudi Arabia would say `OK,' I would think we would do it.'' Aspin said the attack could be managed, although the Iraqi army is larger. ``Well, I guess the first question is, can you do it with air power? I mean, it's a race to the oil fields. Basically, the oil fields are the key, and the Iraqis, presumably, most intelligence think, would go right down the Gulf Coast heading for the Saudi Arabian oil fields, and it's a race to the oil fields. ``Now what we have available to stop that first and foremost would be some air power. Not probably as much as we ought to have in the region, but some air power. The question is can you stop the invading Iraqi force with air power alone?'' Asked whether the Iraqis would be able to use the powerful anti-aircraft missiles supplied by the Soviets, Aspin said: ``No, no. I think that's not a danger in the area of Saudi Arabia. They would be moving down with tanks. It's a great territory to go with tanks. It's flat, it's hard, they could move very quickly with tanks, but they're in the open. There's no cover. There's no concealment. It's essentially the air power against the tanks. I would guess maybe a 1-in-4 chance of stopping those _ and also as you said at the show here today is the logistics problem.'' Besides trying to stop Iraq with air power, Aspin said there are two other things America could do. ``None of this is ideal, but option number two is to carry the war to Baghdad, in other words, to, when the war comes, use air power and go after the Iraqi homeland. The third option _ high risk _ high risk _ and it needs Saudi Arabia to invite us in early enough _ in other words, before the attack _ is to land some American ground forces along that route down to the Saudi oil fields. ``We can't get enough in there to protect the oil fields, but essentially get enough in there as a trip wire, a deterrence. And the message to Mr. Hussein would be, `If you attack those American troops, right along that line, I mean that is war right to the end.' ``Now, those troops would be vastly out-gunned. They would have to retreat very quickly, but it would essentially be the kind of thing like the brigade _ like the brigade we had in Berlin through all the years of the Cold War. I mean, they were there more as a symbol of anything and as a deterrence than as an effective military force. High risk to put U.S. troops in that kind of situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Intervention, 25 Percent Raises End Banana Strike
DOC.TEXT: Threatened with dismissal after the government sent in troops to end their 41-day strike, banana workers have accepted 25.4 percent pay hikes and agreed to go back to work. President Rafael Leonardo Callejas announced late Sunday that the 10,000 Chiquita Brand International workers had accepted his offer ``without any conditions.'' They were to be back on the job today. The army removed 4,000 strikers from company installations on Saturday, and a military source said at least two strikers and two security policemen were wounded by gunfire in the takeover in La Lima, 180 miles north of Tegucigalpa. A union spokesman said two other strikers were beaten. Under the agreement, troops will remain at Chiquita ``until banana production is totally normalized.'' In a statement, the government said: ``The strike movement, provoked by irresponsible union leaders, threatened to destroy Honduran democracy as well as causing enormous, irreparable damage to the national economy.'' Chiquita Brand produces and exports 60 percent of Honduras' banana crop, the country's main source of foreign exchange, and preliminary government estimates said the strike caused $60 million in losses. ``There are no winners or losers,'' Callejas said on nationwide radio and television. ``The situation was overcome so that we can face the enormous problems that afflict the nation.'' ``Free unionism has, the same as the companies and institutions in which it operates, the enormous responsibility of sharing with the government social stability as the basic priniciple of peaceful coexistence,'' he said. The increase will raise the average banana worker's pay from $246 a month to $308.50. Negotiations were to continue today on sick leave and other points. The strikers walked out on June 25, demanding an increase of 60 percent. The wage increase the union accepted was the same one it had rejected on Friday. Chiquita had on Saturday refused the union's counterproposal. Several hundred soldiers and police then ousted the workers and occupied La Lima, a city of 60,000. The government announced in repeated broadcasts that it was giving Chiquita a free hand to replace the striking workers but said they still could return to their jobs. Karl F. Koch, local manager of Chiquita, and Rene Ayestas, the union president, signed the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Has Champagne Taste
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has spent hundreds of millions of dollars on gold-plated chandeliers, golf course projects and other luxuries to boost morale, internal Pentagon documents show. Back in 1985, the Air Force decided to refurbish its officers' club at the Mildenhall base in Britain at a cost of $75,000. The service's champagne taste, however, hardly matched the appropriated amount. Gold-plated chandeliers valued at $145,000 were installed, solid oak paneling lined the walls and fireplaces with marble fixtures completed the decor. The final tally was more than $2 million with U.S. taxpayers picking up the tab. The internal Air Force audits, conducted in April and May of this year, reveal widespread waste and abuse in the Air Force management of its Morale, Welfare and Recreation Activities. Golf course projects at Myrtle Beach Air Force Base cost nearly $600,000, while parties for a departing officer at Ramstein Air Base in Germany totaled $26,000. In a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., called for leadership from the highest levels of the Pentagon to crack down on these abuses. The documents reveal ``a mindset among some senior Air Force officials that the bases they command are their own personal fiefdoms, with appropriated funds to be used at their discretion regardless of law and regulation,'' Boxer said in the letter. According to the documents, strict restrictions on excessive spending on renovation projects have been either ignored or circumvented. Projects valued at more than $500,000 must be reported to Congress. In some instances, however, major projects were split into smaller projects to avoid seeking congressional approval. Even the Air Force auditors expressed dismay at the renovation projects. In the documents, Air Force management at the base in England argued that the chandeliers couldn't be standard-issue. ``Low quality chandeliers could not act as the main architectural highlight of a room as the existing chandeliers do. The crystal used would not have the capability to break apart the available light in a room into its primary colors (prism effect),'' the Air Force said. In response, the auditors said ``spending an additional $15,900 in appropriated funds to purchase chandeliers that have the correct `prism effect' is not appropriate.'' Other instances of abuse include relocation of a skeet shooting club at Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma. The estimated cost of the project was $722,000 and it was included in the cost of a construction project for basing of the B-2 stealth bomber. But when it was discovered that the project was $1 million over budget, the Air Force proposed eliminating the work stations at the facility rather than the Skeet Club. ``I find it appalling that the weaknesses in the management and oversight of Morale, Welfare and Recreation operations have been repeatedly documented by Defense Department auditors, whistleblowers and Congress, that hundreds of millions of dollars are being illegally spent on parties, golf courses and officers clubs, yet internal recommendations to remedy the problems have been ignored,'' Boxer said in the letter.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Turns Down Bid to Bar Support For `Point of View' Projects
DOC.TEXT: An advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts is rejecting a proposal to bar support for any project that advances a particular point of view. The proposal, offered Sunday by Dr. Jacob Neusner, a professor of religious studies at the University of South Florida at Tampa, was defeated 10-2, with one abstention. John Frohnmayer, the chairman of the government arts endowment, said he ``strongly opposed'' the restriction because it represented ``the highest degree of insensitivity.'' The proposal would have barred support for any project that ``advocates or promotes a particular political, ideological, religious or partisan point of view.'' The advisory group, the National Council on the Arts, which Frohnmayer also heads, instead adopted a proposal reaffirming the endowment's commitment ``to bring quality art to the American people'' by fair procedures, careful analysis and an opposition to obscenity. The NEA has been under heavy fire from conservatives since it funded an exhibit by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe that included works some considered obscene.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Recover, But Still Down; Dollar Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to Update with closing figures. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded slightly Monday afternoon from a dramatic morning fall to close sharply down on the day, while the dollar closed slightly up against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, on trading of an estimated 330 million shares. The index closed at 28,599.53 points. The morning's drop of 1,106.69 points, or 3.7 percent, would have been the seventh-largest fall in exchange history if sustained. The sudden fall followed Tokyo's announcement Sunday night that it would impose tough sanctions on Iraq as punishment for its invasion of oil-rich Kuwait. The index lost 729.42 points Friday, the day after the invasion. Meanwhile, the dollar finished the day at 149.50, up 0.15 yen from Friday's close of 149.35 yen. It ranged between 149.40 yen and 150.35 yen during the day's trading. In bond markets, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was 7.960 percent at the close of trading, up from 7.705 percent Friday. The bond price slid to 83.60 points from 84.72 points. Worries about higher oil prices and a tighter monetary policy to combat inflation drove the market fall, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities. ``But it is not as bad as during the oil shock (of 1973-74). Japan, Europe and the United States have reduced their oil imports. Oil prices will probably creep up, so inflation won't rise suddenly,'' he said. He said he thought the market might rebound during the week. Another influence on the current economy is the lack of the commmodity boom that plagued the early 1970s, said Ed Merner, an analyst at Schroders Investment Management Japan. With the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries controlling a smaller percentage of the world's oil output than two decades ago, ``Not only Japan, but also the world is in a very good position. I think people in Japan probably overreacted,'' Merner said. But the Middle East situation, and the sanctions announced Sunday, added one more piece of bad news to a market that has been heading down since the beginning of the year, he said. Japan announced Sunday that it was banning all purchases of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, as well as all Japanese exports to the two countries, suspending loans and banning all Japanese investments there. Japanese companies are still trying to collect $3.3 billion in credits from Iraq. Bankers speaking anonymously said they thought the debts were not as big a concern as their size might indicate because they had been difficult to collect for a long time, and Japanese companies must have accepted that. Japan received 6.2 percent of its oil needs from Iraq in the first quarter of 1990, importing 260,000 barrels a day, and obtained 5 percent of its oil from Kuwait, or 210,000 barrels a day. Japan's current oil stockpile is estimated at about 142 days. The stockpile was expanded over the weekend when Japanese companies bought huge amounts of oil from Iraq at a premium of a dollar per barrel, industry sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Janet Jackson Collapses Backstage in St. Louis
DOC.TEXT: Pop singer Janet Jackson passed out backstage after performing three songs at the St. Louis Arena, a spokeswoman says. Jackson, 24, was treated for exhaustion Sunday at Barnes Hospital and was released, said a hospital administrator who would not give her name. ``She opened with `Control,' `Nasty' and then `What Have You Done For Me Lately,''' said Maureen O'Connor, her spokeswoman. ``Then she excused herself and passed out backstage.'' The singer, who canceled a performance last Thursday in Lexington, Ky., has suffered from exhaustion and flu-like symptoms, O'Connor said. Sunday night's show in St. Louis had been postponed from the night before, O'Connor said. Jackson's tour began March 1 and concludes Sept. 4 in Richfield, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: 2nd Blackout in Eight Days Hits Chicago's West Side
DOC.TEXT: Government officials and consumer advocates are demanding investigations into the cause of a blackout that left 25,000 West Side customers without power for the second time in eight days. Residents and business owners also insisted Commonwealth Edison reimburse them for their losses Sunday after an explosion and fire destroyed a substation used to reroute power around a switching yard that burned July 28. Power was restored to all customers in the mostly poor neighborhood about 7{ hours later, Commonwealth Edison spokesman Bob Berdelle said. There was none of the looting that followed the July 28 blackout, which left 40,000 residents without power, some for three days, police said. The cause of Sunday's explosion was not immediately known, Berdelle said. The blackout sparked complaints that Commonwealth Edison's backup systems are inadequate. Pat Clark, spokeswoman for the consumer group Citizens Utility Board, said outages have become all too common in Commonwealth Edison's service area, and she called on the Illinois Commerce Commission to expand its probe of July's blackout to include Sunday's outage _ a move the commission took later in the day. Illinois Attorney General Neil Hartigan renewed his call for an investigation into the utility's emergency plans. Fire officials began an investigation, and the city will form a committee to study Chicago's utilities and recommend safeguards against failures, said Mayor Richard M. Daley. ``The people who live in those areas are just pulling their lives together from last week. Now they're hit by a one-two punch from Commonwealth Edison,'' the mayor said. ``Commonwealth Edison owes them for all they've been through.'' Commonwealth Edison will probably not pay claims for damages unless the utility is found to have been negligent, Berdelle said. ``We try to have perfect service to everybody all the time, and that's just impossible,'' said Don Petkus, Commonwealth Edison vice president. ``It's a system that relies on technology that occasionally fails.'' About 13,000 homes and businesses in the metropolitan area were without power at other periods Saturday and Sunday because of four smaller outages unrelated to the blackout. An opossum that knocked out a transformer and three other malfunctions caused blackouts of between 40 minutes and more than three hours in the five suburbs and on Chicago's South Side, the utility said. Police said an additional 200 officers were sent to the West Side after the second blackout hit. No arrests were made, said Sgt. Chris Lewis. Manny Patel, manager of an ice cream store, said he lost about $4,000 worth of ice cream last week. On Sunday, he said, ``The ice cream was already melting when I got here.''

DOC.HEAD: Tyson is World's Richest Athlete, Forbes Reports
With PM-Richest Athletes-List.
DOC.TEXT: Dethroned heavyweight champion Mike Tyson still packs a punch at the bank. With an estimated $28.6 million in income this year, he's the highest paid athlete in the world, according to Forbes magazine. Buster Douglas, little known until he upset Tyson for the heavyweight title in February, is second at $26 million, followed by another boxer, Sugar Ray Leonard, at $13 million. Next come two race car drivers, Ayrton Senna at $10 million and Alain Prost at $9 million. Forbes lists the top 30 athletes by income in its Aug. 20 issue and says they will make about $230 million this year, including salary, winnings and money from endorsements. The magazine said about one-third of the income from the top 30 comes from promotional activities. In the top 10 are four boxers, three golfers, two race car drivers and one basketball player. The top 30 include six tennis players, five from baseball and four each from boxing, golf and auto racing. Jack Nicklaus is sixth on the list at $8.6 million, followed by fellow golfer Greg Norman and basketball's Michael Jordan tied at $8.5 million. Golfer Arnold Palmer and boxer Evander Holyfield are tied for ninth at $8.1 million. Boris Becker, the top-paid tennis player at $7.2 million, is 11th. Jose Canseco, the highest paid baseball player, is tied for 14th at $6 million, although that includes the $3.5 million signing bonus from his five-year contract extension that begins in 1991. Wayne Gretzky is the highest paid hockey player at $6 million (tied with Canseco) and Diego Maradona of Argentina and Italy's Napoli club is the top soccer player at $5 million (19th overall). Cyclist Greg LeMond is tied for 26th at $4.2 million. Two women are on the list, both tennis players: Steffi Graf is 13th at $6.1 million and Gabriela Sabatini is tied for 22nd at $4.5 million. Tyson will make $27 million from boxing this year and $1.6 million in outside income, the magazine says. Douglas will make $25 million from boxing and $1 million from endorsements. The biggest shares of the two boxers' earnings come from matches they have signed to fight this year, plus any future deals for which they're receiving money this year. Tyson is fighting Alex Stewart in September. Douglas is fighting Holyfield in October. Nicklaus and Palmer head the outside income list, each at $8 million. The magazine estimates Nicklaus will earn $600,000 from golf this year and Palmer $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: 13 Arrested in Hiroshima Protests
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of anti-nuclear demonstrators gathered at defense installations in Tennessee, South Carolina and Pennsylvania to mark today's 45th anniversary of the dropping of the atom bomb on Hiroshima. Thirteen people were arrested. In Oak Ridge, Tenn., 10 protesters were arrested Sunday for trespassing at the Y-12 Plant, where uranium for the bomb was prepared. About 150 peace activists took part in a religious service and hours of speeches at the gates. ``Take it apart, tear it down and put it to rest forever,'' Colvin Idol told the cheering crowd. He said the bombings of Hiroshima and, later, Nagasaki, were motivated by racism.``I believe it would have never been dropped on white people who look like us,'' he told the virtually all-white crowd. More than 250 people took part in a vigil Sunday outside the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant to remember Hiroshima's victims and to protest plans to restart a reactor at the site near Aiken, S.C., in December or January. Hal French, a religious studies professor at the University of South Carolina, called the attack on Hiroshima ``one of the primary traumas of the 20th century.'' ``We're all of us, in a very real sense, atomic bomb survivors. And we're all of us, in a prophetic sense, atomic bomb victims,'' he said. About 140,000 people died in the Aug. 6, 1945 blast, the world's first atomic bomb attack. Three days later, the United States dropped an A-bomb on Nagasaki, killing 70,000 civilians. Japan surrendered on August 15, 1945, ending the war. In Liberty Township, Pa., three people were arrested Sunday for trespassing at a site that would be used as a command center in the event of nuclear war. The three spent the night praying and singing with about 30 peace activists before crossing the road to read a statement outside the installation, said Elizabeth Small, one of those arrested. ``These facilities are no longer justified in terms of the world situation,'' she said. ``Even if nuclear weapons are never used, we really steal from the poor and our children. One out of four children lives in poverty and if that is not an attack on our national defense, I don't know what is.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``This will not stand. This will not stand _ this aggression against Kuwait.'' _ President Bush, vowing he will not permit Iraqi troops to remain in Kuwait.

``I pay my deep respects to the citizens of Hiroshima who have built this city of international peace from the ashes.'' _ Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, speaking at a ceremony in Hiroshima on the 45th anniversary of the world's first atom bomb attack.

``I pull a calf at 4 a.m., cook for men for breakfast, go to a bank meeting at 9 a.m., move cows, try to get my damn snowmobile to run to check heifers, work outside all day and then have a dinner party.'' _ Mary Mead, a Republican candidate for governor in Wyoming, explaining how life on the ranch has prepared her for politics.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Down Sharply on Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Prices dropped sharply today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, reflecting wide uncertainty about the long-term effects on oil prices and interest rates of Japanese sanctions against Iraq. Meanwhile the dollar closed slightly up against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, on trading of an estimated 330 million shares. The index lost 729.42 points Friday, the day after Iraq's invasion. The index fell 1,106.69 points, or 3.7 percent, in morning trading in response to the government announcement Sunday night that Tokyo would ban all oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait, and Japanese exports to the two countries. Analysts said they expected the market to rebound if the Middle East situation did not further deteriorate. They said Japan's economy is still strong, has a 142-day oil stockpile and is less dependent on oil imports than during the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74. ``The market should rebound later in the week,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities. ``Overall, the economy should remain strong _ unless all falls apart (in the Middle East),'' said Ed Merner, an investment analyst and manager for Schroders Investment Management Japan. Yutaka Yoshino of Nikko Securities said that rising interest rates as well as an increase in the the yield of government bonds also influenced the market Monday. Industry officials said they would comply with the sanctions. Yasuoki Takeuchi, chairman of the Petroleum Association of Japan, said the sanctions against Iraq were unavoidable and that companies would look for other sources of petroleum. ``The government decision is a necessary measure to prompt an early withdrawal of Iraqi troops (from Kuwait). Our company will follow this decision,'' Kentaro Iwamoto, president of Nippon Oil, said in a statement. Nippon Oil imported 30,000 barrels a day from Iraq in the first half of this year and had planned to import about the same amount in the second half, a spokesman said. While companies said they were in no immediate danger of dwindling stockpiles, industry sources said Japanese companies bought an additional 4 to 5 million barrels of Iranian oil over the weekend. The sanctions also could effect Japanese engineering companies, which have large investments in Iraq. Tokyo Engineering lost 20 percent of its value in two days' trading, said Mahmoud Ghaemmaghami, manager of research for West LB Securities Pacific Ltd. ``I'm not sure any contracts have been cancelled, but the market always sees or reads these things in advance,'' he said. Japanese companies are still trying to collect about $3.3 billion in credits from Iraq. Japan and Iraq had agreed to a repayment scheme several weeks ago, but progress toward repayment ended with the invasion, a source said. A spokesman for Mitsubishi, the top Japanese trader with Iraq, said it was too early to tell how the sanctions would effect his company. He described the situation as ``very delicate.'' Japan received 6.2 percent of its oil needs from Iraq in the first quarter of 1990, importing 260,000 barrels a day, and obtained 5 percent of its oil from Kuwait, or 210,000 barrels a day. Meanwhile, the dollar finished at 149.50 yen, up 0.15 yen from last Friday's close of 149.35 yen. It ranged between 149.40 yen and 150.35 yen the the day's trading. Currency market action was described as hectic by dealers. In bond markets, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 7.960 percent as of the close of trading from Friday's close of 7.705 percent. Their price slid to 83.60 points from 84.72 points.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists Complaining of Price Gouging at Gasoline Pumps
With PM-Sanctions-Effect, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. gasoline prices have jumped 2 to 15 cents a gallon at the pump since the Iraqi invasion of oil-rich Kuwait, prompting complaints of price gouging and demands for an investigation. Price boosts since Thursday's invasion stretched from coast to coast. ``It's not a very pretty picture at this time,'' said Al Elkins, executive director of the Oregon Gasoline Dealers Association. Motorists have accused station owners of jacking up prices unnecessarily and using the Iraqi invasion as an excuse. Station owners blame the big oil companies for what Elkins called ``good old-fashioned greed.'' ``We don't believe the situation warrants any price increase at this time,'' he said. Many oil companies sell more gas than they refine during the heavy-driving summer months, so they have to supplement their supplies by buying on the volitile spot market, said John Lord, spokesman for Mobil Oil Co. in New York. Lord on Sunday said many oil companies are apparently anticipating higher costs from the Iraq-Kuwait war. ``When you know future costs are going to go up, if you can recover some of those costs today, you're going to do it if the price will hold,'' he said. ``I think that's what's going on in the marketplace.'' BP Oil Co. told West Cost station managers to mark up prices 7.5 to 9 cents a gallon, said Anne Straiff, spokeswoman at the company's Cleveland headquarters. Richard Kessel, executive director of the New York Consumer Protection Board, said Sunday that gas prices have gone up an average of 4 or 5 cents a gallon since the invasion. Kessel, who is investigating the price hike for New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, said there have been reports of increases up to 15 cents a gallon in the area. ``The governor directed us to begin an investigation of whether these increases are justified,'' he said. ``The product that is being purchased now at the pump is product that was refined well before the invasion.'' Mark Dyen, president of Fair Share Energy Development Corp. of Boston, said price hikes were the result of oil companies and traders preying on panic. ``It's all smoke,'' Dyen said. ``The price (increase) hits almost as quickly as the news, whereas the oil itself might take almost 30 to 90 days to get here.'' Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., on Friday urged a federal investigation of the U.S. oil industry. ``There is absolutely no reason consumers should already be paying more for oil and gas,'' he said. ``It's either panic or profiteering. Either way it must be stopped.'' Massachusetts motorists, already paying higher gasoline prices because of a recent tax boost of 6 cents a gallon, complained of increases of up to 6 cents since the Iraqi invasion. ``I just don't understand how automatically, less than 24 hours after this thing happened, they already have a price increase on the board,'' Boston motorist Jerry Whelan said. Motorists elsewhere also were angry. ``People think it's outrageous,'' said Joe Hedricks, a clerk at a Harrisonburg, Va., Chevron station. ``I tell them I don't have anything to do with it.'' The price at Hedricks' station went up 9 cents a gallon on all blends since Friday. Prices rose by about 5 cents a gallon by Friday at many Richmond and Norfolk stations in Virginia and went up 4 to 9 cents a gallon in Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Showers in Several East Coast States
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in several East Coast states and in New Mexico early today. Showers were reported in New York, Maine and eastern Tennessee. Georgia and Florida had thunderstorms. A band of thunderstorms was expected over virtually the entire East today, with only northern Maine looking for sunny skies. A storm system forming in Colorado was expected to stretch through southern Arizona and New Mexico, along the Gulf Coast region and into the Deep South. Hail and damaging winds were possible in Colorado and New Mexico. Sunshine and low humidity were forecast for the Midwest and the northern central states. Sunny skies were also forecast for the West, but temperatures were expected to reach the 90s and 100s. The highs were expected to be in the 70s and 80s in the East and Midwest and in the 90s in the South. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 115 degrees at Borrego, Springs, Calif., and Laughlin, Nev. DOC.HEAD: Archdiocese Announces Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta says it will investigate whether church funds went improperly to a woman whose intimate relationships with an archbishop and a priest led to their resignations. Bishop James Lyke, acting administrator of the archdiocese, ordered an audit of financial records at the archdiocese and two churches where the Rev. Michael Woods was pastor. Church officials announced Saturday that Woods resigned from St. Jude the Apostle Church after confessing to an intimate relationship with Vicki R. Long, 27. Woods had been Ms. Long's pastor at another church where she was a lay minister. Lyke last week disclosed that Archbishop Eugene Marino, who resigned last month, had an intimate, two-year relationship with Ms. Long. Church officials initially said Marino resigned for health reasons. Lyke ordered the nvestigation to ``put to rest any concerns'' that church funds were used improperly, the Rev. Peter Dora, an Archdiocese spokesman, said Sunday. Ms. Long received $1,500 monthly payments, apparently from Marino, but no church money was involved, Lyke said. The church has not yet accepted Woods' resignation or decided whether to discipline him, Dora said. He said an investigation will be conducted. ``He is in seclusion. As for his future, we just don't know,'' Dora said. Marino, the nation's first black archbishop and highest ranking black Roman Catholic, has not commented publicly on his relationship with Ms. Long, who has refused to comment. Ms. Long has charged that another priest, Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus, Ga., fathered her daughter born in 1986. Blood tests concluded he was not the father, but the archdiocese is paying her child support.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply in thin trading in Europe this morning as investors switched their attention form the Persian Gulf to the weakness of the U.S. economy. Gold prices rose. Traders said the market would continue to monitor the situation in the Gulf closely, although the relative lull in developments had shifted attention back to the underlying weakness of the U.S. economy. Higher oil prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait were regarded as further bad news for U.S. economic prospects. Weak U.S. employment data Friday rekindled perceptions that further easing in U.S. interest rates is inevitable, traders said. ``The dollar had gained impulsively (on news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait), and now people are seeing where it's real support really lies,'' one trader said. Foreign exchange traders predicted the dollar would trade narrowly during the day since no major economic data was scheduled for release. Many market players also were away on summer holidays, dealers said. ``In this kind of market, if even one player comes in and shortens his position, the impact is striking,'' one Milan trader said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.15 yen to a closing 149.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 149.60 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.5769 West German marks, down from 1.5920 _1.3340 Swiss francs, down from 1.3505 _5.2870 French francs, down from 5.3345 _1.7778 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7945 _1,153.50 Italian lire, down from 1,164.90 _1.1487 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1510 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.8725, compared with $1.8570 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $378.00 a troy ounce, down from $379.25 bid late Friday. But at midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $380. In Zurich, the bid price was $380 up from $378 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.20 to close at a bid $378.58. Silver held steady in London at a bid price of $4.87 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Gets off the ``Free Ride'' in Middle East Policy
With PM-Iraq-World Reax, Bjt ^Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to ADD that sanctions toughest Japan has imposed. Picks up 5th pvs, `As a ...' ^AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Three years ago, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone conceded it was ``only too true'' to say that Japan was getting a free ride through the turmoil of warfare in the Persian Gulf. Now Nakasone is out of office and the Iran-Iraq war has been supplanted by the Iraqi seizure of Kuwait. Japan, for a change, is showing itself willing to take a hit in the pocketbook as the price of taking a stand against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's aggression in the world's biggest oil-producing region. The sanctions announced Sunday are the toughest this country has imposed. Fallout from them will affect daily life in Japan, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today. Financial markets reacted by selling the yen and driving down Japanese stocks in anticipation of real economic costs in increased oil prices and inflationary pressure. As a country that imports 99 percent of its oil, including 70 percent from the Middle East, Japan has until now been extremely cautious in its Middle East policy. But the strong sanctions announced Sunday night show Tokyo moving toward the global partnership with the United States and Western Europe that Washington has encouraged. Japan said it will ban imports of oil from Iraq and Kuwait and all Japanese exports to the two nations. It also will freeze economic aid and loans to Iraq and suspend investment, financing and other capital flows to Iraq and Kuwait. For much of the weekend, it had appeared Japan's only reaction would be its issuing Friday of administrative guidance to banks and financial institutions to freeze Kuwaiti assets in Japan, estimated at $20 billion. The hesitance shows how hard it is to break the habit of basing foreign policy on domestic economic considerations. Japanese news reports said the Foreign Ministry had been urging the government to join U.S. and European sanctions while the Ministry of International Trade and Industry argued that sanctions would badly hurt the Japanese economy. ``Sanctions _ Easier Said Than Done,'' said a headline in Sunday's Mainichi Daily News on an article noting that sanctions would stop Iaq's repayments on $4.6 billion worth of Japanese loans. In the end, U.S. pressure helped tip the balance. President Bush telephoned Kaifu on Saturday urging Tokyo to join tough sanctions, and all 100 members of the U.S. Senate urged Japan to take ``mandatory and comprehensive'' sanctions against Iraq. Growing more than 4 percent annually in recent years, the Japanese economy is less reliant on oil than it was during the 1973-74 ``oil shock,'' when the Arab oil embargo knocked Japan into a recession. Then, oil provided 78 percent of Japan's energy needs, as opposed to 57 percent now. Japan received 6.2 percent of its oil from Iraq in the first quarter of 1990, importing an average of 260,000 barrels a day. It obtained 5 percent of its oil from Kuwait, or 210,000 barrels a day, according to the trade ministry. Japanese companies were criticized for buying up Iranian oil in 1979 during the U.S.-Iran dispute, and later when tankers were attacked by both sides in the Iran-Iraq war, it came under fire for not doing more to help freedom of navigation in the Persian Gulf. Nakasone, who tried to lead Japan into a more world-oriented posture during his 1982-87 tenure as prime minister, said in 1987 that Japan would be isolated if it didn't aid in the international effort to let oil flow out of the Persian Gulf to Japan and other nations. Japan subsequently paid for a $10 million navigation system to monitor ship movements in the gulf and made a generous package of loans to Jordan and other pro-Western countries to try to promote stability in the Middle East. Those measures, and a more evenhanded policy toward Israel, were touted as steps toward a more active Japanese policy in the region. Earlier this year, Japan offered $1.95 billion in economic aid to Poland and Hungary, flexing its wealth in another region where, like the Middle East, Japan had kept a low profile. The surprisingly strong sanctions announced against Baghdad show another area where Japan is willing to forge a new policy despite economic risk.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Larry Thorson is the AP's Asia news editor.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Jacob Hecht Dead at Age 66
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Jacob J. Hecht, a radio commentator and head of a Brooklyn congregation, has died of a heart attack. He was 66. Hecht, a member of the Lubavitch sect, died Sunday in Ellenville, said Yehuda Krinsky, a Lubavitch spokesman. Hecht was executive vice president of the national Committee for Furtherance of Jewish Education and headed the Rabbi Meyer Simche Congregation in Flatbush. For the past 35 years, he was a commentator on New York City radio staion WEVD-AM, speaking about Jewish issues, news director Gary R'nel said. Hecht founded Camp Emunah, the Catskill mountain retreat where he died, Krinsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Jump
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices jumped more than three dollars a barrel today on news Europe and Japan were joining the embargo of Iraqi and Kuwait oil. Stock prices plummeted in Tokyo and London on fears that higher oil prices would spur inflation and bring higher interest rates. The dollar was lower on concerns about the effect of high oil prices on the U.S. economy, and gold prices moved slightly higher. The spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, was trading at $26.59 a barrel in London this morning, up from Friday's closing price of $23.48. Traders attributed the rise to the weekend news that the European Community and Japan had joined the United States in its embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude oil in an effort to put economic pressure on Baghdad after its invasion of Kuwait last week. Traders said volume was thin. Futures prices did not rise as strongly as the spot price, suggesting that an initial hiccup in world oil supplies could gradually be overcome by increased supplies from some OPEC member countries with extra production capacity. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-Share index fell 47.8 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,236.8 by 11 a.m. The yen fell because Japan imports nearly all its oil and is therefore especially vulnerable to disruption to oil supplies.

DOC.HEAD: ANC, Government Discuss Ways To Start Constitutional Talks
DOC.TEXT: The South African government and the African National Congress began talks today to try to clear the way for full-scale constitutional negotiations on ending white-minority rule. President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela, leading five-man delegations, arrived separately at a state mansion on the outskirts of Pretoria. Neither leader said anything to waiting jouranlists as their convoys swept through the gates. All leading South African newspapers carried reports Sunday that the ANC was expected to declare a cease-fire if there was progress in today's talks. An agreement would clear the way for full talks, probably early next year, according to political sources. The news reports said the two sides expect to reach agreement on releasing political prisoners and allowing return of political exiles to South Africa. The government is also expected to meet ANC demands for a review of security laws that have been used to suppress political activity. ``The government would like to see immediate progresss on the negotiations. It would like to see negotiations take off. But negotiations cannot take place if there is no climate of stability,'' the Sunday Star quoted an unidentified government official as saying. The Sunday Times reported that as many as 1,300 political prisoners could be released and some 22,000 political exiles could be returned to South Africa. A special committee will consider disputed cases of prisoners who the ANC says are political prisoners but the government claims are criminals, it said. The release of political prisoners and return of exiles have been major stumbling blocks to clearing the way for full-scale talks. The ANC has said it will not take part in such talks until these issues are resolved. De Klerk has countered by demanding the ANC end its armed struggle. The ANC's armed struggle virtually collapsed because of internal problems, the drying up of support following the fall of communist regimes in Eastern Europe and the superiority of the South African military. But Mandela has refused to formally renounce the armed struggle despite intense pressure from the government and many Western nations anxious for a peaceful settlement in South Africa. He has said the government must make equal concessions before the ANC declares a cease-fire. The two sides are also likely to seek a greater effort to end the growing wave of violence that has hit South Africa in recent months, mainly between rival black groups. A special committee was set up after the first round of ANC-government talks in May to consider ways to settle outstanding disputes, including political prisoners. An agreement today would open the way for formal talks on ending white rule and giving political rights to the black majority. The government has already begun dismantling apartheid laws, although substantial restrictions remain. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other black opposition groups Feb. 2. He freed Mandela Feb. 11 after 27 years in jail for fighting apartheid. De Klerk has promised to end white-minority rule and find a new political ``dispensation'' for the country.

DOC.HEAD: Dodge City Fires Back After Dinkins' Remark
DOC.TEXT: Dodge City, Kan., population 21,000, had one reported homicide in the last 20 months, according to its city manager, Jim Witt. New York City has one homicide every 4 hours, 37 minutes. So it's no wonder the folks in Dodge City fired back when Mayor David Dinkins invoked their town's name last week to defend his city. ``This is not Dodge City,'' Dinkins snapped angrily when questioned about his commitment to crime fighting after four child homicides. The Kansans are used to the comparison, but they wish Dinkins hadn't shot his mouth off. ``It gets a little old,'' said Witt. ``Our murder rate is nowhere near New York, Washington, Chicago. It's not paradise, with zero crime, but we don't have that kind of violence.'' Between 1876 and 1885, the first years that records were kept, Dodge City had 15 homicides, said Betty Braddock of the Kansas Heritage Center. ``Violence wasn't wanton, it was more man to man. There was always a reason,'' said Braddock. ``It could be a fight over gambling, or a girl, but it wasn't somebody just blowing out a door.'' Kansans blame Dodge City's undeserved reputation for violence on media hype. ``The one thing about Dodge is that the newspapers blew it all up,'' Frederic Young, a Dodge City native and historian. ``It was fun to write about, they'd exaggerate a little ... They didn't worry much about the laws of libel.'' Much of New York's violence is attributable to drug dealers with Uzis; back then, it was drunken cowboys with Colts, Young said. New York recorded 1,905 homicides last year; Dodge City's big year was six in 1878. Then again, Dodge City had 4,000 residents; New York has 7.5 million. The murder rate was 1.5 murders per 1,000 people in Dodge to 0.26 per 1,000 in New York, but the numbers are misleading, the historians said. ``There really wasn't that much violence here,'' said Young. ``It was worse in the towns southwest of here, in New Mexico and Arizona. There were mostly isolated incidents here.'' Bat Masterson and Wyatt Earp were responsible for law enforcement in the town. Both were more likely to be found sipping a drink in the Long Branch Saloon than gunning down criminals on Front Street. Masterson wound up coming to New York once the West was won in 1916, and he became a sports columist at the New York Morning Telegraph. Earp was more of a career lawmen, but Braddock isn't sure he'd help things in New York now anyway. ``If Wyatt Earp was here, we'd send him back,'' Braddock said. ``But we gave you Bat Masterson, and you didn't do much with him.''

DOC.HEAD: Political Feud Speeds German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Social Democrats issuing more calls for quick unification; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A labor union and the second-largest parties in both German states said today East Germany can only be saved by dissolving it soon and that German unification may happen this week. Pressure built for East Germany to solve its worsening economic problems by immediately dissolving itself and turning the shambles of its economy over to wealthy West Germany. But at the root of the debate is an intense political feud by parties jockeying to use unification to their best political advantage in upcoming united German elections. Horst Ehmke, deputy chairman of the West German Social Democrats, said today that East Germany could vote this week on a clause in the West German constitution that would result in immediate unification. ``The economic, social and financial developments in (East Germany) are going downhill at such a speed that I would not be astonished if we had a very fast unity,'' he said on West German radio. Earlier, he said East German lawmakers could vote on unification Wednesday, when the Parliament meets. The East German Social Democrats planned to meet today to decide whether to press this week for a vote on unification, and decide on Tuesday whether to leave de Maiziere's coalition. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's demand last week to move up united German elections from Dec. 2 to Oct. 14 has prompted his chief rivals, the Social Democrats, to seek unity even sooner. The two Social Democratic parties are closely allied. They are the leading opposition in West Germany and part of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's broad governing coalition in East Germany. The left-leaning Social Democrats want elections to remain in December but unity to take place now. Kohl and his conservative Christian Democrats want to tie the two together and both to take place in mid-October. The Social Democrats want to delay the vote for a united German government in the hope that the costs of bailing out East Germany's collapsing economy will hurt the West German chancellor at the polls. Kohl, for the same reason, wants balloting as quickly as possible, even if it means changing West Germany's constitutional timetable for eections. Friedrich Bohl, leader of the Christian Democrat faction in the West German Parliament said unity and elections must be tied together. ``Unity and common elections are two sides of the same coin,'' he said today on West German radio. ``I cannot see carrying out unity without common elections.'' The head of the German Trade Union, the largest labor association in West Germany, with more than 8 million members, also pressed for immediate unity. Labor association chief Heinz-Werner Meyer said the July 1 economic unification of the German states _ when East Germany made a virtual overnight transition from socialism to a free market _ happened too quickly and will have disastrous effects. He said West Germany should take responsibility for advocating such a quick economic merger by following through with an immediate political consolidation. The deputy chairman of the East German Social Democrats, Karl-August Kamilli, also called for fast unification today. It is up to East Germany to enact unification. That will be done when its Parliament approves a clause in the West German constitution that will allow it to accede to its bigger neighbor. The Social Democrats have sought to slow unification since it was first proposed by Kohl early this year. By now pressing for quick unity and later elections, they can appear to embrace the process while still benefitting politically from elections in December, when the economic woes are expected to be much worse. Kohl, meanwhile, would have to spend more West German money on East Germany right away, and then perhaps pay for it at the polls in December. Kohl, in an interview on West German television on Sunday, sidestepped questions about whether taxes would have to be raised to pay for unification. Right now, East German joblessness, while climbing, is being kept artificially low by a West German-financed program to keep workers on payrolls at shortened hours and lower wages. Without that program, unemployment would likely be more than 10 percent, rather than the 2.7 percent it was estimated at last month. Joblessness is expected to eventually reach perhaps 30 percent or 40 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Blaze Destroys 28 Homes
LaserPhoto BND2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS five grafs after 4th graf with information on fires in Utah and California. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `About 1,100...'
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters today tried to hold a fire line cut around a 3,300-acre blaze that jumped a river canyon, destroyed 28 homes in hopscotch fashion and forced the evacuation of 2,800 people. The blaze, which broke out Saturday and raced from treetop to treetop in the dry woods, destroyed more buildings than any Oregon forest fire since 1936, said Forestry Department spokesman Jim Fisher. Damage was put at $4.5 million. People were evacuated from at least four motels or resorts and about 2,000 vacation and regular homes, the department said. Firefighters cut a line around the fire late Sunday, and department spokesman Randall Lau said they hoped to contain it Tuesday and bring it under control Thursday. The fire was reported 50 percent contained Sunday night. Meanwhile today, firefighters in Utah and California were struggling to contain fires that had consumed about 5,700 acres. At eastern Utah's Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation, firefighters planned a new assault on a fire that has burned more than 5,400 acres in the Florence Creek area. The fire was started by lightning Tuesday in rugged terrain considered ideal habitat for Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep, elk and deer. In central California's Sequoia National Forest, firefighters tried to surround two brush fires sparked by lightning Sunday afternoon. By late Sunday, one fire had blackened about 250 acres northwest of Kernville and the other had burned about 60 acres 3{ miles away. The fires posed no immediate threat to any buildings, firefighters said. About 1,100 firefighters battled the Oregon blaze using 12 helicopters and air tankers. The cost was put at more than $890,000, Lau said. The fire erupted three miles west of downtown Bend, a city of about 19,000 on the eastern slopes of the Cascade Range, and burned in near 100-degree heat. It raced through the pines, jumping roads and the Deschutes Riverin a canyon where the river is about 75 feet wide. It burned eight well-appointed homes in the Sunset Village subdivision. ``It's real odd the way the fire picked one here and one there,'' said U.S. Forest Serice spokeswoman Ann Carlson. ``When you see how hit-and-miss the pattern is, it would have been real scary to have been in here.'' The cause of the fire was under investigation, but it was being called human-caused, since no lightning was present when it started, officials said. The blaze was about a mile away from Central Oregon Community College on the north and the Inn at the Seventh Mountain on the south. The 325-unit resort was evacuated Saturday. The major north-south highway through central Oregon, U.S. 97, was reopened Sunday in the fire area after being closed to all but evacuation traffic. Norv Ritchey, whose daughter and son-in-law own the Entrada Lodge, figured only a miracle saved the motel when the fire came roaring over the hill. ``You could have had every fire truck in the state here and you wouldn't have saved it,'' he said. ``It just split and went by.'' The motel, which had been full, was evacuated Saturday evening when fire bore down on it. ``It sounded like a freight train coming over that hill,'' Ritchie said, pointing to the hill covered with ash and the black skeletal remains of trees. ``We spent the night thinking (the motel) had burned. It's the Entrada Miracle.''

DOC.HEAD: Explosive Device Found on American's Car
DOC.TEXT: A high-explosive device fell off an American woman's car today but did not explode, Scotland Yard said. Police suspected the device was planted by the Irish Republican Army. Police said the car's owner lived in a home in northwest London formerly occupied by Robert Armstrong, now Lord Armstrong, who retired as civil service chief and Cabinet secretary in 1987. Police refused to identify the car's owner at her request. The device was defused and was being examined in the police laboratory, said Cmdr. George Churchill-Coleman, chief of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad. He said he believed the device was planted by the IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. ``This terrorist action shows recklessness and total disregard for human life,'' Churchill-Coleman said. On July 30, the IRA killed Conservative party lawmaker Ian Gow at his home in Hankham, England with a bomb placed beneath his car. A spokesman at Scotland Yard's press office declined to say whether Armstrong's name had been on a list of a hundred government officials, judges and lawmakers _ including Gow _ found in an IRA bomb factory in South London in 1988. Such explosives have also been used frequently by the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic IRA in Northern Ireland in its campaign to unite the Protestant-dominated province with the Irish Republic under a leftist administration.

DOC.HEAD: President Dissolves Parliament, Clears Way For Mid-term Election
DOC.TEXT: The president today dismissed the federal legislature and brought an abrupt end to Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's 20-month-old government. The decision took Mrs. Bhutto's Cabinet by surprise, and her supporters accused President Ghulam Ishaq Khan of a ``conspiracy against all democratically elected people.'' In dissolving the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament, Ishaq Khan accused Ms. Bhutto's government of corruption and political ineptitude. ``The government willfully undermined and impaired the work of the Constitution,'' Ishaq Khan told a hastily called news conference. ``Corruption has reached such proportions that the govvernment cannot carry out the constitution,'' he said. Ishaq Khan set new elections for Oct. 24 and appointed opposition leader Mustafa Jatoi as Pakistan's interim prime minister. The president's decision caught members of Ms. Bhutto's Cabinet by surprise and they promised to fight the dissolution in court. ``This is total high-handedness, unconstitutional and illegal,'' said Tariq Rahim, minister for parliamentary affairs. ``It is a conspiracy against all democratically elected people. We will challenge it in court.''
Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs `The 59 ...' to CORRECT number to 62, sted 59, and show that most are U.S. employees, sted all.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a summary of the evacuation of Americans from the war-torn West African nation of Liberia.
DOC.HEAD: THE ORDER
DOC.TEXT: President Bush ordered the evacuation of Americans from Liberia after one of the rebel leaders trying to oust President Samuel Doe on Saturday ordered the arrest of all foreigners.
DOC.HEAD: THE OPERATION
DOC.TEXT: About 225 Marines in 17 helicopters and escort jets swooped over the capital of Monrovia at 8:47 a.m. local time Sunday at the U.S. Embassy. After the Americans' identification was checked, they were transported by nine CH-46 Sea Knight helicopters to offshore ships. Two CH-53 Sea Stallion choppers carried cargo, weapons and transport vehicles. Four AH-1 Sea Cobra attack choppers flew to two transmitter sites to secure Americans there and security for the air rescue operation was provided by AV-8B Harrier light attack jets. The U.S. ships involved in the operation include the amphibious assault helicopter carrier USS Saipan; the USS Ponce, an amphibious transport dock ship; the USS Sumter, a tank landing ship; and the destroyer USS Peterson. The 2,200 Marines aboard the ships are based at Camp Lejeune, N.C.
DOC.HEAD: THE RESCUED
DOC.TEXT: The 62 Americans, most of whom were said to be U.S. government employees, were reported to be safe aboard the USS Saipan, awaiting transfer to neighboring Sierra Leone.
DOC.HEAD: AMERICANS IN LIBERIA
DOC.TEXT: About 70 U.S. officials and 300 other Americans were in Liberia when the operation started. Many of the 300 U.S. citizens also hold Liberian citizenship. Most of the other Americans are missionaries posted in various parts of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Shot Fired at Gun Show Injures Two
DOC.TEXT: A man trying to sell an automatic pistol at a gun show accidentally fired the weapon into the crowd, injuring two people, police said. A 27-year-old man was arrested for investigation of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon after the shooting Sunday, police said. The man, whose name was not released pending charges, removed a safety strap from a .32-caliber automatic Walther, slipped in a round of ammunition and jiggled the gun, causing it to fire, police said. The bullet passed through a table and struck a woman, who was holding her 8-month-old daughter, and a man nearby. The woman suffered a fragment wound in her leg and the man was hit with fragments in the back of his neck and head, police said. Both victims were treated and released Sunday from Ben Taub Hospital, police said. Their names were not released. The arrested man apparently wanted to demonstrate the gun for prospective customers at the show at the George R. Brown Convention Center, police said. Loaded guns were prohibited at the show and guns on display were fitted with plastic straps, preventing the triggers and hammers from moving. Gun show officials, working for the promotion company SAXET, did not immediately return telephone calls from The Associated Press today. Several hundred people attended the show where exhibitors sold firearms including stun guns, blow guns and scopes.

DOC.HEAD: Robber Dribbles Basketball Into Bank, Succeeds at Fast Break
DOC.TEXT: When the police finally catch up to a man who dribbled a basketball into the Citizens Bank, he'll be cited for more than traveling. ``He came in dribbling this basketball until he got the teller's attention,'' said Jim Dearborn, spokesman for the FBI in Baltimore. ``He then slipped her a note and, when she looked up, he was standing there with this grenade.'' The robber then ordered the teller to hurry up. He fled on foot with an undisclosed amount of cash, police said. Witnesses told police he man had tape on each of his fingers. Investigators believe it was an attempt by the robber to avoid leaving fingerprints. Police could offer no explanation for why the bank robber carried the basketball during the robbery on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Hungry For Funds But Slow To Respond, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross sometimes worries more about its image than about emergency relief, sending agency camera crews in ahead of aid workers, a newspaper concluded after analyzing 200 disasters over the past five years. A nine-month investigation by The Pittsburgh Press showed that, in some cases, the Red Cross lived up to its promise to deliver help quickly, fairly and compassionately. But in others, there were widespread deficiencies. The problems included delays of up to six days before enough trained workers arrived at a disaster site, a lack of cooperation with local agencies and an emphasis on getting favorable publicity to help raise money. The paper, in a series that began in Sunday's newspaper, also said the charity does not always spend all money donated for a specific disaster on that disaster. The Red Cross is by far the nation's largest recipient of disaster contributions, totaling $175 million last year. However, the newspaper concluded that other groups, primarily the Salvation Army and other national church groups, usually arrive at disaster sites first and stay longer. Agency officials said it was unfair to criticize the Red Cross because of highly publicized shortcomings following Hurricane Hugo and the northern California earthquake last year. ``It's absurd to look at last fall's hurricane and earthquake and say the Red Cross can't do the job. The Red Cross may have had a few little problems, but we were dealing with two unprecedented disasters,'' said Barbara Lohman, a national Red Cross spokeswoman in Washington, D.C. ``If you want to be fair and get an accurate picture, look at the hundreds of other disasters that we worked on, and you'll find that the Red Cross performance was almost flawless,'' she told the newspaper. The Red Cross' unique operating position was created in 1900 when Congress passed a law making it the only volunteer agency required to aid victims of disaster. It was founded by Civil War nurse Clara Barton in 1881. Today, funded almost totally by donations from the American public, the $1.2 billion operation promises immediate response to a disaster with food and shelter, medical care, clothing, temporary housing and other basic needs. To raise money, the Red Cross stresses promoting its image even in the early hours of a disaster, according to the newspaper report. Two of the four names posted on the nightly call-out roster at national headquarters in Washington, D.C. _ those people to be notified in case of a major disaster _ are fund-raisers. ``We had a film crew and a still photographer on the ground, on the coast before (Hurricane) Hugo hit the mainland ... and with the earthquake, we had a video crew in San Francisco within the first 24 hours,'' Ms. Lohman said. Most of the national disaster staff did not arrive until several days later. ``When the fund-raising ability of a disaster diminishes, so does the national Red Cross,'' said Carl Bradford, West Virginia's director of emergency management. ``The national organization is clearly driven by how much money it can raise, so when the television crews and reporters leave, the Red Cross is in the next cars out of town.'' George Moody, chairman of American National Red Cross, conceded that problems sometimes occur. But he said they're rare. ``When you have 2,200 active chapters involved in delivering services, you're going to have inconsistency once in awhile,'' he said. Allegations of diverting funds designated for a specific disaster area surfaced after the northern California earthquake. San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos said the charity was leaving town with $55 million contributed specifically to help victims of the earthquake. The Red Cross announced a month later it would spend $40 million more for earthquake relief.

DOC.HEAD: Police Prevent Dissidents from Meeting North Koreans
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of riot police blocked dozens of dissidents from traveling to North Korea for a meeting, and the government banned 42 other activists from leaving the country. The dissidents called off their efforts to cross the heavily fortified border to North Korea after their bus was stopped by almost 500 riot police on a road mid-way between Seoul and the border. Two dissident leaders were arrested and about 40 others returned to Seoul. The Justice Ministry, meanwhile, announced that 42 other South Korean dissidents and radical students were banned from leaving the country, presumably to stop them from traveling to North Korea during a proposed mid-August border opening. ``Their exit is feared to severely hurt national interests,'' said a government spokesman. The dissidents had been trying to reach the border so 12 delegates could travel to North Korea's capital of Pyongyang for a planning session for a proposed joint unification rally scheduled for Aug. 15. Both governments have approved the rally in principle _ which is scheduled to call for the unification of the two Koreas _ but disagree on the details. It remains unclear whether the event will be held and a planning committee has never met to work out the details. The Seoul government has said the committee members will not be allowed to travel to North Korea unless dissidents and the North Koreans also accepted conservative groups as part of the delegation. The border between the two Koreas is the most heavily fortified frontier in the world. Citizens cannot travel across the border without approval from both governments, which is rarely given. The Korean peninsula was divided into the communist North and capitalist South in 1945 and the two sides fought a civil war in the early 1950s.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Dinkins To Hire More Than 1,000 New Cops
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins plans to hire more than 1,000 new police officers in an effort to fight a surge in crime, two newspapers reported today. The New York Post and Daily News each said that the new police officers will be trained at the Police Academy in the October and April classes. Dinkins will obtain the $50 to $60 million the plan will cost by cutting other city services, the papers said. ``What we're doing is flooding the streets with cops,'' a senior mayoral aide who spoke on condition of anonymity told the Daily News. ``But the ambition here is to reduce the level of violent crime, not just put more cops on the street.'' Police Commissioner Lee Brown recently said he would need 5,000 more police to cope with the city's crime crisis. The plan stemmed from a weekend anti-crime meeting of the city's top law enforcement and prosecution officials at Gracie Mansion, both papers said. Under Dinkins' new plan, money would also be freed to pay for more prosecutors, jails, court officers and probation and correction officers. Details of the budget cuts needed to pay for the new police officers were to be announced at a City Hall news conference today, the News said. Dinkins has been under pressure lately to respond to a wave of high-profile random violence. Among those incidents: the slayings of four children by stray bullets, and the killings of two cab drivers, a 14-year-old boy and a Greenwich Village executive.
