On Sunday, a man was shot in the head as he spoke on a pay telephone in front of a token booth at a Brooklyn subway station, police said. John Myers, 26, was killed by a single shotgun blast to the back of his head. No arrests were made. Myers' brother, who was with him at the subway stop, ran to a nearby grocery store and called police. And in another incident, two men were shot, one fatally, when a gunman stepped from a car in the Bronx and fired five or six shots, police said. Louis Shevalir, 44, was shot in the chest and hip and was pronounced dead on arrival at a Bronx hospital late Sunday night. The other man was in stable condition early today. No arrests were made and no motive was known, police spokeswoman Mary Wrensen said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deliberations Resume After Sunday Break
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS lead to update with jury deliberations resuming
DOC.TEXT: Jurors resumed their deliberations today in Mayor Marion Barry's cocaine and perjury trial after a Sunday respite from the work they started last week. The federal panel, kept sequestered during the six-week trial, finally got the case late Thursday. The jurors deliberated all day Friday and four hours Saturday. Shortly before being given the rest of the weekend off, the jury asked District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson for another look at more than 150 prosecution and defense exhibits. Barry, whose lawyer has acknowledged he was an ``occasional'' user of cocaine, faces a maximum of 26 years in prison if convicted of all charges _ 10 cocaine possession charges, three felony perjury counts and one conspiracy charge. While not attempting to persuade the jury that Barry never used drugs, defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy has worked overtime at casting doubt on whether he did so on the occasions the prosecution says he did. The 5,000 pages of trial testimony include the statements of 10 witnesses who have said they saw Barry use drugs more than 200 times since 1984. Among those 10 are four who added an important additional element: that Barry saw convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis using narcotics. One of the perjury charges stems from a January 1989 grand jury appearance in which Barry said he was unaware of Lewis' drug involvement and did not believe his friend was a drug dealer. But four of Lewis' female companions testified that Barry was present when Lewis used drugs during a trip the mayor made to the Virgin Islands in 1986. ``Mr. Lewis lit a marijuana cigarette in the front of the boat and he passed it to the young lady and the young lady passed it to the mayor,'' one witness, Jonetta Vincent, recalled about a June 1986 boat trip she took with Lewis, Barry and others. ``The mayor passed it back to Mr. Lewis and then ... there was another one.'' In addition, the captain on that cruise testified that he, the mayor, Lewis and others shared a marijuana cigarette. ``Was there anything obstructing Mr. Barry's view'' when Lewis lit and smoked from the joint, Terry Lee Brenay was asked. ``Nothing whatsoever,'' he responded. Mundy also has complained that witnesses have provided only vague dates _ and hazier recollections _ of their drug use with the mayor. He also tried to expose flaws in the memory of witnesses not openly hostile to the mayor. Most of Mundy's effort went to undermining the government's two star witnesses: Lewis and former model Rasheeda Moore. Lewis ``was willing to sing any tune ... the government wanted to hear as long as his own fat was in the fire,'' Mundy said. Barry's chief attorney also elicited testimony from other witnesses that pointed out minor inconsistencies in Lewis' description of his drug use with Barry in the Virgin Islands. Lewis' testimony was used to back up all three felony perjury charges and four of the misdemeanor cocaine possession charges. Moore, who participated in the Jan. 18 FBI sting operation that produced Barry's arrest, was portrayed by Mundy as the most hypocritical weapon in the government's arsenal. Although she testified that she used drugs with Barry ``over 100 times'' during the couple's two-year sexual relationship, Mundy hammered away at the fact that she could provide few specific dates. He portrayed her as an opportunistic traitor who, down on her luck, was ripe for recruitment when the FBI approached her about participating in the sting operation.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Diana Moves Toward Gulf of Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with storm warnings for Yucatan canceled, updated position. Pickup 5th pvs, `The state...'
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Diana churned through the Yucatan Peninsula and headed back to sea today after drenching Mexico's Caribbean coast but causing little damage. At 9 a.m. EDT, Diana was centered about 100 miles west of Merida, Mexico. It carried maximum winds of 45 mph and was moving northwest at 15 mph, according to the U.S. National Weather Service in Miami. The service said the storm moved across the Yucatan Peninsula and toward the Gulf of Mexico. The weather service today discontinued tropical storm warnings in the Yucatan. The state government of Quintana Roo, where the storm struck, said preliminary reports indicated there had been no major flooding or damage. Minor street flooding occurred in the state capital, Chetumal, the newspaper Novedades de Quintana Roo reported. The U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami said the storm hit the coast by midafternoon about 70 miles northeast of Chetumal and well south of the popular resort of Cancun. High winds, with velocities ranging from 37 mph to 45 mph, hit the towns of Felipe Carrillo Puerto and Jose Maria Morelos, state government spokesman Javier Venegas said, but no damage was reported.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Force Buildup Reported At Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Cheney arrival, CLARIFIES that Saudi military aircraft sighted on maneuvers. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Oil executives...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil industry sources said today that Saudi Arabia was reinforcing its troops near the Kuwaiti border, and witnesses reported intense air activity near the airport in the Saudi capital. Local residents reached by telephone said Saudi military aircraft were sighted during the night landing and taking off at airfields on the fringes of the capital. U.S. Secretary of Defense Richard Cheney arrived in Jiddah today for talks with Saudi officials. Cheney was accompanied by Lt. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the U.S. Middle East force known as the Central Command. Richard Gates, deputy national security adviser, and Paul Wolfowitz, deputy defense secretary, were also with him. Oil executives at Khafji, reached by telephone from Bahrain, said ``more Saudi troops but no heavy vehicles'' were entering the region. Khafji is a city in northeastern Saudi Arabia on the Persian Gulf, near the Kuwaiti border. Its port has oil loading and berthing facilities for small tankers and freighters. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's troops invaded Kuwait on Thursday and advanced toward the Saudi border, raising fears they also planned to invade the oil giant. The invasion force set up a checkpoint about a half-mile from the Saudi border checkpoint at Khafji. Security officials at the Khafji post said the Iraqis made minor, apparently accidental incursions into Saudi territory Friday and Saturday, then retreated with apologies. The oil executives said the Saudi force deployments were merely a precaution to defend oil fields run by the Arabian Oil Co., a consortium of Saudi, Kuwait and Japanese companies. ``It's calm down here,'' said one Japanese oil executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``There is no shooting anywhere, neither in Khafji city nor at the port area. But the Saudis are reinforcing their defenses. It is a slight increase in the number of soldiers here.'' However, travelers from the area said Saudi tanks were sighted moving northward Saturday, possibly to areas near Khafji. Gulf-based diplomatic sources said Saudi forces went on alert with the start of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Thursday. They were trying to determine the extent of mobilization in the Saudi armed forces. The Saudi borders were closed. The situation inside the kingdom was described by diplomats and residents reached by telephone as ``tense but calm.'' An indication of the military preparedness was the continuous whirring of AWACs over Dhahran, the oil capital and the area with the highest concentration of American interests in Saudi Arabia. AWACS are Airborne Warning and Control aircraft. In Riyadh, the Saudi capital, long lines of people were at the banks. Long lines also formed elsewhere in the region. Some American companies were reported to have begun pulling out their staff from the United Arab Emirates. A U.S. Embassy spokesman in Riyadh insisted however that for the estimated 26,000-28,000 Americans and their dependents, ``life was going about as usual.'' Saudi Arabia is the world's largest oil exporter, and most of the Americans work in the oil industry. The spokesman estimated the number of Americans in Saudi Arabia may be presently ``substantially fewer'' because of the summer holidays. The borders of Kuwait with Saudi Arabia run halfway through the so-called Divided Zone, a new name for what used to be called the Neutral Zone. Under a 1988 agreement, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait agreed to divide the Neutral Zone, drawing their border through it. Khafji is in the zone.

DOC.HEAD: Report Calls on Bush to Spend More on Infant Mortality
DOC.TEXT: A quarter of the 40,000 infant deaths that occur in the United States each year could be easily prevented with existing medical knowledge, according to a high-level Bush administration study. The New York Times reported today that the study calls for spending about $500 million a year more to reduce the country's infant mortality rate. Ninteen other countries have lower rates. The report was begun in July 1989 by a group headed by Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services James O. Mason, but appears to have been put on hold, the Times said. The report found that common techniques, including improved prenatal care, could also prevent vision and hearing loss, mental retardation and other handicaps that afflict 100,000 newborns each year. ``The United States has not achieved its national goals for reducing infant mortality,'' the study said. ``Unacceptable racial disparities and significant geographic inequities are still evident, and progress in reducing the rate of infant mortality has slowed significantly, especially among blacks.'' The Times said it obtained a copy of the report from an official involved in the study who felt its recommendations were being ignored. Others involved in the study said it had been shelved because it was an inconvenient reminder of Bush campaign promises that would be difficult to keep, the Times said. A White House spokesman, Alixe Glen, told the Times that work on the report was continuing and should be completed by early next month. In 1987, the last year for which data is available, the overall infant mortality rate for the United States was 10.1 deaths in the first year of life for every 1,000 births. The rate was 17.9 for blacks and 8.6 for whites. In the 1970s, the Public Health Service set a goal of reducing the rate to nine by 1990, and said no racial group should have a rate exceeding 12.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Closes Pipeline Through Turkey
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to ADD further explanation for pipeline, CORRECTS percentage of Iraqi oil used by Turkey and adds that pipeline closing should not affect Turkish purchases from Iraq. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq told Turkey that embargos against Iraqi oil today forced it to close one of two pipelines used to pump Iraqi crude oil through Turkey, the Anatolia news agency reported. Anatolia said Iraq also notified Turkey that it would use only 70 percent of the capacity of the second pipeline. The United States, Japan and the European Community announced in the past week that they no longer will import Iraqi oil to protest Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Those countries bought more than half of the oil exported from Iraq. With the widespread boycott, Iraq would have trouble selling all the oil flowing through Turkey, said a Turkish government official quoted by Anatolia. Turkey was reportedly under U.S. pressure to close the pipelines following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Thursday. The Turkish official said the Iraqi decision was a ``great relief'' to Turkey. Government officials said the action would not affect Turkish purchases of Iraqi oil. Turkey is expected to rely on Iraq for about 40 percent of its oil needs this year. The pipelines take Iraqi crude oil from the Kirkuk fields to a terminal on Turkey's Mediterranean coast, where it is loaded for export to other countries. The pipelines have a capacity of 1.6 million barrels of oil a day, more than half Iraq's estimated daily output of 2.7 million barrels. They had been pumping about 1.5 million barrels daily, according to the Middle East Economic Survey. The Turkish official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, Iraq's State Organization of Marketing Oil told Turkey's state-owned Botac company, which operates the pipeline, of the closure. It said the move took effect this afternoon. No further details were given. There was no immediate word from Iraq. Turkey earns $250 million from Iraq annually for operating the pipeline.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Service Vows to Remove Protesters from Forest Logging Area
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials promised to evict environmentalists who blocked logging roads and ignored orders to leave a southern Illinois national forest slated for a timber harvest. ``We may hand out tickets, or we may bring a paddy wagon up there and haul them away,'' Norbert Boe, acting forest supervisor of the Shawnee National Forest, said Sunday. Forest officials posted an eviction notice Friday, ordering the environmentalists out by Saturday morning. But no one had attempted to evict the protesters by early today, Jackson County sheriff's deputies said. Environmentalists emulating West Coast demonstrators moved into the forest June 20, anticipating that a judge would allow a timber company to cut trees within a 144-acre area of the forest. On June 26, U.S. District Judge James Foreman ruled the timber harvest could proceed. Since then, environmentalists have maintained a round-the-clock vigil, physically blocking access to the area scheduled for logging. Loggers have already removed too many trees, threatening the forest's fragile ecosystem, protesters said. The East Perry Lumber Co. of Missouri paid about $50,000 for the right to harvest in the Shawnee National Forest. Nearly 26 acres would be cleared in two-acre patches. Larger trees in the rest of the harvest area, including oak trees more than 100 years old, also would be cut down, Forest Service spokesman Tom Hagerty said. Sympathizers brought food and supplies to protesters Sunday. Lester Kujawa, who delivered a box of food, said his great-grandfather moved into the area in the 1800s. The forest should be preserved as it is for his children, Kujawa said. ``I'm here to show support for these people as long as they need,'' Kujawa said.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Secure Embassy in Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with breakdown of total number of people, Americans and foreigners evacuated; nearly half the Americans already flown to Sierra Leone. EDITS to tighten and DELETE now redundant material
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines who rushed to the defense of Americans caught in the midst of Liberia's bloody civil war have evacuated 74 people from the capital, the Pentagon said today. More than 200 Marines are dug in at the Embassy to defend the ``skeleton size'' diplomatic staff remaining there and to ferry those people who want to escape the West African nation's civil strife, officials said. Of the 62 U.S. citizens evacuated in the helicopter rescue mission that began Sunday, 35 have been flown to neighboring Sierra Leone and ``on to London where travel arrangements are being made'' for them to return to the United States, the Pentagon said in a statement today. Most of the Americans are U.S. government employees. Twelve citizens from other nations also have been helped to leave Monrovia, the capital. The statement identified them as eight Liberians who are dependents or escorts for Americans, two Italians, one Canadian and one French Catholic priest. ``Marine Corps helicopters will continue to ferry back and forth from the U.S. Embassy to the USS Saipan'' if further evacuations are necessary, the statement said. ``The Marines are there to protect lives. They are authorized to use whatever means are necessary and they are there in a battle situation,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Sunday. In a precision helicopter rescue mission, about 225 Marines plucked the Americans from the embassy grounds and airlifted them to safety aboard U.S. warships off the coast, the Pentagon said. ``No hostile action was taken against the operation, which was conducted smoothly and without incident,'' the Pentagon said. President Bush ordered the Marines to go ashore after one of the rebel leaders trying to oust President Samuel Doe ordered the arrest of all foreigners in an attempt to provoke outside intervention in the civil war, Fitzwater said. The United States has steadfastly refused to intervene in the increasingly violent dispute. The maneuver, code-named ``Sharp Edge,'' was launched from four warships that have been stationed in international waters off Liberia since early June. The goal was to secure the seaside U.S. Embassy compound and to retrieve 21 Americans posted at two transmitter sites just outside the capital. The embassy was trying to get word out to any other U.S. citizens remaining in Liberia, a U.S. official said. ``But they'll have to reach the embassy compound for the Marines to pick them up, and that may be hard for most of them because of the fighting,'' he added. Ambassador Peter de Vos was remaining behind in charge of a ``skeleton size'' staff, Fitzwater said. About 70 U.S. officials and 300 other Americans were in Liberia when the operation started, Fitzwater said. ``We'll take out as many as want to get out,'' he said. The Pentagon said the Marines would airlift other foreigners if they asked. Fitzwater stressed that the Marine presence ``does not indicate or constitute any intention on the part of the U.S. government to intervene militarily in the Liberian conflict.'' ``The purpose of this operation is to safeguard lives, to draw down the number of Americans at the embassy to minimum staff and to provide additional security for those who remain,'' Fitzwater said. Pentagon sources said about 237 Marines _ traditionally the protectors of diplomatic sites _ would defend the compound ``as long as necessary.'' Fitzwater said Doe was told of the operation in advance. The United States has a standing offer to evacuate Doe, who has holed up in the presidential mansion. Fitzwater said attempts were made to contact rebel leaders as well, but he could not confirm that contact had been made. U.S. officials notified Americans on Saturday that the evacuation could take place, and military officials expected that many of the 300 Americans would decline to leave. Many of those 300 U.S. citizens also hold Liberian citizenship. They have been living in Liberia for years and have extensive families that they don't want to leave behind. Most of the other Americans are missionaries posted in various parts of the country. All American employees of the Voice of America station near Monrovia were evacuated in May.

DOC.HEAD: `Considerable Doubt' Whether Saudi Arabia Would Pump Extra Oil
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB graf 7, `The U.N...' with 2 to update with closing of Turkish pipeline. Pickup 8th pvs, ``If anything...' Insert graf after 17th, `The upshot...' with Turkish comment. Pickup 18th pvs, `The newsletter...' Delete last graf to trim.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's oil export facilities are shut down and will remain so for some time, and there is considerable doubt Saudi Arabia will be willing to make up the potential world oil shortage, the Middle East Economic Survey said today. The weekly newsletter, published in Nicosia, said the total loss of supply to world oil markets because of the Kuwaiti shutdown and embargoes on Iraqi oil could exceed 4 million barrels a day. ``There will be a potential restriction of oil supply in the near future that could range in intensity from significant to highly severe depending on how circumstances unfold,'' it wrote. The respected newletter said Kuwaiti oil production and exports _ cut after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's powerful army invaded on Thursday _ would be shut down for some time ``both for physical-technical reasons and as a consequence of impending international efforts to interdict purchases of Kuwaiti oil.'' The newsletter said the impact of the Kuwaiti shutdown could be compounded by restrictions on Iraqi oil supplies. Since Friday, when the article was written, numerous sanctions have been announced, including Japanese and European embargoes on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The United States announced an on Thursday just hours after Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor. As a result of the embargos, Iraq today closed one of two major pipelines that was pumping its oil through Turkey to a terminal on the Mediterranean. It said the second pipeline would be used at just 70 percent capacity. The pipelines were carrying about 1.5 million barrels of oil a day, more than half Iraq's daily output. ``If anything like the full Iraqi-Kuwaiti shortfall of 4 million barrels a day manifests itself, the world will not be able to get by for very long without some additional supply from other sources, above and beyond the current OPEC quota levels,'' the newsletter said. It said current spare capacity by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries amounted to not much more than 3.5 million barrels of oil a day. This spare capacity is concentrated in a few countries: Saudi Arabia with a spare 2 million barrels a day, the United Arab Emirates with 600,000, Venezuela with 500,000 and Libya with 300,000, the newsletter said. ``Here the key obviously lies with Saudi Arabia; and there must be considerable doubt as to how far the Kingdom would be prepared to go on antagonizing Iraq by cooperating with measures to restrict Iraqi oil exports and increase its own production in deference to the wishes of the United States and the world community,'' it said. Iraq and Kuwait have accounted for 20 percent of OPEC's output. The newsletter noted that Iraq's pre-invasion oil exports amounted to 2.7 to 2.8 million barrels a day, divided between three outlets: pipelines across Saudi Arabia and Turkey, and the Gulf sea lanes. It said 1.5 million barrels a day were exported using the pipeline through Turkey to the Mediterranean, 900,000 via the Saudi Arabian pipeline to the Red Sea and 300,000 to 400,000 loaded onto tankers at Iraq's Mina al-Bakr terminal in the northern Persian Gulf. ``The pipelines across Turkey and Saudi Arabia would clearly be prime targets for international oil sanctions against Iraq,'' the Middle East Economic Survey wrote. ``But it should be remembered on the one hand that Turkey gets a substantial part of its own oil supply through the Iraqi pipeline, and on the other that any action by Saudi Arabia to interfere with the terminals by means of U.S. naval power could also be a tricky exercise,'' the newsletter wrote. ``The upshot of all this is that although effective global oil sanctions would undoubtedly cripple Iraq, they would be difficult to implement and administer in practice,'' it said. Turkish officials, however, said the decision to close the pipeline through their country would not affect Turkish purchases of Iraqi oil, expected to account for about 40 percent of Turkey's oil needs this year. The newsletter noted the agreement last month by OPEC ministers _ under pressure from Saddam _ to restrict production in order to push up oil prices. ``Now the normal pattern of oil supply and trade have been radically distorted, and crisis buying has already lifted prices to somewhere around the $21-a-barrel OPEC basket range,'' it wrote. It said unless ``conditions return to normal pretty soon, the damage to the agreement _ and perhaps OPEC itself _ may prove beyond repair.'' The Middle East Economic Survey said this brought to mind the two previous occasions in the past 20 years when the oil market was convulsed by political upheavals: in 1973-74 when the Arabs imposed an oil embargo during the Arab-Israeli war, and the 1979-81 price explosion. Those ``oil shocks,'' especially the second one, drove the world into economic recession.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Lung Drug for Premature Babies
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug that could help save thousands of premature infants born with immature lungs. The drug, a powder mixed with sterile water, substitutes for a naturally occurring foam that coats the inside of the lungs and keeps them from collapsing when the infant exhales. The infants receive the drug through a tube into their windpipes. They must be on a mechanical ventilator to receive it. About 250,000 infants are born prematurely each year in the United States. One-fifth of them have respiratory distress syndrome, or breathing difficulties, due to immature lungs. The problem is fatal in some 5,000 cases a year. That makes respiratory distress syndrome the leading cause of death and disability among premature infants, the FDA said. In 1963, a baby born to President Kennedy and his wife died of the condition. The newly approved drug, called Exosurf Neonatal, can be used immediately after birth to prevent death in high-risk infants under three pounds and also to treat infants who have developed the disease. The FDA said the drug represents such an important advance that it has been widely available since July 1989, when it was still experimental. The drug was invented by Dr. John Clements of the University of California at San Francisco. Burroughs Wellcome Co. of Research Triangle Park, N.C. applied to market it in February. The FDA said its approval came in ``a near-record five months.'' The FDA also said it has designated Exosurf an orphan drug under a program that provides incentives for the development and production of drugs and medical products to treat conditions affecting small numbers of people.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait-At-a-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Kuwait:

LAND _ Kuwait, a land of 6,880 square miles, is bordered by Iraq to the north and west, Saudi Arabia to the south-southwest, and the Persian Gulf to the east. The oil-rich country is flat and very dry. The nation gets an average of 5 inches of rain a year.

PEOPLE _ About one-quarter of Kuwait's 1.7 million residents live in the capital of Kuwait City and its suburbs. More than half are foreigners, mainly Arabs, including 300,000 Palestinians. Most Kuwaitis are Sunni Moslem, but 30 percent adhere to the rival Shiite sect. Shiites of Iranian descent number nearly 150,000. The al-Sabah clan has ruled Kuwait as an emirate since they settled there in 1756 after trekking from the Arabian hinterland. More than 70 percent of the people speak Arabic, the official language, while 10 percent speak Kurdish and 4 percent Persian. A constitutional monarchy rules the country.

ECONOMY _ Oil is the chief resource of Kuwait, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Only 1 percent of the land is cultivated. Per capita income in 1986 was $13,890. Oil revenue reached $30 billion in 1983, but has been declining since because of a drop in oil prices and production curbs. Kuwait currently produces about 1.5 million barrels of oil a day and has reserves of 89.7 billion barrels, 12.8 percent of world reserves and enough to last for more than 250 years. Little grows in the desert climate, so the emirate has to import nearly all its food.

HISTORY _ The Mongols, Arab caliphs and Ottomans were in turn overlords of the bleak and largely unpopulated land until 1899, when the British became the dominant power in the region. Kuwait gained its independence in 1961. It is a member of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, a defense and economic alliance. Iraq, which has historically laid claim to all of Kuwait, invaded Thursday and announced the formation of a provisional government. The al-Sabah family fled to Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Little Vacation For British Primer Minister in Mountain Resort
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Thatcher's departure. Picks up 4th graf pvs: `The trip...'
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today left Aspen for a meeting in Washington with President Bush after a five-day visit shortened by the Kuwait invasion and a terrorist bombing at home. Mrs. Thatcher, who arrived Aug. 1, shortened her scheduled 10-day visit to this mountain resort so she could attend the funeral Wednesday of Ian Gow, a conservative member of Parliament slain by an Irish Republican Army bomb on June 30. The trip was trimmed further to make time to meet Bush. She was scheduled to return home on Tuesday. Mrs. Thatcher spoke Sunday to more than 3,000 people at the 40th anniversay of the Aspen Institute, a group dedicated to humanistic values worldwide. Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's bold takeover of tiny neighbor Kuwait dominated concerns during her visit. Bush met with her Thursday to discuss the invasion before he delivered the anniversary celebration's opening speech. The United Nations must work to end the Mideast occupation, she said. ``Iraq's invasion of Kuwait defies every principle for which the U.N. stands. If we let it succeed, no small country can ever feel safe again. The law of the jungle takes over,'' she said. She also proposed human rights guarantees for all of Europe similar to those established in Britain's Magna Carta, which protects freedom of speech, religion, law and commerce, and the right to hold democratic elections, own property and maintain nationhood. Mrs. Thatcher said all Europeans deserve to remain free from ``fear of an over-mighty state.'' She also suggested that the European Community should be prepared to accept all Eastern European nations for full membership. ``We don't see this new Soviet Union as an enemy, but as a country groping its way towards freedom,'' she said. ``We no longer have to view the world through the prism of East-West relations. The Cold War is over.'' During her stay, Mrs. Thatcher visited the ``Star Wars'' Strategic Defense Initiative center and the North American Aerospace Defense Command in Colorado Springs and the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder. Mrs. Thatcher received the institute's Statesman Award for contributions to democracy and peace. The award has been given twice before in the institute's 40-year history _ to Jean Monnet, founder of the European economic integration, and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. Founded in 1950, the nonprofit institute gathers leaders in all parts of society to discuss critical issues in the world. The symposium this weekend concentrated on topics ranging from health care to education.

DOC.HEAD: Bill to Create Cabinet-Level Department of Environment Stalls in Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 10th graf, Nothing has ... to CORRECT date of Earth Day
DOC.TEXT: Legislation to create a Department of the Environment to give new focus to environmental issues brought nothing but cheers six months ago, but now the proposal is mired in turf wars and its future is in doubt. The administration cooled toward the idea after the House passed a bill it didn't like. Legislation has languished for months in the Senate with no indication when it might be scheduled for a floor vote. ``I think at the moment it's sort of stalled,'' said Sen. William Roth, R-Del., one of the key sponsors of the bill introduced in January to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee who has pushed the EPA Cabinet issue, said he hasn't given up hope. Glenn said in an interview that some progress is being made to get differences resolved. But he added ``I'm not predicting a date'' for getting the bill to the Senate floor, much less working out differences from the House bill. A number of complex issues, from the budget deficit to child care and clean air, face Congress when it returns next month from its August recess with only a few weeks remaining before the October campaign season. Despite all the talk of smooth sailing earlier this year, the EPA cabinet bill could easily become a casualty to the calendar, some environmentalists fear. With considerable fanfare in January, President Bush announced his support for the legislation, which would create the government's 15th Cabinet-level agency. The environmental challenges ``are so important that they must be addressed at the highest level,'' he declared at a White House news conference. Nothing has been heard publicly from Bush on the issue since. The president made no secret that he had wanted the legislation to sign on Earth Day on April 22. There was no bill and he went fishing in Florida instead. Meanwhile, what had been seen as a simple piece of legislation with widespread bipartisan support began taking on political baggage. In March, only four days before Earth Day, the House voted 371-55 to create a Department of the Environment, but added requirements seen by the White House as an attempt to ``micro-manage'' the executive branch. The president made known he likely would veto a bill that contains the House restrictions. The administration especially doesn't like provisions to create an independent Bureau of Statistics _ and bar its director from being replaced short of malfeasance _ and limit the number of political appointees in the new department. In the Senate a succession of turf battles, involving Senate committees and parts of the executive branch, have kept the legislation in limbo since it cleared Glenn's Government Affairs Committee months ago. Committees with jurisdiction over the Commerce and Energy departments, as well as the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, have voiced objections to parts of the bill they fear might affect them. The Senate disputes have not centered on the heart of the legislation, but on the fringes: How will it affect the president's Council on Environmental Quality? Who will chair an interagency group on environmental issues within the White House? Will the new department usurp powers now in the Commerce or Energy departments? Some leading environmental groups, including the National Wildlife Federation, Sierra Club and Natural Resources Defense Council, urged Senate leaders in a letter to end the stalemate and move the bill. ``The environmental community is pushing for it. The issues in the 1990s are going to be more global in nature and to give the EPA equal footing with other (environmental) ministers is vitally necessary,'' said Bill Klinefelder, legislative director for the Wildlife Federation. But not all environmentalists are as enthusiastic. Environmental Action, a Washington-based environmental group, has not kept close tabs on the bill. Its president, Ruth Caplan, said creating a Department of the Environment would be nice, but perhaps not so significant. ``It could give the impression of doing something for the environment without having to spend any real political chips,'' Ms. Caplan said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill Two Cultists in Bizarre Attack
DOC.TEXT: Machete-wielding cultists attacked an army outpost after rubbing oil over their bodies to repel bullets, but soldiers killed two and wounded four other attackers, the military said Monday. The clash occurred Sunday in a village outside Valencia town, about 50 miles south of here on Mindanao island, said Lt. Col. Bartolome Bagares, civil-military operations chief of the 4th Infantry Battalion. Thirteen new recruits of the ``Bolo (Machete) Battalion,'' were sent by their leader to free a detained comrade and to prove that a ``wonder oil'' would make them invincible, Bagares said. The cultists raised their machetes in the air, chanted Latin prayers and charged the soldiers, Bagares said. But the oil proved ineffective. Two were shot dead and four others were wounded when troops opened fire, he said. Three other attackers were captured and the rest fled when they saw their comrades fall, Bagares said. There were no casualties among the soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Prepare to Take Apart Sunken Barge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs explaining tanks must be cleaned before barge is salvaged and adding details of flyover today. Picks up 2nd graf pvs: ``Crews also...' ^LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Salvage crews today cleaned the tanks of a crippled oil barge so it could be cut up and the Houston Ship Channel reopened to unrestricted traffic for the first time in more than a week. The barge's tanks must be cleaned of oil so that a spark from a welding torch won't cause an explosion, officials said. They did not know how long it would take to clean and cut up the barge, crippled in a collision that left 700,000 gallons of heavy oil in busy Galveston Bay. After an early morning flyover, Coast Guard officials reported that little oil remained along the shoreline at Houston Point, on the north end of the bay. Only a few patches of heavy oil were spotted along the shoreline, but a rainbow sheen stretched about two miles into the bay, said Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt. ``I think that's good because the heavy stuff is right at the shoreline where it can be collected by the vacuum trucks. The sheen is more susceptible to natural breakdown,'' Meidt said. Crews also sprayed oil-eating bacteria on marshes Sunday and vacuumed up heavy sludge from the spill, caused when a Greek tanker collided with two oil barges July 28. The tanker lost none of its cargo. Both barges were damaged. Vessels became bottled up in the channel while the Coast Guard worked to free the barge that sank in the accident. Ships were allowed to leave the harbor Sunday night, with help from tugs, for the first time since the accident. Inbound towboat traffic resumed Friday. As of late Sunday, about 40 vessels were waiting to get in, and fewer than 10 were waiting to leave, the Coast Guard said. ``Traffic is moving, just not freely,'' said Scott Inbody, chief warrant officer of the Coast Guard's vessel traffic service in Houston. ``We're making sure no vessels meet or overtake each other in the waters near the accident.'' The delays were estimated to cost $10,000 to $20,000 per day for each vessel. Coast Guardsmen and salvage crews using skimmers, hundreds of yards of booms and 18 vacuum trucks worked into the night to contain and suck up the estimated 100,000 gallons of brown sludge believed remaining in Galveston Bay. Cleanup crews collected about 315,000 gallons of the medium to heavy crude, and little remained visible in Galveston Bay, said Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene. He said he expected the cleanup to cost about $5 million. The sunken barge is believed to have lost most of its 716,000 gallons of oil; the second barge lost nearly 50,000 gallons, officials said. A ban on shrimping imposed in Galveston Bay on Thursday remained in effect. The ban on fin fishing was lifted Saturday. Cleanup crews sprayed some 150 pounds of oil-eating bacteria on marshlands that cannot be safely reached with skimming vessels. In the process begun last week, the naturally occurring microbes reduce the oil to a fatty substance that sinks and is eaten by fish. ``This is different from oil on rocks or oil in open waters,'' said Texas Water Commission chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne. ``This is on a living, organic system and it's absolutely the most sensitive place it can be.'' Greene said strong winds had pushed some oil from marshlands back out into the bay. Some of the oil washed ashore, while streamers up to 100 yards long moved toward Trinity Bay, a sensitive marine area. But Larry McKinney, director of the resource protection division of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, said such a drift could be beneficial because the oil would be in open waters where skimmers and booms could more easily contain and suck up the sludge. McKinney said crews had found dead crabs, mussels, small fish and other small animals along the shore. He said crews searched the marshlands for oil-soiled wildlife but had been unable to catch any of the animals. ``Really, we've been lucky,'' McKinney said. ``The oil's not up here like we thought it would be in the marshes.'' An inquiry board of officials from the Coast Guard and the National Transportation Safety Board concluded five days of hearings on the cause of the accident Sunday. An official report is not expected for several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Seton House Dedicated as Sanctuary for Outcast AIDS Victims
DOC.TEXT: Seton House, a place where AIDS victims may find a home and be treated with dignity, has been completed and dedicated by Missionaries of Charity, the order of Mother Teresa. ``All of us are witnesses today to what most of us hope to see once in a lifetime _ a miracle,'' Archbishop J. Francis Stafford told a crowd that filled the small chapel Sunday. Seton House, a former church building that had been closed for eight years, was reopened by five sisters sent to Denver by the order. It will provide a home for up to 20 men and women with AIDS when it begins accepting residents in a few weeks. Gov. Roy Romer, who attended the dedication, said to the nuns: ``I am absolutely in awe of the service you have given. Yos, a tomato reddening on the vine embodies the spirit of summer. Moreover, it's easy to grow. You don't even need a garden, just a pot and a sunny place. Amid such poplularity, breeders have developed hundreds of varieties and more keep coming every year. The oldies are still around, too, and available from seedhouses specializing in heirloom varieties. Living in the country, with plenty of space for experiment, I grow the new and the old, the large and the small, the red and the gold. This year I've grown the smallest tomato in creation, the currant _ no larger then a marble _ and found the taste intense, but attractive. The skin was tough, however. Taste, of course, is highly personal _ and fickle, too _ but the small ones are getting high marks for flavor nowadays and many of us would say they're the best for salads. My own favorite smallie is an old cultivar named ``Yellow Pear,'' producing a tantilizing blend of tart and sweet. Some people, however, think ``Yellow Pear'' too bland, and prefer something sweeter, like one called ``Sweet Million.'' Gardeners, naturally, like earliness in tomatoes and watch the catalogs for cultivars with that feature. The best one to come along for my climate _ chilly spring nights 50 miles north of New York City _ is another smallie called ``Subarctic Plenty,'' which sets fruit in the 40s and even high 30s Fahrenheit. This gives me salad tomatoes in mid-July, three and four weeks ahead of my other tomatoes. By the middle of August, however, ``Subarctic'' has done its thing and I'm eating other tomatoes with later and longer maturing times. A new one called ``Ida Gold,'' small and yellow, has excellent flavor, but the harvest is short. ``Yellow Pear,'' on the other hand, keeps bearing until fall and I've seen it survive a few degrees of frost. A new gardener interested in long-bearing tomatoes should look for varieties labeled ``intermediate.'' Those called ``determinate'' are usually bush types with all-at-once yields. Some bush types, like ``Red Robin,'' grow no taller than a foot or so and have little spread, ideal for the small garden or for patio or container growing. While using smallies for salads, I still grow medium-sized fruit for cooking such dishes as stuffed tomatoes. Among the best-tasting medium tomatoes marketed in recent years is a red one called ``Carmello,'' which I've seen described as both California and French. I also raise beefsteak tomatoes for slicing on sandwiches. This may sound like a lot of tomatoes, but all told I limit myself to about a dozen plants, which is plenty for me and my wife. Actually, much of my harvest goes into making spaghetti sauce for the freezer. When I first started gardening some 40 years ago, staking and pruning tomato plants made for a lot of work. But as I got older and lazier, and maybe wiser, I stopped this. Now I just lay down a bed of hay around my plants and let them sprawl. The hay gives pretty good protection to the fruit. Sure, I get a blemish and a hole here and there, but I'm not growing for show and the taste is just as good. A historical curiosity about the tomato is that despite its American Indian origins it was practically unknown as a vegetable to whites in North America until long after the Europeans, with some misgivings, ate it. The poison fear persisted, probably because the tomato belongs to the nightshade family. But with today's popularity of small toamtoes, we are returning to the plant's ancient origins. The wild cherry tomato from the Andes is indeed believed to be the granddaddy of them all.
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday, Aug. 9

DOC.HEAD: Japan Mourns Victims of Hiroshima Bombing
LaserPhotos HIR4, TOK8
DOC.TEXT: Hiroshima on Monday mourned the 140,000 victims of the 1945 atomic bomb attack with a solemn look back and a note of optimism for the future as tensions ease between the Soviet Union and the United States. For an eery moment, the city fell silent. Taxis and street cars stopped, and people throughout this industrial center of 1 million joined in a moment of prayer for the souls of those killed in the bombing. Dignitaries, Hiroshima residents and foreign guests bowed their heads at 8:15 a.m., the exact moment the bomb exploded in a blinding flash of light. ``I pay my deep respects to the citizens of Hiroshima who have built this city of international peace from the ashes,'' Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said at a ceremony attended by 55,000 people. ``As the only country in the world to have experienced an atom bomb attack, Japan has resolved not to let it be repeated,'' Kaifu said. He reiterated Japan's appeals for total nuclear disarmament. Kaifu told a news conference that his government was working to increase medical and financial support for those exposed to the bomb's radiation. Hiroshima Mayor Takeshi Araki, in his annual peace declaration, praised the growing promises for disarmament in the United States and the Soviet Union. ``Hiroshima has the highest regard for this tide of disarmament, changing the fate of mankind from one of annihilation to one of survival,'' Araki said. The United States, in an effort to avoid a bloody invasion of Japan to end World War II, dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945. It wiped out nearly half the city's population, killing most immediately. Many others died within a few months, mostly from radiation or burns. Hiroshima, a major military center during the war, has been honoring the dead at a solemn peace ceremony annually for 43 years. But not all Hiroshima residents can face the memories. Retired school teacher Minako Tanabe said her husband has never attended the ceremony although he has lived in Hiroshima all his life. ``My husband won't come here because it's too sad. So many of his friends died that day,'' Ms. Tanabe said. Monday, thousands of visitors streamed through the city's Peace Memorial Park, leaving flowers, messages and garlands of folded paper cranes, symbols of peace, draped around the park's 29 monuments. At a ceremony, officials added 5,551 names of people exposed to the bomb who died over the past year to the names enshrined in a granite cenotaph, raising the total of claimed victims to 167,243. But it is difficult to determine which deaths were directly related to the bomb, and 140,000 victims is the more accepted figure. Many researchers believe the risk of death from leukemia, lung, bone and breast cancer is greater for those exposed to the bomb. Three days after the attack on Hiroshima, the United States dropped a second atom bomb on the city of Nagasaki, killing 70,000 civilians. Japan surrendered six days later, ending World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent GOP Gov. Mike Hayden Faces Tough Test in Kansas
With AM-Elections Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Mike Hayden has never lost since he first won election to the Kansas House of Representatives in 1972, but he faces a strong challenge from a political newcomer in Tuesday's primary election. Recent polls have had Wichita real estate executive Nestor Weigand Jr. gaining rapidly on Hayden in a six-way battle for the GOP governor nomination. One poll last week put Weigand ahead but by such a small margin that the race was considered too close to call. Hayden claimed his own polling had him solidly ahead. On the Democratic side, former Gov. John Carlin, who served in 1979-87 and was ineligible under the state constitution to run for a third four-year term in 1986, was expected to have less trouble than Hayden in winning his party's nomination. Carlin's chief rival for the Democratic nomination is Joan Finney, who has been state treasurer for 15{ years. The problems for Hayden, 46, stem from a lack of popularity in urban areas and the political backlash from property taxes that soared after the state reappraised all property and implemented a classification system that assessed property at different rates. The changes hit some medium and small businesses especially hard and taxpayer protest groups came to the Capitol last winter demanding changes. When the Legislature adjourned in early May without doing anything Hayden bore the brunt of the blame. Weigand, 51, wealthy president of a family real estate business, the largest in Wichita, has tried to capitalize on the discontent, billing himself as a candidate who can solve the property tax problem. However, Weigand has been criticized for lacking governmental knowledge and for proposing impractical solutions, such as restoring business inventories to the tax rolls, which industry strongly opposes and probably can block in the Legislature. Also at stake on Tuesday's ballot were nominations for one U.S. Senate seat and five seats in the House. U.S. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum faced token opposition in the Republican senatorial primary from little-known Gregory Walstrom of Lawrence. In the Democratic primary for Kassebaum's seat, former U.S. Rep. Bill Roy filed for nomination in June, than a week later announced he would not campaign for it. Roy represented northeast Kansas in Congress in 1971-75 and lost senatorial races to Bob Dole in 1974 and to Kassebaum in 1978. Roy could not get his name off the ballot after the filing deadline, and could beat political neophyte Dick Williams on name recognition alone. If so, Roy will have to decide if he wants to campaign against Kassebaum in the fall. On the House side, U.S. Rep. Bob Whittaker, who has represented southeast Kansas in Washington for 12 years, did not seek re-election this year and 10 candidates sought the two party nominations to succeed him. There was no clearcut favorite in either party. Incumbent Republican Reps. Pat Roberts and Jan Meyers and Democrat Dan Glickman had no primary opposition, while Democrat Jim Slattery faced token opposition in Mark Creamer, a crusader for the legalization of marijuana who sat in jail on a possession conviction during the primary campaign. Secretary of State Bill Graves forecast a turnout of 415,000 voters, 275,000 in the Republican primary and 140,000 in the Democratic primary. Kansas has 1.166 million registered voters, but 346,000 of them are not registered with either party.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts Iranian Town Devastated By Previous Earthquake
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake sharply jolted a northern Iranian town on Monday, more than month after a quake killed 40,000 people in the region. There was no immediate report of damage or injuries. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the temblor struck Rudbar, in northern Gilan province, at 12:55 p.m. It measured 4.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion. It said more than 2,000 quakes have shaken the region since the devastating June 21 earthquake, which registered 7.3 on the Richter scale. That quake also left 60,000 injured and rendered half million homeless irovinces of Gilan and Zanjan. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one on the northern pf 6.5. An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage in the local area, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: World Health Organization Urges Smoking Ban on All Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization on Monday urged a smoking ban on all passenger aircraft. ``We are now calling for all airlines to be smoke-free. We think it's sensible, we think it's possible and we think the airlines would support it,'' John Roberts, WHO's tobacco and health program manager, told reporters. Martin Jarvis, senior scientist of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, said separately: ``Simply having non-smoking seats on aircraft is not an answer to the problem. Non-smokers are still exposed to smoke.'' Air Canada last month became the first airline to ban smoking on all its trans-Atlantic flights. Smoking is banned on most domestic flights in the United States. A survey conducted by the World Health Organization and the British Medical Association found that some airlines would welcome a smoking ban if it was introduced by a third party such as a government or aviation industry body. The survey showed the main reason airlines changed their smoking policy was pressure from consumers. ``You can't step off an aircraft if you don't like the smoke. You are trapped,'' Roberts said. A pro-smoking group, Forest, attacked the survey, saying: ``Yet again the BMA forget that the role of doctors is to serve their patients, not to dictate to them by force of law how they should live their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Prepares for Attack; Turkish Oil Pipeline Closed
LaserPhoto AMS2, BON1-2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th pvs, `Saudi Arabia...' to UPDATE with reports carrier battle group within striking distance of gulf, U.S. rapid deployment force dispatched. Pickup 5th pvs, `In other...'
DOC.TEXT: Ruling party members said today that the government, fearing a U.S. air attack, was distributing automatic weapons to tens of thousands of supporters and preparing to evacuate the Iraqi capital. A boycott of Iraqi oil forced Baghdad today to close one of two pipelines in Turkey that were pumping the bulk of Iraq's exported oil, Turkish officials said. A British official said Iraqi troops rounded up American and British visitors in Kuwait and taking them to Iraq. The Foreign Office spokesman said most were passengers from a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion Thursday. ``There is no evidence that they are in any way in trouble,'' the official said. Saudi Arabia was reported reinforcing its troops along the Kuwaiti border following concerns Iraq may try to invade it. Pentagon sources said the USS Independence and its carrier battle group are now on station in the Arabian Sea, a position that would allow it to launch fighter planes into the Persian Gulf region. Gulf-based diplomats said soldiers from the American rapid deployment force, formed to react to crises in the Middle East, had been dispatched to the area. In other developments: _The new Kuwait government installed by Iraq hinted it might take hostages or seize property of nations that take punitive measures against Iraq. _Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said the 100,000 soldiers who invaded Kuwait began to pull back Sunday. President Bush said Iraq was lying. _Oil prices jumped more than $3 a barrel on news Europe and Japan were joining the embargo of Iraqi oil. Stocks slumped worldwide. _Hospital officials said at least 300 Kuwaiti and Iraqi soldiers were killed during the invasion. In London, Kuwaitis arriving on a special plane said 700 Kuwaitis died. The embargo of Iraqi oil grew over the weekend to include Japan and the European Community. Along with the United States, they bought more than half Iraq's exported oil, with most of it pumped through Turkey. An official of the state-run Turkish pipeline company BOTAS said pumping stopped at one of the two Turkish pipelines at 5 p.m. Iraq reduced flow in the second, wider, pipeline to 70 percent of capacity, they said. There was no comment from Iraq. The two pipelines pump Iraqi crude from Kirkuk oil fields in northern Iraq to a terminal at the northeastern tip of the Mediterranean. They carry 70 million tons of crude annually, providing the outlet for the major share of Iraqi exports. The BOTAS official said all the countries participating in the embargo purchase their Iraqi crude from the Turkish outlet. Iraq also exports oil through a Saudi Arabian pipeline and via tankers in the northern Persian Gulf. A Foreign Office spokesman said today as saying a total of 366 people had been assembled by Iraqi troops in Kuwait, mostly passengers from a stranded British Airways flight. They were being transported by bus to the Iraqi border. Baghdad did not give any reason for its action. Immediately after the invasion Thursday, 11 Americans were rounded up by Iraqi troops. They turned up safe in Baghdad. The new Iraqi-installed foreign minister of Kuwait, Lt. Col. Walid Sa'oud Mohammed Abdullah, warned against further sanctions in a statement broadcast Sunday by Iraqi radio. ``Countries that resort to punitive measures against the provisional free Kuwait government and fraternal Iraq should remember that they have interests and nationals in Kuwait,'' he said. Iraqi soldiers invaded Kuwait after complaining that its violation of OPEC production quotas was driving down world crude prices, lowering Iraqi oil revenues. Saddam also accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a field that includes land both sides claim. The respected Middle East Economic Survey reported today that Kuwait's oil export facilities had been shut down. It also said there was considerable doubt Saudi Arabia, with the world's largest oil reserves, would be willing to make up the potential world oil shortage. Kuwait and Iraq together account for one-fifth of the 23.5 million barrels produced daily by the 13 OPEC nations. Tensions remained high in the region; a U.S. official said in Washington that Iraqi troops massed on the Kuwaiti-Saudi border were apparently digging in. An American technician at a secret Saudi Arabian base said the kingdom had sent 200 to 300 tanks toward its border with Kuwait. Oil industry sources in Saudi Arabia reached by telephone from Bahrain said Saudi troops were entering the region of Khafji, near the border. Residents reached by telephone reported intense air activity near the Saudi airport overnight. The Washington Post reported today that Egypt was mobilizing some elements of its armed forces to assist Saudi Arabia in the event of an invasion. U.S. officials said there was no indication Iraqi troops were preparing to invade Saudi Arabia. But Bush sent Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to the kingdom to confer with its leaders, and the White House said Secretary of State James A. Baker would go this week to Turkey. Saadi Mehdi Saleh, the Iraqi army commander, was quoted by the Al-Iraq newspaper as saying tens of thousands of volunteers had joined the army to defend what he called ``Iraq and the revolution in Kuwait.'' Americans, he was quoted as saying, ``should understand that the people of the great leader Saddam Hussein cannot be frightened.'' Local members of the ruling Baath party said preparations were under way to evacuate all of Baghdad's 4 million people to camps outside the city. They were being told that the U.S. Air Force might attack or that Israel might attack with chemical or nuclear weapons. The party members also said the party had distributed guns, mainly AK-47 automatic rifles, to tens of thousands of people around the country. State radio said Saddam had ordered the formation of 11 new Iraqi army divisions, expected to generate 100,000 troops. The Arab world's most formidible military force is already estimated at 1 million men. At a border checkpoint 30 miles south of the Iraqi port city of Basra, dozens of tanks, armored personnel carriers and trucks carrying hundreds of soldiers crossed back into Iraq on Sunday. But thousands of Iraqi soldiers remained behind in Kuwait, controlling major government buildings, commerical centers and ports. Diplomats in the region said a new Kuwaiti army fanned out through Kuwait. The force comprises about 80,000 troops, mostly Iraqis. The nine-member Kuwaiti military government, announced by Iraq on Saturday, remained a mystery. No photographs of the named leaders have been shown and 12 reporters brought to Kuwait by the Ministry of Information could not locate any of them. Kuwaiti diplomats said they were all Iraqis, including a son-in-law of Saddam, a charge official Iraqi media denied.

DOC.HEAD: American Workers' Productivity Rebounds in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in 18 months, climbing at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the government said Monday. Analysts said they were encouraged by the gain in non-farm productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ especially in light of recent data showing rising unemployment and stagnant economic growth. ``It's one tiny bright spot in the midst of a lot of negatives,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer in New York. However, economists said the 1.6 percent gain was still below the level needed to dramatically boost Americans' standard of living and improve the nation's ability to compete internationally. They also were disturbed at the report's findings on hourly labor costs, a major inflation measure for businesses. Those costs rose at an annual rate of 5.6 percent the second quarter of 1990, well above the 3 percent rise for all of 1989. ``The inflation numbers for the rest of the year look horrible, especially with the shock of the Middle East oil crisis,'' said Michael K. Evans, who heads a Washington economic forecasting firm. The rise in productivity in the second three months of the year was the first increase since productivity climbed 0.5 percent in the final quarter of 1988, the Labor Department said. Though the report offered good news on American workers' performance in the April-June period, the agency said revised figures on last year showed productivity actually fell 0.3 percent rather than increasing 0.9 percent as first reported. The poor 1989 showing was the worst since non-farm productivity dropped 0.9 percent during the 1981-82 recession, the government said. The report showed that from April to June, the number of hours Americans worked fell 0.1 percent _ a likely sign that workers were being laid off in the face of slower economic growth and businesses just weren't hiring as many new workers, analysts said. ``It's a good news-bad news thing,'' Evans said. ``The good news is that producers are starting to cut costs and lay off (inefficient) workers and the bad news is that when they lay off too many workers, we have a recession.'' In revising numbers for the first quarter of 1990, the agency offered slightly better figures, saying productivity fell 1.9 percent rather than the 2.7 percent plunge first reported. Monday's report showed that unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 3.9 percent for the April-June period, compared with a 3.3 percent increase during all of 1989. In the manufacturing sector, productivity increased 3.7 percent, a big improvement over the 2 percent increase during all of 1989. Unit labor costs in that sector rose 2.6 percent, compared with the 2.2 percent increase during all of last year. Total business productivity, including farming, rose 1.9 percent for the first quarter, compared with a 0.2 percent drop for all of 1989. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged 1.4 percent a year. Increasing productivity is considered basic to boosting living standards because it allows businesses to pay workers more as their output rises without risking higher inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Heading to Turkey; Cheney Arrives in Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today it is ``clearly in the national interest'' to end Iraq's aggression. Sources said the USS Independence moved close enough to the tense Persian Gulf region to launch fighter planes. The White House said Secretary of State James A. Baker III will travel to Turkey mid-week, as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived in Saudi Arabia to open talks on ``appropriate ways to defend their country.'' Oil pipelines critical to Iraq's oil distribution run through Turkey and Saudi Arabia. Bush also stepped up discussions with Western allies. Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the president would meet over dinner tonight with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, following meetings with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner. The White House continued its tough line on Iraq's military invasion of Kuwait. ``It is true that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait threatens regional and world stability, threatens OPEC and could force severe economic consequences on the United States,'' Fitzwater said. ``From the moment the first Iraqi soldier entered Kuwait, it has been clearly in the national interest to stop Saddam Hussein. This is an overt situation. His tanks are real and moving. Our response is real and moving on all fronts, diplomatic, economic, political and military,'' he said. Meanwhile, Pentagon sources said the USS Independence and its carrier battle group are now on station in the Arabian Sea, a position that would allow it to launch fighter planes into the Persian Gulf region. Officially, the Pentagon would only say that the huge warship was operating in the Indian Ocean, and that it is being escorted by eight smaller warships and four support ships. Asked the purpose of Baker's mission to Turkey later this week, Fitzwater said every country in the region faces ``a degree of threat'' from Iraq, which last Thursday launched a lightning invasion of Kuwait. ``We don't know what Saddam Hussein's intentions are. And certainly every country suffers a more indirect threat of OPEC takeover'' by Iraq, he said. He said the situation in the Gulf ``remains extremely serious. There is no information suggesting that Iraqi military units are departing Kuwait. To the contrary, the Iraqi military presence throughout Kuwait, including along the Saudi border, remains extremely large and threatening.'' Asked if the Cheney was offering the Saudis assurances that the United States would defend the desert kingdom, Fitzwater said, ``We have discussed military possibilities and our abilities with all the countries in the gulf.'' ``The defense of Saudi Arabia is of paramount concern,'' he said. Fitzwater declined comment on reports that Turkey, a member of NATO, had agreed to cut off the pipelines that carry much of Iraq's oil to market. He also said the White House could not confirm a report that Iraq itself had reduced the flow of its oil through Turkey. ``Iraq's invasion of Kuwait threatens regional and world stability, threatens OPEC and could force severe economic consequences on the United States,'' he said. Fitzwater said Jordan's King Hussein, who has defended Saddam, called Bush Sunday night. He did not offer details. He also expressed concern about possible price gouging by oil companies that sharply raised gasoline prices within hours of the Iraqi invasion. ``We are concerned about the price increases. There have been some immediate increases in the spot price of crude oil. It is not clear that all of the increases that have been reported at the consumer level are necessary,'' said Fitzwater. ``It would be most unfortunate if there were any gouging or anyone was trying to take advantage of this situation,'' he said. Currently, he added, ``the disruption is fairly moderate'' in U.S. oil supplies. An irate Bush on Sunday vowed that Iraq's ``brutal, naked aggression ... will not stand.'' The Cheney delegation to Saudi Arabia included Bush's deputy national security adviser Robert Gates, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander in chief of the Central Command, which includes the Persian Gulf, and Paul Wolfowitz, undersecretary of defense for policy. They undertook the mission as the United States intensified efforts to build worldwide support for a boycott of oil from Iraqi and Kuwait and to press for United Nations sanctions that could include a ban on trade with Iraq. Bush met with top military and civilian advisers Sunday evening at the White House after issuing a stern denunciation of the Iraqi invasion that has inflamed the Middle East. The president said Sunday there was ``a strong feeling'' among the NATO allies including Turkey, which controls a pipeline vital to Iraq's oil exports, ``that we must have concerted action to isolate Iraq economically.'' To Baghdad's claim _ accompanied by government television footage _ that it had begun pulling out its 80,000 troops, Bush snapped that the Iraqis ``lied once again.' Bush said he knew of no country willing to recognize the ``puppet regime'' of military officers that Iraq has installed in Kuwait to replace the ruling royal family. The emir fled to Saudi Arabia as the Iraqi tanks rolled down on Kuwait City. ``I want to see the Arab states join the rest of the world in condemning this outrage and doing what they can to get Saddam Hussein out,'' said Bush. Asked about Jordan King Hussein's defense of the Iraqi ruler, Bush said, ``I am disappointed to find any comment by anyone that apologizes or appears to condone what's taken place.'' Jordan's monarch said Saturday that other Arab states were ``premature'' in condemning the Iraqi invasion. He called Iraq's ruler ``a patriotic man.'' But Jordan's foreign minister, Mudar Badran, said his country would not recognize the new Kuwaiti government. Bush lauded Japan, which has joined the U.S. and European boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait despite Japan's heavy reliance on Persian Gulf oil. Iraq and Kuwait have supplied more than 11 percent of Japan's oil. Bush refused to discuss any military moves, but told reporters his options were ``wide open.'' The United States imposed an economic boycott on Iraq hours after its lightning invasion of Kuwait last Thursday. Bush has spent much of his time since then urging other nations to use economic pressure to bring Baghdad to heel. Asked how he and other world leaders could thwart the Iraqis' puppet regime, a clearly agitated Bush said, ``Just wait. Watch and learn.'' Tens of thousands of Iraqi troops were reported massed in Kuwait near the Saudi border.

DOC.HEAD: Man Says His Father Helped Assassinate John F. Kennedy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: REWRITES throughout to tighten, to move up FBI comment, and to delete defacing of statue in Boston. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A 29-year-old unemployed oil equipment salesman said today that his father was one of three men who fired the shots that killed President John F. Kennedy on CIA orders. During a press conference, Ricky White said his late father, Roscoe White, joined the Dallas Police Department two months before the Nov. 22, 1963 assassination so he could carry out the assassination. White, who said his father went by the code name ``Mandarin,'' was stationed at the grassy knoll. Two other CIA operatives with code names ``Lebanon'' and ``Saul'' were stationed in the Texas School Book Depository and the County Records Building overlooking Dealey Plaza, the assassination site, he said. ``He was told by the government to do something,'' White told dozens of reporters. ``You don't question the government.'' White said that Lee Harvey Oswald was a part of the plot, but did not fire shots. He described Oswald and police officer J.D. Tippit as ``patsies.'' The Warren Commission concluded that Oswald, acting alone, fired the shots that killed Kennedy and wounded John Connally, then the Texas governor. Despite the commission's findings, conspiracy theories have abounded since the assassination. Woody Specht, an FBI agent in Dallas who spent nine years assigned to the Kennedy assassination case, refused to comment on the claims other than to say: ``You really need to evaluate the source on these types of things. ``There's been so many claims like this in the last 27 years,'' Specht said. ``You have to use good judgment here, especially from somebody who was, what, 2 years old at the time?'' White said today that his father and Tippit picked up Oswald following the assassination, although Tippit apparently had no knowledge of the assassination or the plot. White said the plan was to drive Oswald to Red Bird Airport but somewhere along the way, Oswald panicked and got out of the car. At that point Tippit apparently became suspicious and told Roscoe White that they would have to go to police headquarters for questioning. At that point, White shot Tippit, Ricky White said. ``I know he had to live with this the rest of his life because J.D. Tippit was a close friend of the family,'' White said. Roscoe White's pastor at the time of the assassination, the Rev. Jack Shaw, was also at today's press conference held in the JFK Assassination Information Center, which has examined various conspiracy theories over the years. Shaw said Roscoe White discussed the assassination with him on several agonizing occasions, including a last conversation on his deathbed. Shaw said he believes Roscoe White, who died in a 1971 fire, was killed by a witness elimination team activated after Kennedy's death. White had resigned from the Dallas Police Department in 1965 to go into private business, his son said. Roscoe White's wife, Geneva, told Shaw of overhearing her husband and Jack Ruby discuss the assassination plot, Shaw said. She also overheard them discuss how White would kill Tippit and Ruby would kill Oswald at police headquarters. Ruby fatally shot Oswald two days after Kennedy was assassinated. Shaw said Mrs. White overheard Ruby say ``I will take care of Oswald.'' White responded, ``I will take care of the president and I will take care of Tippit.'' Ricky White and several others today characterized Roscoe White as a CIA operative who had committed several other killings at the government's behest. White said he learned of his father's involvement in the plot 12 years ago and struggled to come to terms with that knowledge. White said he read part of a diary that discussed the assassination plot, but he said the diary was taken from the family by the FBI in the last couple of years. White showed reporters documents Monday that he said buttress his claims that his father killed Kennedy. Among the items were embarcation slips showing that both White and Oswald left on the same ship for Marine duty in Japan on Aug. 22, 1957. He also gave reporters copies of three faded messages he believes were sent by U.S. intelligence officials ordering Kennedy's assassination. Bobby Inman, the former deputy CIA director, viewed the messages and said they were not genuine.

DOC.HEAD: Carter: Don't Deploy Troops to Kuwait Yet
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter said Monday it would be a mistake to send U.S. troops to the Middle East in retaliation for the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, unless Iraq also invades Saudi Arabia. Carter said in an impromptu news conference in his hometown that he believes President Bush and other U.S. leaders have taken the right economic and political steps to address last week's invasion. ``I don't have any criticism to make of what President Bush and our leaders have done,'' Carter said. ``I think they have taken very strong economic and political action _ the condemnations of Iraq in the United Nations. The martialling of economic punishments for deprivation of Iraq in Japan and Europe have been a pleasant surprise for me.'' ``It would be a mistake at this point, obviously, to deploy any American troops halfway around the world in an area that's almost totally inaccessible to us,'' he said. During his administration, Carter sent a secret military force to the region in an effort to rescue American hostages in Iran. The attempt failed when several of the rescue aircraft crashed and burned. But, Carter said, if Iraq crosses the border of Saudi Arabia, it is ``inevitable that our nation would respond militarily.'' He cautioned that trade embargoes will not be a successful long-term sanction if Iraq refuses to withdraw from Kuwait, noting that nations will resume buying oil in order to avoid hurting their own economies. ``If Japan does maintain their present decision not to purchase oil from Kuwait or Iraq, that would be a notable achievement and a pleasant surprise,'' he said. Carter told reporters that Americans must realize many Arab leaders, out of fear or other considerations, support what Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has done. ``My guess is he hopes to consolidate his position in Kuwait to let time pass, to let the economic punishments fade away and then to hold what he's got,'' he said. Carter's comments came as he and his wife, Rosalynn, toured the Plains High School, which they attended. The school is being restored as part of the Jimmy Carter National Historic Site.

DOC.HEAD: Town Watchers Get Ready for Annual Night on the Streets
DOC.TEXT: The grim business of fighting crime will lighten up a little Tuesday when millions of people are expected to join in the seventh annual National Night Out. The event started with the suggestion that, for one night, people turn on their exterior lights and go outside as a presence against street crime. More people join in every year and they find novel ways to make a statement, said Matt Peskin, national co-ordinator, from this Philadelphia suburb. ``It's a July 4 atmosphere, but there's seriousness,'' said Peskin. ``We call it a party with a purpose.'' Cities will sponsor hundreds of block parties for residents and police. Milwaukee is planning 1,000 of them, plus demonstrations to show people how they can illuminate their properties. Night Outers in Syracuse, N.Y., will hold a candlelight march. Organizers in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, will hand out lollipops wrapped in the local theme: ``Light it Bright, Lock it Tight, Lick Crime.'' In Louisville, Ky., fire sirens and church bells will sound at 8 p.m., a signal for people to turn on their outside lights and check the batteries in their home smoke detectors. ``The first year, we had about 2{ million people in 400 communities in 23 states,'' Peskin said. ``After the second and third ones, things began to pick up. Last year we counted 20.2 million people participating in 7,620 communities.''
