This year, the Night Out organizers hope more than 21 million people will turn out in 8,000 communities in all 50 states, plus Canadian cities and on U.S. military bases around the world. There have been a few success stories _ Night Out people who spotted a break-in and notified police, Peskin said, and so far no confrontations or incidents of retaliation. ``Generally speaking, crimewise, it's pretty quiet that night,'' Peskin said. ``Houston measured it last year, and they were down 51 percent in major crimes for that full day.''

DOC.HEAD: President Dismisses Bhutto Government, Alleges Corruption
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: The president dismissed Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her government Monday, alleging rampant corruption, and the army took over state-run television and the telephones. Opposition leader Mustafa Jatoi was immediately sworn in as acting prime minister. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan said elections for a new National Assembly would be held Oct. 24. Ms. Bhutto called the president's action ``illegal and unconstitutional'' and said the corruption allegations were part of a ``slander campaign'' against her government. Ms. Bhutto, the daughter of a former prime minister, took office in December 1988 and became the first woman to head a modern Moslem nation. She was hailed as a heroine for restoring democracy to Pakistan after 11 years of military rule. However, the image steadily eroded amid allegations of corruption among senior members of her government and even members of her family. Ms. Bhutto also has been accused of inaction for failing to control ethnic violence in her home province, Sindh. ``The government has willfully undermined and impaired the working of the constitution, resulting in discord, confrontation and deadlock adversely affecting the integrity, solidarity and well-being of Pakistan,'' Ishaq Khan told a hastily called news conference. ``Corruption and nepotism in the federal government has reached such proportions that the orderly functioning of the government does no longer carry public faith and credibility and despite being subject to wide public condemnation, the government has failed to take approriate action,'' he said. Pakistan's constitution gives the president the authority to dissolve the National Assembly if he believes the government is unable to carry out its duties. But many diplomats and observers said the president's decision appeared to have been based largely on hearsay and could not have been done without the consent of the powerful army generals. The military ruled Pakistan for 25 years of its 43-year history. Soldiers were deployed throughout the capital Monday, but the army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, insisted the military had no intention of seizing power. ``We are not involved in politics. We have never been involved in politics. We are not going to get involved in politics,'' Beg said. Ms. Bhutto told a news conference that soldiers had surrounded her house Monday and sealed government offices, including the intelligence bureau. She said her Pakistan People's Party would decide later whether to challenge the president in Supreme Court. ``I don't feel betrayed by the president. I believe there were other elements that wanted me out,'' she said. Asked if she planned to run in the October elections, she replied: ``Most certainly. I intend to win.'' The president said his decision was motivated by his commitment ``to democracy and the integrity and stability of Pakistan.'' He accused the government of ``flouting the constitution, disrepect of the judiciary, misuse of the official machinery.'' The move caught members of Ms. Bhutto's Cabinet by surprise. ``This is total high-handedness, unconstitutional and illegal,'' said Tariq Rahim, minister for parliamentary affairs. ``It is a conspiracy against all democratically elected people.'' Rumors had been circulating for weeks that Ishaq Khan planned to dissolve the 237-member National Assembly. The assembly, which Ms. Bhutto's party narrowly controls, had been expected to convene Wednesday. But by Monday, the president still had not formally called the session, giving credence to the rumors. On Sunday, political opponents announced they intended to introduce a no-confidence motion against Ms. Bhutto's government, the second in nine months. Ms. Bhutto narrowly survived a no-confidence vote in November. A month after Ms. Bhutto took office, polls placed her popularity at 54 percent. The latest Gallup Pakistan poll showed that in June her popularity had tumbled to 34 percent. Many Pakistanis, from the tea vendors in the local bazaars to the country's most powerful industrialists, began to see their young and inexperienced prime minister as arrogant, unwilling to compromise and even vindictive. Members of her own party privately expressed disillusionment with Ms. Bhutto's government, complaining that daily life was worse than under the dictatorship of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. Zia died in a mysterious plane crash in August 1988, leading to Ms. Bhutto's election in Pakistan's first free vote in more than a decade. Zia had seized power in a 1977 coup that toppled Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was hanged two years later. Many of Ms. Bhutto's party members in Parliament have expressed fears of an early election, saying they have nothing to show voters. During 20 months in power, the government has passed no legislation except the federal budget. Ms. Bhutto's relationship also has deteriorated with the army, which has become increasingly critical of the government's inability or unwillingness to deal with the violence in Sindh Province. Gang warfare between rival ethnic groups claimed more than 400 lives since late May.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Taking American, British Visitors From Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 10 grafs with U.S. saying 38 Americans among those rounded up. Pickup 7th pvs, `We hope...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops in Kuwait rounded up American and British visitors from two hotels in Kuwait for transport to Iraq, but the foreigners did not appear to be in danger, the British Foreign Office said today. Thirty-eight Americans were among those rounded up, the State Department said in Washington. A Foreign Office spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the government believed 366 people had been assembled, mostly passengers from a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait since the invasion by Iraqi troops Thursday. ``We are trying to establish the precise details now,'' said the spokesman. ``There is no evidence that they are in any way in trouble.'' Word of the roundup was received from the British Embassy in Kuwait. The official added that Baghdad had not given any reason for its action and Britain was trying to organize a team of diplomats to meet the buses carrying the foreigners at the Iraq-Kuwait border. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said: ``We hold Iraq responsible'' for the safety of the 28 Americans. Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat to demand information about the whereabouts of the 28, she said. ``It's premature to call them hostages,'' she said. ``We don't know their destination.'' The British Foreign Office said the tourists apparently were being taken to Baghdad. ``We hope the idea is that they will be able to continue their flight from there,'' a Foreign Office spokesman told Britain's domestic news agency, Press Association. The British and U.S. visitors were staying at a transit hotel at Kuwait airport and at the SAS hotel in Kuwait city. The spokesman said the Iraqi move did not appear to involve foreigners who live in Kuwait. Shortly after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Iraqi troops took 34 British military advisers to Baghdad. They are still being held there. The government said it did not consider the soldiers to be hostages but rather in ``temporary custody.'' The Foreign Office said today it was holding negotiations both with the Iraqi Embassy in London and through officials in Baghdad for their release. The Foreign Office summoned Iraqi Ambassador Azmi Shafiq Al-Salihi, who was told in ``robust'' language about Britain's anger over the invasion of Kuwait. The ambassador was also warned of Iraq's international obligations toward British citizens in Kuwait and the servicemen who were taken to Baghdad. Eleven American oil workers were also seized by Iraqi troops after the invasion, but they turned up unharmed in Baghdad. In Bonn, a West German Foreign Ministry spokesman said it heard reports from its embassies in Kuwait and Baghdad that over the weekend a number of Germans also were taken from hotels in Kuwait. ``We don't have precise information about how the action occurred. We have information that at least some of them were brought to Baghdad,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be further identified.

DOC.HEAD: West Africans Expected to Send Task Force to Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with agreement to send African troops, naval task force to Liberia; pickup 4th pvs, `Nigeria, the...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Five West African leaders agreed today to send troops and a naval task force to Liberia to help end a tribal war one leader said has turned the nation into ``a slaughterhouse.'' Salim Ahmed Salim, secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity, told The Associated Press the summit had agreed in principle to intervene militarily and were discussing modalities and logistics. Conference sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said leaders were considering sending in troops by land from neighboring Sierra Leone and Guinea as well as a naval force to impose a cease-fire and install an interim government. The government would organize free and fair elections in the West African nation devastated by seven months of civil war, according to the plan. It comes a day after the United States sent Marines into Monrovia to evacuate Americans. In Liberia, the rebel National Patriotic Front said it was organizing demonstrations in four Liberian towns against the African intervention. Nigeria, the most powerful nation in the region, already hasese companies are usually given two options: the traditional ``mommy track'' or the same professional track taken by male employees. Fearing the overtime and transfers that men endure for a business career, about 95 percent choose the traditional track. When those women return to work after having children, they find only ``part-time'' jobs, positions that are really full-time work without the benefits of lifetime employment. Many firms rely on non-permanent female employees, who earn one-half to two-thirds what their male colleagues earn for similar work, to cut personnel costs. Eiko Shinotsuka, a labor economist at Ochanomizu Women's University in Tokyo, says the system is efficient, but it means that most women work as clerks or in other dead-end jobs. And remaining single or childless is no guarantee of career opportunity, Shinotsuka says. Surveys show that just over 1 percent of all managers in major Japanese corporations are women, mostly at lower levels of management. Only 3.8 percent of all Japanese companies, in most cases tiny entrepreneurships or family businesses, are headed by women, according to Tokyo Shoko Research, a private research institute. Sexual equality is guaranteed by the Japanese Constitution. Since 1986, an equal employment opportunity law has required companies to let women apply for positions previously open only to men. Unlike the United States, the law does not specify penalties or require that women be hired or receive equal training or promotion opportunities. In July, a Japanese court made the first ruling in favor of women who complained they had been denied promotions on the basis of their sex, but the court did not order any mechanism for promoting the complainants. The 18 women, however, were awarded $640,000 in compensation. ``Women can't go to the courts with a law that only says firms should `try' to provide equal treatment. The law has helped, but it's still no good. It needs penalties for enforcement,'' Mrs. Shinotsuka says. ``It would be better to eliminate discrimination altogether.'' The absence of a popular women's movement and customs prevailing outside the office have inevitably slowed progress in overcoming discrimination. Most Japanese men still expect their mothers and sisters, their wives and even their female colleagues to wait on them. After working hours, many men entertain clients in bars where beautifully clad women light their cigarettes, flatter and serve them. Attitudes are beginning to change slowly. Some women also have begun to protest against Japan's immense sex industry, against violence and pornography in comics read openly by Japanese men on subways and elsewhere, and other images that they say dehumanize women. The nation's first sexual harassment case ever was filed last year and since then complaints of such problems have ballooned. Some analysts credit the rising awareness of women's problems to Takako Doi, a sharp-witted former law professor who has led Japan's top opposition party since 1986.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Work Round-the-Clock at Kuwaiti Embassy
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: By Monday, Ali al-Sabah, counselor at the Kuwaiti Embassy, had shed his traditional, coat-and-tie diplomat's uniform in favor of a short-sleeved shirt. Like the other 15 diplomats at Kuwait's embassy, al-Sabah has been pulling round-the-clock shifts at the heavily guarded, suburban chancery. But sleep deprivation was nothing, he said, compared to the hardship of Kuwaitis in their homeland, invaded by Iraq last Thursday. ``We have people suffering back home,'' said al-Sabah. Although Kuwait is under occupation, al-Sabah said the embassy was functioning: Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah has met with State Department officials, granted interviewed and appealed for the United States to take military action to oust the Iraqis. Embassy officials stay in touch with Kuwait's royal family, who fled to neighboring Saudi Arabia after the invasion. Life, however, was far from normal at the embassy _ a low-slung building, opulently furnished with plush couches and thick red carpet. ``Things are about as abnormal as you can get,'' said one of the eight armed State Department security officials assigned to guard the embassy since the crisis started. Al-Sabah said embassy officials had received telephone threats. Outside the mammoth iron gates leading to the embassy is a sign that reads: ``No passports or documents will be accepted until further notice.'' Al-Sabah said a telephone hotline had been established to allow Kuwaiti students around the country to stay in contact with the embassy. Some 2,000 Kuwaitis live in the United States. Meantime, al-Sabah said the embassy was in full support _ but did not pay for _ a full-page advertisement placed in Monday's editions of The Washington Post. ``Stop Iraqi Aggression Against Kuwait,'' read the ad, which urged people to call the White House and members of Congress. It provided a number for the White House, where an aide said the telephone was ringing constantly. A group calling itself the Committee to Free Kuwait from Iraqi Occupation and for the Restoration of Sovereignty placed the ad. A spokesman, who didn't want his name used, said the group was composed of Kuwaiti citizens and their friends.

DOC.HEAD: President Dissolves Parliament, Army Takes Over TV, Telephones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency declared. Pickup 6th pvs, `In dissolving...'
DOC.TEXT: The president today dissolved Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government and declared a state of emergency. The army took over the national television station and telephone exchanges. Ms. Bhutto called the president's charges of corruption and ineptness during her 20-month administration a ``slander campaign.'' She hinted the military might have been involved in the dismissal. Army chief of staff Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg said the military moves were taken to assure an orderly transition to other civilian authorities, and were not an attempt by the military to seize power. ``We are not involved in politics,'' Aslam Beg said of the military, which has controlled the country for 25 of its 43-year history. ``We are not going to get involved.'' President Ghulam Ishaq Khan's dismissed the government, called for new elections, appointed an interim prime minister and declared a state of emergency. ``The president is satisfied that a grave emergency exists in which the security of Pakistan is threatened by external aggression and by internal disturbance beyond the power of the provincial governments to control,'' said the proclamation issued by Ishaq Khan on Monday night. In dissolving the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament, Ishaq Khan said Ms. Bhutto's government was corrupt and politically inept. Ishaq Khan, who as head of state has the constitutional power to dissolve the government, set new elections for Oct. 24. Opposition leader Mustafa Jatoi was immediately sworn in as acting prime minister to head a four-member caretaker government. Ms. Bhutto, 37 and the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation, called the president's action ``illegal and unconstitutional'' and said corruption charges were part of a ``slander campaign.'' ``He has established an undemocratic interim government by disbanding a democratic government,'' said a subdued Ms. Bhutto, adding her Pakistan People's Party would decide later whether to challenge the president in the Supreme Court. ``I don't feel betrayed by the president. I believe there were other elements that wanted me out,'' she said. Asked if she planned to run in the elections, she replied: ``Most certainly. I intend to win.'' ``I have told members of the People Party to stay peaceful. We will not ask them to take to the streets,'' she said. ``The situation should be tackled politically. We must not give any pretext to the present regime to get away from the promise to hold elections on Oct. 24.' Ms. Bhutto has been criticized widely for inaction, unwillingness to compromise, failure to control resurging ethnic violence in her home province and mounting charges of corruption within her government. But many diplomats and observers said the president's decision would not have been done without the consent of the powerful army generals, who still cast a long shadow on Pakistan's infant democracy. Ms. Bhutto said the army this afternoon had surrounded her house, sealed the offices of the Prime Minister's Secretariat as well as the offices of the Intelligence Bureau. ``This is very strange if this is a civilian process,'' she said. Rumors have been circulating for weeks around Pakistan's capital that Ishaq Khan planned to dissolve the 237-member National Assembly and call new elections. The army has become increasingly critical at the government's handling of ethnic strife that has claimed more than 400 lives since late May. The army blames members of Ms. Bhutto's party for much of the violence, which is centered on Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sindh. Ishaq Khan cited the violence as another reason for dismissing the government. Ms. Bhutto took office on Dec. 2, 1988 and at age 35 became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. She was hailed as a heroine for restoring democracy to Pakistan after 11 years of military rule. But that image has steadily been eroded, largely because of increasing charges of corruption among senior members of her government and even members of her family. Even members of her own party privately express disillusionment with Ms. Bhutto's government, complaining that life was worse under her than under the dictatorship of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who seized power in a 1977 coup that toppled Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. Bhutto was hanged two years later for his alleged complicity in a murder plot.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Injured, 82 Houses Burned in Hindu-Moslem Clash
DOC.TEXT: The slaughter of a cow by Moslems led to rioting with Hindus that injured at least 50 people and left 82 houses burned, witnesses said Monday. Hindus revere cows. The clash took place Sunday at Gojeta, 62 miles south of Katmandu, three days after the dispute began during a Moslem festival, said the witnesses contacted by telephone. The witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Hindus objected when Moslems killed a cow as part of the festival Thursday. Nepal, the world's only Hindu kingdom, bans the slaughter of cows. It is punishable by 14 years imprisonment. The witnesses said that in retaliation, Hindus killed a pig later Thursday and threw the carcass in front of a mosque, escalating tensions. Pork is banned under Islamic law. Tensions simmered between the two communities over the weekend, and the violence broke out Sunday after an argument between the two groups. At least five of the injured were in serious condition, the witnesses said. About 90 percent of Nepal's 17 million people are Hindus. Moslems comprise 3 percent of the population and live mostly in southern Nepal along the border with India. Clashes between the two communities are not unusual.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Hurt When Squad Car Rear-ended by Mother
DOC.TEXT: A police officer was slightly injured while on patrol when his squad car was struck from behind by another vehicle _ driven by his mother. The accident occurred when Senior Cpl. Joe Copeland, 26, slowed down on a freeway Sunday to avoid a rolled-up tarpaulin that had just fallen onto the pavement from a truck, said Sgt. W.D. Elsey. The driver of the car that struck his squad car was Joyce Copeland, 45, of Lancaster. Copeland's 16-year-old sister was a passenger in his mother's car. Police Sgt. Jay Cooper said the three Copelands were slightly injured and stayed in their cars until other officers arrived. Mrs. Copeland asked the officers to relay a message to her son that she had been in an accident. ``They informed her that she was in an accident with her son,'' Cooper said. The three Copelands were treated at Methodist Medical Center and released. Both mother and son refused to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Marshall Released from Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall was released from a hospital on Monday, five days after he suffered a fall in the lobby of his Chicago hotel, a court spokeswoman said. Marshall, 82, underwent testing and observation after being admitted to National Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., said spokeswoman Kathy Arberg, who added she had no other details. Marshall fell as he was preparing to address the annual convention of the American Bar Association in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Disruption of Oil Supplies is No Reason to Panic, Experts Say
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Disruption of oil supplies from Iraq and Kuwait poses no immediate danger of shortages, experts said Monday. But the world's oil reserves could be called upon quickly, putting upward pressure on prices, they said. All eyes will be on Saudi Arabia, which has the greatest capacity to make up for the disruption, but would fear retaliation from neighboring Iraq, the experts said. ``In the short-term, I don't think people are panicking too much,'' said Lucy Mullins, an oil analyst at the London investment firm of Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. ``The world could last six months or so almost quite happily.'' The Iraqi supply is being disrupted by a joint embargo by the United States, the European Community and Japan. Iraq on Monday reduced the flow of oil through Turkish pipelines which can carry up to half of Iraq's oil production. Kuwaiti production has come to a halt since Iraq's Thursday morning invasion. Although Iraq and Kuwait are among the world's biggest producers, their combined production of 4.7 million barrels a day represents just 9 percent of the world's output. The oil market has been experiencing an excess of supply and oil importers' stocks are high, experts say. The oil shocks of the 1970s also have made industrial nations used to cutting demand. Oil prices still jumped about $3 a barrel Monday, as oil buyers scurried to secure supplies. The spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, was trading at $26.29 a barrel in London late Monday afternoon. The 24-nation International Energy Agency's governing board planned to meet at its Paris headquarters on Thursday to assess the situation's impact on its members, spokeswoman Joyce Heard said. But the meeting was unlikely to result in the imposition of the agency's emergency oil sharing program, she said. One or more member countries must be deprived of at least 7 percent of its normal oil supply before the countries start sharing their oil, she said. But the board was expected to discuss demand restraint measures, which can include taxes, fuel switching and the use of oil stocks, she said. Iraq produced 3.1 million barrels a day in July and Kuwait 1.6 million, the IEA said. Total world production came to 54.2 million barrels a day in the second quarter, the agency said. Consumption in the traditionally weak three-month summer period came to 51.4 million barrels a day. As of July, the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development had 99 days worth of oil stocks, the IEA said. The Middle East Economic Survey, a weekly newsletter, reported Monday that current excess capacity by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries amounted to 3.5 million barrels of oil a day. This extra capacity is concentrated in Saudi Arabia with a spare 2 million barrels a day, the United Arab Emirates with 600,000, Venezuela with 500,000 and Libya with 300,000, the newsletter said. Venezuela, far from Iraq, is most likely to increase its output, experts said. Norway, which doesn't belong to OPEC, might be able to kick in an extra 200,000 barrels a day, Ms. Mullins said. But supplies from the North Sea have been constrained by summer maintenance and industrial action by oil workers. It is still unknown if OPEC members will observe their output quotas and back the oil shortage. Some members would welcome the higher prices prompted by Iraq's actions. But pricing moderates in the cartel might increase output to ease prices and reduce the crises. Said Ian Graham, an oil analyst with County Natwest Woodmac: ``It's a matter of whether Saudi Arabia feels confident enough to bump up its production in the face of a belligerent neighbor.''

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Orphans Visit Disney
DOC.TEXT: Twenty children orphaned by the Armenian earthquake spent Monday at the Magic Kingdom, visiting a longtime idol. The children, who range from 9 to 15 years old, speak little English but their eyes lit up when told they were going to Disney World. ``Mickey Mouse! Mickey Mouse!'' some of them exclaimed at an Orlando hotel before beginning a two-day visit to the tourist attraction. The young survivors of the 1988 quake were brought to this country by the Diocese of the Armenian Church of North America in New York. Diocese members decided to sponsor the trip because they believe the survivors need help long after the tremors have stopped, said Arpie Highgas, their American guide. They already had visited Washington and Boston, and spent two weeks at a diocese summer camp in New York state's Catskill Mountains. They leave Orlando on Tuesday to go to New York City, where 18 will be baptized at St. Vartan's Armenian Church.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Postpones South American Trip
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is postponing a South American trip in September under the pressure of budget negotiations with Congress, but still plans to spend five days stumping for Republican candidates around the country, the White House said Monday. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush put off a scheduled Sept. 16-22 trip to Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Venezuela. Bush postponed the trip because of ``the need to be personally involved in the budget negotiations in September and the prospect of preparing for a sequestration on Sept. 30,'' he said. If the budget talks fall, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will require an estimated $100 billion in automatic, across-the-board cuts on federal programs in October. In addition to political trips to 10 cities over five days, Bush will visit New York City twice next month _ to dedicate Ellis Island on Sept. 9 and attend a U.N. conference on children on Sept. 30. He also will address the U.N. General Assembly on Oct. 1. Fitzwater said Bush plans to travel to Kennebunkport, Maine, on Friday for a 24-day summer vacation. Here is the president's full travel schedule: Aug. 10: Departs White House for summer home in Kennebunkport. Aug. 20: Travels to Baltimore to address Veterans of Foreign War convention, returns to Maine. Sept. 3: Returns to White House from Maine. Sept. 6: Tsravels to Topeka, Kan., for fund-raiser for Gov. Mike Hayden and Tallahassee, Fla., for Rep. Bill Grant, R-Fla., and the Florida GOP. Sept. 9: Attends dedication of the restored Ellis Island in New York harbor, the historic waystation for immigrants to the United States. Sept. 11-12: Flies to Denver for fund-raiser for Rep. Hank Brown, a Senate candidate, and the Colorado GOP. Proceeds to Los Angeles for a fund-raiser for Sen. Pete Wilson, running for governor, and spends night in Los Angeles. Flies to San Francisco Sept. 12 for another Wilson fund-raiser. Sept. 26-27: Flies to Akron, Ohio, for fund-raiser for former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich, now running for governor, then to Chicago for a fund-raiser for Rep. Lynn Martin, a Senate candidate. Spends the night in Minneapolis. He attends a fund-raiser on Sept. 27 in Minneapolis for the GOP gubernatorial candidate, flies to Cleveland for another fund-raiser for Voinovich and then Detroit for a fund-raiser for Senate candidates. Sept. 30: Travels to New York City to attend the U.N. Conference on Children, remains overnight. Oct. 1: Addresses U.N. General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Visits GOP Chairman Atwater at Hospital
DOC.TEXT: President Bush paid a brief visit Monday to Republican Party Chairman Lee Atwater, back in a hospital in his fight against a brain tumor. Atwater re-entered George Washington University Hospital Thursday and reportedly was running a fever. A press aide at the Republican National Committee said Atwater was ``fine.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush decided to visit the GOP chairman on the spur of the moment. ``He just got to thinking about Lee this morning and called him at the hospital and during the phone call said he'd like to come over and see him. Lee said, `Great,' and he went over,'' Fitzwater said of Bush. The president spent 15 minutes in the hospital, a few blocks up Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. Atwater, 39, collapsed before a speech in March and subsequently underwent radiation treatment for an inoperable brain tumor. He has also been undergoing physical therapy. The party recently named Republican strategist Charles Black to act as its chief spokesman during Atwater's convalescence. Scott Sowry, deputy press secretary at the Republican National Committee, said Atwater re-entered the hospital Thursday. ``The tumor is dying. Everything is fine and he's working on his therapy,'' said Sowry.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Approves Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd pvs to UPDATE with Bush reaction. SUBS 6th pvs, `The sanctions...' with one graf to ADD that sanctions apply to all U.N. nations. Pickup 7th pvs, `The vote...'
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council today overwhelmingly approved sweeping trade and military sanctions against Iraq, including a ban on oil purchases, to punish Baghdad for invading Kuwait. The vote was 13-0, with two abstentions by Cuba and Yemen on the 15-member council, which adopted the sanctions resolution proposed by the United States. It said Iraq had launched an armed attack against Kuwait and usurped the authority of Kuwait's legitimate government. The sanctions were intended to force Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and the resolution bans ``the import into their territories of all commodities and products originating in Iraq or Kuwait and exported there from after the date of this resolution.'' President Bush praised the decision and called for ``full and total implementation of these sanctions, ruling out nothing at all.'' He told reporters at the White House: ``The will of nations around the world will be to enforce these sanctions.'' It was the third time in its 45-year existence that the world body had voted sanctions against a member state. The last time was 1967 when the Security Council voted similar, comprehensive sanctions against the white minority government of Rhodesia. An arms embargo against South Africa still is in effect. The sanctions are legally binding for all member nations, although past council resolutions have often been ignored or flouted. The United Nations has no enforcement mechanism but later could call on members to take military action against Iraq or impose a blockade. The vote followed similar sanctions imposed on Iraq by much of the West, including the United States, Japan and the European Community. The Soviet Union and China said they would halt arms shipments to Iraq. In a statement carried by the Iraqi News Agency on Sunday, the Iraqi-installed military government of Kuwait warned other nations not to take ``punishing measures'' against it or Iraq. The provisional government said countries ``have to remember they have interests and citizens in Kuwait.'' The U.N. role in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis assumed increasing importance after divided Arab nations canceled a weekend emergency summit on the invasion. In an emergency session just hours after Thursday's invasion, the Security Council condemned Iraq's invasion, demanded immediate and unconditional troop withdrawal, and called for negotiations between Iraq and Kuwait. The council threatened to impose sanctions if Iraq did not comply. The council includes the five permanent members with veto power _ the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union. The 10 non-permanent members are: Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Drug For Lung Disease Of Premature Infants
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said Monday it has approved a drug that cuts the death rate in half in premature infants suffering from a severe lung disease. The disease, called respiratory distress syndrome, is the most common cause of death in infants under 30 days old, the American Lung Association said. The ailment afflicts 50,000 infants each year and kills about 3,000 of them, the lung association said. The drug, called Exosurf, is a mixture of synthetic chemicals that mimic the action of lung surfactant, a liquid found in the lungs that helps keep them inflated. Premature infants are unable to make surfactant, and their lungs can collapse if not treated. The drug was invented by Dr. John Clements of the University of California, San Francisco, and is made by Burroughs Wellcome Co. of Research Triangle Park, N.C. The approval of the drug ``is a very important development,'' said Dr. Mary Ellen Avery, professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School in Boston. ``There has been a significant reduction in deaths among those who were treated.'' Exosurf and another experimental surfactant made from cows' lungs have both been available since last year, when the FDA allowed distribution under what is called a ``treatment IND.'' That is intended to make life-saving experimental drugs available before approval. The bovine surfactant, called Survanta, is made by Abbott Laboratories in Abbott Park, Ill. Both have been widely used, and although they have not been directly compared, ``both work pretty well,'' said Avery, who has used them. ``I don't think anyone is in a position to say which is better.'' A spokesman for Abbott said approval of Survanta was expected soon. Dr. Anthony Corbet, a neonatologist at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston who has participated in experimental studies of Exosurf, said: ``This drug will have its greatest place in treating very small premature infants, perhaps those under 3 pounds. But those babies under 3 pounds make a very large contribution to infant mortality.'' The infant mortality rate in the United States is 10 deaths per 1,000 live births, Corbet said. About three infant deaths per 1,000 are due to respiratory distress syndrome, he said. Cutting the number of those deaths in half with Exosurf could significantly lower the U.S. infant mortality rate, he said. In studies with 1,600 infants with respiratory distress syndrome, Exosurf cut the death rate by 66 percent, the company said. When given to 1,800 infants who were at risk of developing the disease but had not yet contracted it, the drug reduced the death rate by 50 percent, company officials said. Corbet said he is giving Exosurf routinely to premature newborn infants weighing 3 pounds or less, whether they have the disease yet or not. They have about a 70 percent chance of developing the disease, he said. In less premature infants, Corbet said he generally administers the drug when the disease appears. Dr. Richard Kent of Burroughs Wellcome explained that in the absence of surfactant, the little air sacs in the lung called alveoli collapse like inflated balloons if air pressure is not maintained. When surfactant is added, the alveoli become more like bubble-gum bubbles and maintain their shape when air pressure falls, he said. About 10,000 infants have been treated with the drug so far, Kent said. Infants getting the drug in the clinical trials showed few side effects, with the exception of apnea, a treatable disorder in which infants intermittently stop breathing for short periods, the company said. There was also a slight increase in bleeding in the lungs, the company said. Corbet said the drug reduces the need for oxygen and ventilators with premature infants, and thus can reduce lung injury. ``Both oxygen and the pressure from the ventilator damage the lungs,'' he said. ``And you get lung injury, which doesn't go away very quickly. That causes a great lengthening of hospitalization.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Federal Civil Suit Filed by Peggy Buckey
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Monday dismissed Peggy McMartin Buckey's $1 million civil suit alleging malicious prosecution in the marathon McMartin Pre-School molestation trial that ended with her acquittal. U.S. District Judge Richard A. Gadbois Jr. said he could understand how Mrs. Buckey could feel about her seven-year ordeal. But ``being very, very upset does not state a cause of action,'' he said. Because Mrs. Buckey was ultimately acquitted, the civil action ``just isn't going to fly,'' he said. Mrs. Buckey filed the civil suit in January after she and her son, Raymond, won acquittal on 52 felony charges of child molestation at the now-defunct pre-school in Manhattan Beach. Ray Buckey was not named as a plaintiff. A second trial, with Ray Buckey as the sole defendant, ended in a mistrial last month when jurors deadlocked on eight counts. Los Angeles County District Attorney Ira Reiner said he would not retry Buckey. An attorney for Mrs. Buckey said he would appeal Gadbois' ruling. ``The only way we have been able to stay in court anywhere is to take it to the appellate level,'' said attorney James H. Davis. ``Nobody wants to hear this case. Everybody has had enough of this case.'' Mrs. Buckey's civil suit contended she was the victim of a conspiracy by Los Angeles County, the city of Manhattan Beach, former District Attorney Robert Philibosian, Children's Institute International and therapist Kee MacFarlane, Capital Cities-ABC Inc. and its former reporter Wayne Satz. The defendants were accused of defamation, malicious prosecution, conspiracy and violation of Mrs. Buckey's civil rights. The suit sought general damages of $1 million and unspecified punitive damages. Although the judge tossed out the federal suit, Mrs. Buckey may still file claims in state court. After the second trial, Raymond Buckey filed a civil suit in state court against the same defendants.

DOC.HEAD: American Returning Home From Captivity in Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: An American tourist who spent four days in a military jail in his native Yugoslavia last week headed home Monday after paying a $4,500 fine for deserting the Yugoslav army 30 years ago. Zjelko Skalicki, a Cleveland industrialist and naturalized U.S. citizen, also was given a suspended four-month prison sentence by a Yugoslav military tribunal, said Pero Novak of Cleveland, who lobbied Congress for Skalicki's release. Skalicki, 53, was making his first visit to his homeland with his wife and three children when he was arrested last week in a hotel in Porta Rose, Slovenia. Skalicki, who became a U.S. citizen 22 years ago, was a young man nearing the end of a mandatory two-year tour of duty in the Yugoslav military when he fled the country. ``He did not like the Communists, he did not like the government, he wanted to be a free man,'' Novak said in a telephone interview from Cleveland. Before he left on vacation, Novak said, Skalicki obtained visas from the Yugoslav consul in Cleveland and discussed his defection 30 years ago. ``They said, `You have amnesty, you're free to go,'' Novak said. As for Skalicki's arrest, Novak said, ``You never can depend on a Communist government. They are ruthless, they are undependable. They just wanted to get his money.'' Novak said he did not know whether the Yugoslav military returned the $7,000 bond that Skalicki posted for his release from jail on Friday. After Skalicki's arrest, about 100 members of several American-Croatian organizations appealed repeatedly to diplomats and members of Congress to call attention to Skalicki's plight, Novak said. Among the legislators who contacted diplomats on Skalicki's behalf were Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kan.; Reps. William Broomfield, R-Mich., and Edward Feighan, D-Ohio, and Ohio's Democratic senators, Howard Metzenbaum and John Glenn.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Income Gap Between Hispanics And Others Grows
DOC.TEXT: The widening income gap between the rich and the poor in the United States has hit Hispanics especially hard, a research group said Monday. Hispanics have traditionally earned less than non-Hispanics. But a study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities said the difference grew in the 1980s because Hispanic income stagnated. Wage levels declined and there were fewer government assistance programs to aid the poor, the center said. In 1979, the group said, the income of the typical Hispanic family was 71 percent that of the average non-Hispanic family. That figure had fallen to 66 percent by 1988. The center found 28 percent of Hispanics had incomes placing them in the poorest one-fifth of households in 1987. Eleven percent of Hispanic households had incomes that put them in the wealthiest one-fifth that year. The report came two weeks after the center reported a post-World War II high in the earnings gap between poor and rich Americans. The top 20 percent of households will receive as much after-tax income this year as the other 80 percent combined, the center said. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities is a non-profit research organization, financed by foundations, that studies government spending, programs and policies affecting low- and moderate-income Americans.

DOC.HEAD: City To Hire 1,058 New Cops, Cut Other Departments to Pay for Them
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins on Monday ordered the hiring of 1,058 new police officers for expanded street patrols to combat what he called ``a surge in violence'' citywide. Among the recent incidents that have put Dinkins under pressure have been the slayings of four children by stray bullets, and the killings of a 14-year-old boy and a Greenwich Village executive. In addition, 19 cab drivers have been killed this year. On Monday, a sleeping baby was wounded when a bullet went through the wall of his apartment. The bullet cracked his skull but didn't penetrate his brain, said Judy Murphy, a spokeswoman for St. Luke's Hospital. Police had no suspects. The mayor said he ``scraped, scratched and squeezed'' to find $24 million in the just-passed, $27.8 billion fiscal 1991 city budget to pay for the new officers. The police force now numbers 26,000. Among the cuts are $4.6 million from reserves and overhead at city schools, $4.1 million from city hospitals, $2.8 million from city-owned residential buildings, and $1.5 million from the Transportation Department. The first group of new recruits will enter the police academy in October and should graduate by April, when the second class of recruits enters the program. Speaking in Brooklyn's East New York section, which had the most homicides in the city last year, Dinkins said his goal is not simply a larger police force. ``We want to reduce the rate of violent crime,'' he said. ``To accomplish that we must do more than simply arrest the criminals. We must also keep them off the streets.'' Toward that end, Dinkins also authorized $4.3 million more for the district attorneys' probation offices and other criminal justice agencies. Most of the 1,058 new officers will be assigned to walk beats, Dinkins said. Last month, more than 1,100 officers were shifted from specialized units into seven high-crime precincts. An additional 200 senior officers were assigned to overtime duty in those areas.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Service Veteran Nominated to be Ambassador to Mali
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has nominated Herbert Donald Gelber to be ambassador to Mali, the White House announced Monday. If confirmed by the Senate, Gelber would succeed Robert Maxwell Pringle. Since 1986, Gelber has been special assistant for international affairs to the NATO commander in Europe. Since joining the Foreign Service in 1957, Gelber has served in U.S. embassies in Greece, Turkey, Nigeria and Pakistan; in consular posts; as an adviser to U.S. military commanders and in State Department positions in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Work Diplomatic Channels, Keep Options Open on Iraq
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While the United States was moving on diplomatic, economic, political and military fronts against Iraq, the Soviet Union was working its own diplomatic channels on Monday and keeping its options open. The official news agency Tass said Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Belonogov met for a second day with Iraq's ambassador here, Ghafil Jassim Hussein. It said they discussed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait but gave no details. Belonogov also met Monday with Kuwait's ambassador in Moscow, Abdulmokhsin Yusef al-Duadj. The Soviets were also pursuing an end to the crisis in diplomacy at the United Nations, where Belonogov previously served as Soviet representative. No sign emerged that the Soviets were working militarily with the United States against Iraq. However, Stanislav Kondrashov, a Soviet commentator on foreign policy, said no options were ruled out. In a front-page article in the government daily Izvestia, Kondrashov wrote, ``By no means is the Soviet Union automatically giving its consent to everything that could be done in Washington, but so far it has not hindered the freedom of ... (U.S.) actions by not defining beforehand the line beyond which the coincidence of our positions could end.'' That appeared to keep Soviet options open further than indicated by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Friday. ``As for military intervention, the Soviet Union has no plans, no operations,'' Shevardnadze said when asked if the Kremlin planned any military action in connection with Iraq's invasion. He spoke in Moscow after making a joint call with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III for a world arms embargo against Iraq. The Soviet Union, Iraq's biggest arms supplier, stopped weapons deliveries last week. Soviet security interests are not threatened as much as those of the United States and other Western countries, but there are humanitarian concerns. Shevardnadze said 900 Soviets are in Kuwait and 7,000 to 8,000 are in Iraq and that ``very, very severe consequences'' would result if they are harmed. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Francois Mitterrand of France spoke about the crisis by phone Saturday, Soviet media reported. Kondrashov kept up the Soviet media's harsh criticism of one-time ally Iraq. He said a 1972 friendship and cooperation treaty between Baghdad and Moscow, which involved military aid, was a holdover from ``the epoch of global East-West confrontation.''
Here is a transcript of remarks Monday at the White House by President Bush, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner on the situation in Kuwait.

PRESIDENT BUSH: This was basically a chance to have a photo to show that we were having this very _ these very important consultations. I might say that we are very encouraged, all of us, by the action taken in the United Nations _ a strong resolution up there that shows, I think, that the world is united against the kind of aggression that we've witnessed. But I'd like to ask our guest, the prime minister, to say a word. And then the secretary general, who has just arrived. And we were going to do this differently, but now we're out here, go ahead, please, Margaret. PRIME MINISTER THATCHER: May I support the President of the United States in saying that the news from the United Nations and the strength of the vote _ 13 votes in favor of mandatory, comprehensive sanctions, and no votes against _ is very good. That means that it becomes law in all the countries of the world. That is extremely good. It also follows the strong support that has been given by the European countries in their condemnation of the action of Saddam Hussein in invading Kuwait. Japan also condemned strongly, and so did the Soviet Union. So really, the world is condemning the action and the United Nations resolution will become mandatory and mean that those sanctions must be enforceable. I cannot remember a time when we had the world so strongly together against an action as now. And I hope that those sanctions will be properly and effectively enforced as a positive action against what we all totally and utterly condemn. PRESIDENT BUSH: Manfred, are you prepared to say a word? SECRETARY GENERAL WOERNER: Well, I just arrived. Just a few thoughts which we have exchanged. My impression is that this is the moment for the West to show cohesion, determination, and to make it clear what cannot be accepted in this world, and to safeguard its own security interests. Q: Mr. President, have you received _ PRESIDENT BUSH: Thank you all. Q: Mr. President, did you hear from Saddam today? Q: _ any assurances from Saddam Hussein that he won't invade Saudi Arabia? PRESIDENT BUSH: I've had no such assurances directly to me. And what was the last question? We really have to get in. You all are getting _ Q: Did you get a message _ a personal message from Saddam? PRESIDENT BUSH: No, I've not had a personal _ Q: Do you hope that these sanctions _ do you _ in light of these sanctions, that you can forego a blockade? PRESIDENT BUSH: These sanctions _ we need to discuss full and total implementation of these sanctions, ruling out nothing at all. These sanctions must be enforced. I think the will of the nations around the world _ not just the NATO countries, not just the EC (European Community), not just one area or another _ the will of the nations around the world will be to enforce these sanctions. And so, we'll leave the details of how we implement it to the future, but we'll begin working on that immediately, working _ one of the consultations that's going on right now in the Oval Office is just exactly how we go about encouraging others to do that and what we ourselves should be doing. Q: Mr. President, the oil pipeline _ the pipeline through Saudi Arabia _ Q: What did Saddam tell the US counselor _ charge? PRESIDENT BUSH (off mike): These sanctions will be enforced, hatever it takes.

DOC.HEAD: A Chronology of Key Events in the Dispute Between Iraq and Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology in the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait: July 17 _ Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accuses Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the oil market and driving prices down. He says Iraq has lost $14 billion in oil revenue. He further charges that Arab states in the Persian Gulf are conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. July 18 _ Iraq accuses Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells along the disputed border and of seeking to wreck Iraq's economy by overproducing oil. July 20 _ Kuwaiti officials suggest Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence is aimed at getting its creditors _ including Kuwait _ to write off billions of dollars in debts from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. July 24 _ The U.S. Defense Department announces that U.S. Navy warships and aircraft are holding a ``short-notice exercise'' in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates, about 600 miles southeast of the Kuwait-Iraqi border. Kuwait calls a state of alert. July 25 _ The Iraqi government in Baghdad says that it will not be intimidated by U.S. pressure in its oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and Saddams summons the U.S. ambassador for talks. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt says Iraq and Kuwait plan to meet in Saudi Arabia in an effort to resolve their dispute. July 26 _ OPEC ministers in Geneva agree to halt overproduction in hopes of pushing up the price of crude oil. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates pledge to abide by the agreement. Analysts say Saddam clearly influenced the outcome of the meetings. July 31 _ Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to negotiate the oil and border dispute. Diplomats say Iraq has massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border, more than triple the number originally estimated. Aug. 1 _ Iraq pulls out of talks on the 2-week-old border, oil and money dispute with Kuwait. Aug. 2 _ Iraq's powerful army overruns Kuwait before dawn. Tank-led troops quickly seize the ruler's palace and other government buildings. Aug. 3 _ Shelling and gunfire shake portions of Kuwait's capital, indicating a last-ditch attempt by Kuwaiti forces to hold out against the more powerful Iraqi army. Iraqi troops push to within 5 to 10 miles of the Saudi Arabian border. Aug. 4 _ Baghdad announces a new military government for Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The 12-member European Community imposes an embargo against imports of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil. Aug. 5 _ Kuwait's new Iraqi-installed government claimes Iraqi troops begin pulling out of Kuwait, but the United States says it doubts a withdrawal is really under way. Aug. 6 _ The U.N. Security Council orders a worldwide embargo on trade with Iraq to punish the Arab oil and military power for its invasion of Kuwait. In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other U.S. military leaders confer with Saudi leaders about how to defend the oil kingdom against any attack by Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Tension Grows As The United Nations Imposes Sanctions On Iraq
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here at-a-glance are some of the developments Monday in the Iraq-Kuwait dispute. _In New York, members of the U.N. Security Council voted for a mandatory worldwide economic embargo against Iraq, the first such total U.N. boycott in 23 years. _Iraq curtailed its oil through Turkishpipelines, handed out weapons to civilians and declared its people ``cannot be frightened'' by U.S. economic and military threats. _In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other U.S. military leaders conferred with Saudi leaders about how to defend the oil kingdom against any attack by Iraq. _Tension remained high along the Saudi Arabia-Kuwait border. Saudi Arabian forces were reported moving northward into areas near the Iraqi units in Kuwait. Diplomats in the Persian Gulf _ in reports otherwise unconfirmed _ said the U.S. Rapid Deployment Force had been dispatched to the Middle East. _In the Arabian Sea, a 13-ship U.S. Navy battle group, led by the aircraft carrier USS Independence, took up station outside the mouth of the Persian Gulf, within striking distance of Gulf flashpoints, Pentagon sources said. _Major stock markets worldwide plummeted again, worried that an oil crisis could touch off a recession. Oil prices rose more than 10 percent. Many motorists in the United States and elsewhere were paying sharply higher prices for gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: African Leaders Agree to Military Intervention in Liberia
With AM-US-Liberia
DOC.TEXT: Five West African leaders agreed Monday to send troops into Liberia to impose a cease-fire in that country's civil war. Salim Ahmed Salim, secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity, told The Associated Press the leaders were working out logistics, but he gave no details. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said rebels seized 14 or 15 foreigners in the Liberian capital of Monrovia on Monday, including one American, and moved them to an insurgent headquarters outside the city. She said the U.S. Embassy reported that forces of Prince Johnson, the leader of one of two rebel factions, ``have seized hostages.'' Sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said the leaders at Banjul were considering sending in troops by land from neighboring Sierra Leone and Guinea, as well as a naval force. The troops would impose a cease-fire and install an interim government to organize free elections, according to the sources. They said the interim government would not include any warring party. The task force would comprise troops from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone, and Gambia. Nigeria already has three ships _ one armed with missiles and heavy guns _ off Sierra Leone, which neighbors Liberia. Thousands of rebels and sympathizers of Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor rallied in opposition to the plan. They gathered in Monrovia and waved banners reading: ``Liberia will be the graveyard of foreign aggressors.'' Taylor told them his forces ``will resist any foreign intervention to the last man,'' the British Broadcasting Corp. reported. The intervention plan was agreed at a summit of the West African Economic Community. Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara said in his opening address that the world was looking to West African leaders to end the Liberian war. ``We can no longer afford to let the situation deteriorate further,'' he said. Most of the 5,000 people killed in the war have been civilians from the Gio or Mano tribes, which form the backbone of the rebellion, or from President Samuel Doe's Krahn tribe and the Mandingo tribe, which also supports Doe. The only Liberian at the meeting Monday was the Rev. Regis Carr of the Liberian Council of Churches, which with the West African Economic Community had tried to mediate peace talks between the rebels and the government. Those talks broke down after Doe refused to surrender to rebel demands that he step down. Other representatives at the meeting Monday were from Sierra Leone, Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Togo, and Mali. The heads of state and Cabinet members refused to comment on their three hours of talks. They planned to meet again Tuesday. The African initiative would follow U.S. intervention by hundreds of Marines who flew into Monrovia on Sunday from warships off Liberia to begin evacuating Americans and some other foreign nationals. The operation continued Monday without resistance. A joint African military intervention is unprecedented, though individual nations have sent in troops to help friendly leaders. Senegal, for example, sent 3,000 troops into Gambia in 1981 to put down a coup attempt against Dir Dawda Jawara. Both Doe and Johnson, who split from Taylor's mainstream rebel army, have appealed for the United States to intervene militarily. They also have said they would welcome African peacekeepers. Johnson precipitated the U.S. evacuation by threatening to start kidnapping foreign nationals Monday, targeting Americans, Britons, Indians and Lebanese. He made it clear he wanted to provoke military intervention. Taylor's opposition to intervention stems from distrust of Nigeria, whose president, Ibrahim Babangida, has been a close ally of Doe. Ms. Tutwiler said Monday's hostages were sent to Johnson headquarters in Caldwell. No indication emerged that any hostage was harmed. Nationalities of the non-American hostages were not disclosed. Cuba warned that the use of U.S Marines in the evacuation is a ``gross interference which could bring grave consequences.'' Cuba's news agency, Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico, said Monday that President Fidel Castro wrote to Yoweri Museveni, acting head of the Organization of African Unity. The message said Cuba condemned the Marine action, done ``with the well-known pretext of protecting the lives and property of American citizens in Monrovia, cynically declaring that they would stay in the African country as long as necessary.''

DOC.HEAD: Young Reaches to Civil Rights Days, Miller Emotional With Black Group
With AM-Kansas Election
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young recalled his days in the civil rights struggle Monday as he implored Georgians to defy the pollsters and give him the Democratic nomination Tuesday to become the state's first black governor. Meanwhile, the former Atlanta mayor's front-running opponent, Lt. Gov. Zell Miller, expressed gratitude to a group of black supporters. In Michigan, Republican candidates wrapped up campaigns in primaries to choose challengers to Democratic Gov. James Blanchard and U.S. Sen. Carl Levin. And Kansas Republican Gov. Mike Hayden braced for a strong primary challenge from wealthy real estate agent Nestor Weigand. Missouri also has primaries Tuesday, but no statewide races. U.S. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., is expected to have no trouble winning renomination. The winner of Georgia's gubernatorial primary will meet Republican state Rep. Johnny Isakson in the November general election. The incumbent, two-term Democrat Joe Frank Harris, wasn't eligible to seek re-election. On Monday, Miller and Young held news conferences in television markets across the state, winding up a three-week campaign that began when they emerged from a five-man field in the July 17 primary. Miller received 41 percent of the vote in that race to 29 percent for Young, and two polls last week gave the white lieutenant governor a lead of about 20 percentage points. Despite the prospect that Young could be Georgia's first black governor, race had come up rarely until Monday, when both candidates mentioned past associations with black groups. Blacks make up about 28 percent of the state's registered voters. Young's campaign day began at Paschal's Motor Lodge in Atlanta, a headquarters of the civil rights movement. He noted that Monday was the 25th anniversary of the signing of the Voting Rights Act by President Johnson, and recalled that some fellow supporters of the late Martin Luther King Jr. died in the struggle for that law. Young then took a jab at Miller's main issue, a proposed state lottery. ``I don't believe anybody marched, I don't believe anybody went to jail _ or died, for certain _ for a lottery,'' Young said. Miller appeared in Savannah before about 50 members of the Political Advisory Council of Chatham County, a black group that endorsed him over Young. Miller said the group helped him 16 years ago when he won his first race for lieutenant governor. Appearing to choke up, he said, ``Now, 16 years later, when it's so difficult to do what you're doing, you're reaching out to me again. ``We're going to be the Democratic nominee, and you're going to play an important part in it, and I ain't going to forget it,'' he promised. In Michigan, conservative U.S. Rep. Bill Schuette is running against the more conservative Clark Durant for the right to take on Levin, who is unopposed in the Democratic primary in his bid for a third Senate term. Recent polls favored Schuette. He said Monday that he wasn't taking anything for granted, but said, ``I'm going to take it right to Carl Levin. We're going to be aggressive. I'm pulling no punches.'' Michigan Senate Majority Leader John Engler is expected to roll over his primary opponent, General Motors Corp. engineer John Lauve, to win the GOP gubernatorial nomination. Engler has focused on Blanchard, a two-term Democratic incumbent, and his 20 years experience in the Legislature. Blanchard, who is seeking a third four-year term, has no primary opponent. In Kansas, Hayden's bid for a second four-year term faces strong opposition from Nestor Weigand of Wichita, and Democratic former Gov. John Carlin is favored to win the Democratic nod to seek his old job. U.S. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum is opposed by political unknown Gregory Walstrom of Lawrence in her bid for the GOP nomination to a third six-year term. In Missouri, Gephardt's only challenger in the Democratic primary in his St. Louis district is Nicholas F. Clement, a supporter of right-wing extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Three Republicans are running for their party's nomination in the district.

DOC.HEAD: Quirky How-To Cassettes Highlight Video Convention
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps ``Room Arranging Dos and Don'ts'' won't sell as many videocassettes as ``Batman.'' But business for how-to videos is up, and even the most obscure instructional cassettes have a chance. At the ninth annual Video Software Dealers Association Convention here this week, hit films like ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' are drawing most of the attention from the 15,000 video retailers, distributors and producers. In the corners of the VSDA's convention floor, though, lurk more intriguing productions. Pacific Arts Video offers ``Sirius Puppy Training,'' with hints on how to teach man's best friend to sit, stay, heel and go to the bathroom outdoors. The Crocus video distribution company is pleased with sales for ``Aerobics With Soul,'' a workout set to African music. Wood Knapp Video is featuring ``Yo-Yo Man,'' an instructional cassette hosted by the Smothers Brothers that comes with a free yo-yo. ``The how-to, self-instruction category is one of the fastest growing,'' said John Bjerke of Better Homes & Gardens Video. In addition to its new ``Room Arranging'' release, Better Homes is selling the popular ``Building a Deck,'' ``Refinishing Furniture,'' ``Wallpaper Like a Pro!'' and ``Foolproof Flower Beds.'' According to figures compiled by Nielsen Media Research, exercise and instructional titles accounted for an estimated 16 percent of pre-recorded cassettes sold last year. Another study found that demand for instructional titles is growing. Two of the four most popular selections from Wishing Well Distribution are yoga cassettes: ``Alive With Yoga With Lilias Folan'' and ``Richard Hittleman's Yoga Course.'' ``People are focusing more on stress reduction and relaxation these days,'' said Wishing Well's Kim Heron. ``And that's what yoga is.'' The cmpany's sales more than doubled from 1988 to 1989. Proudly proclaiming ``Identify birds by video!,'' MasterVision is showcasing a five-volume series called ``The Audubon Society's Video Guide to Birds of North America.'' ``It's sight and sound _ perfect for bird-watching,'' said MasterVision President Richard Stadin. ``No book can do this. Books are two-dimensional, but the video is three-dimensional.'' Other MasterVision cassettes include one on little-league baseball tactics and ``Basic Arabic by Video.'' ``This is very current today,'' Stadin noted. Not all of the new how-to titles are necessarily tame. Playboy Home Video introduced ``Secrets of EuroMassage,'' with a Playboy bunny giving convention goers free massages to help boost sales. One how-to video that would interest convention guests isn't available in any booth. That's a cassette that would give distributors and retailers tips to help stop slowing video sales and consumer dissatisfaction. In a glum convention keynote address, Robert Klingensmith, president of the Paramount Picture's video division, said that after 10 years of explosive growth the cassette business now has stalled. ``We have new customers who are hard to reach and old customers whose interests may be waning or need to be reinforced,'' Klingensmith said. He called on store owners to make the practice of renting and buying tapes more pleasant. To help generate business, Paramount pledged $100,000 to a proposed industry-wide advertising campaign that would highlight the joys of videocassettes. For another reason, Paramount wasn't welcomed warmly on the convention floor. Its decision to sell copies of ``The Hunt for Red October'' at a retail price of $99.95 _ instead of the traditional $89.95 or less _ means that many store owners may have to raise their rental fees or see their profit margins narrow.

DOC.HEAD: Man Claims His Father Helped Assassinate John F. Kennedy
LaserPhoto DN3
DOC.TEXT: Adding yet another theory to the bulging file on the assassination of John F. Kennedy, an unemployed Texas salesman on Monday claimed his father was one of three people who killed the president. Ricky Don White contends his father joined the Dallas police department in September 1963 to carry out the assassination. He said his father, Roscoe White, was one of three CIA operatives who fired the shots. The CIA issued an unusually strong rebuttal to White's claims. ``These allegations _ that this was done on CIA orders, that this guy worked for us and that CIA had any role in the assassination of President Kennedy _ are ludicrous,'' CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield said in Washington. Roscoe White never worked for the CIA, Mansfield said. ``Normally, we never confirm nor deny employment, but these allegations are so outrageous that we felt it necessary and appropriate to respond,'' he said. The FBI said in a brief statement that it had received the same information in 1988 but ``determined that this information is not credible.'' The Warren Commission concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald, acting alone, fired the shots that killed Kennedy and wounded John Connally, then the Texas governor, on Nov. 22, 1963 in Dallas. Despite the commission's findings, conspiracy theories have abounded since the assassination. Ricky White said at a news conference that his father also killed Dallas police officer J.D. Tippit about an hour after the assassination. Tippit's killing has been blamed on Oswald. White said his father served in the Marines with Oswald, who he said also was part of the conspiracy but fired no shots. Roscoe White died in 1971 from burns suffered in a fire. Ricky White, 29, is a former oil equipment salesman from Midland. He made his claims during a news conference at the JFK Assassination Information Center, a privately run group that researches various assassination theories. White acknowledged he has tried to sell a book or movie on his theory. White said he drew his conclusions from what he read in his father's diary and from his parents' discussion with a minister. White said he got the diary after his father's death and never showed it to anyone. He said the diary disappeared after he talked to the FBI about his theory in 1988. White said his father referred to himself in the diary by a CIA code name of ``Mandarin'' and to two other CIA operatives _ ``Lebanon'' and ``Saul.'' White claimed his father was on a grassy knoll in front of the presidential caravan and fired two shots that struck Kennedy, according to the diary.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to restore Bjt designation.
U.N. Sanctions Aim at Crippling Iraqi Oil Exports, Forcing Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council on Monday imposed broad sanctions against Iraq for invading Kuwait, including a ban on trade aimed at cutting off the Middle Eastern nation's oil trade and arms supplies. The 15-member council voted 13-0 to adopt a U.S.-crafted resolution calling for the measures in an effort to force Iraq to unconditionally withdraw its troops from Kuwait. Yemen, the council's only Arab member, and Cuba abstained. The resolution, which was sponsored by 10 council members, said the Security Council is ``determined to bring the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq to an end and to restore the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait.'' The measure, which takes effect immediately, bans all imports from Iraq and Kuwait. It also prohibits any activities, including the transfer of funds, that would help Iraq and Kuwait export their goods and forbids loans to the two countries. If successfully enforced, the sanctions could cripple the oil-dependent Iraqi economy. Its sweeping provisions would in effect bar U.N. members from importing Iraqi oil, and oblige Turkey and Saudi Arabia to shut down Iraqi oil pipelines running through their territory. The Iraqis, fast losing customers for their oil, stopped pumping petroleum on Monday through one of their two pipelines that run through Turkey to the Mediterranean. They reduced the flow in a second pipeline there. Turkish President Turgut Ozal, in an interview with ABC News, had indicated that Turkey would close down the pipeline completely once the Security Council adopted the sanctions resolution. ``We will obey the U.N. embargo,'' Ozal said. The resolution also bans the sale or supply of any commodities or products to Iraq and Kuwait, which would include weapons and military supplies. The only exceptions to the trade embargo under the resolution were for such items as food and medical supplies ``in special humanitarian circumstances.'' President Bush praised the council's decision and called for ``full and total implementation of these sanctions, ruling out nothing at all.'' He told reporters at the White House: ``These sanctions must be enforced.'' It was only the third time in its 45-year existence that the world body had voted sanctions against a member state. In 1967, the Security Council voted similar, comprehensive sanctions against the white minority government of Rhodesia. A mandatory U.N. arms embargo against South Africa, approved in 1977, is still in effect. The sanctions are legally binding on all U.N. members, although past council resolutions have often been ignored or flouted. The United Nations has no enforcement mechanism but later could call on members to take military action against Iraq or impose a blockade. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking to reporters at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington, said Britain and its allies will consider a naval blockade of Iraq if the U.N. sanctions prove ineffective. The vote followed similar sanctions imposed on Iraq by much of the West, including the United States, Japan and the European Community. The Soviet Union and China said they would halt arms shipments to Iraq. At Monday's council session, U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering accused Iraqi President Saddam Hussein of plunging ``into crisis the strategically critical area of the Persian Gulf.'' ``Iraq must learn that its disregard for international law will have crippling political and economic costs, including but not limited to arms cutoffs,'' Pickering said. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul al-Anbari denounced the sanctions and accused the United States of pressuring other countries to take action against Iraq. ``One superpower is trying to use the U.N. and the Security Council to realize its objectives, as if the Security Council was simply its foreign ministry,'' he said. The Iraqi ambassador said the sanctions resolution would only exacerbate the crisis and impede Iraqi troop withdrawals from Kuwait, which Baghdad says have already begun. The United States has disputed Iraq's claims about the troop withdrawal. Before the vote, Kuwait's Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan called the invasion a threat to international security and said strong U.N. action was needed to protect small nations against aggression. ``You are representing the conscience of the world.'' he told the council. ``Now it is your responsibility by proving to the whole world that the security of nations, be it big ones or small, is not a commodity for sale, or for terrorism or for threats.'' Security Council members had been discussing possible sanctions for days after passing a resolution condemning Iraq on Thursday, just hours after Iraqi troops moved into Kuwait. The council includes the five permanent members with veto power: the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. The 10 non-permanent members are: Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Foresees Possible Naval Blockade in Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2nd graf to note ship reinforcements; SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT location of Mobassa from South Africa to Kenya; adds byline
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Monday that Britain and its allies will have to consider mounting a naval blockade of the Persian Gulf if United Nations sanctions against Iraq prove ineffective. Britain, she said, had ordered two frigates to join its two-ship Persian Gulf patrol. Mrs. Thatcher said she was heartened by the overwhelming vote by which the U.N. Security Council adopted a comprehensive ban on trade with Iraq and Kuwait, and expressed confidence that the sanctions will work. Mrs. Thatcher spoke after meeting with President Bush on her way home from a Colorado vacation. She said the U.N. sanctions follow ``one of the most complete condemnations we have seen for a very long time.'' She said other past sanctions, including one against Rhodesia _ now the African nation of Zimbabwe _ could not be effective because they did not have comprehensive backing by the world community. But she said the world clearly agrees that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's military seizure of Kuwait is ``the act of an aggressor that must be stopped.'' Speaking of the U.N. sanctions, she said: ``I see great determination and great perseverance that that resolution will work.'' Asked about the possibility of a naval blockade to reinforce U.N. sanctions, the prime minister said the first priority is to ensure that the sanctions are effective by themselves. But if Britain, the United States and the world community concluded that a blockade was a vital next step, ``you would have to consider'' such action, she said. She said Britain has one warship and an associated supply ship already in the Persian Gulf and that two additional frigates, one in Mombassa, Kenya and the other in Malaysia, will reach the gulf by Sunday. ``If it comes to considering blockades, then of course we would have to consider those,'' she said. ``If not, we will have to consider joint action ... such as a blockade.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Psychologist's Tapes Can Be Used in Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: Conversations between a psychologist and two brothers after their parents were slain can be allowed as evidence in the brothers' murder case, a judge ruled Monday. Superior Court Judge James Albracht said the psychologist, L. Jerome Oziel, had believed Erik and Lyle Menendez made threats during their psychotherapy sessions with him and it was necessary to disclose their conversations to prevent danger.
