Albracht said that such a threat constitutes an exception to the psychologist-patient privilege and the exception applies to all taped conversations between the brothers and their therapist. The tapes of counseling sessions ``concern the brothers' emotional and psychological state after the murder of their parents,'' Albracht said. The brothers are charged with shooting to death their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in the family's Beverly Hills mansion last Aug. 20. Prosecutors say the gruesome shotgun slayings were prompted by the brothers' greedy hurry to collect their parents' $14 million fortune. Jose Menendez was president of Live Entertainment, a video production company. Erik, 19, and Lyle, 22, who have pleaded innocent, remain in jail without bail. They could face the death penalty if convicted. The murders, in the heart of plush Beverly Hills, remained a mystery for six months until police arrested the brothers. At one point there were rumors Menendez and his wife were victims of a Mafia execution. There was a stunned gasp in the courtroom from the Menendez family as the judge announced his ruling. The grandmother, aunts and uncles of the defendants have attended all of the hearings. Erik and Lyle Menendez, clad in blue jail uniforms, exchanged glances with their relatives as they were led in and out of court. ``If the judge's ruling is upheld it brings a virtual end to the psychotherapist-patient privilege,'' said defense attorney Leslie Abramson. Albracht did not give the legal basis for his ruling and said he would seal his written opinion until Aug. 15. He said defense attorneys could seek an appeals court order before that to have the decision sealed permanently. Defense lawyers, claiming the conversations are privileged, said they would appeal to prevent the tapes from being used in the brothers' prosecution. He said the law required that the tapes be kept confidential and that even the prosecutors could not hear them or know what was in them until the matter was resolved. The prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Elliott Alhadeff, said he felt the tapes contained ``very important evidence, but it is not crucial to the case.'' The judge said months of hearings on the issue were exceptionally complex. Ms. Abramson said Albracht based his ruling on a recent court decision that held that if a psychotherapist discusses a patient's statements with someone else the privilege disappears. But other courts have held that the privilege belongs to the patient, not the therapist, she said. ``The therapist cannot simply be a gossip or a liar _ which we claim in this case _ to make the privilege disappear,'' she said. ``In my opinion, Dr. Oziel was less than credible with this court.''

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Continues, Crews Ready Barge For Exit Out of Bay
DOC.TEXT: The tanks of a barge that spewed oil into the Houston Ship Channel were cleaned Monday so the vessel can be cut up and moved out of the way of ship traffic, and crews scooped up oil patches that washed ashore. Two-way traffic can't resume in the Houston Ship Channel until the barge is removed. An estimated 700,000 gallons of oil spilled into the vital Galveston Bay on July 28 when a tanker collided with two barges in the ship channel. Cleanup crews scoured the barge's emptied tanks Monday. ``We want to get whatever oil is on it, off of it. We don't want to cut it open and have a mini-oil spill added to what we've already got,'' Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt said. The tanks also must be cleaned of oil because a spark from cutting torches could set off an explosion, the Coast Guard said. The channel was open Monday to two-way barge traffic, but deep-draft ships could only travel one way because the Coast Guard is concerned their wakes could disrupt the salvage operations. A few heavy patches of oil remained to be cleaned up along the shoreline and a light sheen floated about two miles into the bay. ``There's not much oil out there right now,'' Meidt said. ``The heavier concentrations are just splotches here and there along the shore.'' ``I think that's good because the heavy stuff is right at the shoreline where it can be collected by the vacuum trucks. The sheen is more susceptible to natural breakdown,'' Meidt said. ``Most of the oil that was in the water, that was visible, is gone. It's been picked up by vacuum trucks.'' The oil stained several beaches. Oil also seeped into some marshes and collected around several residential docks, but officials said it had not washed into additional marshes, breeding grounds for much sea life. Crews used vacuum trucks again Monday to clean up the remaining oil that has washed ashore. More than 316,000 gallons of an oil-and-water mixture has been picked up so far, Meidt said. Crews also sprayed oil-gobbling microbes on an oil-tainted marsh area south of Cedar Bayou, said Petty Officer Scott Campbell. The microbes were sprayed on another marsh area Sunday and a beach last week. The microbes, used in a process call bioremediation, reduce the oil to a fatty emulsion that is eaten by marine life. When the oil is gone, the microbes die. The cleanup is expected to last about a week, and the total cost is estimated at $5 million, Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said.

DOC.HEAD: Military, Private Planes Collide In Air Near San Antonio
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force jet and a single-engine Cessna collided Monday, sending the military aircraft plunging to the ground in a fireball, authorities said. Two military crewmen ejected from the T-38 jet as the aircraft collided shortly before 3 p.m. The crewmen, whom the Air Force identified as as 2nd Lt. James Kline, 23, of Freemont, Ohio, and 1st Lt. Steven Perlman, 25, of East Chester, N.Y., were not seriously hurt, said Charles Metzger, chief of the Sandy Oaks Volunteer Fire Department. A flight instructor and teen-ager in the private Cessna escaped injury after the instructor landed the small plane, minus its front nose section. ``All I saw was a fireball. Then I saw black smoke everywhere,'' said Metzger, who was at an intersection near the collision when it occurred. The pilot of the T-38, based at Laughlin Air Force Base in Del Rio, was making training approaches into Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, said Bill Czervinske, a Federal Aviation Administration manager.

DOC.HEAD: German Party Demands Unification in Mid-September
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with East German Social Democrats to propose Sept. 15 unity deadline to East German Parliament, other details; CHANGES byline
DOC.TEXT: The Social Democrats, the second-biggest party in both German states, demanded Monday that the nations unite by mid-September, saying East Germany's social and economic conditions are ``catastrophic.'' Earlier in the day, German union leaders and the German Social Union, a small East German archconservative party, also pushed for quicker unification. The Christian Democrats of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere insist unity must wait for united German elections that should be held Oct. 14. However, left-of-center Social Democratic leaders from both nations _ in a joint three-hour meeting in Bonn _ set Sept. 15 as their deadline for formal German unity. The East German Social Democrats backed off a threat to pull out of de Maiziere's government this week over a disagreement on when all-German elections should occur. But they could resurrect the threat. Wolfgang Thierse, head of the East German Social Democrats, said the party would seek a vote in the East German Parliament on Wednesday that would set Sept. 15 as the deadline for unification. ``The coalition question is not the decisive one,'' said Thierse. ``The decisive question is what can be done for the people of the DDR (East Germany).'' The conflict had threatened to break up de Maiziere's broad coalition government and further fuel the political, economic and social upheaval in the young democratic nation. Oskar Lafontaine, the West German Social Democrats' candidate for chancellor, said a ``catastrophic situation'' has developed in East Germany. He told reporters the best way to rescue East Germans is forging unity ``as quickly as possible.'' Lafontaine said quickly joining East Germany to West Germany would make Kohl's government ``responsible for the DDR'' and for what the Social Democrats say are mistakes by Kohl that have led up to East Germany's problems. ``The federal chancellor has nothing else on his mind but becoming chancellor of all Germany. But that is not the question,'' said Lafontaine, adding the important task is to worry about the welfare of all Germans. At the heart of the debate is an intense political struggle by parties jockeying to use unification to their political advantage in united German elections. It is up to East Germany to enact unification. That will be done when its Parliament approves a clause in the West German constitution allowing it to join its bigger neighbor. The Social Democrats began pressing for quick unification last week after Kohl and de Maiziere called for united German elections to be moved up from Dec. 2 to Oct. 14. The Social Democrats believe voters will start turning against Kohl as conditions in East Germany worsen, and therefore see a later election date _ but early unification _ as their best chance to defeat him. The two German Social Democratic parties are closely allied. They are the leading opposition in West Germany and the second-largest faction in de Maiziere's strife-ridden coalition. Kohl's Christian Democrats and the Social Democrats seemed to be moving toward a compromise on an election date. Social Democrats said holding all-German elections on Nov. 18 is one possibility. Kohl is to meet with leaders of the West German Social Democrats on Tuesday in Bonn to discuss their disagreements. But a spokesman for Kohl, Dieter Vogel, said the chancellor was not ready to accept any compromise on the election date. ``The chancellor assumes the date will be Oct. 14,'' said Vogel. The head of the German Trade Union, the largest labor association in West Germany with more than 8 million members, also pressed for immediate unity. Labor association chief Heinz-Werner Meyer said the July 1 economic unification of the Germanys _ when East Germany made a virtual overnight transition from socialism to a free market _ happened too quickly and will have disastrous effects. IG Metall, a West German metal workers union and West Germany's largest individual labor union, also called for immediate unity.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Meets King Fahd to Discuss Saudi Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to ADD remarks on Cheney's talks by White House spokesman and U.S. military official. Pickup 4th graf pvs `Cheney was ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met King Fahd on Monday to discuss defense strategy for Saudi Arabia against a possible attack by Iraqi troops deployed along its border with Kuwait. Residents reported increased military activity here. In Iraq, President Saddam Hussein told the U.S. charge d'affaires he had no plans to invade Saudi Arabia and said the United States was fabricating reports about troop buildups to justify an attack on Iraq. Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Thursday. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The defense of Saudi Arabia is of paramount concern.'' He said Cheney was in Jiddah to discuss the possible Iraqi threat and ``appropriate ways to defend'' Saudi Arabia. One U.S. military official, requesting anonymity, said Cheney's talks with the Saudis are crucial to U.S. hopes of halting further Iraqi aggression. The official said it would be impossible to carry out a major air strike in the Persian Gulf without overflight or landing rights from friendly nations in the region. Cheney's talks with the Saudis centered on direct U.S. assistance in the event of a full-scale Iraqi invasion, as well as options for possible U.S.-Saudi military cooperation. Cheney was also to confer with Prince Sultan, Saudi defense minister, and other senior officials. With Cheny were Lt. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, chief of the U.S. Middle East force known as the Central Command; Richard Gates, deputy national security adviser; and Paul Wolfowitz, deputy defense secretary. Saudi TV showed segments of the meeting but gave no details. The foreign ministers of the small Arab states around the Persian Gulf were to meet Tuesday in Jiddah, but it was not confirmed they would meet with Cheney. Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, also came to Jiddah on Monday following his talks with Saddam in Baghdad and with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Alexandria. The PLO and Libya said they were pursuing a joint peace plan but released no details. Cairo papers briefly referred to that plan as having four points: Iraq would withdraw; Iraq would receive economic aid; the Kuwaiti people alone must choose their government; and Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Iraq and Yemen would create an Arab force to protect Persian Gulf waterways and coordinate passage through them. The United Nations voted on Monday to impose sweeping sanctions on Iraq, which invaded Kuwait early Thursday. The official Saudi Press Agency denied reports that the kingdom called a general mobilization and was reinforcing its military along the borders. But witnesses reported intense air activity overnight near the airport area in Riyadh, the Saudi capital. Oil executives at Khafji, reached by telephone from Bahrain, said the Saudis were bolstering their forces near the Kuwait border. Residents speaking on condition of anonymity said the deployments were a precaution to defend oilfields run by the Arabian Oil Co., a consortium of Saudi, Kuwait and Japanese companies. ``It's calm down here,'' said one Japanese oil executive. ``There is no shooting anywhere ... But the Saudis are reinforcing their defenses.'' Khafji is a small city in northeastern Saudi Arabia on the gulf. Its port has oil loading and berthing facilities for small tankers and freighters. Travelers from the area said Saudi tanks were sighted moving northward on Saturday, possibly to areas near Khafji. An American technician who returned Sunday from Saudi Arabia said in New York that the kingdom deployed 200 to 300 tanks toward its border with Kuwait; moved families of American civilian employees at a Saudi military base in the northern desert to Riyadh, and put ``all others ... on notice to evacuate.'' He spoke on condition that he not be identified. Reports reaching Bahrain indicated that parts of the Iraqi invasion forces in Kuwait have been moving in the direction of Khafji and were deploying at points about 15 miles from the oil region. They reinforced Iraqi troops who set up a checkpoint on the second night of the invasion about half a mile from the Saudi border checkpoint at Khafji. The border was closed. Gulf-based diplomatic sources, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said no indications surfaced of any significant crossing of Iraqi forces into Saudi territory. They said Saudi forces went on alert with the start of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Security officials at the Khafji post in the Divided Zone said Iraqi troops were making minor incursions into Saudi territory and then ``politely'' retreating with apologies. Kuwait's borders with Saudi Arabia run halfway through the so-called Divided Zone, a new name for what used to be called the Neutral Zone. Under a 1988 agreement, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait agreed to draw their border through the Neutral Zone, but to share the revenues of the oil field that straddles it.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Monday it would prosecute any anti-trust violations it finds in the oil and gasoline price run-up _ and it's looking for them. The Energy Department, meanwhile, noted that consumers could reduce pressure on prices by conservation. A joint statement by the Justice, Energy and Transportation departments ``expressed concern'' over sharp increases in petroleum prices that saw average gasoline pump prices rise by about 10 percent since Thursday, according to an American Automobile Association survey. ``We will look closely for any indication that these increases may be the reult of anti-competitive activity,'' said James F. Rill, assistant attorney general in charge of the anti-trust division, according to the statement. Such activity ``will be met with vigorous anti-trust prosecution,'' he said. W. Henson Moore, deputy energy secretary, said his department's Energy Information Administration `is monitoring the commerical oil market hourly to track any sharp fluctuations in the marketplace,'' and would share its findings with the Justice Department. ``The domestic and international markets are reacting, as one would expect, to uncertainty about future petroleum supplies,'' Moore said. ``While this reaction is normal, the fact remains that oil stocks, at home and abroad, are at record high elevls. We believe that the oil industry should not be carried away by speculation about future events.'' Moore also said, ``Consumer efforts to conserve can contribute to reducing immediate demand pressures.'' ``We just do not understand the basis for the price increases seen in the last several days,'' Transportation Secretary Samual Skinner told the American Bar Association's annual convention in Chicago. The statement quoted him as urging transportation companies ``not to overreact.'' Several airlines have raised ticket prices on their grounds their fuel costs suddenly were rising out of control The early evening three-department statement followed a day of congressional outcry and hasty scheduling of hearings for Tuesday. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., said oil companies have gone on ``a feeding frenzy'' despite near-record oil stocks. ``The oil companies are playing the old game, heads they win, tails you lose,'' he said. Bryan scheduled a hearing before the Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee. Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., called a similar session before the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on energy and power he chairs. Sharp also called on Bush, in cooperation with allies, to dampen price increases by releasing crude oil from the 90-day emergency supply stored by the government in Louisiana and Texas. ``The Strategic Petroleum Reserve has to be used to make sure shortages don't show up ... to short the market and protect the consumer,'' said Sharp. Moore last week ruled out such a course, saying the reserve was not meant to dampen price fluctuations. Seventeen senators signed a letter circulated by Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., asking Bush to establish an Emergency Oil Price Task Force to focus public scrutiny on the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Stops Oil Flow Through One Turkish Pipeline, Reduces Another
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq stopped pumping oil on Monday to one of two pipelines running through Turkey and reduced crude running through the other as a world embargo shrank the Iraqi market. The United Nations voted to clamp an embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil as part of broad sanctions to punish Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. President Turgut Ozal, in an interview with ABC News, had indicated earlier that Turkey would stop transporting Iranian oil if the Security Council adopted the sanctions. ``We will obey the U.N. embargo,'' Ozal said to ABC news. One Turkish government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Iraq's decision to curtail oil on its own came as ``a great relief.'' Even before the U.N. sanctioons, the United States had been pressuring Turkey to cut off the pipeline flow. The White House announced that U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will travel to Turkey, a member of NATO, this week for consultations on the crisis set off by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday. President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran also was sending a special emissary to Ankara for similar talks, Ozal's office said. Vural Oktay, director of the state-run Turkish pipeline company BOTAS, said pumping stopped at one pipeline at 6 p.m. Iraq reduced flow in the second, larger pipeline to 70 percent of capacity, he told reporters. The United States, the 12-nation European Community and Japan were among countries that had earlier imposed an embargo on Iraqi oil purchases. They said that before Iraq's decision was announced, a Norwegian tanker waiting at the terminal to load crude for Britain sailed away empty. Iraq acted a day after a high-level envoy of President Saddam Hussein visited Turkey and talked with Ozal and Prime Minister Yildirim Akbulut. Asked if the official mentioned the plan for oil reduction, Akbulut told reporters Monday: ``He said they had some measures they were planning to take and it appears this was one of them.'' Akbulut did not elaborate. In the talks Sunday, Turkey demanded Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait and reinstatement of Kuwait's deposed rulers. On Monday, Foreign Minister Ali Bozer again asked Iraq to heed world reaction and restore Kuwait's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The two pipelines run parallel for 620 miles from oilfields in northern Iraq to a terminal in Yumurtalik on the Mediterranean. Iraq's daily output is reportedly 2.7 million barrels, of which 1.5 million barrels would flow through Turkey. Now only about half that amount will be pumped through the Turkish connection, a BOTAS official reported, speaking on condition of anonymity. The shutdown of Kuwait's oil export facilities followed by the reduction in Iraqi output is expected to cause a shortfall in the world market of at least 4 million barrels daily, oil experts have said. Turkey will have no problems, the BOTAS chief said Monday, because it had completed most of its purchases from Iraq this year and has another part in storage tanks at the terminal. Turkey purchased 60 percent of its oil imports from Iraq last year. This year Turks, diversifying their oil sources, reduced the Iraqi share to 40 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Head to Mediterranean, Fort Bragg on Alert
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A force of 2,500 Marines are shipping out to relieve another Marine unit off war-torn Liberia's coast, military officials said Monday, denying reports the troops were headed for the Persian Gulf. Meanwhile, troops at the Army's Fort Bragg rapid deployment base have been put on alert. And a carrier battle group is scheduled to leave Atlantic ports on Tuesday for the Mediterranean in a deployment planned before the Iraqi invasion.said Lt.j.g. Cate Mueller, a spokeswoman for the Navy's Atlantic Fleet. The battle group of nine ships, including the aircraft carrier Saratoga, and 11,500 sailors is to sail Tuesday from Norfolk and Mayport, Fla., Mueller said. Four air squadrons from Virginia Beach will join the carrier off the coast. The 2,500 Marines from Camp Lejeune and the New River Air Station, including a helicopter squadron, are to depart Morehead City at noon Tuesday aboard ships of Amphibious Squadron 2, said 1st Lt. Colleen Ryan, a spokeswoman. The movement is not related to the crisis stemming from Iraq's invasion Thursday of the Persian Gulf nation of Kuwait, she said. The unit is scheduled for a six-month deployment in the Mediterranean, but will first replace a 2,200-member Marine unit from Lejeune and New River operating from a flotilla off the Liberian coast, Ryan said. Two rebel factions have been fighting the government of Liberian President Samuel K. Doe. Rebels on Monday seized 14 or 15 foreigners, including one American, and moved them to an insurgent headquarters outside the Liberian capital of Monrovia, the State Department announced. Early Sunday, a force of 225 Marines from the 2,200-member unit landed in Monrovia, and began evacuating Americans and other foreigners. The five ships of Amphibious Squadron 2 _ the USS Nashville, USS Inchon, USS Whidbey Island, USS Fairfax County and USS Newport _ left Norfolk, Va., on Monday morning for Morehead City, the Atlantic Fleet's Mueller said. Meanwhile, spokesmen at Fort Bragg and the Defense Department refused to comment on speculation that forces were being massed for possible use in the gulf region. Some Fort Bragg soldiers said units at their base have been on standby. Pfc. Cheryl Curtis of the 17th Military Intelligence Company said her unit has been on one-hour recall since Friday afternoon, meaning soldiers have one hour to report to duty stations if called. Members of the 82nd Airborne Division also were on one-hour recall, said Spec. David Lykens of the military intelligence company.

DOC.HEAD: Diana Enters Gulf, Strengthens Slightly After Soaking Yucatan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note that Cesar's location won't be updated until at least 11 p.m.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Diana slowed and picked up some strength in the Gulf of Mexico on Monday after soaking the Yucatan Peninsula but doing little damage. The government of Mexico late Monday afternoon issued a hurricane watch for the coast from Boca Jesus Maria south to Tuxpan, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Small craft were warned to remain in port from Baffin Bay, Texas, southward. At 9 p.m. EDT, Diana was centered about 270 miles east-southeast of Tampico, Mexico, near 20.7 degrees north latitude and 94 degrees west longitude. Maximum winds had increased slightly to 65 mph, and the storm was moving west at 12 mph. Gusty winds and heavy rains were expected along Mexico's Gulf coast well in advance of the westward moving storm, said hurricane specialist Bob Case. The storm hit the Yucatan at midafternoon Sunday about 70 miles northeast of Chetumal and well south of the popular resort of Cancun, causing only minor flooding. Meanwhile, tropical storm Cesar weakened to a tropical depression Monday in the mid-Atlantic. At 6 p.m. EDT, the center of Cesar was located near latitude 27.0 north, longitude 46.5 west, or about 1,15o miles east-southeast of Bermuda. It was west-northwest near 3 mph and was expected to continue through noon Tuesday. Maximum sustained winds were near 35 mph. A new depression formed Monday about 175 miles southwest of the westernmost Azores island, the hurricane center said. Tropical depressions become named storms if sustained winds hit 39 mph. They become hurricanes if the sustained winds hit 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Former Clerk Reads Marshall Speech
DOC.TEXT: Justice Thurgood Marshall could not attend an American Bar Association meeting Monday, but a former law clerk stepped in and delivered Marshall's speech calling for better legal protection for murder defendants. Marshall injured himself in fall in Chicago last week and was forced to return to Washington for treatment. Karen Hastie Williams, a former clerk and Washington lawyer, pinch-hit for the justice, delivering a speech in which Marshall said steps must be taken to provide competent lawyers for those facing execution if convicted. ``If not remedied, the scandalous state of our present system of capital punishment will cast a pall of shame over our society for years to come,'' he said. ``We cannot let it continue.'' Marshall opposes the death penalty under all circumstances, arguing it violates the Constitution's ban on cruel and unusual punishment.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Orders Embargo; Iraq `Cannot Be Frightened'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Thatcher blockade comment, Turkey saying it would cut off pipelines, Persian Gulf states consulted by U.S., other details; CORRECTS that foreigners rounded up included other than U.S. and Britain; TRIMS pvs; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CAI1, PAR1, TOK4, BON2, LOW1
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council on Monday ordered a worldwide embargo on trade with Iraq to punish the Arab oil and military power for its invasion of Kuwait. A defiant Iraqi leadership vowed to resist the economic and military pressure being marshaled by the United States. The Iraqi people ``cannot be frightened,'' Iraq's army commander said. The Security Council vote, 13-0, came on a U.S.-sponsored resolution and represented the first such total trade and arms boycott by the United Nations in 23 years. Two members of the 15-nation council, Cuba and Yemen, abstained. If successfully enforced, the sanctions could cripple the heavily oil-dependent Iraqi economy. In Washington, President Bush declared, ``These sanctions will be enforced _ whatever it takes.'' Britain's visiting Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said after meeting with Bush that the West would have to consider a naval blockade of the Persian Gulf if the U.N. sanctions proved ineffective. The vote in New York came on the fifth day of a crisis precipitated by the Iraqi army's blitzkrieg takeover of neighboring Kuwait. In occupied Kuwait, meanwhile, Iraqi troops rounded up some Americans, Britons and other foreigners Monday, but they appeared to be in no danger, British officials said. Tension remained high along the Saudi Arabia-Kuwait border. Saudi Arabian forces were reported moving northward into areas close by Iraqi units in Kuwait. Diplomats in the Persian Gulf _ in reports otherwise unconfirmed _ said U.S. rapid deployment units had been dispatched to the Middle East. In other developments: _In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney conferred with Saudi leaders about how to defend the oil kingdom against any attack by Iraq. The White House said it was discussing ``military possibilities'' with Gulf states to stop Iraqi aggression. _The U.S. aircraft carriers Independence near the Persian Gulf and Eisenhower in the Mediterranean Sea moved within range to launch warplanes to the gulf and as far as Iraqi targets, Pentagon sources said. _Major stock markets worldwide plummeted again, worried that an oil crisis could touch off a recession. Oil prices rose more than 10 percent Monday. Many motorists in the United States and elsewhere were paying sharply higher prices for gasoline. Iraqi tanks and infantry poured into Kuwait on Thursday after President Saddam Hussein complained that the Kuwaitis' violation of OPEC production quotas had driven down world crude prices, lowering Iraqi oil revenues. Saddam also accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a border oilfield both countries claim. Together, Iraqi and Kuwaiti output equals 9 percent of world daily oil production. The United States led the worldwide condemnation of the invasion as a threat to international order, and mobilized world governments to cut off oil and other business with Iraq. Bush says Iraq's ``naked aggression ... will not stand,'' and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday that ``the defense of Saudi Arabia is of paramount concern.'' But Iraq defied the diplomatic, economic and military pressure. In Baghdad, President Saddam summoned the U.S. charge d'affaires, Joseph Wilson, and ``warned against any act that might endanger the region's peace and security,'' the official Iraqi news agency reported. Iraqi army commander Saadi Mehdi Saleh was quoted by the Al-Iraq newspaper as saying Americans ``should understand that the people of the great leader Saddam Hussein cannot be frightened.'' Members of Saddam's ruling Baath Party said preparations were under way to evacuate all of Baghdad's 4 million people in case of U.S. air attack. They also said the party distributed weapons to tens of thousands of people throughout Iraq. State radio said Saddam had ordered formation of 11 new Iraqi army divisions, adding 100,000 troops to his 1-million-man military force, the strongest in the Arab world. Iraqi officials continued to dismiss suggestions Iraq has any intention to strike against Saudi Arabia. But the vastly outnumbered Saudi military was taking no chances. Oil executives in the northeastern Saudi city of Khafji, an oil-loading port near the Kuwait border, said Saudi ground reinforcements were moving into the area. The Iraqi invasion force had set up a checkpoint just a half-mile from the border near Khafji. In addition, Saudi military aircraft were sighted landing and taking off at airfields on the fringes of Riyadh, the Saudi capital, said local residents reached by telephone. Americans and Britons were among an estimated 366 people who were rounded up from hotels in Kuwait city by Iraqi forces and put aboard buses. They were apparently mostly passengers from a British Airways flight stranded in Kuwait, a British Foreign Office spokesman said. ``There is no evidence that they are in any way in trouble,'' he said. The Iraqi move did not appear to involve foreigners who reside in Kuwait, including about 3,000 Americans, the spokesman said. The State Department said 28 Americans were among those rounded up and said Iraq would be held responsible for their safety. ``It's premature to call them hostages,'' spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. Bush said Sunday he would ``do whatever is necessary'' to protect American lives. The U.S. Navy was dispatching another carrier force, led by the Saratoga, from the U.S. East Coast to the Mediterranean. A French missile frigate was en route to the Gulf to join two French warships already there. There was no immediate confirmation of diplomatic reports that units of the U.S. Rapid Deployment Force, organized for crisis duty in the Mideast, had been sent to the region. Meanwhile, Kuwait's ambassador to Britain said a resistance force was being organized among Kuwaitis living abroad. ``We will get back,'' Ambassador Ghazi Al-Rayes told reporters.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: told reporters.
DOC.TEXT: The growing anti-Iraq economic embargo produced its first results Monday, when Turkish officials reported that the Iraqis, fast losing customers for their oil, stopped pumping petroleum through one of two pipelines that cross Turkey, and reduced the flow in the second. A total cutoff of Iraqi oil flow through Turkey and Saudi Arabia ``is key'' to squeezing Saddam's government economically, the British foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, said in London. He said he believed the Saudis and Turks would take that step once the U.N. Security Council ordered a total embargo. In an interview with ABC News before the embargo vote, Turkish President Turgut Ozal indicated Turkey would close down the pipeline completely if the U.N. sanctions were ordered. ``We will obey the U.N. embargo,'' Ozal said. A flurry of diplomatic contacts continued among Middle Eastern governments trying to defuse the explosive situation. Prime Minister Mudar Badran of Jordan, whose King Hussein is trying to mediate a peaceful end to the crisis, arrived in Damascus to discuss the impasse with Syrian leaders. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat was in Saudi Arabia bearing a proposed peace plan under which, Egyptian newspapers said, Iraq would withdraw from Kuwait in exchange for Western financial aid. But more ominous notes also emerged. Iran's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, delivered a letter to Syrian President Hafez Assad from Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, and said upon departing from Damascus, ``We cannot remain idle toward this invasion.'' Iran fought an eight-year war with the Iraqis in the 1980s, and Syria has long quarreled with neighboring Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Electrical Storm Blasts Open Dozens of Tombs in Mausoleum Wall
DOC.TEXT: A mausoleum wall in one of the city's old cemeteries collapsed under the battering of a violent storm, scattering bricks and the contents of dozens of tombs across a Garden District sidewalk. The storm Sunday night knocked out a 30-foot stretch of the plastered wall in Lafayette Cemetery No. 1, across the street from Commander's Palace, one of New Orleans' premier restaurants. A clutter of bricks, skulls, bones and coffins pieces cascaded 10 to 15 feet into the street, said Bret Clesi of Save Our Cemeteries, a volunteer group that gives tours to raise money to restore New Orlean cemeteries. ``Fortunately, the wall vaults really haven't been used in years and years and years,'' Clesi said Monday. ``I would be surprised if there's been a burial in those wall vaults in 50 years,'' he said. ``The size is different than modern caskets, and many were not owned to begin with. The cemetery was almost deserted by the 1950s.'' The cemetery, a city-owned owned national historic landmark, was opened in the early 1850s. Only three standing graveyards are older, and all are owned by the Archdiocese of New Orleans, Clesi said. The wall contains a honeycomb of about 1,000 vaults roughly big enough to slide a coffin into. About 50 of the tombs were exposed by the collapse. New Orleans, which is below sea level, buries its dead above ground. Most of the vaults in the wall were used in the 19th century as temporary rental space until a family tomb could be built or opened, Clesi said. ``There was a sort of rule that tombs could not be opened within a year and a day after the last burial,'' he said. ``So if someone in a family died six months after a funeral, the family could rent one of these vaults and use it as a receiving vehicle until the tomb could be opened.'' City officials attributed the damage to lightning. But Clesi said he believed the wall was buckling before the storm pounded New Orleans with rain and hail, knocked down tree branches around the city and battered the air with nonstop thunder and lightning. ``I suspect they were water-soaked from the downpour. Vibration from the thunder may have done it. ... I sort of doubt it was in fine form and a bolt of terrific lightning sheared it away in one stroke,'' he said. The marble headstones inside the cemetery were undamaged. And there appeared little damage to the concrete and brick vaults themselves. Only seven of the tombs were marked. The rest had been closed in with plain marble tombstones in the 1960s and '70s, because the original stones were broken past repair. The most recent burial date was 1914; the others were all in the middle to late 19th century, including five family members who died from 1848 to 1888. Save Our Cemeteries has been trying for five years to persuade the city to turn over maintenance of the cemetery to the volunteer group.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Calls Bhutto Dismissal `Internal Matter' For Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Monday it regards Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's dismissal from office as an internal matter, but Democrats in Congress called for sanctions against that government. ``A constitutional change in government is an internal matter for the people in Pakistan to decide,'' said State Department spokesman Nancy Beck. ``U.S. support of further democratic development in Pakistan has been repeated many times.'' Congress was in recess but several Democrats issued strong statements and two, Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., and Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J., sent President Bush letters urging suspension of all economic and military aid to Pakistan under the U.S. law applying to any democratically elected government ousted by military coup or decree. ``In view of the armed forces' role in holding Ms. Bhutto under house arrest and controlling state television and telephone operations, I urge you to immediately suspend all economic and military foreign aid to Pakistan,'' Mikulski wrote in her letter.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the text of a joint statement Tuesday by the South African government and the African National Congress after talks on clearing the way for constitutional negotiations. The ANC agreed to halt its armed struggle against the white government: The Government and the ANC have held discussions at the Presidency, Pretoria, today 6 August 1990. The meeting has instructed the Working Group (on political offenses) to draw up a plan for the release of ANC-related prisoners and the granting of indemnity to people in a phased manner and to report before the end of August. In the interest of moving as speedily as possible towards a negotiated peaceful political settlement and in the context of the agreements reached, the ANC announced that it was now suspending all armed actions with immediate effect. As a result of this, no further armed actions and related activities by the ANC and its military wing Umkonto We Sizwe (Spear of the Nation) will take place. Both sides once more committed themselves to do everything in their power to bring about a peaceful solution as quickly as possible. Both delegations expressed serious concern about the general level of violence, intimidation and unrest in the country, especially in Natal. They agreed that in the context of the common search for peace and stability, it was vital hat understanding should grow among all sections of the South African population that problems can and should be solved through negotiations. Both parties committed themselves to undertake steps and measures to promote and expedite the normalization and stabilization of the situation in line with the spirit of mutual trust obtaining among the leaders involved. The Government has undertaken to consider the lifting of the State of Emergency in Natal as early as possible in the light of positive consequences that should result from this accord. The government will continue reviewing security legislation and its application in order to ensure free political activity and with the view to introducing amending legislation at the next session of Parliament. The Minister of Justice will issue a statement in this regard. We are convinced that what we have agreed upon today can become a milestone on the road to true peace and prosperity for our country. In this we do not pretend to be the only parties involved in the process of shaping the new South Africa. We know there are other parties committed to peaceful progress. All of us can henceforth walk that road in consultation and co-operation with each other. We call upon all those who have not yet committed themselves to peaceful negotiations to do so now. Against this background, the way is now open to proceed towards negotiations on a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Rocks Markets; Oil Companies Defend Price Hikes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 graf with Tokyo market falling sharply; picks up 4th graf pvs, `Companies and...
DOC.TEXT:
Panic over the Persian Gulf plunged the stock market in its worst one-day dip in almost a year Monday, and gasoline station owners, officials and consumer groups accused the major oil companies of exploiting the crisis by jacking up prices. Oil prices soared to a five-year high, and stock markets were shaken by panicky selling sparked by fears the consequences of the crisis could topple the teetering U.S. economy into recession. The Dow Jones average fell 93.32 points to 2,716.34, its steepest decline since Oct. 13, 1989, when the widely watched market barometer fell 190.58 points. The Tokyo market fell sharply for the third straight day upon opening Tuesday. Companies and some anlaysts attributed the soaring gasoline price increases over the weekend to higher costs, fluctuations on the frenetic oil markets and added demand during the summer driving season. ``This whole damn thing stinks to high heaven,'' said Rocco Gentilella, a Gulf service station operator in Freeport, N.Y. ``Why are they able to get away with it by raising the price of gas the way they have?'' ``There's no shortage of crude oil, there's no shortage of gasoline,'' said Lee Lauer, who heads a group of service station dealers in Kansas and Missouri. ``It's just a thing the refiners are doing to make extra profits.'' Random checks of gas stations around the country showed gasoline prices at the pump rising as much as 14 cents per gallon since Iraq seized Kuwait on Thursday. Prices for home heating oil also have risen sharply. The American Automobile Association said the average cost of self-service unleaded gasoline increased 11.1 cents from last Thursday to $1.186 per gallon, including a 7.1-cent jump over the weekend. The Interstate Commerce Commission said the average price of diesel fuel, based on a check of 16 stations nationwide, rose 8.6 cents to $1.186 per gallon Monday from last Tuesday. The American Trucking Associations, representing 4,000 motor carriers and trucking organizations, asked the ICC for authority to raise freight rates on one day's notice because of higher diesel fuel prices. Increases normally are allowed only on seven days notice. Pan American World Airways announced a 10 percent fare increase on all its flights to offset rising jet fuel costs. Northwest Airlines announced an $8 per ticket fuel surcharge on Friday. State officials in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Texas, North Carolina, New Jersey and Pennsylvania said they would investigate allegations of price gouging by oil companies. In Washington, a House panel set a hearing Tuesday on the price jumps. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said his department would gather information in the coming days about the rapid hikes. ``We just do not understand the basis for the price increases seen in the last several days,'' Skinner told the American Bar Association's annual convention in Chicago. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``It is not clear that all of the increases that have been reported at the consumer level are necessary.'' Gas station owners say they have little influence over prices set by gasoline distributors and refineries owned by the major oil companies. They contend the oil companies shouldn't be increasing their prices immediately because the higher-priced crude from the Middle East can take up to 90 days to reach the refineries, and theoretically the costs shouldn't be passed to consumers until then. Oil companies note that crude oil prices have shot up drastically since last month and the Iraq invasion of Kuwait is only the latest reason. Prices for the benchmark grade of crude exceeded $28 a barrel Monday, vs. $16 a barrel in early July. It was the highest level for the West Texas Intermediate crude grade since August 1985, when the price reached $28.08 per barrel.
``But retail prices have gone up much less,'' Texaco Inc. spokeswoman Anita Larsen said. ``Refiners are not yet recovering in the marketplace a significant portion of crude oil cost increases that they've already incurred.'' An embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil by the United States and Europe has reduced world oil supplies and increased demand, raising more pressure on prices. In addition, U.S. oil companies now purchase large amounts of gasoline on ``spot'' markets for immediate delivery, where prices can move rapidly. ``The marketplace is reacting to uncertainties in the near-term supply situation resulting from the Iraqi invasion and the sanctions,'' Exxon Corp. said in a statement. Industry officials said companies also are increasing the price at the pump now to cover for higher cost of replacing crude oil in the future if crude prices fall. ``This is not a major oil company phenomenon at all,'' said energy industry analyst Trilby Lundberg. ``It is a general refining capacity crunch in the summertime ... that ordinarily wouldn't hit us this hard except for the invasion of Kuwait.'' Citizen Action, a Washington consumer group claiming more than 1 million members, called the pump price increases ``blatant acts of economic aggression'' by large companies ``profiteering at a time of international tension.''

DOC.HEAD: Hanford Tank Releases Hydrogen Gas
DOC.TEXT: A radioactive waste storage tank that officials at the Hanford nuclear reservation fear might explode belched hydrogen gas, and the level of waste inside dropped, officials said Monday. Workers had been preparing to take a sample of the tank's contents but were waiting for the complex chemical reactions inside to create a ``burp'' to vent off hydrogen, said Westinghouse Hanford Co. spokesman Mike Berriochoa. Tank 101-SY, which is one of 177 tanks at Hanford containing waste from the production of plutonium for hydrogen bombs, vented at 5:30 a.m. Sunday, according to a company statement. No environmental contamination occurred, the company said. The gas is released through filters that trap any radioactivity, company officials have said. The venting caused waste in the 1 million-gallon tank to drop from a depth of 416 inches to about 411 inches by Sunday evening, and a slower decline continued, said Berriochoa. ``That's why we waited until after the burping, so we didn't risk running into a hydrogen bubble,'' Berriochoa said. The tanks at the reservation in south-central Washington are managed by Westinghouse for the Department of Energy. Earlier this year, Hanford officials said a buildup of hydrogen, ammonia and nitrous oxide in 20 of the 177 tanks had the potential to cause a fire or explosion. Efforts to reduce the danger have been stymied by a lack of knowledge about the chemical reactions occurring inside the tanks. Last week, Ron Bliss, Westinghouse vice president for waste management, said the company planned to insert a probe into tank 101-SY soon to gather waste samples that will take months to analyze. Venting has been occurring about every eight weeks and dates from 1979, Westinghouse said. The last venting occurred in April. Tank 101-SY is believed to contain the greatest hydrogen buildup because it has the greatest fluctations in waste depth. Bliss has suggested that might be the result of experiments in which large amounts of liquid were removed from the tank in the late 1970s in an effort to increase its storage capacity. Department officials have said the hydrogen buildup comes from organic matter in the tanks decaying, leaving the gas trapped beneath a hard crust on the surface of the waste. The double-walled tank has been under continuous scrutiny since the hydrogen buildup problem was announced in March. ``The risk of ignition of the hydrogen is considered to be low,'' Westinghouse repeated in its latest statement A critical report last week by the Energy Department's Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety raised questions of whether the risk of an explosion was as low as officials have contended. In a letter to Energy Secretary James Watkins, panel Chairman John Ahearne declined to characterize the risk of an explosion because of the lack of information. Ahearne said no one knows what chemical combinations are in the tanks and that unreliable temperature sensors may be misleading.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Charter Gives Council Powers To Impose Sanctions, Use Force
With AM-UN-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt and AM-UN-Charter-Text
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of the resolution on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait passed by the Security Council 13-0 Monday.

THE SECURITY COUNCIL, REAFFIRMING its resolution 660 (1990), DEEPLY CONCERNED that this resolution has not been implemented and that the invasion by Iraq of Kuwait continues with further loss of human life and material destruction, DETERMINED to bring the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq to an end and to restore the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait, NOTING that the legitimate Government of Kuwait has expressed its readiness to comply with resolution 660 (1990), MINDFUL of its responsibilities under the Charter for the maintenance of international peace and security, AFFIRMING the inherent right of individual or collective self-defence, in response to the armed attack by Iraq against Kuwait, in accordance with Article 51 of the Charter, ACTING under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations, 1. DETERMINES that Iraq so far has failed to comply with operative paragraph 2 of resolution 660 (1990) and has usurped the authority of the legitimate Government of Kuwait; 2. DECIDES, as a consequence, to take the following measure to secure compliance of Iraq with operative paragraph 2 and to restore the authority of the legitimate Government of Kuwait; 3. DECIDES that all States shall prevent: (a) The import into their territories of all commodities and products originating in Iraq or Kuwait exported therefrom after the date of this resolution; (b) Any activities by their nationals or in their territories which would promote or are calculated to promote the export or transshipment of any commodities or products from Iraq or Kuwait; and any dealings by their nationals or their flag vessels or in their territories in any commodities or products originating in Iraq or Kuwait and exported therefrom after the date of this resolution, including in particular any transfer of funds to Iraq or Kuwait for the purposes of such activities or dealings; (c) The sale or supply by their nationals or from their territories of using their flag vessels of any commodities or products, including weapons or any other military equipment, whether or not originating in their territories but not including supplies intended strictly for medical purposes, and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs, to any person or body in Iraq or Kuwait or to any person or body for the purposes of any business carried on in or operated from Iraq or Kuwait, and any activities by their nationals or in their territories which promote or are calculated to promote such sale or supply of such commodities or products; 4. DECIDES that all States shall not make available to the Government of Iraq or to any commercial, industrial or public utility undertaking in Iraq or Kuwait, any funds or any other financial or economic resources and shall prevent their nationals and any persons within their territories from removing from their territories or otherwise making available to that Government or to any such undertaking any such funds or resources and from remitting any other funds to persons or bodies within Iraq or Kuwait, except payments exclusively for strictly medical or humanitarian purposes and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs; 5. CALLS UPON all States, including States non-members of the United Nations, to act strictly in accordance with the provisions of this resolution notwithstanding any contract entered into or licence granted before the date of this resolution; 6. DECIDES to establish, in accordance with rule 28 of the provisional rules of procedure of the Security Council, a Committee of the Security Council consisting of all the members of the Council, to undertake the following tasks and to report on its work to the Council with its observations and recommendations; (a) To examine the reports on the progress of the implementation of this resolution which will be submitted by the Secretary-General; (b) To seek from all States further information regarding the action taken by them concerning the effective implementation of the provisions laid down in this resolution; 7. CALLS UPON all States to cooperate fully with the Committee in the fulfilment of its task, including supplying such information as may be sought by the Committee in pursuance of this resolution; 8. REQUESTS the Secretary-General to provide all necessary assistance to the Committee and to make the necessary arrangements in the Secretariat for the purpose; 9. DECIDES that, notwithstanding paragraphs 4 through 8, nothing in this resolution shall prohibit assistance to the legitimate Government of Kuwait, and CALLS UPON ALL STATES: (a) To take appropriate measures to protect assets of the legitimate Government of Kuwait and its agencies; and (b) Not to recognize any regime set up by the occupying power; 10. REQUESTS the Secretary-General to report to the Council on the progress of the implementation of this resolution, the first report to be submitted within thirty days; 11. DECIDES to keep this item on its agenda and to continue its efforts to put an early end to the invasion by Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Two Israeli Teen-agers Killed, Police Suspect Arab Nationalists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE injury toll; anti-Arab rioting worst since 1989; estimate that 10,000 Israelis involved in riots; new details; EDITS to conform; no pickup. ^By JIM RON
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of the bodies of two slain Israeli teen-agers prompted hundreds of Jews to take to the streets Monday, hurling rocks and yelling threats during anti-Arab riots. At least 22 people were reported injured. Earlier in the day, search teams discovered the stabbed and bound bodies of the two Israeli teen-age hitchhikers in a dry river bed in Jerusalem. Police said they suspect the two were killed by Arab nationalists. The riots that followed were the worst anti-Arab unrest since spring 1989, when two Israeli soldiers were kidnapped and killed by Arabs. Israel army radio estimated that 10,000 Jews were involved in rioting around Jerusalem. Most of the anti-Arab attacks were carried out by groups of dozens or hundreds, including many teen-agers and women. Hundreds of angry Israelis _ some chanting ``Death to the Arabs!'' _ blocked main highways in several Jerusalem neighborhoods, hurling rocks and cinderblocks at Arab-owned cars. The rioting continued into the night with scattered stone-throwing incidents and fist fights. Police bolstered forces in the city and canceled all vacations, saying they viewed the situation as an emergency. Police said 20 to 30 Arabs were injured, and a Jew was also hurt. They said a police officer was injured in an attack by an angry mob. Seven Israeli rioters were detained. Security forces clamped a curfew on one Palestinian village and searched other villages near where the bodies of the teen-agers were found, but there were no reports of arrests in the slayings. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir vowed that ``our hand will reach these mean killers.'' ``This cruel and evil murder ... is an expression of the deepest hate and despair of criminals who wanted revenge because they cannot kill all the people of Israel,'' Shamir added. Teen-age volunteers discovered the bodies of Ronen Karamani, 18, and Lior Tubul, 17, in a dry river bed near the Jewish neighborhood of Ramot in Arab east Jerusalem. Ramot is just inside the Jerusalem city limits and surrounded by the West Bank villages of Beit Hanina and Beit Iksa. Both bodies had multiple stab wounds, National Police Commissioner Yaacov Turner said. Tubul, who had a pink towel tied around his mouth, ran for about 70 yards after being stabbed, then collapsed and died, Turner said. Karamani, who had his hands tied behind his back, was pushed after being stabbed. He fell and died. ``The way they were tied down, the way they were stabbed points definitely to a political murder,'' Turner said. ``There was no reason to think that these two normal, good teen-agers were murdered for any criminal reason.'' Tubul and Karamani were last seen Saturday evening on the outskirts of Ramot. They had told friends they were headed to the West Bank settlement Givat Zeev to visit girlfriends. Turner said this was the second time within a month that hitchhiking Jewish teen-agers had been attacked. Late last month, two Israeli youths said a Palestinian picked them up and tried to kidnap them. The youths jumped out of the moving car. The slayings of Tubul and Karamani brought to 47 the number of Israelis killed in the 31-month Palestinian uprising. A total of 725 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians during the uprising. In addition, 245 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. At least two buses and dozens of car window were smashed in the anti-Arab rioting that followed the discovery of the bodies, police said. In one case, demonstrators trapped and stoned a Palestinian bus, forcing about 70 passengers to lie on the floor. One passenger suffered a bloodied head. Police stood nearby but did not detain anyone. In Beit Tzafafa, an Arab village in Jerusalem, a stone-throwing melee broke out between a crowd of Jews and dozens of Arabs armed with clubs and metal bars. Police said one Jewish woman was injured.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Confers With Saudis on Defense Against Iraqi Attack
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``Both Prime,'' with blockade discussion and reported Pentagon international naval proposal; SUBS graf 12: ``Both CBS,'' to delete captain's now-redundant first name ^With AM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney held sensitive talks with Saudi Arabian officials Monday about U.S. military options for defending the oil-rich desert kingdom against a possible blitzkrieg by Iraqi forces massed along its border with Kuwait. The U.S. aircraft carrier Independence and its escort of a dozen warships and supply vessels reached the Arabian Sea, putting the naval battle group close enough to launch air strikes against Iraq and other targets in the Persian Gulf. The Independence joined the carrier Eisenhower, cruising in the eastern Mediterranean, in the Middle East to guard against the possibility of expanded hostilities by Iraq, which seized Kuwait last Thursday. A third U.S. carrier, the USS Saratoga, will leave Mayport, Fla., on Tuesday for the Mediterranean. ``The defense of Saudi Arabia is of paramount concern,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, as Cheney began conferring with Saudi officials after an overnight flight from Washington to Jidda. ``Quite obviously, we are discussing a possible threat by Iraqi forces directly to that country,'' Fitzwater said. ``... It's quite clear that would involve appropriate ways to defend their country.'' Added the White House spokesman: ``We have discussed military possibilities and our abilities with all the countries in the gulf.'' Both Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada said after talks with President Bush that a blockade might prove necessary to halt Iraq's oil trade. The Washington Post said in Tuesday editions that the Pentagon had sent the White House a proposal for an international naval force, including vessels from the Soviet Union, to be activated if desired to enforce trade sanctions. A Pentagon spokesman, Air Force Capt. Sam Grizzle, said he had no information on such a proposal. One U.S. military official, who spoke only on condition that he not be identified, said Cheney's talks with the Saudis are crucial to U.S. hopes of halting further aggression by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The official said it would be difficult to carry out a major air strike in the Persian Gulf without overflight or landing rights from friendly nations in the region. Some assistance is available from Bahrain and Oman, he said, but those gulf states are loathe to acknowledge cooperation with Americans. Such cooperation enabled the reflagging of Kuwaiti tankers and escorts by U.S. naval vessels during the height of the eight-year war between Iraq and Iran. Both CBS and NBC said in their evening news broadcasts that FB-111 bombers from U.S. bases in England were seen in Turkey, at Incirlik air base some 425 miles from the Iraqi border. It was these planes that bombed Libya in 1986. A Pentagon spokesman who was not identified told NBC it was coincidence the planes were in Turkey. Asked about the reports, Capt. Grizzle told The Associated Press, ``We do not discuss operational movements or the alert status of forces, particularly at a time like this.'' Other Pentagon sources, however, said the Strategic Air Command was conducting a world-wide exercise, ``Giant Warrior,'' announced on July 15, and reports of U.S. bombers in unfamiliar places could be expected. Cheney's talks with the Saudis centered on direct U.S. assistance in the event of a full-scale Iraqi invasion, as well as options for possible U.S.-Saudi military cooperation. Cheney accompanied by U.S. Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commands U.S. forces in the Mideast; deputy national security adviser Robert Gates, and Paul Wolfowitz, undersecretary of defense for policy. Fitzwater described the situation in the Gulf as ``extremely serious'' and there was no evidence Iraq had fulfilled its promise to begin withdrawing its military forces from Kuwait on Sunday. Officially, the Pentagon would say only that the Independence was operating in the Indian Ocean and was being escorted by eight smaller warships and four support ships. Three additional support craft loaded with fuel and food are shifting to the region to boost U.S. supply lines, officials said. Carriers are outfitted with a range of F-A-18 Hornet jet fighters, F-14 Tomcat attack aircraft, A-6E Intruder bombers and specially outfitted KA-6D jet planes assigned to carry out airborne refueling of fighters and bombers. Meanwhile, five Navy amphibious vessels headed for Camp LeJeune, N.C., to pick up 2,100 Marines for a rendezvous with the Saratoga in the Mediterranean. The battleship Wisconsin was scheduled to leave Norfolk, Va., on Tuesday to join the Saratoga, which is expected to take at least a week to reach its new duty station. Three other vessels will leave Norfolk on Tuesday for what an Atlantic Fleet spokesman called ``previously scheduled deployments'' with the battle group. Four air squadrons from Virginia Beach will join the Saratoga. Altogether, the departing naval vessels will be carrying more than 15,000 sailors and Marines. The Eisenhower and its 12 escort ships are steaming in the eastern Mediterranean, Pentagon sources said, while the eight-ship Middle East Task Force led by the command ship LaSalle remains in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Patients Hurt by Restrictive Drug Policies
DOC.TEXT: Health maintenance organizations are risking patients' lives by cutting costs on prescription drugs, according to a national survey of doctors commissioned by the Oregon Medical Association. ``Cost is affecting quality. Quality is being sacrificed,'' said Dr. Michael Graham, president of the Oregon Medical Association. The telephone survey of 700 physicians, including 200 in Oregon, was conducted by the Gallup Organization in January and the results were released Friday. Graham said Monday the survey of cardiologists, internists and general practitioners showed they were concerned about limits on the way they prescribe drugs. ``What it amounts to is the HMOs and other managed-care organizations are restricting the choice of medications,'' Graham said. ``It restricts the ability of the physician to prescribe what's necessary.'' Graham said nine doctors in the survey reported that a patient had died because of cost-cutting practices by HMOs. ``I can't give you the details on those nine deaths,'' Graham said, ``but the physicians felt that the restrictions or lack of availability of a drug led to the death of the patient.'' He also blamed those practices for slowing the recovery of millions of Americans suffering from various health problems. Larry Freshnock, vice president of health care research for Gallup, estimated drug prescription restrictions already may have affected 2.7 million people, based on the survey. However, a spokesman for one of the largest HMOs in Oregon said the medical association's claims were exaggerated. ``This could scare a lot of people,'' said Ron Morgan, spokesman for Blue Cross of Oregon, which operates Health Maintenance of Oregon. ``From our experience with these practices, we haven't seen any problem with the quality of care,'' Morgan said. ``You have to balance cost containment with finding a way to make drugs available to everyone, but you just don't sacrifice quality of care.'' Health maintenance organizations attempt to hold down medical costs by paying doctors a fixed amount no matter how many services they provide, rather than a fee for every service. Managers of HMOs also try to hold down costs on medical equipment, supplies and drugs by seeking the least expensive source. Among the restrictions opposed by doctors and cited in the study were: _Therapeutic drug interchange, a policy that requires pharmacists to substitute less expensive drugs when possible, despite differences in chemical ingredients. _Prior authorization, which requires physicians affiliated with HMOs or other managed-care plans to obtain approval before prescribing certain drugs. _Step-care protocols, a practice that forces doctors to prescribe drugs in a fixed order, using lower-priced drugs first and more expensive or advanced drugs later. _Mandatory generic substitution, which requires pharmacies to substitute chemically identical generic drugs for brandname drugs. Morgan said that therapeutic drug interchange is illegal for outpatients in Oregon, and Health Maintenance of Oregon does not use step-care protocols. Morgan also said the Blue Cross HMO does not have a mandatory generic substitution policy and its formulary is only a recommended list. Representatives of other state and national HMOs said they could not comment on the survey because they had not seen it. The most common problem resulting from drug policies, according to the study, was slower recovery from illness, followed by failure of the drug to work. Other problems cited by doctors in the survey were allergic reactions, heart problems, pain, nausea and convulsions. ``I don't think they're trying to implicate any particular drug or a particular class of drugs,'' Graham said. ``The main point of the study is that we think that employers and companies should be cautious about signing contracts with restrictive policies.''

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lankan Military Says Tamil Separatists Kill 23 Villagers
DOC.TEXT: Military officials said Monday that Tamil militants shot and hacked to death 23 Moslem villagers in eastern Sri Lanka in the second attack on the Moslem community in three days. They said rebels of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam raided three adjoining villages in Ampara district on Sunday and rounded up the villagers before killing them. No independent confirmation or rebel version of the government account was available. Most communications were severed after the Tigers broke a 13-month truce on June 11 and resumed their 7-year-old war for independence in Tamil-dominated territory in the north and east of this Indian Ocean island nation. On Friday, gunmen stormed two mosques at Kattankudi village in eastern coastal Batticaloa district and killed at least 140 worshipers, the government said. It blamed Tamil Tigers. The militants accuse the Moslems of siding with the Sinhalese-dominated government. The Moslems say they are neutral. The officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said all the victims were farmers. Their bodies were dumped in paddy fields, they said. Mohammad Ashroff, leader of the opposition Sri Lanka Moslem Congress party, said, ``All the dead had their hands tied behind their backs and were either shot or cut with swords.'' The killings took place in Addalachena, Oluvil and Palamuna villages, about 125 miles east of Colombo. In other fighting, at least 35 Tamil rebels and three government security men were killed Sunday, the officials said. They said 12 rebels were killed when naval gunboats destroyed a fiberglass dinghy trying to land on a beach of northwestern Mannar town, and two more rebels were killed in the north in a landmine explosion. Two policemen and a soldier were killed when rebels fired mortars, rockets and small arms at a military-held fort in Jaffna town, the officials said. Helicopter gunships straffed rebel positions, killing at least 21 guerrillas, they added. About 14,000 people have been killed since 1983 when Tamil rebels took up arms, claiming they were discrimnated by the majority Sinhalese in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language. Tamils form 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese make up roughly 75 percent, and Moslems 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: New Crossbred Owl Appears in Northwest Forests
DOC.TEXT: Scientists in Oregon and Washington have discovered two cases 600 miles apart in which a rare northern spotted owl has bred with the more common and aggressive barred owl, producing a new hybrid. Biologists don't know whether the crossbreeding is an isolated quirk of nature or the first sign of evolution into a new owl species. But the barred owl is a much hardier owl, and there have been concerns that the growth in its range could threaten the survival of the spotted owl, listed as a threatened species in June. The first ``sparred owl'' was confirmed about two weeks ago near Mount Baker in the northern Cascade Range in Washington, said Eric Forsman, who leads a U.S. Forest Service spotted owl research team. The second was confirmed Wednesday east of Medford in southwestern Oregon. ``I don't know where it's going to lead us,'' Forsman said. ``Nobody does.'' The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's designation of the spotted owl as threatened cast doubt on the future of logging in old growth forests, the bird's sole habitat. The barred owl appears similar to the spotted owl, except that it is somewhat larger, has vertical bars on its chest instead of brown and white spots and is paler. The more aggressive barred owl can live in a variety of forest types. There are only about 2,000 known pairs of spotted owls. The barred owl is common in the United States and Canada. Only in the past 15 or 20 years, however, has the barred owl expanded its range south from British Columbia into Washington, Oregon and Northern California, where the spotted owl lives. The barred owl's ability to thrive in logged areas of the Pacific Northwest probably explains its invasion of the region, biologists say. That ability, its aggressive behavior and similar prey make the barred owl a competitor with the potential for cutting the spotted owl population, a Fish and Wildlife Service review team said in its recommendation to designate the spotted owl as threatened. Forsman alerted biologists two weeks ago to the first confirmed hybrid, a male adult found by Washington state biologist Tom Hamer. ``A very strange looking bird!'' Forsman wrote. He said it looked like a pale spotted owl, but weighed a little more than 1{ pounds, more than a male spotted owl. ``His call is intermediate between a barred and spotted owl. It goes, `Hoo ... hoo-hoo ... hoooawww!''' The last note is characteristic of the barred owl, Forsman wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of July 30-Aug. 6:
DOC.HEAD: Newsrooms Should Hire More Minority Journalists, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers should hire minority journalists to reflect the country's racial composition, the vice president of the National Association of Black Journalists said. ``America is browner and tanner and is going to continue to be in the future,'' said Denise Johnson at the association's annual convention Aug. 2. Hiring rates for minorities have increased little in recent years, according to a report by the American Society of Newspaper Editors released at the convention. The report said that 4 percent of newsroom employees, including reporters, editors, artists and photographers, were minorities in 1978, compared with 7.86 percent this year. Blacks now account for 4 percent of the newsroom population, the highest percentage among all minority groups. ``If you look at the percentages and how slowly the industry has moved to respond to a very rapidly changing population, the progress isn't nearly as impressive,'' said Johnson, an editorial writer and columnist for the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press. The report also said that 4 percent of newspapers across the United States employ no minorities. ``Most institutions in this country are still pretty much dominated by white middle-age males and I think the tendency on their part is to look out over the staff of people they direct and take under their wing a person who reminds them of themselves,'' Johnson said. Editors surveyed by the ASNE said the most frequent reasons for not hiring more minorities include the lack of qualified journalism graduates, poor starting salaries and a lack of commitment to affirmative-action hiring. The study queried more than 300 newspaper editors, said Cornelius Foote Jr., minority affairs director of the ASNE. On another front, Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder said negative media focus on the private lives of black politicians does not mean there is a white conspiracy against leading blacks. Recent stories, including those on the drug trial of Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry, only leave that impression, Wilder said. Wilder himself has been the focus of stories saying he has used a state helicopter to spend weekends with socialite Patricia Kluge. ``If I thought that there was a conspiracy, I couldn't exist,'' Wilder said. ``I couldn't have existed in the courtroom where, being an African-American lawyer, I was asking for justice from a jury that was all white and judges who were all white. But I found justice.'' Wilder called for journalists to go beyond problems of the black community and focus on problems that blacks and whites have in common. ``We do the public a disservice _ we limit our perspective _ if we think of ourselves as `black' officials or as `black' journalists,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Paper Sues to Keep State Out of Labor Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: The New York Daily News filed suit Aug. 1 to stop the state from intervening in contract negotiations between the newspaper and its 10 unions. The lawsuit in Manhattan's federal court seeks to dissolve a fact-finding panel appointed by state Labor Commissioner Thomas Hartnett to help the two sides reach agreement. It also asks for a court order stopping the panel from taking any immediate action in the labor negotiations. The unions, under the umbrella of the Allied Printing Trades Council, requested the state board of inquiry because they said they weren't getting a fair shake in the negotiations over contracts that expired March 30. The Daily News said actions by the board of inquiry, which has the power to subpoena witnesses and gather evidence, would cause ``substantial and irreparable harm'' to the newspaper. ``This action will exert governmental and public pressure on the Daily News and the unions in an undue and unwarranted attempt to coerce or otherwise improperly influence a resolution of the labor dispute and negotiations,'' the lawsuit said.
DOC.HEAD: Buffalo News, Guild Settle Contract
DOC.TEXT: The Buffalo News and the Newspaper Guild reached tentative agreement on a new four-year contract calling for 5 percent pay raises each of the first three years. Talks on economic issues would be reopened in the fourth year. Health insurance was the main issue in bargaining before the Aug. 2 agreement. The News agreed to pay $300 for each employee with individual coverage and $600 per employee with a family plan into a special fund on Jan. 1. That fund will be drawn down over the next two years to cover the employees' 20 percent share of any increase in health insurance premiums, said Robert McCarthy, president of Local 26 of the Newspaper Guild. A cost-saving ``cafeteria-style'' health plan will go into effect in 1994 and any money left in the fund at that time will revert to the Guild. Also in the contract are new provisions for job security for non-editorial employees, family leave and a new section on professional standards that covers such topics as libel suits and dealings with confidential sources. The Guild represents nearly 400 of the News' 1,100 employees. The News is owned by Berkshire-Hathaway Inc. of Omaha, Neb., which is controlled by investor Warren Buffett, who also owns stock in the Washington Post Co.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: News Employees File Third Liability Lawsuit Against Computer Company
DOC.TEXT: Atex Inc. has been sued for a third time by news employees who claim they were injured while using the computer company's keyboard and video display terminals.
