A $210 million lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan claims Atex ``knew or should have foreseen'' that users of its computer systems would develop repetitive strain injuries or cumulative trauma disorders. The lawsuit said Atex failed to adequately warn workers of ``the risks, dangers and harm'' resulting from exposure to its product. Two similar lawsuits against Atex were filed in June _ one by eight journalists from five different organizations and the other by four employees of Newsday and New York Newsday. The new lawsuit was brought by two employees of the New York Daily News, Margaret Kleinman, a copy editor, and Joseph Bulfaro, a supervisor; Kathy Sizemore, an assistant news editor at Newsday; Domenica Trevor, a copy editor at American Banker; Darcy Reid Trick, a reporter for USA Today, and Jennifer Paradis Hagar, a typesetter at People Magazine. The husbands of three of the journalists also are plaintiffs, saying they suffered ``loss of consortium, companionship, services, society and support'' as result of their spouses' injuries. A call for comment to Atex was not immediately returned. Previously, the company said it would not comment on pending litigation.
DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Purchases 50 Percent of Spanish Daily
DOC.TEXT: The Times Mirror Co. said it has agreed to purchase 50 percent of La Opinion, one of the nation's largest Spanish-language daily newspapers. Executives of Times Mirror, parent company of the Los Angeles Times, and La Opinion said Aug. 2 that the two Los Angeles-based newspapers will maintain separate staffs and operations. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. ``Through the partnership with the Times Mirror Co., we can continue to strengthen the newspaper, expand its coverage and make it even more relevant to the lives of our readers,'' said Jose Lozano, La Opinion's publisher. The partnership is ``something that's been under consideration for some time,'' said David Laventhol, president of Times Mirror and publisher of the Times. ``The Latino community is an increasingly important part of our readership.'' Federal antitrust officials must review the agreement before it is final. A board of directors will be formed to oversee the partnership, with a majority of seats filled by representatives of La Opinion, which is owned by Lozano Enterprises of California. The Spanish-language daily has been a family-controlled operation since it was founded in 1926 by Lozano's grandfather. It has a daily circulation of about 100,000. El Nuevo Herald of Miami, published by The Miami Herald, claims a daily circulation of 102,000, and almost 118,000 on Sundays. The Times has a daily circulation of about 1.2 million and about 1.5 million on Sunday.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Says Newspaper Treated Him Unfairly
DOC.TEXT: The only black federal judge in the city accused The Pittsburgh Press of being racist by trying to force him from the bench. Senior U.S. District Judge Paul Simmons made the accusation during a hearing July 26 in which he was asked by John Bingler, attorney for the Press, to remove himself from a lawsuit against the paper. The Pittsburgh Press obtained a copy of the transcript of the 35-minute hearing. ``I think it's a case of pure racism, that's what I think,'' Simmons said during the hearing. ``The way I've been treated is just scandalous by The Pittsburgh Press.'' He criticized the newspaper and Bingler before agreeing to remove himself from the case. Alan Frank, an attorney convicted of tax evasion and fleeing Pittsburgh to avoid prosecution, filed the lawsuit in September against the newspaper, Allegheny County police and a McKeesport attorney. The lawsuit will be assigned to another judge. Frank charged in his suit that the newspaper libeled and defamed him by conspiring with two county detectives to damage his reputation by printing a false story that he stole money from his son. In a motion, attorneys for the Press said the newspaper alleges Simmons ``has a personal bias or prejudice against it due to articles and editorials which it has published in the past.'' The motion cited articles and editorials about the judge, including an article in April in which he was quoted as accusing a woman of being greedy and vengeful for suing her ex-husband in a child-custody case. The local bar association filed a complaint in connection with the comments. The Press published an editorial criticizing Simmons, 68, for the comments he made and suggested he retire.
DOC.HEAD: `Doonesbury' Controversial Again
DOC.TEXT: Some editors are taking a close look at a ``Doonesbury'' comic strip in which a character clad in nothing but rope utters provocative language. ``Frankly, it didn't offend me, but I'm thinking of all the people out there,'' Jim Hughes, executive editor of the Baton Rouge Morning Advocate@State Times, said Aug. 1. The strip by Gary Trudeau features the character J.J. giving her rendition of ``performance art'' with a bucket over her head and nothing but rope covering her privates. She speaks in fragmented sentences laced with words with sexual connotations such as ``ooze,'' ``lubricate'' and ``hot juices,'' but makes no direct reference to sex acts. The strip is scheduled for release from Aug. 6 to Aug. 11. ``The way I read it, it's an attempt to show the lengths that the art community will go to thumb their noses at government grants,'' said Jack Morrissey, an associate editor at Universal Press Syndicate, which distributes the strip to about 1,000 newspapers. Morrissey said Trudeau appeared to be referring to controversy over National Endowment of the Arts funding. Some conservative politicians have tried to block government money going to artwork they consider obscene. Morrissey said several editors had called with questions about taste and the reason behind releasing the strip. But no paper indicated that it would pull the comic, he said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Ms. Magazine Publishes First Ad-Free Issue
DOC.TEXT: Eight months after suspending publication, Ms. magazine returned to newsstands July 30 without advertising. The magazine also has a slightly new name, Ms.: The World of Women, which its backers say better reflects its worldwide scope. Subscriptions are priced at $40 a year for six issues that will appear bimonthly. The newsstand price is $4.50. Industry analysts have expressed doubts about the magazine's chances for survival without advertising. They say the relatively high price will discourage some readers, and that the topics Ms. made its reputation on are now covered adequately in other mass magazines.
DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Hail End of Most Censorship Rules
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers that once trumpeted government propaganda hailed the end of most censorship rules Aug. 1. ``Goodbye, censorship,'' read a headline in Izvestia about the Soviet Union's first press freedom law, which guarantees broad rights for journalists and potential publishers. ``Almost everything was forbidden, even mention of the existence of (the censorship agency) Glavlit itself,'' said Izvestia, the main government newspaper. ``The truth was the main secret.'' Editors wrote that the guarantees won't stop attempts at interference overnight. The government can still censor articles construed as calling for the violent overthrow of the government, promoting racial or religious intolerance, or publishing propaganda for war, violence or cruelty. In addition, the shortage of newsprint and its increasing costs could be a major barrier for independent publications.
DOC.HEAD: Israel Denies Paying for Favorable Radio Reports
DOC.TEXT: Two journalists claim that some radio reporters working free-lance for foreign stations accepted money or favors from the Foreign Ministry. The gifts were said to be in exchange for pro-Israel stories packaged as independent news items. The two, speaking July 30 on condition of anonymity, said the free-lancers worked out of a Jerusalem recording studio that has close ties with the ministry. The ministry denied the allegations, but said it suspended all ties with the studio lest ``some aspects of the current arrangements ... be misconstrued as involving a conflict of interest.'' The New York Times reported that ministry officials secretly channeled money to the studio to pay the reporters' salaries. It also said Israeli diplomats abroad helped the free-lance reporters recruit radio clients in major locations. One Jerusalem-based radio reporter told The Associated Press the ministry paid the studio fee of $75 per hour for some free-lance reporters who otherwise would have to cover the expense themselves. In return, ``sometimes they (ministry officials) ask the reporters to publish certain information,'' the reporter said. Another broadcast journalist said some colleagues working for foreign stations accepted money from the ministry in exchange for stories favorable to Israel packaged as independent news reports. The ministry said it has worked with the studio for years, commissioning programs on current events and other subjects that are distributed by Israeli embassies abroad. It said the programs were ``distributed by us and in our name.'' The ministry claimed that it decided to suspend ties with the studio on July 18 _ 10 days before it was first asked by The New York Times about the relationship.
DOC.HEAD: Editors Condemn Intimidation
DOC.TEXT: The Editors Guild of India condemned what it called growing intimidation by gun-toting militants threating to kill editors who refuse to publish their statements. The guild said July 31 that newspaper editors in the state of Punjab were forced at gunpoint to print the full text of a 21-page letter by Sikh militants seeking independence from India. The statement also cited cases last year when gunmen killed an unspecified number of newspaper vendors in Punjab for selling papers hostile to the militant cause. Other cases of death threats were reported in Kashmir, where Moslems are seeking to break away from the Indian federation, and by separatists in the far eastern state of Assam. The guild, the smaller of two professional associations of editors in India, represents about 100 newspapers.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Chung Wants Baby
DOC.TEXT: Connie Chung said July 29 that she's putting her new television series on hold while she tries to become pregnant. The move marked the second time this year that a female anchor of a network news series has opted for a family over a show. ``We want very much to have a child,'' said Chung, who is married to ``A Current Affair'' anchorman Maury Povich, 51. ``Unfortunately, time is running out for me when it comes to childbearing.'' CBS said it would welcome ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' back as a series when the 43-year-old anchorwoman is ready to return. Earlier this year, NBC's Maria Shriver left the ``Sunday Today'' show she had co-anchored since 1987, saying she wanted to spend more time with her baby daughter and her husband, actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, in Los Angeles.
DOC.HEAD: TV Service Being Launched in Pediatrician's Waiting Rooms
DOC.TEXT: A video program that lets advertisers reach patients in doctor waiting rooms could be in 2,500 locations by the end of the month, its director says. Healthlink Television debuted Aug. 1. The executive overseeing it, David Moore, said TV sets and video disc players were placed in 100 pediatricians' offices in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Plans are to expand nationally to 5,000 doctors' offices by the end of September and 20,000 by early 1991, he said. Doctors will be given a one-hour program on a laserdisc that is to be played continuously on the TV system during the business day. The program will focus on health care topics with up to nine minutes of commercials _ each two to four minutes long _ per hour between program segments. Healthlink Television is the first of two commercially-sponsored video programs that are being produced for audiences in medical waiting rooms. Healthlink is a subsidiary of Hearst-ABC-Viacom Entertainment Services, a joint venture of Capital Cities-ABC Inc., the Hearst Corp. and Viacom International Inc. The other video program is Special Reports Television, being produced by Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., and debuting in October. Whittle is half-owned by the entertainment giant Time Warner Inc. Both services are aimed principally at mothers visiting the doctor either for themselves or with their children. They are the latest example of media vehicles developed to enable advertisers to reach narrowly defined audiences. Similar programming includes the Channel One news show for teens in the classroom, programs for women at the beauty parlor and a news show for shoppers in the grocery checkout line.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Inquirer Editor Roberts Retires
DOC.TEXT: Eugene L. Roberts Jr. announced July 31 he is retiring as executive editor and president of The Philadelphia Inquirer, effective Sept. 1. Succeeding Roberts will be Maxwell E.P. King, an Inquirer editor for 15 years until his promotion in 1987 to vice president for consumer marketing and distribution. He was promoted to senior vice president in 1988. King's title will be editor of the Inquirer and executive vice president of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. Roberts planned to work as a consultant to the Knight-Ridder newspaper group and possibly to teach. The Inquirer is a Knight-Ridder newspaper. Son of a weekly newspaper editor, Roberts, 58, joined the Inquirer in 1972 and led the newspaper to 17 Pulitzer Prizes in the last 16 years along with more than 150 other national awards. He began his career as a farm reporter for the Goldsboro (N.C.) News-Argus. He also worked at The Virginian-Pilot of Norfolk, Va.; The News and Observer of Raleigh, N.C.; and the Detroit Free Press before he joined The New York Times. Roberts was national editor at the Times after covering the 1960s civil rights movement and the Vietnam War for the newspaper. He became president of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., which publishes the Inquirer and the rival Daily News, in 1986.
DOC.HEAD: McCutchen Named Editor and Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Glenn McCutchen, executive editor of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, has been named editor and publisher of The Nacogdoches Daily Sentinel. The announcement was made July 31 in Atlanta by David Scott, vice president of Cox Newspapers, which bought the Daily Sentinel last year. McCutchen, 46, joined the Columbus Ledger as a reporter in 1966 and went to the Constitution as a reporter that same year. He became executive news editor of the Atlanta Journal in 1978, and deputy managing editor of the Atlanta newspapers when their news staffs were combined in 1982. McCutchen was promoted to executive editor last year.
DOC.HEAD: Cody to Publisher, Editor at Americus Times-Recorder
DOC.TEXT: C.J. Cody, circulation manager of The Daily Citizen-News in Dalton, was named publisher and general manager of the Americus Times-Recorder on Aug. 1. Cody replaces Keith Blevins, who goes to the Dalton newspaper as general manager and publisher. Both companies are owned by Thomson Newspaper, Inc. Rudy Hayes, managing editor of the Dalton newspaper, moves to the Times-Recorder as editor.
DOC.HEAD: Trussell to Greeley Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Dave Trussell, publisher of The Tahoe Daily Tribune in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., was named publisher of The Greeley Tribune on Aug. 1. He replaces Richard Larson, who leaves to devote full attention to his post as general manager for Swift Newspapers Inc. of Carson City, Nev., which owns both properties. Trussell started at the Daily Tribune as a reporter after working as a journalist in the Army. Larson came to the Tribune from The World in Coos Bay, Ore.
DOC.HEAD: Sun-Times, Tribune Appointments
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Sun-Times has named an executive of the St. Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press as its senior vice president of consumer marketing and distribution. Thomas L. Foster, 41, was assistant to the president and publisher at the Pioneer Press.
DOC.HEAD: McCormack to Senior Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Evelyn McCormack, assistant managing editor-features for Gannett Westchester Newspapers, has been appointed senior managing editor of the nine-paper group. She succeeds Barry Rothfeld, whose was earlier promoted to executive editor of the Poughkeepsie Journal.
DOC.HEAD: Wayne Gay to Production Director
DOC.TEXT: Wayne Gay, publisher of the Baxter Bulletin in Mountain Home, Ark., has been named production director of the Asheville Citizen-Times. Gay, 55, started his newspaper career in the production department of the Moultrie (Ga.) Observer in 1951. He moved to the Baxter Bulletin in 1981 as business manager and two years later was named publisher, guiding the newspaper's transition from weekly to daily publication.
DOC.HEAD: Bolt Named Texas News Editor
DOC.TEXT: John A. Bolt, business editor in the Dallas bureau of The Associated Press, was named news editor for Texas on Aug. 1. Bolt, 38, succeeds Sue Cross, who became Illinois news editor. He joined the AP in Atlanta in 1983, became the bureau's night supervisor two years later and was appointed to the new position of Texas business editor in Dallas last year. He previously worked on newspapers in South Carolina for the Greenville News-Piedmont Co., and the Anderson Independent-Mail.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: James Stanford Bradshaw, a former Associated Press correspondent and college journalism teacher, died of cancer Aug. 2. He was 68. Bradshaw joined the Associated Press in Detroit in 1949 after working for the Grand Rapids Press and the Ann Arbor News. He worked in Argentina and Brazil from 1951 to 1955, reporting on the Cuban Revolution, Eva Peron's funeral and President Dwight D. Eisenhower's trip to Latin America. After his Latin American assignment, Bradshaw worked for the AP in Washington before joining the U.S. Agency for International Development for six years. Bradshaw joined the faculty at Central Michigan University as an assistant professor in 1969, teaching advanced reporting and journalism history courses. He retired from the school in 1983. Survivors include his wife, three daughters and a son, a brother and two sisters.

L.J. ``Bud'' Maher, former publisher of the Huron Daily Plainsman, died Aug. 4 after a long battle with cancer. He was 72. Maher began his career with the newspaper in 1946 as advertising salesman and moved to advertising manager before becoming associate publisher and then publisher. He served as president of the South Dakota Press Association from 1978 to 1979. In 1987, the Journalism and Mass Communications Department at South Dakota State University honored Maher for outstanding contributions to journalism. Survivors include his wife and four children.

Nixon Smiley, an author and roving reporter who chronicled Florida history, died of cancer July 29. He was 78. Smiley's 13 books described the history and ecology of Florida, focusing on offbeat characters and rural life. After a stint in the Navy, Smiley worked as a teletypist with The Associated Press and went to work for The Miami Herald in 1940. He was the newspaper's gardening reporter from 1947 to 1963 and later moved to feature writing. Survivors include his wife, son, four grandchildren and uncle.
DOC.HEAD: Rowan To Get Neuharth Award
DOC.TEXT: Columnist Carl T. Rowan will receive the Allen Neuharth Award for Excellence in Journalism at the University of South Dakota on Oct. 19. The award is made possible through a grant from the Gannett Foundation. Neuharth, a South Dakota native and graduate of the school, is former chairman of Gannett Co. Inc. and head of the foundation.

After National Enquirer reporters started asking her colleagues if she seemed troubled lately, Joan Lunden told ``Good Morning America'' viewers on July 31 that she's not suffering from any personal problems. ``It was a pre-emptive strike,'' she said afterward. ``I told them I could either do that or just be a wimp and sit back and let them make up whatever they want and print it.''... From APME's Newsroom Management Committee comes this request to members for a continuing studies report: ``We are continuing our search for the perfect editor for the 90s. If you know of any such person (other than yourself) please contact ....''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Hiroshima came to a halt for a moment today in observance of the world's first atom bomb attack, which leveled this bustling coastal city 45 years ago. For an eery moment, the city fell silent, automobiles stopped and people throughout this industrial center of one million residents joined in a moment of prayer to comfort the souls of the 140,000 people who died frm the bomb. ``I pay my deep respects to the citizens of Hiroshima who have built this city of international peace from the ashes,'' Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said in an address to a crowd of 55,000 at a commemoration ceremony. ``As the only country in the world to have experienced an atom bomb attack, Japan has resolved not to let it be repeated with our three non-nuclear principles and our calls for total nuclear disarmament and everlasting peace.'' The United States dropped the atom bomb on Hiroshima, a major military center, during World War II, on August 6, 1945. The bomb wiped out nearly half the 300,000 people who lived in the city, killing most immediately. Many others died within months from radiation, burns and other afflictions.

The domestic textile industry and its workers are portraying themselves as sacrificial lambs in the administration's jockeying to reduce foreign trade barriers to U.S. exports. Casting itself as a victim is nothing new for an industry that has lost 30 percent of the American textile and clothing market and about 400,000 jobs to foreigners in the 1980s alone. In the past decade, the foreign share of the U.S. fiber and apparel market has climbed from 28 percent to 60 percent. As a result, 1,500 domestic plants have been closed and U.S. employment in the industry has dropped 25 percent. The industry blames a wide variety of economic and political forces:

Legislation to create a Department of the Environment to give new focus to environmental issues brought nothing but cheers six months ago, but now the proposal is mired in turf wars and its future is in doubt. The administration cooled toward the idea after the House passed a bill it didn't like. Legislation has languished for months in the Senate with no indication when it might be scheduled for a floor vote. ``I think at the moment it's sort of stalled,'' said Sen. William Roth, R-Del., one of the key sponsors of the bill introduced in January to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee who has pushed the EPA Cabinet issue, said he hasn't given up hope.

Republicans are putting Wyoming's nickname as the Equality State to the test this year, asking residents to elect their second woman governor in state history. Two women are vying for the GOP nomination in the state's Aug. 21 primary, hoping for a shot at first-term Democrat Mike Sullivan, who is one of the most popular politicians in heavily Republican Wyoming. ``Wyoming touts the slogan that this is the Equality State. I'll have to run on that premise,'' Nyla Murphy, one of the GOP contenders, says. ``We had the first woman governor in our nation's history, I see no reason why we couldn't have another woman governor.'' Her GOP rival is Mary Mead, who says her life on a ranch has more than prepared her for the governor's office.

The Air Force has spent hundreds of millions of dollars on gold-plated chandeliers, golf course projects and other luxuries to boost morale, internal Pentagon documents show. Back in 1985, the Air Force decided to refurbish its officers' club at the Mildenhall base in Britain at a cost of $75,000. The service's champagne taste, however, hardly matched the appropriated amount. Gold-plated chandeliers valued at $145,000 were installed, solid oak paneling lined the walls and fireplaces with marble fixtures completed the decor. The final tally was more than $2 million with U.S. taxpayers picking up the tab. The internal Air Force audits, conducted in April and May of this year, reveal widespread waste and abuse in the Air Force management of its Morale, Welfare and Recreation Activities.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv 07
For Release PMs Tues Aug 07 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Want Action on S&L Mess? Start an Investigation
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: When politicians face a problem issue with no easy way out, their instincts often create an urge to investigate. Or at least to demand an investigation. That way they are advocating action, even if it isn't a solution. That's happening now in the savings and loan mess. The bailout price is going up, the voters are getting angry, and the only solution is to keep spending money Congress doesn't want to appropriate and taxpayers don't want spent. But that is the unavoidable bill for decisions made a decade ago, coming due in a congressional election year. So campaigning incumbents are being forced into an unpopular position, and that puts a premium on votes that seem to do something about it. Something like investigating, and supporting legislation to impose stiff sentences on people convicted of savings and loan crimes, with life terms for kingpins _ laws that can apply only to future wrongdoing. As with punishments, so with payments. The past is not subject to reform, and the costs _ estimated as high as $500 billion _ stretch on for years. The administration has alerted Congress that it will need more money, probably about $100 billion, to pay for the savings and loan bailout during the budget year that begins Oct. 1. That is particularly uncomfortable timing, five weeks before congressional elections, so it may be handled with a stopgap appropriation until early 1991. That prospect produced a chorus of congressional complaints about blank check spending. To which Robert R. Glauber, the treasury official dealing with the S&L crisis, replied that the blank check was written long ago, when deposit insurance was boosted to $100,000 an account. That was done by act of Congress in 1980, during the Carter administration. Then, and in another measure enacted in 1982 and signed by Ronald Reagan, the rules were changed to let savings and loans make investments far more speculative than the home mortgages that had been their business. With more insurance on deposits, and less regulation of a savings and loan industry that already was having problems, the meter started running up the costs the taxpayers face now. When insured institutions fold, depositors have to be paid. ``We don't really have a choice,'' said L. William Seidman, the man in charge of the bailout. But what can't be changed can be investigated. So the National Governors' Association adopted a resolution urging an investigation of ``this unprecedented disaster'' by an independent commission. A measure seeking a commission investigation has been proposed in the Senate. The House approved creation of a million-dollar bipartisan commission to investigate the S&L mess, as part of a bill to speed prosecution and stiffen punishments for S&L crimes. There were only four votes against it. The administration didn't like the idea, with a White House spokesman saying there was no need for a new bureaucratic entity to investigate. But after the overwhelming House vote, the administration decided it would not oppose an investigation. That makes a commission investigation a virtual certainty, satisfying the political urge to be seen doing something about the S&L mess before election time. A skeptical senator says the findings of an investigating commission are predictable and he wonders about its value to the taxpayers, but he'll vote for it anyhow. But Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., said that is less important ``than knowing what is going on today, right now,'' in a bailout he contends is being mismanaged. Investigations, some by commissions, some by Congress, can and have served vital purposes. The Warren Commission did so after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, even though conspiracy theorists still dispute its finding that a lone gunman murdered the president in 1963. The Senate Watergate committee discovered the existence of the White House tapes that sealed the case against Richard M. Nixon and ultimately led him to resign the presidency in 1974. After the Challenger disaster of 1986, the Rogers Commission conducted an inquiry that otherwise would have drawn contentions, competing investigations in Congress. In the savings and loan debacle, said Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois, ``We already know the answer.'' Thompson opposed the investigation the governors sought. He is not running for another term.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: For Cold War Junkies, a Berlin Wall in Manchester
DOC.TEXT: Nostalgic for Checkpoint Charlie? Miss those snarling East German border guards? Cold War junkies, despair not: The old days live on in Manchester. The real Berlin Wall may be vanishing, but its English replica, complete with mock-nasty guards, stands firm for the tourists at Granada TV Studios in the northwest city. When it went up two years ago to honor Granada's spy series ``Game Set and Match,'' based on the Len Deighton trilogy, its architects never dreamed it soon would be old hat. ``We're keeping it as a piece of history,'' said Marina Efstathiou, public relations officer for the 90-minute tour of Granada's sets. The tour, similar to those which have been conducted for nearly two decades at Universal Studios in Los Angeles, has attracted one million visitors since it opened for business July 20, 1988. Granada's graffiti-smeared Berlin Wall hoves into view between Sherlock Holmes' Baker Street and Coronation Street of British soap opera fame. The Edwardian tram carrying 40 tourists stops, and the atmosphere becomes bleak. Two men in Berlin border guard uniforms board the upper level of the tram. One of them, tall and blond, demands my briefcase and admonishes me for smiling. ``Don't laugh,'' he barks in German-accented English while his companion, short and dark, glowers at his side. ``It will give you wrinkles in later life.'' Returning my briefcase, the two move on, and the tour resumes on foot. Granada, which charges 6.95 pounds (about $12) for the tour, has adapted the wall experience to keep pace with history. When the Cold War was for real, there were guard dogs and tourists got frisked. Now such niceties are reserved for corporate clients who specially request them. ``We used to pick up dad and take him off the tram and children would say, `Don't take my daddy away.' We would threaten to lock people up,'' recalled Roy Stonehouse, the Yorkshireman who designed the tour. After the wall opened, ``We toned it down, obviously,'' he said. Stonehouse said he tried to acknowledge the geopolitical change by carving a hole in his wall after the real one opened last November. ``It wasn't very successful,'' he said. ``It looked as if the mice had been at it.'' ``Game Set and Match,'' starring Ian Holm, was a 13-hour series filmed partly at the real Berlin Wall and partly on a studio set. It was the first time permission was given to film on location at Checkpoint Charlie. The wall serves a practical purpose as well, screening off the adjacent Science and Industry Museum whose visitors otherwise would be able to gaze down at the Granada Tour for free. That unpleasant border guard turned out in an interview in the replica Checkpoint Charlie hut to be Gareth Williams, 20, an amiable college student. ``We've had one or two comments like, `It doesn't exist anymore,' but there's nothing you can say to that,'' Williams remarked during a break between tramloads of tourists. ``There's a lot of patriotism that comes out. People still get a buzz out of it,'' said Terry Holm, 26, a drama student at the Manchester Polytechnic theater school. ``It seems to me the public are here to be entertained basically, aren't they?'' said Williams, whose mother is a Berliner. Visitors seemed to take this bit of history in stride. ``I can handle it,'' said Paul Russell, from Basingstoke near London. ``I enjoyed it,'' said Irene MacPhee, a Canadian tourist from Calgary, adding, ``I bet they've had to change their dialogue in the last year.'' And besides, imitation East German guards are nothing compared with Granada's own security. ``Excuse me; what paper do you represent? Who have you OK'd it with?'' snapped a Granada official, who emerged out of nowhere to challenge a reporter taking notes. After explanations, her tone softened. ``We have to be very careful because of press leaks,'' she said with a smile, and vanished. __ Elsewhere in television... EMMY AWARDS _ THE FACTOID: Ten of last week's 361 prime-time Emmy award nominations were for ... other award shows. This year's Oscar awards show was nominated for five Emmys, ``The 17th Annual American Music Awards'' for three, and Broadway's Tony awards show was tapped for two, one of them for the show's hostess, Angela Lansbury. She also was nominated for best-actress honors for her ``Murder, She Wrote'' work.

DOC.HEAD: Girl's Death in Gate Causes Debate of School Practices
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf `Hosoi has' to update with teacher charged. ^By S.L. BACHMAN
DOC.TEXT: Ryoko Ishida is dead because she was a few seconds late in slipping through the school gate. Television programs provide constant reminders of the tragedy by showing the closing of the quarter-ton gate of the Kobe Takatsuka High School, which crushed the 15-year-old's skull. Her death caused an outcry by critics who feel Japan's acclaimed secondary education system is far too rigid. Parents and educators generally defend the rules. Miss Ishida was killed July 6 by the school gate in Kobe, a port city 270 miles west of Tokyo. A teacher, Toshihiko Hosoi, 39, pushed the gate shut promptly at 8:30 a.m. to teach the children a ``lesson'' about promptness. Hosoi has been fired and charged with professional negligence resulting in death. Other school and education officials have been disciplined. Commentators and human rights groups blame the death on overzealous application of strict rules. At a minimum, schools require students to wear uniforms. These often are sailor-type dresses for girls and black Prussian-style outfits for boys. Some prescribe white socks and even white underwear, crewcuts for boys and pageboy haircuts for girls, with black hair bands. Students at many schools are not allowed to patronize coffee shops or obtain drivers' licenses. Rules even describe exactly what a student may bring to school and list what is banned, such as playing cards and hair dryers. ``In some schools, if you go from your neighborhood to a neighborhood where there is another high school, you have to bring your high school identification card,'' said Seiji Fujii, a writer whose frequently criticizes the rules. Enforcement usually is strict. Teachers patrol neighborhoods, inspect students at the school gate as they arrive, and search book bags and luggage. Punishment often ranges from humiliating to violent. Students were buried in sand up to their necks in one recent case and corporal punishment is widely practiced, although it has been illegal since World War II ended. ``Teachers often slap, punch, kick,'' said Morikatsu Imahashi, an opponent of corporal punishment who teaches at Ibaraki University in Mito, 60 miles northeast of Tokyo. Imahashi demonstrated with his hands how teachers sometimes clap their hands suddenly over students' ears. Fujii, the writer, said the practice broke the eardrum of a friend. Five deaths from corporal punishment were reported in 1985-1987. After a student's death in 1988, the Education Ministry advised schools to ease their rules. A few students have filed lawsuits, including a Tokyo senior expelled from a private high school for waving her hair, said Yasuhiro Yoshimine, a lawyer active in children's rights issues. In Kobe, where about 30 percent of junior high and high school boys are required to wear crewcuts, more than 3,000 names of individuals and groups appeared in a March newspaper advertisment against the rule. Rebellion can be costly. Adverse comments on obedience might show up in the secret record that follows a student from grade school and helps determine whether he or she will get into high school or win a job recommendation. ``In Japan, if the parents insist on their rights, they will be called strange, a problem,'' said Yoshimine, the lawyer. In Japan's homogeneous society, being seen as different or a problem is a major stigma. ``It can be tough,'' said Kurumi Tanabe, a 40-year-old mother from the Mito area. ``I got many letters criticizing me, saying the idea is bad, that I should have my son cut his hair.'' Kentaro Tanabe, 14, is one of four in a 1,000-student middle school who refuses to wear a crewcut. Some students crack under the strain. Newspapers occasionally carry reports of students beating their teachers, and many who refuse to attend school blame strict rules. Strong regulations are popular with teachers and school authorities. In a 1988 survey, 95 percent of middle-school teachers responding agreed with the statement that ``disorderly attire is a sign of mental disorder.'' Atsuo Nomura, principal of Kobe Takatsuka told students after Miss Ishida was killed: ``If all of you had woken up 10 minutes earlier, the teacher would never have had to raise his voice. I don't mean to put the responsibility on your side, but now I still want all of you to improve your life habits.'' Nomura later resigned. ``Parents generally believe stricter rules mean better education,'' said Tetsuo Tsujimura, who directs the Education Ministry's middle-school division and feels some rules are too strict. Critics say tough school regulations and rigid curriculums suffocate individual differences and hurt Japanese education. Strict rules were adopted by schools in the 19th century. Enforcement eased in the 1960s, but tightened again in the early 1980s in response to unruliness among teen-agers. Yoshimine and others say the strict regulations reflect authoritarian attitudes left over from prewar militarism. Since April, the Education Ministry has required schools to display the national flag and play the unofficial national anthem, both symbols of the prewar years, at entrance and graduation ceremonies. News reports have linked rigid education with grisly crimes, such as the case of four boys who kidnapped, raped and beat a high school girl, then encased her body in a drum of concrete. At the sentencing last month, their lawyer blamed an ``ailing society'' for the boys' actions.

With BC-APN--Pop Myths
DOC.TEXT: Imagine John, Paul and George making music without Ringo. Ben, Little Joe, and Adam running the Ponderosa without Hoss. The Cowardly Lion, the Tin Man and the Scarecrow off to see the Wizard without Dorothy. Unthinkable! Would we have loved the Beatles, the Cartwrights and the Oz gang as trios? Perhaps. But author Harold Schechter, an expert on myths in popular culture, thinks it's likely some of their magic would have been lost. Quaternity, the mythic union of four characters into a single, cohesive unit, often results in ``an invincible psychic totality,'' says Schechter, a professor of English at Queens College in New York. Swiss psychiatrist Carl Gustav Jung defined the special power of four in terms of four functions of consciousness working in balance and harmony: sensation, thinking, feeling and intuition. ``The Beatles spoke of themselves as being four parts of a single personality,'' Schechter says. Mythically speaking, they were right. ``The literate, sardonic Lennon stood for thinking; Harrison _ deeply immersed in Eastern mysticism _ for intuition; the romantic, androgynously pretty Paul McCartney, for feeling; and the clownish Ringo, with his puppy-dog charm, for sensation. ``Together these four musicians constituted an astonishingly creative and dynamic entity; separated from one another, however, they seem to have lost most of their artistic power.'' Other famous foursomes break down as follows, Schechter says: Sensation was a function shared by Hoss, the Cowardly Lion, and Scotty, chief engineer of the Starship Enterprise. Thinking was the role of Ben Cartwright, the Scarecrow and the logical Mr. Spock. Feeling fell to Little Joe, the Tin Man and Enterprise physician ``Bones'' McCoy. And intuition was the realm of Adam, Dorothy and Captain James T. Kirk.

DOC.TEXT: As chairwoman of the Japan Socialist Party, Ms. Doi, 61, helped draw many women into politics last year after veteran politicians came under fire for money and sex scandals, including the alleged keeping of paid mistresses. The new female politicians made some inroads in their campaign against money politics and against a sales tax that squeezed the purses of Japan's traditional family spenders, the housewives. A record 22 women won seats in Parliament's upper house in the July 1989 elections, and 12 were elected to the lower house in February. Before the two elections, about half that number were in Parliament. Seeking to placate angry female voters, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who succeeded two scandal-tainted leaders, named two women to his first cabinet last August. But Kaifu's second cabinet, named after the February election, was all male. Females still account for less than 5 percent of Parliament's 764 members. And most women legislators belong to the opposition, which has little chance of passing laws on women's issues in the face of the big majority held by the Liberal Democratic Party. The conservative governing party did not run a single woman candidate in last February's election for the more powerful lower house of Parliament. Economic trends have done more to create opportunities for women than politics. Enterprising female entrepreneurs are finding niches in new businesses, ranging from computer software engineering to household and catering services that have emerged to meet the demands of working mothers. The growing influence of women as consumers _ both professionals and traditional holders of the purse strings _ is leading companies to listen more to women employees and generating new opportunities for career-oriented women. A growing labor shortage also is opening doors, especially in computer-related industries, says Tomoko Shibata, executive director of the Japan Institute of Women's Employment. ``Even if companies don't really want to employ women in mainstream jobs, they simply have no choice,'' Mrs. Shibata says. ``They're so desperate for good people they feel it's worthwhile to hire women even if they're likely to quit when they have families.'' Japan's major electronics companies are energetically recruiting female college graduates for specialized technical jobs, and some are developing child care programs so that those women can return to work as soon as possible. In a groundbreaking decision, the managements of those companies agreed this spring to labor unions' demands for a one-year unpaid leave for childbearing, up from the current eight weeks' leave required by law. Ms. Higuchi, a frequent participant in committees on women's issues, says she believes such a policy will spread throughout Japan in the next few years. But merely providing lengthier maternity leaves will not solve the real problems facing the Japanese family, she says. ``Japanese companies treat men as if they were bachelors, without any family responsibilities other than a paycheck. They might as well be bachelors, given their lack of real involvement in their families,'' Ms. Higuchi says. Most Japanese men spend their waking hours outside the home _ working overtime, socializing with business associates and commuting two to four hours a day. They leave decisions on education, child rearing and household spending to their wives. ``It's unnatural for a society to leave no room for families. We have to make it possible for men to share the responsibility for bringing up children,'' Ms. Higuchi says. ``The way things are now, many married women are virtually running single-parent households.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR`S NOTE _ An American missionary family makes its home in Thailand as protectors of the Mlabri _ one of the world's smallest and most primitive tribes.

The Spirits of the Yellow Leaves, some of the world's most primitive and timid tribal people, have found protection from an unlikely source: an American missionary family. Eugene Long, his wife Mary and their three children have lived among the Mlabri for nine years. While their goal is to Christianize, the Longs have yet to bring up God or the Bible. Their more immediate task is to ensure the tiny tribe's survival and bridge a vast gap between these hunter-gatherers and the 20th century. There are fewer than 200 Mlabri in Thailand. A small number is also believed living deep in the forests of neighboring Laos. The Thai population has decreased over the past decade and Long says further shrinkage would probably mean the tribe's extinction. Not long ago, all Yellow Leaves roamed the jungles in small family groups, eating wild fruits, roots and any animals they could snare or spear. In Laos, they may still live this way. Myths spread about these furtive people, who were said to move their homes each time the leaves of their flimsy shelters turned yellow. They wore little more than loincloths and used crude implements of a prehistoric age. Their language, which has no written form, identifies just three colors _ green, red and blue; does not distinguish between a month and a year, and provides for a counting system that includes only the words for ``one,'' ``two'' and ``many.'' The first known outsider to meet and study the group was Austrian anthropologist Hugo Bernatzik who made contact in 1937. Danish scholar Jesper Trier described them as technologically among the most primitive people on Earth, ancient remnants of Australoid tribes overwhelmed by the great Mongoloid migrations into Southeast Asia from the north. When Long first encountered the Yellow Leaves he had images of cannibals feasting on missionaries, while some of its members later confided they thought he had come to eat them. His trail to the tribe had been circuitous. At 14, Long was a self-described ``hood'' with a police record. The turning point came after a close brush with death from alcohol abuse. After graduating from high school near Orlando, Fla., he joined the New Tribes Mission, which works with remote, little-known tribal groups around the world. At its school he met his wife, who is from Muscatine, Iowa, and the couple were sent abroad. The family moved to the hills of Phrae Province in northern Thailand. Their rough, wooden home is located in a lovely valley, a three-mile trek from the nearest village. The house has no refrigerator or window panes and no television to distract Allen, 14, Jared, 11, and 7-year-old Crystal from their studies, done by correspondence. Staying healthy is a problem; Long has suffered two bouts with malaria. Initially, the Mlabri _ which translates as ``People of the Jungle'' _ came and went. Their faces would be expressionless. The women and children would run away when Long approached. They lied or refused to talk about themselves and their culture, even after the Longs became the first known outsiders to speak their language. ``The lives of the Yellow Leaves are ruled by fear _ fear of human enemies, tigers, disease, the spirits of their animist world,'' Long said. ``They themselves are passive. Resolution of conflict is flight.'' But the widespread disappearance of Thailand's once great forests has shut off their escape hatch and most of their traditional sources of livelihood. Waiting for them as they came out of the jungles were the Hmong, a large, more aggressive and technologically sophisticated tribe. Long says the Hmong treat the Yellow Leaves ``like slaves,'' luring them with pigs _ their great dietary obsession _ and then forcing them to work off their ``pork debt'' under appalling conditions and for abysmally low wages. Now, 25 of the tribespeople are living in simple, leaf-roofed huts on hillsides around the Long home, and much of their suspicion and fear seems to have subsided. The family provides meals, medicine and basic first aid; the Yellow Leaves are given wages for work that ultimately benefits them. Long paid the equivalent of $750 to acquire squatter's rights over several hundred acres of land on which the Yellow Leaves have planted fruit trees, sunk fish ponds and reforested denuded strips of hillside with teak trees. Pigs are raised. Long is aware of criticism leveled by some anthropologists that his kind of involvement leads to ``detribalization'' of people like the Mlabri. ``I want to preserve aspects of their culture. Ideally, I would want them to live in undisturbed forests and have them come out to see us when they needed help,'' he counters. ``But that doesn't seem possible now, so we want to give them a fair chance in today's world. In order to be Yellow Leaves, do they have to be slaves of the Hmong and die of malaria? Do they have to be extinct? If so, then yes, I am ruining them.'' Unlike some foreign missionaries in Thailand, the boyish, 35-year-old Long and his family, all of whom have informally taken Thai names, get favorable coverage from the Thai press. Long says the support he has received from Phrae provincial authorities and the Thai military has been good, although the Thai government does not have a formal program to help the Yellow Leaves. But serious problems remain, he says, in neighboring Nan province where the majority of the Mlabri live and where exploitation by the Hmong continues.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Eagles fly again above the Great Lakes, but they are dying faster than they can reproduce. The majestic birds are victims of high levels of the same poisons that wiped them out of the area 20 years ago.

More than two decades after the oily Cuyahoga River caught fire, after Lake Erie was declared dead and DDT was banned, eagles again soar above the Great Lakes. They are not doing well. Yearly, they return to try to colonize the contaminated shoreline. And yearly, scientist Bill Bowerman climbs to their nests to remove the unhatched eggs. In the dead embryos and in the blood of surviving eaglets, the Michigan State University researcher sees high levels of the same poisons that wiped eagles out of the Great Lakes 20 years ago. The birds are dying faster than they can reproduce, Bowerman says. For them and more than a dozen other animals that feed on Great Lakes fish, the shore is a zone of death and deformity. It's a red flag warning, Bowerman says, ``a sign of what's happening to everything in the food chain.'' The bald eagle is a perfect example, said Conservation Foundation researcher Dr. Theodore Colborn in Washington, D.C. Up and down the inland sea, from cold, deep Lake Superior to the roiling St. Lawrence River, wildlife scientists tell of shore birds born with twisted beaks, clubfeet and stomachs outside their bodies. They tell of whales wracked with cancers and diseases, of expanses of beach where mink have vanished, and of eagles that can barely reproduce. In a report to the U.S.-Canadian International Joint Commission last year, Colborn listed 16 predator species whose shoreline populations have dropped in association with high toxin levels. The killer is silent. Pesticides such as DDT, mirex and dieldrin and toxins such as PCBs and dioxin persist in the mucky lake sediments despite 20 years of cleanup efforts. The toxins are picked up by worms and leeches and travel up the food chain, from smelt to trout to gulls to eagles. The concentrations of poisons increase 10 times at each level. Contamination levels vary from lake to lake, but there are basin-wide warnings for humans to limit the sizes and kinds of Great Lakes fish they eat. Fish contamination in some areas has dropped because of controls and bans on toxins pumped into the lakes by industry. Researchers say it will be a century or two before the vast lakes shed the poisons they have absorbed. Meanwhile, the eagles try to return. Bowerman's research shows Michigan eagles on lakes Michigan and Huron are reproducing at less than half the rate of those who nest inland. A pair must raise one chick a year to keep the population stable. Lake Huron eagles have one chick for every three nests. After five years of eating Great Lakes fish _ the time when inland birds reach their reproductive peak _ shore bird reproduction in Michigan falls to one chick for every seven nests. Wisconsin's only Lake Michigan eagle nest, near Green Bay, has not produced a chick in four years. Another pair on the Straits of Mackinac near St. Ignace has not produced a chick in eight years. In the Hiawatha National Forest in Michigan's untamed Upper Peninsula, prime eagle territory, seven shoreline eagle pairs went three years before one of them produced a chick this year. The eagle has made a remarkable comeback inland. Michigan, with 150 inland nesting pairs, has surpassed its federally set goal of 140 pairs. Minnesota reports 390 inland pairs and Wisconsin has 336, according to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. In the three states, the eagle is classified as threatened, not endangered. Bowerman believes that as those healthy eagles fly to the shore, their stunted efforts to reproduce are sapping the entire population. There are no nests on Lake Ontario, the most contaminated of the Great Lakes. The Canadian side of Lake Huron is barren. Five of the eight U.S. Great Lakes states _ Illinois, Indiana, Pennsylvania, New York and Minnesota _ have no eagles on their shores. ``There's some beautiful land there,'' Bowerman said. ``I don't know why. I don't know what the flow is from the pulp mills in Canada. I don't know where it's all coming from.'' He lost nine nests on Lake Superior this year. The parent birds have vanished. Tim Kubiak of the Fish and Wildlife Service in Lansing said the eagles' problems are a sign of the poor health of the entire Great Lakes basin, the world's largest freshwater system. ``Growth problems, retardation, smaller head sizes, lower birth rates ... we see it in mink, the birds,'' Kubiak said. They are clues to the health of shore-dwelling humans. The toxic problems show no signs of abating. This spring, a research team found 22 deformities in cormorant chicks in Wisconsin's Green Bay colony _ a deformity rate of 1 in 72 where 1 in 10,000 would be the norm. Last year, Bowerman tested a Saginaw Bay eaglet with 2.25 parts per million of PCBs in its blood. The 5-week-old Lake Huron chick carried contamination 100 times higher than inland eaglets. Like other Great Lakes researchers of terns and whales and mink, Bowerman is unable to say what the toxins actually do inside the bodies of their subjects. ``We're seeing messages from the environment, indications that there are problems,'' New York biologist Robert Foley said. His work shows elevated PCB concentrations in Lake Ontario mink _ when he can find them. He thinks the toxins and the population problems are related, but he has yet to prove it. Eight years of analyzing the blubber of dead beluga whales beached in the St. Lawrence River have given Canadian researcher Pierre Beland a chemical catalog of the lakes. The dead whales' ailments run an odd list of cancers and diseases previously unseen in belugas. Yet Beland cannot explain what is happening to the living whales. Why do some of them have bent spines? Why are St. Lawrence belugas failing to recover despite a ban on commercial hunting? ``We're simply hoping the population will hold out until things get cleaner,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: After 20 years as an actor, Michael Moriarty says, he thought it was time to settle down and get a steady job. Moriarty, a jazz pianist and composer who moonlights on the stage, television and movies _ or maybe it's the other way around _ stars in his first television series this fall. He won a Tony Award for his role in ``Find Your Way Home'' and Emmys for ``The Glass Menagerie'' and ``Holocaust.'' One of his most memorable parts was in the 1974 movie ``Bang the Drum Slowly,'' as the ballplayer whose friend, played by Robert De Niro, is dying. He's also starred in such movies as ``Pale Rider'' and ``Hanoi Hilton.'' Moriarty is well known to those who frequent clubs in New York for his jazz work on the piano. Five years ago, he turned to composing. Moriarty plays a New York prosecutor in NBC's ``Law and Order,'' a one-hour drama that follows a case in a quasi-documentary style from investigation to trial. ``I thought I was mature enough to finally do a series,'' he says with a slight smile. ``I thought a steady job would suit me fine. I'm as happy as a clam at high tide.'' Moriarty portrays an assistant district attorney. George Dzundza and Christopher Noth are the detectives and Richard Brooks is Moriarty's fellow prosecutor. The show also stars Dann Florek and Steven Hill. ``This reminds me of `Naked City,''' says Moriarty, who's completed 13 episodes. Like ``Naked City'' in the 1950s, ``Law and Order'' is filmed on location all over New York City. ``We tell stories. The six of us take you through the lives of other people, played by New York actors. It captures the very rich fabric of the city. I play Ben Stone, who's in a state of evolution. ``The more I play him the more he gets like me. The only difference between us in the beginning was that he had a steady job. Now I have a steady job.'' Moriarty says ``Law and Order'' doesn't show personal relationships. ``So it's hard to show a man in his profession when he has no personal life,'' he adds. ``You have to find a hook. I tried to flirt, and they got all upset. I want Ben to take his job seriously, but not himself. Sometimes he does, and I have to pull him back. We have to open up the show and bring in a woman character.'' Moriarty, nevertheless, is lavish in his praise of the series and those people connected with it. ``I liked this show and I liked the fact that Joe Stern was the co-executive producer,'' Moriarty says. ``I felt good about that. Joe's been an actor in the theater. We'd never worked together, but we were professional friends. When you sign on a series for five months, let alone five years, you need to feel at home. I feel very comfortable. Joe knows every actor in New York, and we're getting those wonderful faces.'' He says the show looks at many issues, including vigilantes, alcoholic doctors, abortion, euthanasia, AIDS and racism. Moriarty lives with his wife and son in New York. He grew up in Detroit, attended Dartmouth and went to the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts on a Fulbright Scholarship. He began his acting career in off-Broadway shows and in regional theater, including four years at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. He made his movie debut in ``Glory Boy'' in 1972. His portrayal of a hockey player charged with manslaughter in the CBS movie ``The Deadliest Season'' led to his Emmy-winning role as a Nazi SS officer in ``Holocaust.'' Although ``Law and Order'' is his first series, he has done guest roles before. He's been on ``Hotel'' and ``Cagney & Lacey,'' and a role on ``The Equalizer'' brought him an Emmy nomination. Moriarty has played piano in New York's jazz clubs for many years. In 1985 he began composing for chamber orchestras, string quartets and piano and violin solos. His first album, ``Reaching Out,'' was released earlier this year. He also did the score for a television movie. ``I think Ben Stone might play the piano or conduct a chamber orchestra in a future episode,'' says Moriarty. ``But if he does, it won't be my own music. MCA demands all rights to the music.'' The series is made in association with MCA's Universal Television.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``The Two Jakes'' opens Aug. 10. ``Metropolitan'' opened Aug. 3 in New York and Los Angeles and will open in other cities during the month.''
DOC.TEXT: ``The Two Jakes'' The mood of Jack Nicholson's ``The Two Jakes'' is established before the titles. The Paramount Pictures logo appears, but not as the usual bright and shining pinnacle. The mountain peak is shrouded in gloom, like Mount St. Helens poised to blow its top. ``Chinatown,'' the earlier saga in the violent life of detective Jake Gittes, dealt with Los Angeles in the 1930s. Director Roman Polanski and writer Robert Towne told a grim but fascinating tale of corruption, betrayal and incest, against the background of the power plays in securing water for the booming metropolis. ``The Two Jakes'' takes place 11 years later. The war is over, and the new power battles concern the housing developers and the oil interests. Private detective Gittes has returned from the war and is back at his old stand, sneaking evidence for divorce cases. Builder Harvey Keitel brings Nicholson what seems to be a simple case of adultery. But when the setup is made at a motel, Keitel shoots his wife's lover, who turns out to be his business partner. That's just the first of many discoveries in the labyrinthine script, also written by Robert Towne, who won an Academy Award for ``Chinatown.'' ``The Two Jakes'' ranks with ``The Maltese Falcon'' and other private-eye classics in the richness of characters and prevalence of mood. Since Nicholson also directed, you could expect strong perfomances, and the gallery is rich: Keitel, an enigmatic villain-hero; Meg Tilly, his mysterious wife; Madeline Stowe, the explosive widow; Ruben Blades, a vicious mobster; Eli Wallach, a sympathetic lawyer; Joe Mantell, Gittes' dutiful aide; Perry Lopez, a friendly cop; James Hong, a Chinese mystic. The latter three appeared in ``Chinatown.'' The postwar Los Angeles is brilliantly captured in Jeremy Railton's production design and by Zilmos Zsigmond's photography. Van Dyke Park's score makes excellent use of 1940s music, played low-key. The problem with ``The Two Jakes'' is the same with others in the genre: understanding the plot. A knowledge of ``Chinatown'' is utterly essential; the nuances of the new film are lost without it. Nicholson's narration, added post-production, helps untangle the plot, but many of the early scenes are abruptly cut. Nicholson's Gittes is another of his masterpieces: a rare, complex man, battered by police, mobsters and lying women, but ever in pursuit of the truth. Nicholson remains today's premiere film actor. The producers: Robert Evans and Harold Schneider. The rating is R for language, violence and sexual content. _ By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer.

``Metropolitan'' The time is Christmas vacation, not so long ago. The setting is a Manhattan as white as frosted glass, a city of opera and hotel ballrooms, where erudite youths stroll in top hats and purple gowns and the parents who pay for it all conveniently disappear each evening. It is also, perhaps, the last deb season as we know it. ``I think we are, in a sense, doomed _ the whole preppie class,'' laments one young Park Avenue socialite in ``Metropolitan,'' a witty, sweetly-paced film by writer-director Whit Stillman. Stillman cites F. Scott Fitzgerald's 1920 novel ``This Side of Paradise'' as inspiration, and the ill-fated Sally Fowler Rat Pack is a worthy update of the author's celebrated chronicle of egotists and debutantes. Here is ``The Breakfast Club'' with a sense of humor, a world of young people terminally bored but never boring. Led by the mocking, self-satisfied Nick Smith (Christopher Eigeman), the SFRP (as they sometimes call themselves) drifts from party to party, contemplating morality, class conflict and the imminent obsolescence of the ``urban haute bourgeoisie.'' It all begins with a recital at Carnegie Hall, attended by the SFRP and Tom Townsend (Edward Clements), a red-headed loner brooding inside a rented tux. When each happens to hail the same cab, Tom is offered a free ride, not only for the taxi but as a new member of the rat pack, which suffers from a shortage of good escorts. Considering himself a principled socialist (and one who eats cornflakes for breakfast), Tom wants no part of it. ``It wouldn't be any great tragedy if these people lost their social perogatives,'' he says huffily, knowing well that Karl Marx would never succumb to an evening of duplicate bridge. But Nick sees right through him. Why spend all your time with the more fortunate, he observes, ``when one can be at home worrying about the less fortunate.'' Promised a life of ``music, drink, entertainment and hot, nutritious meals,'' Tom stays, buying the tux instead and welcoming the chance to get away from his unfeeling stepmother. Nick appreciates him and so does Audrey Rouget (Carolyn Farina), a shy, Jane Austen devotee who develops a crush on Tom despite literary disagreements and his lingering infatuation with the beautiful Serena Slocum. The story is about Tom and Audrey, but Nick carries the film, right from the moment he derides Tom as a ``public transportation snob'' for preferring buses to cabs. Eigeman, his head cocked, his lip curled, offers running commentary on the rat pack's vapid lifestyle _ and his own inability to resist it. Whitman makes the film in Nick's spirit, never missing an opportunity to make fun of these people but helpless to do anything except wish them well. ``Metropolitan'' moves along so effortlessly you'd never guess Whitman and all the actors are making their film debuts. In fact, Farina still works as a sales clerk at Macy's. But not for long. The New Line Cinema Release is rated PG-13. Running Time: 98 minutes. _ By Hillel Italie, Associated Press Writer.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Lohengrin'' (CBS Masterworks) _ Woldemar Nelsson conducts the Bayreuth Festival Orchestra, with Karan Armstrong, Peter Hofmann, Leif Roar, Siegfreid Vogel, Bernd Wiekl and Elizabeth Connell.
Wagner's ``Lohengrin'' doesn't make superhuman demands of its singers the way some of his later works do. But assembling an ideal cast isn't easy, either. The lineup for the 1982 Bayreuth performance that was recorded live by CBS Masterworks and has now been transferred to compact disc, was, unfortunately, far from ideal. ``Lohengrin'' is a romantic fairy tale with nationalistic and religious undercurrents. Elsa, the heroine, is a maid in distress who calls on the man of her dreams for help when she is falsely accused of murder. He arrives in a boat drawn by the famous swan, saves her reputation and marries her. But all their happiness is on one condition _ that she never ask him his name. Elsa can't bear the mystery and soon ruins everything. The title role is sung here by Peter Hofmann, whose pleasant sound and handsome physique made him the most sought-after of Wagnerian tenors for a few years in the late 1970s and early '80s. It wasn't long before his voice grew coarse and strained under the pressure of singing roles too strenuous for him. In this recording, he still sounds pretty good. But there are some forced high notes that in hindsight show he was pushing his voice to do things it wasn't meant to do. Elsa is Karan Armstrong, whose thin, basically unattractive soprano copes adequately with the music but fails to convey the warmth and passion that make her one of Wagner's most treasurable heroines. Elizabeth Connell, as Ortrud, the sorceress who plants fatal seeds of doubt in Elsa, also has a thin voice, but it's more appealing to the ear than Armstrong's. Her husband, Telramund, is sung with little impact by baritone Leif Roar. Siegfreid Vogel is King Henry, and Bernd Wiekl, who would go on to sing more substantial roles at the Metropolitan Opera and elsewhere, is heard in the small part of the Herald. Woldemar Nelsson conducts the Bayreuth Festival Orchestra in a fast-paced reading of the score. The sound is naturally not as well-focused as with a studio recording, but some of the excitement of a live performance comes through. _ By Mike Silverman, Associated Press Writer.

``Hell to Pay'' (Arista) _ The Jeff Healey Band
Since Paul Shaffer plays keyboards on the Jeff Healey Band's ``Hell to Pay,'' here are 10 reasons the album doesn't deserve a plug from David Letterman: 10. It will be controversial, with the title likely to draw objections from those that applauded the 2 Live Crew album ban. ``Heck to Pay'' would've been better. 9. George Harrison and Jeff Lynne both sing harmony on Harrison's ``While My Guitar Gently Weeps.'' Since their voices sound alike, this is a redundant use of Traveling Wilburys. 8. Guitarist-singer Healey and bandmates Joe Rockman (bass) and Tom Stephen (drums) are poor songwriters. The six songs written by one or more of them are built on recycled riffs, and it seems every chord change is telegraphed. 7. Of the four covers, only the bluesy ``I Think I Love You Too Much'' by Mark Knopfler supplies much sizzle. Highlighted by some nifty guitar interplay from Knopfler and Healey, the song makes the rest of the record just that much more disappointing. 6. Other sparks ignited by Healey's guitar are quickly doused when he sings. His voice is dead on arrival. 5. The opening cut, ``Full Circle,'' sounds as though it came from the Foreigner songbook. 4. Even worse, the title cut sounds as though it came from the Bachman-Turner Overdrive songbook. 3. Healey sounds tired on only the second album of a promising career. There are few surprises, few fresh ideas. Producer Ed Stasium must share the blame. 2. Paul Shaffer plays keyboards. 1. With better singing and better songs, the 23-year-old Healey has the talent as a guitarist to make a great album. Letterman should save his plug for it. _ By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer.

Mariah Carey (Columbia) _ Mariah Carey
Not Whitney Houston, the commercial voiceover could say, but an incredible simulation ... That's 20-year-old Mariah Carey, who's making a big splash with her debut album. She's a formidable talent at risk of being a victim of corporate gamesmanship. Trade papers tell of how Columbia Records, concerned about a competing label's plan to release a new Whitney Houston record this fall, tried to steal some thunder with Carey's new record. Consider it stolen. Carey mimics Houston's stylish mixture of light dance pop and synthesized ballads so adeptly one half expects her to break into a chorus of ``How Will I Know.'' This is not to belittle young Carey's talent. The daughter of a New York City opera singer, she's got an amazing seven-octave singing range and is responsible for some other-worldly sounds. Not since the late Minnie Riperton has a pane-shattering voice such as this come around. Hide your dogs for the end of ``All in Your Mind.'' However, while Carey has the ability, she's yet to match it with a vision. The songs and instrumentation are like something you'd find in the generic aisle of a grocery store. If she ever matches her voice to the right songs, watch out. _ By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

On Show: Museum and Gallery Shows and Exhibits
DOC.TEXT: The striking images of James Lesesne Wells are on view at Hammonds House Galleries in Atlanta as part of the National Black Arts Festival. ``James Lesesne Wells: Selected Works, 1926-1988,'' illuminates the range of the artist's work, from the lithograph ``Negro Worker,'' to the delightful nude, ``The Vamp.'' Wells, who was born in Atlanta in 1902, flourished in New York during the Harlem Renaissance, and his modernist black and white prints established him as a leading printmaker of that period. Watercolors and drawings from the George A. Lucas collection are on show at the Baltimore Museum of Art through Oct. 14. The Lucas collection, known for its fine paintings by Corot, Gerome, Pissarro and others, and for its holdings of more than 20,000 French 19th-century prints, also contains an extraordinary group of about 100 watercolors and drawings, including works by Barye, Besnard, Daubigny, Daumier, Delacroix, Jongkind, Millet and Whistler. It is particularly strong in landscape views and scenes of daily life in France. Thirty-five of the finest works, most of which are rarely seen because of light sensitivity, have been selected for the exhibition. The Lucas collection came to the Maryland Institute College of Art as a gift in 1910 upon Lucas' death. It has been on indefinite loan to the BMA since 1933. Star Watch: Working With Marlon
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Imagine being a foreigner and learning English from Marlon Brando. That happened to Maximilian Schell 28 years ago, but he still has managed to win an Academy Award and a host of other honors. The English lessons happened when Schell made ``The Young Lions.'' The Austrian actor had to learn his lines by phonetics, and Brando, the notorious mumbler, proved a big help. ``It was my first experience in a Hollywood movie,'' Schell recalls. ``I didn't speak much English at that time, and Marlon was extremely kind to help me with the part. ``Whenever people say that Marlon was difficult, I just say with me he's the easiest guy in the world.'' The two actors have met on occasion over the years, but they lost touch because, says Schell, ``I don't like to bother famous people.'' They staged a reunion for ``The Freshman,'' in which Brando parodies his classic Don Corleone portrayal in ``The Godfather.'' Schell plays an expert chef who joins the mob boss in an outrageous scheme. ``We embraced each other,'' reports Schell, ``and we sat in the trailer and talked, not about old times, but about philosophy; that was our favorite theme (on `The Young Lions'). He has become more of a philosopher than he was at that time. ``While he has lost some of that young drive that he had, he still is a great screen personality. When he's on the screen, you always have to find a way to stand up against him. That was the same problem on `The Young Lions.' ``I come from the classical stage _ `Hamlet' and `Everyman' and so forth. So I was a very eloquent actor, especially in my native tongue. And Marlon, of course, was famous for this: `mumble, mumble.' It was fascinating, because you had to listen and figure out what he was saying. He changed the style of acting. ``Obviously there is a chemistry between us,'' Schell said. ``Even while we were shooting `The Freshman' we talked about a sequel. We thought it was a good idea of two guys, both retired, one in Switzerland and the other in Sicily. They call each other and say, `Are you bored?' ```Yes.' ```Let's do something together.''' Schell, 59, hadn't heard of Matthew Broderick, the college freshman who stumbles into the Mafia, but found him to be ``fresh and innovative; he stands up very well.'' Acting was inevitable for Maximilian Schell, whose father was a Swiss writer and poet and mother a Viennese actress. Four of their children became actors, including Maria, who starred in ``The Brothers Karamazov,'' and ``Cimarron.'' After the Nazi invasion of Austria in 1938, the family moved to Switzerland, and that's where Max grew up, attending universities at Zurich and Basel. Schell appeared in the classical theater and in German films, and in 1957 he was cast as a German officer in ``The Young Lions,'' along with Brando, Montgomery Clift and Dean Martin. He managed to hold his own in that high-powered company, and Stanley Kramer chose him to play the enigmatic defense attorney in ``Judgment at Nuremberg.'' Both Schell and Spencer Tracy were nominated for the best-actor Oscar for their roles in the drama of the Nazi war-criminal trials, and Schell was the surprise winner. He has also been nominated for best actor in ``The Man in the Glass Booth'' and supporting actor in ``Julia.'' He has continued to act and direct on the stage, and he has directed such films as ``Marlene'' (Academy nomination for documentary), ``First Love'' and ``End of the Game.'' Long one of Europe's most eligible bachelors, he surprised his friends three years ago by taking a bride, Natalia Andreichenko, a Russian actress he met while filming ``Peter the Great.'' They have a daughter 18 months as well as a 7-year-old son by her previous marriage. The Schells now live in Los Angeles. ``It all goes together, I think,'' explains the philosophical Schell. ``You see, the moment I left Switzerland and went to Germany, Austria, London and New York, I became an immigrant. Or emigrant. I once said to a sculptor, `You know, what I miss is a home base; like a tree needs ground, instead of putting a palm tree in the mountains or a pine in the desert.' ``He said, `No, Max, you're a part of the future. We all live on one planet, and you represent that artist who is home everywhere.' That is a consolation for me. ``Marriage was also a new experience. It was unavoidable. When I was in Russia playing Peter the Great, Natasha played my first wife. She said, `I'm very angry with you, because you're putting me into a monastery.' That was a line from the (TV miniseries) because she couldn't speak English. ``That was a good way to introduce herself. Instead of sending her to a monastery, I took her with me to Hollywood. When we came in January, she said, `I will never leave here.' ``I like it, too. When I was a bachelor, I was always going home. You know Hollywood; it can be very cruel. A bachelor can be lonely, even with all the friends you have. So, I went back to Europe. ``Now, with my wife and the babies, you come home, you may be sad, but she throws her arms around your neck, and it's all good.''
