For release Thursday, Aug. 9, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Elder Abuse Project Targets Fraud, Other Financial Problems
With BC-PRI--Abuse-Louisiana, b2002
DOC.TEXT: Suppose you're an elderly man living alone and using an electric wheelchair. Financial difficulties force you to pawn the chair, but you can't move without it. What do you do? Imagine you're an elderly woman living alone and a salesman knocks on your door, saying one of your friends referred him. He comes in, describes the product, and you say you're not interested. But instead of leaving, he stays for hours until you sign a contract and buy the product. Now what? In Arizona, you can call the Elder Abuse Project. These situations happened, and project staff members or volunteers found remedies. Of 3.7 million Arizona residents, nearly 468,000 are 65 or older, the Arizona Center on Population Statistics estimates. The center says that total grows by an estimated 250,000 during winters. About four years ago, Attorney General Bob Corbin and his chief assistants noticed the number of cases involving financial exploitation of the elderly was growing, says project director Anita O'Riordan. The project was developed to help attorneys and investigators prosecute such cases and to help the victims. It has evolved into a broader community service. In the wheelchair case, the man tried to retrieve his chair from the pawn shop but learned it had been sold. The project persuaded the pawn shop to locate another electric wheelchair for him. In the other case, the woman told the abuse project that a carpet cleaning salesman had come to her home and stayed seven hours. During that time, he sold her an expensive ``vacuum system'' she couldn't use. The woman suffered from a heart condition and was so upset by the salesman's visit that she spent the night in a hospital emergency room. When she returned home, she was told by the carpet cleaning company that she was too late to cancel the contract. That contract included a lien on her home if she failed to make payments on the system. Ms. O'Riordan contacted the company's headquarters in another state. The company refunded nearly $2,000 to the woman and released her from the contract. Situations like these happen all the time, and not only to older people, Ms. O'Riordan said. But older people are more likely to become victims because they are more trusting, she said. Many grew up in small towns where everybody knew everybody else, and a handshake was enough. ``Even after they've been taken ... they'll say something like, `I can't believe he would do that, he looked so nice,' '' said Jack Confer of the project staff. Among other cases were: _ Alleged fraudulent sales of fiberglass burial containers totaling about $550,000. A man was charged in April with violating the Arizona Consumer Fraud Act. _ A Phoenix man pleaded guilty in May in connection with fraudulent sales of energy-saving products. Under the plea agreement, he will be liable for restitution to victims. The investigation was triggered by a complaint to the project. The office also sometimes prosecutes physical abuse cases. Those cases are referred first to either the Department of Health Services or Adult Protective Services, but the agencies may refer a case back to the Elder Abuse Project. A case usually starts with project and ends with the project, which can prosecute physical abuse as either a criminal or civil case, Confer said. The project has three full-time paid staff members, plus an average of 35 volunteers a year. The $82,000 in salaries and other costs are covered within the attorney general's budget. Some people bring their complaints to the project. Others use its ``Fraudline'' phone number. Additionally, volunteers travel to senior centers throughout the state. After someone contacts the project, a volunteer assists in preparing a complaint for the project's files. If the matter involves an individual or company licensed by a state agency, the elder is assisted in filing a complaint with that agency. Project staff members and volunteers work to clarify issues in the case, verify facts and obtain documentation. They may consult experts. The staff then may try to resolve the complaint through mediation, or it may be referred to the appropriate division of the attorney general's office. Volunteers also speak at crime prevention meetings arranged in response to community or group requests. Under the project's BEEP system, for Beware of Elderly Exploitation Program, volunteers are trained to speak to community groups about health quackery, financial exploitation, and how not to be a victim. The project also offers a brochure: ``Consumer Protection Kit: An Older Person's Guide.''

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Has No Money for Adult Protective Services
With BC-PRI--Abuse-Arizona, b2001
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana, barely able to balance its budget each year, may be the only state that does not finance a program to curb abuse of the elderly. An estimated 1.5 million older Americans, or 5 percent of all elderly, are abused each year, up from 1 million in 1980, according to a congressional report. Only one in eight cases is reported, according to estimates. Information was not available from 10 states in the 1989 survey for the U.S. House Select Committee on Aging. Of the other 40, only Louisiana provided no money for Adult Protective Services. A program still exists under state law, but the money ran out in 1988 and has not been included in the state budget since. It's not that nobody wants to provide money for adult protection. Gov. Buddy Roemer included $1.4 million for the program in his proposed budget for the fiscal year that started July 1. However, the Legislature couldn't reach a consensus on numerous Roemer tax proposals, and lawmakers found themselves having to trim hundreds of millions of dollars in programs in the session's final hours. They salvaged an $85 million teacher pay raise _ part of a three-year commitment that was among Roemer's highest priorities. But they couldn't save numerous other programs, including Adult Protective Services. An APS office would check out complaints of abuse or reports of adults unable, because of age or other reasons, to take care of themselves, said Brenda Kelly of the state Department of Social Services. If the reports were valid, the office could then refer the victim or the victim's loved ones to the proper government or private agency. Police and local councils on aging _ the offices that run federal- and state-financed programs for old people _ do what they can, Kelly said. ``But when you look at law enforcement and councils on aging, they're pretty stretched,'' she said. Mike Edwards, administrative director of the Jefferson Parish Council on Aging, agrees. ``There is a need out there for it. We have the legislation on the books. The authority to investigate lies with Adult Protective Services workers,'' he said. ``There's nothing we can do. We're strapped.'' Re-establishing an Adult Protective Services system would give the public a single place to call to report abuse and neglect problems, Kelly said. ``Relying on information from local councils on aging, I think what's missing is that front-end piece _ some central place that the public can call and have someone look into it,'' she said. When the money ran out in 1988, 12 people were working Adult Protective Services cases statewide, Kelly said. Often those people also were working on programs protecting children, too. The total monthly case load for Adult Protective Services staff members from June 1985 through June 1988 averaged more than 800, Kelly said. The $1.4 million Kelly had hoped would be available this year would have paid for a staff of 44 that would have concentrated efforts in 12 of the state's more populous parishes, which are Louisian's equivalent of counties.

DOC.HEAD: Avoiding Problems of the Summer Heat and Sun
DOC.TEXT: For many people summer is the time for swimming, sailing, picnics and outdoor recreation. However, summer heat and sun can be treacherous. Older people should be wary of food poisoning and heat strokes, two potentially fatal illnesses associated with summer. These days, most people do not give much thought to food posoning. Modern methods to preserve food and retard bacteria should make the food we eat safe. Bacteria such as salmonella, botulism, staphylococcus and campylobacter are presumed to be fears of a former generation. In fact, most people would be surprised to learn that about 2 million cases of food poisoning occur each year in this country due to improper handling of food in the home. Food poisoning can become epidemic at picnics or other events where food is left unrefrigerated for a long time, when power outages cause refrigerators to shut down, and from canning procedures that fail to kill bacteria. Older people are especially vulnerable to foodborne illness because they are more likely to have medical problems that lower their resistance. Further, many people experience sensory losses that affect food handling. Older people with impaired vision, for example, may have problems recognizing spoiled food or dirty utensils. Diminished taste and smell also may be significant in determining if food is spoiled. Older people who live on a fixed income may be wary of throwing food away. And, in order to hold utility bills down, refrigerators often are kept above the recommended 40 degrees. The following precautions can eliminate most sources of bacteria and prevent food poisoning: _ Refrigerate food at 40 degrees; freeze it at 0 degrees Fahrenheit. _ Freeze raw meat and poultry that will not be used within two days. _ To thaw food, place it in the refrigerator, not on the counter, where bacteria can grow quickly. _ Make sure food and utensils are clean. _ Wash hands with soap and water before preparing food. _ Cook food thoroughly, including food prepared in a microwave. Avoid recipes that call for raw eggs or raw fish. _ Freeze or refrigerate leftovers promptly. _ Never leave a perishable food out of the refrigerator for more than two hours. Symptoms of food poisoning include diarrhea, abdominal pain and nausea. Sometimes it is accompanied by fever and general discomfort. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has established a toll-free number to respond to consumer questions about safe handling of meat and poultry. Call 1-800-535-4555 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. weekdays for information on proper food handling. Heat exhaustion and heat stroke are other potentially dangerous conditions associated with hot weather. Many people become needlessly ill each year because they do not take simple, preventive steps. Heat exhaustion is a warning that the body is getting too hot. Symptoms include thirst, giddiness, weakness, nausea and profuse sweating. If not attended to, heat exhaustion can develop into a more serious condition known as heat stroke. Older people are especially vulnerable to heat-related illnesses. Changes that can effect a person's ability to cope with heat include inefficient sweat glands, poor circulation and changes in the skin. Frail older people who cannot move easily to a cooler place or who are not aware of the heat also are in jeopardy. Some medications such as diuretics, sedatives and tranquilizers, and certain heart and blood pressure drugs, may affect the way an individual copes with heat. Don't discontinue medication, but discuss potential problems with a doctor. Diseases that require special diets also may make a person more vulnerable to heat stroke. People with high blood pressure, for example, generally reduce the amount of salt in their diet, making temperature regulation more difficult. However, a person should not take salt tablets without consent of a doctor. Avoid heat exhaustion and heat stroke by following some simple steps: _ Drink plenty of water and juices. _ Wear light-weight, light-colored and loose-fitting clothing. _ Avoid activity during the hottest part of the day. _ Keep meals simple and light. Keep oven use to a minimum. _ Use air-conditioners liberally or, if none is available, plan trips to cool places such as shopping malls, theaters and libraries. Anyone suspected of suffering heat stroke should receive immediate attention. Victims of heat stroke have a body temperature of 104 degrees or higher. The pulse may be rapid. Other symptoms may include flushed skin, a faint feeling, confused and bizarre behavior and combativeness. If symptoms are mild, get into a cool place, drink non-alcoholic, non-caffeinated fluids, and sponge off with cool water or take a cool bath or shower. If symptoms are severe, get emergency medical assistance immediately. Without quick attention heat stroke is frequently deadly, especially for older people.

DOC.HEAD: Pepper Commission Urges New Aid for Elderly
DOC.TEXT: New help for the poorest elderly and improvements for those who buy private insurance to supplement Medicare coverage are being urged by the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care. Known as the Pepper Commission in honor of the late Rep. Claude Pepper, a champion of the elderly, the panel said implementation of the recommendations would close gaps in Medicare that ``expose the elderly to considerable financial risk'' and may result in their receiving less health care. The recommendations are intended to complete the commission's set of proposals for a comprehensive national policy designed to provide adequate health care and long-term care for all Americans. The newest proposals would: _ Help the poorest elderly pay premiums, deductibles and co-payments required under Medicare. The commission said this would require $2.6 billion in additional federal spending if implemented this year. _ Expand Medicare to cover certain preventative services, including tests for cancer and prostate screening. Estimated yearly cost: $200 million. _ End or reduce abuses in private insurance coverage by creating federal standards for ``Medigap'' insurance. The standards would include requiring insurers to pay out a higher proportion of their premium revenue as benefits; bar insurers from refusing to sell insurance to anyone based on health standards and develop simpler and easier to understand premium language to be standard for each company. _ Establish registries of Medigap policies to minimize duplication of coverage.
DOC.HEAD: `Real Life Poverty' Affects Millions, Foundation Says
DOC.TEXT: The official U.S. government poverty line understates the number of Americans who live in poverty, a report by the Families USA Foundation says. The report estimated that 45 million people live in ``real life poverty'' in the United States, significantly higher than the 32 million counted by the government. The report also said that by its standards, the poor are more likely to be white, older and better-educated than government figures would indicate. The report is based on an analysis of 3,511 responses to four Gallup polls conducted between July and October 1989. People were asked what income they would use as a poverty line for a family of four in their communities. The average response was $15,017 a year compared to the government's official poverty line of $12,092. Ron Pollack, the foundation's president, contended the government poverty line is based on an arbitrary and outdated formula. ``The real life poverty line is rooted in the experience of America's consumers who know the real costs they have to pay to purchase the essential necessities of life,'' Pollack said.

DOC.HEAD: Foster Grandparents, Celebrating 25 years of Service to Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Yde is cq in 13th graf.
DOC.TEXT: As a child, Tom Flatley was separated from his parents and placed with his brother in a Missouri home for the retarded, mentally ill and criminally insane _ even though both children were normal in all respects. Flatley, now 79, who suffered ``environmental retardation'' because of his surroundings, has returned to the same institution as a volunteer, working with children who need help. Flatley is a part of Foster Grandparents, a low-key, relatively inexpensive government program that pairs low-income elderly people with children in need. Foster Grandparents is celebrating its 25th anniversary this summer and Flatley and 27 of his colleagues from programs around the country were welcomed to the White House by President Bush and his wife, Barbara, to mark the occasion. Over the last quarter-century, since President Johnson signed enabling legislation on Aug. 28, 1965, 400,000 Foster Grandparents have offered cheer and a ready ear to millions of children. Today, there are 27,000 Foster Grandparents, ages 60 to 100. Each is paid a stipend of $2.20 an hour for 20 hours of work each week. Some get assistance with transportation and meals, and each is eligible for a free yearly physical checkup. Sixty is the minimum eligible age. An income near the poverty line also is a requirement. The volunteers serve some 79,000 children with special needs in 275 programs in every state, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The program's budget last year was $58 million. Foster Grandparents are found in halfway houses, schools, Head Start facilities, drug abuse rehabilitation centers, foster homes, juvenile detention centers and homes for unwed mothers. The children they help may be blind, deaf, or retarded; they may be emotionally disturbed, or suffer from drug or alcohol abuse, parental neglect or abuse, learning disorders or any combination of conditions. Some are ``boarder babies,'' abandoned at birth and cared for at hospitals. Many were born to addicted parents and suffer the inherited effects of alcohol or drug abuse. Many are AIDS babies, born to a parent who has the disease. ``Some of these situations are not in any way easy,'' says Nancy Yde, public affairs director for ACTION, the federal domestic volunteer agency that directs the Foster Grandparents program. She said one Foster Grandparent is working with an emotionally disturbed child who killed her father, saying she did so because he had killed her mother. At the White House ceremony, Mrs. Bush said the need is growing for older people with ``precious gifts to exchange with the children of this world.'' Mrs. Bush said William Bennett, head of the U.S. government's war against drugs, told her that more Foster Grandeparents are needed than ever before ``because unfortunately the boarder babies and the other babies that need you are multiplying.'' Tom Flatley says he talks to the mentally retarded children with whom he works and reads them stories. ``They can do for themselves a little bit, but I help them along,'' he says. ``One little boy can walk a little, with help. ``The other child I have doesn't respond at all; but he still needs someone to love him,'' Flatley told ACTION for a profile written about his work. ``Children all over the country need someone to love them and I am going to do my part.''

DOC.TEXT: Rising unemployment and fears of spreading Middle East conflict have blasted the financial markets. Stocks plummeted and interest rates jumped on speculation the battered U.S. economy could get worse. Feeding the turmoil Friday was the government's report that unemployment rose in July, another sign the economy might be slipping into recession. Oil prices rose sharply for the second straight day after Iraq's invastion of Kuwait, feeding inflation fears.

Motorists across the country already are being hit by higher gasoline prices due to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent jump in oil prices. The American Automobile Association said Friday its survey of 1,400 retail gasoline stations nationwide showed self-serve unleaded gasoline prices had gone up 4 cents in two days, to an average of $1.115 a gallon.

The nation's unemployment rate shot up to 5.5 percent last month, its highest level in two years, the government said. The Labor Department's unemployment report on Friday showed widespread weakness in the job market as payrolls fell by 219,000 jobs. That number was bloated by the 160,000 temporary census workers the government laid off, but other sectors of the economy posted job losses, too.

Sales of cars and trucks made in North America by the Big Three automakers rose 4.6 percent in late July, primarily because of strong sales by General Motors Corp. GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. reported Friday that combined sales of cars and light trucks at an average daily pace of 37,914 during the July 21-31 period this year, compared 36,256 last year.

Ford Motor Co. has agreed to sell its Ford Aerospace Corp. unit to the defense electronics company Loral Corp. for $715 million in cash. The sale, announced Friday and subject to government approval, moves Ford closer to its goal of ridding itself of its non-automotive businesses.

A New York firm that invests in corporate takeovers said it is considering trying to buy Greyhound Lines Inc. in a deal to end a drivers' strike. A partner in the Blackstone Group said Friday that any deal to take over the bus line would have to include the return of the 6,300 union drivers who have been on strike since March 2. Greyhound has been operating under protection of federal bankruptcy laws since June. A Greyhound spokesman said the firm had no plans to sell the bus line voluntarily.

President Bush nominated attorney Richard Y. Roberts to fill a vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Roberts, a former chief of staff to Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., would fill the seat of Joseph Grundfest, who left the five-member commission in January. The nomination announced Friday is subject to confirmation by the Senate. No date for confirmation hearings was set.

Allegheny International Inc. announced bankruptcy court approval of an agreement that will give a New York investment group control of the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The court approved an agreement that allowing the investors, Japonica Partners, to take control of Allegheny International on Aug. 15. The deal is contingent on Japonica's ability to raise enough money.

Northwest Airlines, moving to counter rising jet fuel prices, said it will add a flat one-way surcharge of $8 to the price of domestic tickets beginning Aug. 9. The surcharge stems directly from increases in jet fuel costs incurred by the carrier since Iraqi troops invaded oil-rich Kuwait, Northwest said Froday.

Stock prices fell sharply Friday in a convulsive reaction to Middle East oil worries and mounting recession fears. The Dow Jones industrial average, down more than 120 points at its midsession low, closed with a 54.95-point loss at 2,809.65. The dollar climbed against most major currencies in volatile trading. Long-term bond prices plunged again on high unemployment and Middle East tensions. Oil futures ended sharply higher; precious metals were higher; copper futures fell; livestock and meat were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plummet
DOC.TEXT: Share prices plummeted Monday on London's Stock Exchange as worries over increasing oil prices gripped the market. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 60.4 points, or 2.6 percent, at 2,224.2. Volume was 377.6 million shares at midday, compared with 290.3 million shares at the same time Friday. The rapidly rising oil price has sparked fears of low economic growth plus inflation in the British economy, which already has been under pressure from the government's high interest rate policy, dealers said. Most of the share price declines came from markdowns by market makers. Few investors were entering the market, dealers said. Earlier in Tokyo, the Nikkei index slumped 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, to 28,599.53.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Motors to Produce Cars in Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Motors Corp. said Monday it will provide technical assistance for a joint venture to produce its passenger cars in Venezuela beginning in September. Mitsubishi spokesman Kyoichi Shimada said the joint venture, MMC Auto Motriz de Venezuela SA, will produce 800 passenger cars this year primarily with parts shipped from Japan. The production will increased to 10,000 cars and small trucks by 1995, he said. Shimada said MMC Auto is capitalized at $24.5 million and is owned 49 percent by Consorcio Inversionista Fabril SA of Venezuela, 42 percent by Nissho Iwai Corp., a major Japanese trading firm and 9 percent by Japan International Development Organization Co. of Japan. He said the cars will be assembled at an idle plant in Barcelora, 210 miles east of the Venezuelan capital of Caracas. The plant is owned by a subsidiary of Consorcio Inversionista Fabril, Shimada said. Mitsubishi Motors is owned 13.1 percent by Chrysler Corp. of the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis and Foreign Market Reactions Rattle Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: The convulsions continued on Wall Street this morning where stock prices plunged in the wake of setbacks on foreign markets. Worries about the economic impact of the Persian Gulf crisis and resulting oil price spiral caused investors to bail out of stocks in a big way earlier in Tokyo, London and elsewhere. Circuit breakers designed to cushion market declines were tripped by early activity in stocks and stock index futures, the New York Stock Exchange said. A ``sidecar'' computer file had assumed the role of handling computer-driven program trades. After the first 30 minutes of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 blue chips was off about 85 points at 2,724. Most of the stocks included in the most widely watched U.S. market barometer were delayed in opening due to imbalances between sell and buy orders. But by 10 a.m. EDT, 27 issues had opened. Declining issues took a huge lead over advances on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,083 down, 144 up and 199 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board amounted to 36.04 million shares. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 4.12 to 184.70. Meanwhile, at the American Stock Exchange the market value index lost 4.81 to 341.82. U.S. stocks, already weakened by concerns about U.S. economic health, have been battered by speculation that sharply higher oil prices could trigger a recession accompanied by rising inflation. A few stocks, particularly oil and gold issues, benefited from the situation. Exxon added 1] to 54{ and was the most active issue on the Big Board with volume of nearly half a million shares. Texaco rose 2] to 67, Chevron gained 1\ to 80, Mobil moved up 1| to 68{ and Amoco jumped 1] to 58~. Among heavily traded blue chips, International Business Machines slid 3] to 103{, Philip Morris lost 2~ to 43| and American Telephone & Telegraph skidded 1{ to 34{. Market watchers had expected stocks to get off to a rocky start in the United States. Earlier, the Toykyo market's Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, on trading of an estimated 330 million shares. On the London market at midday, the Financial Times-100-share index was down about 60.4 points, or about 2.6 percent, to 2,224.2. Eugene Peroni, director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia, said ``I think it's going to be pretty rough.'' But he said that ``later in the session we'll see the market begin to turn.'' On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 100 points early on and then recovered some of its loss, ending the day off 54.95 points at 2,809.65. The average lost 88.86 points in the week. Losers swamped gainers in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 5 to 1 with 264 up, 1,457 down and 305 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board reached a 1990 high of 292.36 million shares, up from 253.09 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index tumbled 3.54 to 188.82. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slumped 5.52 to 346.63.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Imposes Oil Embargo; China Stops Arms Sales to Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with latest on oil prices, stocks. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rose more than $3 a barrel today after Japan and the European Community joined other nations in halting imports of Iraqi oil to protest the invasion of Kuwait. China halted weapons sales to Iraq. Australia's government today banned oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait and defense sales to Iraq, revoking an export license for the sale of $680,000 worth of engine components to the Iraqi air force. The spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, was $26.59 a barrel in London this morning, up from Friday's closing price of $23.48. In early trading today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate _ the benchmark grade of U.S. crude _ was trading at $26.75 a 42-gallon barrel, up $2.26 from Friday's close. The rising prices led to fears of inflation, and stock prices fell in Tokyo, London and the United States. Japan, which imports 99 percent of its oil, announced Sunday it would stop importing Iraqi oil. It also imposed an embargo on oil from Kuwait, which Iraq seized Thursday. Japan's prime minister, Toshiki Kaifu, said today that 142 days worth of oil reserves should cushion the impact for Japan. Nevertheless, the Tokyo Stock Exchange took a sharp tumble. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent. In London at midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 60.4 points, or 2.6 percent, at 2,224.2. On Wall Street, the closely watched Dow Jones industrial averaged plunged around 93 points to the 2,716 level in the first half hour of trading. In Beijing, Premier Li Peng reiterated China's opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and said Beijing supports the U.N. Security Council resolution condemning the invasion and demanding an immediate pullout. ``Under such circumstances, it is only natural that China will not sell arms to Iraq,'' he said. Western intelligence reports indicate China has sold billions of dollars worth of arms to Iraq, including Silkworm missiles, but Beijing has denied supplying weapons. The Soviet Union and France, Iraq's main arms suppliers, halted weapons sales to Baghdad last week. The governments of France, Italy and Spain declared Sunday they would follow EC guidelines and impose sanctions voted by that group Saturday. Sanctions include oil embargoes, freezing of Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets, and ending preferential trade agreements with Baghdad. This significantly broadened the campaign to punish Baghdad. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in Washington that President Bush welcomed Tokyo's decision. Such measures ``will help intensify international pressures aimed at achieving the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait,'' Fitzwater said. Just hours after Thursday's invasion, Washington imposed an embargo on oil and other imports from Iraq, and froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States. Japan's action was seen as especially tough because Tokyo has taken a low profile in the Middle East with an eye to guaranteeing oil imports. Kaifu said the Iraqi invasion ``was not a permissible act.'' The sanctions, he said ``will press Iraq to consider its action, and we have to consider how this will affect our people.'' Japan relied on Iraq and Kuwait for 11.2 percent of its oil supplies in the first quarter of the year, the trade ministry says. ``This is a problem that will have an effect on our lives to some extent,'' Kaifu conceded. ``We will come up with necesssary measures to cope with the problem, but Japan, after the past oil crises, has 142 days of reserves.'' Iraq and Kuwait supplied about 11 percent of the European Community's oil needs. Those countries will face difficulties roughly equal to Japan's in maintaining oil supplies if the crisis drags on for a long time. Kaifu called on Japanese to conserve energy, a recurrent theme this summer as a long hot spell had the Tokyo area's electricity generators working at full capacity. The dollar was lower on concerns about the effect of high oil prices on the U.S. economy. It closed at 149.50, up 0.15 yen from Friday's close of 149.35 yen. Oil traders in Asia say Japanese companies made large purchases of Iranian oil over the weekend to bolster their positions ahead of the announcement of the oil embargo. Japan's sanctions also include a freeze on Iraqi assets in Japan, suspending loans to Iraq and banning investment and financing in both Iraq and Kuwait. The sanctions will hurt Japanese companies hoping to recover debts from Iraq, which owes $4.6 billion to Japan, much of that held by the private sector. Repayments were coming through sales of Iraqi oil to Japan.

DOC.HEAD: What Will it Take to Make Saddam Blink?
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 5th graf, In an... to UPDATE with Iraq's reported decision to stop pumping most of its oil through Turkey. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Economic reprisals against Iraq are piling up as Europe and Japan join the U.S. boycott of Iraqi oil. But for international pressure to defeat the invasion of Kuwait, two Middle Eastern neighbors may have to take an even tougher step. Turkey and Saudi Arabia would have to choke off the oil pipelines _ literally. More than half of Iraq's daily export of 3.14 million barrels pours through two pipelines, one through Saudi Arabia and the other through Turkey. The rest is shipped in tankers through the Straits of Hormuz, which have become difficult to traverse because of wreckage and mines left over from the Iran-Iraq war. Despite subtle pressure from President Bush, neither Saudi Arabia nor Turkey has been willing _ so far _ to incur the wrath of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein by taking such a dramatic step. With Iraqi forces massed menacingly along its border, Saudi Arabia seems particularly vulnerable. In an apparent attempt to forestall such a blockade, Iraq today notified Turkey it would stop pumping through one of the two pipelines and would use only 70 percent of the capacity of the second, Turkey's semi-official Anatolia news agency reported. Many experts believe the current embargo will be difficult to sustain. Without oil from Iraq and Kuwait, prices will rise and economic growth will drop _ distasteful scenarios in any of the Western democracies. Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, predicted the oil boycott could collapse. ``Some people lie. Some people don't get on board,'' he said. On CBS-TV Sunday, Aspin said a blockade cutting off Iraqi oil deliveries might stand a better chance of forcing Saddam to blink. ``Saddam Hussein did not make his decision lightly,'' said James Schlesinger, a former defense and energy secretary and one-time CIA director. ``Because he has decided to accept the diplomatic flak ... it will be hard to bluff him out of his booty.'' International navies _ especially the Americans, French and British, which maintain ships in the Indian Ocean _ could mount a sea blockade at the southern tip of the Straits of Hormuz. But to be fully effective such a move would have to be carried out jointly with a disruption of the land pipelines. Incensed at Saddam's flagrant invasion of his tiny neighbor last Thursday, the United States succeeded in gaining unprecedented international support for a campaign to strangle Iraq's limping economy. The administration, followed by the 12-nation European Economic Community, wealthy Japan and Canada, banned oil purchases from Iraq. The Soviets, French and Chinese _ Iraq's main arms suppliers _ promised not to send Saddam any weapons. The United States, Britain and Japan froze Kuwait's considerable assets so that Iraq couldn't loot them, and banned food shipments to Baghdad. Japan, one of Iraq's main bankers, also suspended lending to cash-hungry Saddam. Saddam, his economy in tatters from a ravaging eight-year war with Iran, is vulnerable. He launched the invasion of Kuwait after failing to pressure that country into reducing oil production so world oil prices would rise and fill Iraq's coffers. Saddam faces 45 percent inflation, food shortages and a lack of ready cash for badly needed reconstruction. Despite massive oil reserves _ Iraq is second only in proven reserves to Saudi Arabia _ debt-ridden Iraq has had trouble getting loans. But Saddam, by all accounts a clever man, probably figured the potential gain from taking over Kuwait's bountiful oil fields and rich treasury was worth the risk. He knows a successful oil embargo against Iraq could backfire by punishing Western motorists with higher gasoline prices, Schlesinger wrote in the Washington Post. Barely a day into the U.S. sanctions, prices at many gas stations went up several cents despite the fact that little U.S. oil comes from Iraq and that oil storage facilities here are full to overflowing. Price hikes are unlikely to sit well with Americans. ``We're back to driving big cars again,'' said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio. ``Will the American public make a long-term commitment to seeing that those oil lanes remain open from the Mideast? That's something we've never done.'' European leaders, too, might have a problem getting support for a long-term oil boycott. Europe imports 11 percent of its oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Finally, there are many who believe Saddam _ a military man _ only understands one language. Sanctions, said Kuwaiti Ambassador Saud Nassir al-Sabah, ``take months and months to have any effective return ... to deal with this man and with his regimes, he can only understand force.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ruth Sinai has covered the Middle East for The Associated Press and is now covering foreign policy in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Definitive Merger of Firstar Corp., Banks of Iowa Inc. Announced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits to make it Monday sted today in lede, conforming to style.
DOC.TEXT: Firstar Corp. and Banks of Iowa Inc. said Monday they had agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $200 million. The companies said it would be the first interstate merger agreement in Iowa since that state approved an interstate banking law earlier this year. The agreement calls for Firstar, which is an $8.5 billion bank holding company based in Milwaukee, to exchange 2.7 of its shares for each outstanding share of the common stock of Banks of Iowa, a $2.5 billion bank holding company based in Des Moines. Based on the closing price of Firstar stock Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, Banks of Iowa shareholders would receive a Firstar stock with a value of about $75.60 per share or a total of $219.1 million. The Iowa company would become Firstar Corp. of Iowa upon completion of the transaction, and the combined organization would have 52 banks and 174 offices in Wisconsin, Iowa, Minnesota, Illinois and Arizona, as well as a trust subsidiary in Florida. The agreement is subject to, among other things, approval by the shareholders of both companies and state and federal banking authorities. The merger ``benefits Firstar by moving us into the growing urban areas of Iowa, which enjoy healthy diversified economies. It benefits Banks of Iowa by adding major new resources for its customers and operations,'' said Firstar Chairman John H. Hendee Jr. Banks of Iowa Chairman Holmes Foster said James R. Lang would become president and chief executive of Firstar Corp. of Iowa upon the closing of the transaction, which is expected in the first half of 1991. Iowa's interstate banking law does not go into effect until Jan. 1. Lang is now president of the First Wisconsin National Bank of Madison. Foster, 63, is to retire upon completion of the transaction. The agreement calls for two members of the Banks of Iowa board to be added to the Firstar board, bringing the total number of Firstar directors to 22. The transaction grants Firstar an option to purchase newly issued shares of Banks of Iowa common stock in an amount equal to 24.9 percent of Banks of Iowa's current outstanding shares.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis and Foreign Market Reactions Rattle Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: The stock market moved broadly lower amid heavy, panicky selling today as the Middle East turmoil and resulting oil price surge unsettled investors. Severe setbacks in foreign financial centers also set the stage for a volatile day on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chips was off 78.71 points at 2,730.94 by 12 a.m. on Wall Street, an improvement from a morning loss of about 105 points. Declining issues took a huge lead over advances on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,448 down, 194 up and 223 unchanged. Trading activity was close to Friday's brisk pace. Volume on the floor of the Big Board was a heavy 131.07 million shares, compared to 132.72 million at the same point Friday. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 4.94 to 183.88. Meanwhile, at the American Stock Exchange the market value index lost 5.93 to 340.70. Circuit breakers designed to cushion market declines were tripped by early activity in stocks and stock index futures. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano told reporters the nation's biggest stock market was weathering the session with no problems. The levels of trading and price swings were far below the hectic thresholds that the exchange experienced during the October 1987 crash and October 1989 minicrash, he said. ``The market continues to react to current economic and political situations coming out of the Mideast,'' Torrenzano said at an impromput news conference. In Washington, a Securities and Exchange Commission spokesman had no comment while a spokeman at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said the agency was monitoring the situation. U.S. stocks, already weakened by concerns about U.S. economic health, have been battered by speculation that sharply higher oil prices could trigger a recession accompanied by rising inflation. A few stocks, particularly oil and related issues, benefited from the situation. Exxon added 1] to 54{, Texaco rose 1] to 66, Chevron gained { to 79\, Mobil moved up 1] to 68\ and Amoco jumped 1} to 59\. Among heavily traded blue chips, International Business Machines slid 3\ to 103|, Philip Morris lost 2[ to 44], American Telephone & Telegraph skidded 1\ to 34} and General Electric lost 3] to 66]. Market watchers had expected stocks to get off to a rough start in the United States. Worries about the economic impact of the Persian Gulf crisis and oil price spiral caused investors to bail out of stocks in a big way earlier in Tokyo, London and elsewhere. The Toykyo market's Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, on trading of an estimated 330 million shares. But market analysts said stocks could stabilize later in the session. Eugene Peroni, director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia, said ``later in the session we'll see the market begin to turn.''

DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Plunges by 30
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States plunged again this week, dropping by 30 to 966, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. Last week, the count dropped by 26 to 996. A year ago this week, the count was 874. Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes who keeps track of the count, attributed the decline to weak gasoline prices in the past few months. He said the effects of the higher gas prices that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait probably will not be felt in the drilling industry for several weeks. ``Gas prices have been very disappointing for several months. I think there is a time lag, so you haven't had the effect of higher oil prices. I'd expect (increased drilling) before too many weeks,'' Kerridge said Monday. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The Houston-based oil toolmaker company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Texas' count was down by 16, Oklahoma lost 10 and New Mexico was down by seven. Pennsylvania lost four, Michigan was down six and California and Colorado lost two rigs each. Wyoming gained nine rigs, Louisiana's count increased by seven and North Dakota was up two.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Bonds Dollar Plunge; More Money Into T Bills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites thruout with midday numbers, sharp drop in bonds, analysts' comments. ADDs byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The crisis in the Persian Gulf sent more shock waves through the financial markets today, with stocks, bonds and the dollar plunging because of anxiety about the economic impact of rising oil prices. The panicky selling on Wall Street, meanwhile, heightened the demand for Treasury bills, considered among the most secure investments anywhere. Short-term interest rates declined as a result. ``The situation is sort of confused and chaotic,'' said Robert A. Brusca, chief financial economist for Nikko Securities Co. International. ``Investors are adrift. They don't know what to do.'' The Dow Jones industrial average, the best-known barometer of the stock market, declined about 85 points to the 2,724 level by 12:30 p.m. EDT today, after slipping as much as 105 points earlier in the trading session. In the broader market, declining issues far outpaced advances among stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Overseas stocks also fell sharply. The early plunge tripped so-called ``circuit breakers'' designed by the nation's financial markets to cushion market declines in stocks and stock index futures. The NYSE said a ``sidecar'' computer arrangement had assumed the role of handling computer-driven program trades, which sometimes can inject volatility into prices. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano said the nation's biggest stock exchange was weathering the session with no problems. Traders said speculation that sharply higher oil prices stemming from Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait last week could trigger a recession, accompanied by rising inflation, were responsible for today's selloff. ``The outlook for stocks had been decidedly bad for quite awhile,'' said Brusca. ``The problems in the Middle East have made things worse.'' A key issue now is what action the Federal Reserve might take in directing interest rates, economists said. Inflationary pressures are high as oil prices continue to soar but recent economic data have shown the economy is weakening and could fall into a recession, they said. Those concerns contributed to the drop in the bond market. Investors, unwilling to lock their money into anything long range, dumped long-term Treasury bonds. The government's bellwether 30-year issue, for instance, plunged about 1{ points, or $12.50 per $1,000 face amount, by midday today. The drop was far less dramatic, however, in shorter-term bonds and notes. In foreign exchange trading, the dollar also weakend against most major currencies, although it was showing some signs of recovery. For instance, it was trading at 149.80 Japanese yen, down from 149.925 at Friday's close; 1.5715 German marks, down from 1.5935; and 1.33 Swiss francs, down from 1.3505.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks End Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed sharply lower on London's Stock Exchange Monday, battered by concerns about the conflict in the Middle East and pessimism over oil prices. Stocks opened significantly lower and fell for most of the session, with market watchers nervous about when the price slide would abate. ``Until the (Middle East) situation is resolved, I can't see anyone being enthusiastic about doing any bargain hunting for the moment,'' said George Hodgson, U.K. equity market strategist at Warburg Securities in London. ``There's a total preoccupation with events in the Gulf. All other issues have taken a back seat,'' he said. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 64.4 points, or 2.9 percent, to 2,220.2. The session low was 2,202.5. It peaked at 2,253.1. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 61.5 points at 1,731.9 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 34.22 to close at 1,203.42. Volume came to a busy 591.3 million shares compared with 523.4 million shares traded on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing figures from Europe; selected midday New York prices.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell today against most major foreign currencies in dealings in Europe where traders appeared to focus on recent evidence of weakness in the U.S. economy. Gold prices were higher. Market participants said the dollar slipped mostly in the absence of fresh news from the Middle East, where last week's Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has raised grave doubts about the stability of the region and drove the dollar higher as investors sought safety in the currency. Today's decline reflected speculation that weakness in the U.S. economy will prompt the Federal Reserve to encourage lower interest rates, traders said. ``It if hadn't been for Iraq-Kuwait, the dollar would have dropped to these levels days ago,'' said a senior trader at a large Frankfurt bank. Sharply higher oil prices and a big drop in stock prices on Wall Street where the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 100 points in early trading also pushed the dollar down, dealers said. ``I think the dollar's losing some of its safe haven status,'' said Michael James, head of interbank dealing at Midland Bank in London. ``People are focusing on the fundamental weaknesses (in the dollar).'' In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 149.50 Japanese yen from 149.35 yen at Friday's close. Later in London, it rose to 149.55 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 149.85 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8725 from $1.8570 late Friday. At midday in New York, the pound was trading at $1.87665. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5762 West German marks, down from 1.5920; 1.3315 Swiss francs, down from 1.3505; 5.2863 French francs, down from 5.3345; 1.7760 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7945; 1,154.00 Italian lire, down from 1,164.90, and 1.1490 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1510. Selected midday dollar rates in New York included: 1.5770 West German marks, 1.3255 Swiss francs, 1,150.00 Italian lire and 1.15125 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to $382.50 a troy ounce, up from $379.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to $382.00 an ounce, up from $378.00 late Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.20 to close at $378.58 an ounce. Silver bullion rose in London to $4.91 a troy ounce, up from $4.87 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airlines, Managers Enter Innocent Pleas
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines pleaded innocent Monday along with eight top managers to charges of falsifying safety and maintenance records. U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser in Brooklyn released all eight without bail and continued proceedings to Sept. 12. Prosecutors allege the violations took place from July 1985 to October 1989 and were meant to avoid expensive flight delays and cancellations. Phony records allegedly were kept at Kennedy International and La Guardia airports in New York, Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta and Eastern headquarters in Miami. Eastern and the managers were indicted July 25 on charges of conspiracy to defraud the government, wire fraud, falsification of documents and obstruction of justice. It was the first time an airline has faced a criminal indictment. Attorney Jane Parver entered the innocent plea on behalf of Eastern. The eight managers appeared in court but made no statements other than to enter their pleas. The managers include Thomas Lewis, Eastern's maintenance director for the region from Washington to Montreal; Edward Upton, former vice president of maintenance and engineering; and Joseph Moser, former maintenance manager at Kennedy. The other five were maintenance foremen at Kennedy. They are Charles Catarelli, Stephen Jones, Roy Hardy, Robert Knox and Jacques Jean. The ninth Eastern official charged, former foreman Elia Dragone, pleaded guilty July 31 to two of the 20 counts in which he was named. He faces five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count at sentencing Oct. 17. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles Gerber refused to comment Monday on whether any more plea bargains were in the works. Eastern's employees struck the airline March 4, 1989, and the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five days later. Pilots and flight attendants quit the strike several months later but mechanics remain on strike. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney said in announcing the indictments that there was no evidence of improprieties at Eastern since Martin Shugrue, the court-appointed bankruptcy trustee, assumed management in April.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Fuel Costs May Boost Airline Fares
DOC.TEXT: Higher airline ticket prices almost certainly await U.S. travelers with jet fuel costs rising due to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, industry analysts said Monday. Northwest Airlines announced an $8 fuel surcharge on Friday. Other airlines said they were considering whether to follow suit. But several said such increases were still premature. ``We have not decided to put such a surcharge on yet,'' said Delta Air Lines spokeswoman Glenda Johnson. ``I can't say that we won't, but we don't want to pass these costs on to the consumer.'' She said the airline considered it ``premature'' to increase ticket costs, but didn't rule out an eventual price hike. She said Delta calculated that each penny-per-gallon increase in jet fuel prices costs the airline about $20 million a year. The average domestic price of jet fuel is 61 cents a gallon. Spokesmen for Continental Airlines, Pan American and Eastern Airlines each said their companies were considering increases to offset fuel costs but hadn't reached a decision yet. United Air Lines said it had decided not to comment on the issue. Robert J. Joedicke, an airline analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., called Northwest's price increase ``a little premature because most fuel contracts aren't negotiated until the end of the month.'' But he added: ``It's safe to say there will be an eventual increase by other airlines. I'm certain that depending on the magnitude (of oil price increases) that there will have to a pass through.'' David Swierenga, assistant vice president of airline industry data for the Air Transport Association, a Washington-based industry group, pointed out that a $5-a-barrel rise in world crude oil costs raises jet fuel prices by about 15 cents a gallon. ``The industry consumes about 15 billion gallons of jet fuel a year,'' he said. ``Every penny increase in the price translates into an added $150 million in costs. If, in fact, the industry is faced with a 15-cent-a-gallon increase, that translates into $2.25 billion in added costs.'' Such an increase could well lead to higher ticket prices, he said. But he said that with air travel approaching the post-Labor Day lull, airlines try to hold back or temper any price hikes to avoid cutting too deeply into consumer demand.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Buys Dutch-Manufactured Passenger Planes
DOC.TEXT: Iran Air has signed a deal to buy six Dutch-manufactured Fokker-100 passenger aircraft, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported Monday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Hassan Shafti, head of the state-owned airline, as saying the first of the twin-engine, short-haul aircraft will be delivered next month. The rest will be shipped by the end of the year. Shafti added that a number of Iranian pilots and engineers were being trained in the Netherlands at Fokker's expense, IRNA said. Iran, with one of the fastest growing populations in the world, has faced surging demand for air travel. Aviation experts say the Fokker-100s are too small for Iran Air's needs. The Fokkers are normally equipped with 120 passenger seats. Iran Air ideally would have liked to buy the newer Boeing 757s, 767s, or Airbuses. But it has been unable to add to its fleet of U.S.-manufactured Boeing aircraft and European-made Airbus planes due to American embargoes banning the export of American technology to Iran's anti-American government. Airbus aircraft, manufacted by Aerospatiale, a European consortium, are powered by American-made jet engines.

DOC.HEAD: Predict Federal Reserve Will Lower Interest Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve Board will lower short-term interest rates soon to stimulate a tottering economy that faces a damaging new blow from higher oil prices resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, analysts predicted Monday. An economy that already had slowed to barely perceptible growth during the first half of the year is threatened further by embargoes imposed by the United States and many other Western nations on imports of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. As a result, many analsysts said the Federal Reserve probably will nudge its federal funds rate down from 8 percent to 7} percent to stimulate growth. The federal funds rate, the interest charged by the Fed for overnight loans to banks, has remained high for more than a year as the central bank sought to slow the economy and reduce inflationary pressures. ``Historically, the Fed has actively fought inflation only as long as the economy was not threatened by recession,'' economist Samuel D. Kahan wrote in the current issue of Perspectives, the Fuji Securities Inc. weekly commentary. ``When it appears that the U.S. economy is about to fall into a recession, the Fed must shift its policy efforts,'' he said. ``Recent economic releases suggest that we have entered this zone and we look for the Fed to shift its policy directive and emphasize economic growth.'' ``We expect the Fed to ease the federal funds rate to 7} percent any day soon,'' said Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. If the United States manages to escape a recession induced by Middle East developments, some analysts said higher energy costs combined with rising unemployment would produce something similar to the ``stagflation'' of the late 1970s. ``Its won't be as severe ... but it's an unpleasant combination,'' said Donald Straszheim, chief economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. Charles Schultze, former chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter administration, suggested during a weekend TV interview that the Iraqi invasion could produce a ``mild recession'' if nothing else happens. Many private economists believe the stagnant economy is as close to no-growth as possible without actually being negative. ``Right now, we're skirting the edge'' of a recession, says Robert G. Dederick, chief economist of Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``The economy is just creeping ahead.'' The gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services, rose just 1.2 percent in the second quarter. Some economists said the economy had worsened in July, even before the Iraqi invasion. However, Zandi and some other analysts noted that business inventories, one of the classic portents of a recession, had declined since the first of the year. ``In other major recessions, businesses accumulated big inventories,'' Zandi said, resulting in production declines and job layoffs to correct the situation. Zandi predicted that unemployment will reach about 6 percent by year's end. The jobless rate rose to 5.6 percent in July, the highest level in two years. It exceeded 10 percent during the last recession in 1981-82.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Futures Lead Gains in Grains
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by sharp gains in corn and soybeans as the surging crude oil and gold markets stoked inflation fears. The jump of more than $3 per barrel in crude oil futures also sparked speculation that the Soviet Union, which exports oil to European countries, might soon have more money to spend on grain imports, said Joel Karlin, a grain market analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. ``There are ideas that the higher crude prices will give them a few more dollars to play with and, putting two and two together, they'll have more to spend on food,'' Karlin said. Crude-oil traders bid prices up dramatically Monday in reaction to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and the potential for further armed conflict in the Middle East. Karlin said unseasonably cool overnight temperatures in the Midwest revived concerns about the possibility of early frost damage to soybeans, which added further support. But Karlin said market fundamentals remained bearish. For example, the Agriculture Department's weekly grain export-inspections report indicated export demand for U.S. grains and soybeans is relatively sluggish. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.83 a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 4} cents higher with September at $2.54 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 3 cents higher with September at $1.17 a bushel; soybeans were 5} cents to 13 cents higher with August at $5.95\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Wall Street Trader Agrees to Settle Civil Charges
DOC.TEXT: Former Wall Street trader Salim B. ``Sandy'' Lewis agreed Monday to pay $475,000 to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit arising from his guilty plea to criminal stock manipulation charges. The SEC suit, filed Monday in federal court, alleged Lewis violated securities laws by helping to manipulate the price of Fireman's Fund Corp. stock in 1986 _ the same accusations to which he pleaded guilty in a criminal proceeding. SEC attorney Bruce Hiler said the $475,000 would be placed in a fund and an administrator would return the money to victims of the scheme. Lewis, 51, of Short Hills, N.J., also consented to an order that bars him from any future securities violations. ``Although we believe no one was hurt by the trades in question and there were no financial losses by investors in the marketplace, the settlement was made to avoid lengthy and costly litigation with the government,'' Lewis' attorney, Theodore Wells Jr., said. During his guilty plea last August, Lewis admitted that he manipulated the stock price of the Fireman's Fund in May 1986 on the same day American Express Co. planned to sell to the public a large part of its stock in Fireman's Fund. Lewis was implicated by West Coast trader Boyd L. Jefferies, who said he helped in the Fireman's Fund stock manipulation. Lewis was sentenced to three years probation and a $250,000 fine. His former firm, S.B. Lewis & Co., also pleaded guilty in the criminal case. Jefferies was sentenced to five years probation and a $250,000 fine.
The stock market remained broadly and sharply lower late this afternoon. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was off 82.42 at 2,727.23 with five minutes left to go in the session.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Denies Report It Will Make Trucks
DOC.TEXT: An automotive trade journal reported Monday that Honda Motor Co. Ltd. plans to enter the truck market and boost its U.S. sales by 50 percent by 1995, but Honda denied the report. Honda, which makes no trucks, denied the story in Ward's Automotive Reports, saying only that the company is studying an expansion into the truck market, which includes minivans, pickups and sport-utility vehicles. ``Eventually, we want to be in every segment of the market with the possible exception of full-size,'' Ward's quoted Honda's executive vice president for car sales Thomas Elliott as saying. ``We want to be in trucks, vans and sport-utilities.'' On Monday, Honda spokesman Bob Butorac said Elliott's comments last week at the introduction of the company's new Acura NSX sports car meant only that the company was studying entering the truck market. ``We have no plans to enter it at this time,'' Butorac said. James W. Bush, editor of Ward's Automotive Reports, said the weekly journal stood by its story. There has been speculation in the past that trucks may be in Honda's future in the United States. Honda makes the Accord, the best-selling car in the United States last year; the Civic subcompact; and the Acura line of upscale cars. The truck segment has been one of the fastest growing segments of the entire market. One truck is sold for every two cars in the United States. Honda sold 515,439 cars during the first half of this year, up 13.2 percent from last year. The company commands 9 percent of the U.S. car market with vehicles made in Japan and at its two Ohio assembly plants. Ward's also said Monday that Honda plans to sell 1.5 million vehicles in the United States by 1995. Butorac denied that. ``We've never talked about sales projections beyond the early to mid-1990s, and that's 1 million.''
