DOC.HEAD: Economic Impact of Persian Gulf Crisis Rattles Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices throughout; ADDS point loss since July 30 for Dow Jones industrial average in 3rd graf; changes Dow Jones transportation average close in 13th graf.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The stock market took its worst hit since the ``mini-crash'' last October amid panicky selling sparked by fears that consequences of the Persian Gulf crisis could topple the teetering U.S. economy into recession. Severe setbacks in foreign financial centers had set the stage for a wild day on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chips ended down 93.31 points, or 3.32 percent, at 2,716.34. Since July 30, the widely watched market barometer has lost 200.99 points. It plunged about 105 points in the first 45 minutes of trading Monday and never managed to recover much ground. The day's point loss was the largest since Oct. 13, 1989, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190.58 points. Declining issues swamped advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,530 down, 255 up and 255 unchanged. Trading activity slowed slightly from Friday's brisk pace. But volume on the floor of the Big Board still came to a heavy 240.40 million shares, the third highest of the year and compared to 292.36 million shares on Friday, which was the 1990 high. Last Thursday's volume of 253.09 million shares was the second highest total for the year. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 273.26 million shares. Market watchers had expected stocks to encounter rough going. Worries about the economic impact of Iraq's occupation of Kuwait had caused investors to bail out of stocks in a big way earlier in Tokyo, London and elsewhere. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent, on trading of an estimated 330 million shares. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 64.4 points, or 2.9 percent, to 2,220.2. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano told reporters the nation's biggest stock market coped well with the powerful wave of selling. ``Circuit breakers'' designed to cushion market declines were tripped by early activity in stocks and stock index futures. He said the mechanisms worked without a hitch and appeared to have calmed the volatile market. Investor confidence has been eroded by speculation that the struggling U.S. economy will slump into recession if it must weather a prolonged oil price spiral. Recession fears were fanned Friday by a Labor Department report that showed the nation's unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July from 5.2 percent in June. Airline and trucking stocks were among the biggest losers. The Dow Jones transportation average skidded 58.76 to 980.29, its lowest close in 19 months. A few stocks, particularly oil and related issues, benefited from the situation. The contract for September delivery of the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil jumped $3.56 to $28.05 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But a plea from the White House for oil companies to resist price hikes tempered the rally. Exxon added 1[ to 54\, Texaco rose ] to 65, Chevron gained | to 79], Mobil moved up 1[ to 68 and Amoco added ] to 57~. The volume leader on the Big Board was Philip Morris, which tumbled 2{ to 44 as more than 3.65 million shares changed hands. Among other heavily traded blue chips, International Business Machines slid 3 to 103~, American Telephone & Telegraph pulled back by 1| to 34], American express fell 1{ to 26\ and General Electric lost 3} to 66. UAL plunged 12} to 110 after a published report indicated a proposed employee-led buyout of the parent of United Airlines has run into new difficulty. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $95.47 billion, or 2.92 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slumped 5.50 to 183.32. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 12.32 to 394.74, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 10.43 to 334.43. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slid 17.42 to 417.34. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 340.27, off 6.36.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Surge On Oil-Fueled Inflation Fears
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices climbed strongly Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting growing fears that the soaring price of crude oil will lead to higher inflation. Crude oil futures rose to their highest levels in more than 4{ years as Iraq and the United States appeared to be headed for a showdown over Iraqi aggression in the Middle East. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures rose; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $7.30 to $7.80 higher in New York with the contract for delivery in August at $384.70 a troy ounce; silver ended 5 cents to 5.7 cents higher with September at $4.92 a troy ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished $1 to $3.56 higher with September at $28.05 a barrel, the highest settlement for a near-month crude oil contract since the latter half of 1985; heating oil futures settled 3 cents to 8.97 cents higher with September at 75.55 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 3 cents to 9.34 cents higher with September at 81.52 cents a gallon. Strength in petroleum and precious metals _ as well as weakness in the stock market _ was attributed almost entirely to investor fears that Iraq's occupation of Kuwait could draw the United States into a Middle East war. Especially disturbing, analysts said, were reports that 28 Americans were in Iraqi hands; that American naval forces were in position to launch an aerial attack on Baghdad; and that Iraq appeared to be increasing the size of its force near the border between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. ``You have Iraq's leader and you have President Bush and they're looking at Saudi Arabia, staring each other down, seeing who will be the first to flinch,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in New York. Analysts said the gold market was thinly traded and seemed to have encountered strong resistance near a bid of $385 an ounce. They said the market's next move probably would depend on overnight developments in the Middle East. Grain and soybean futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by sharp gains in corn and soybeans as the surging crude oil and gold markets stoked inflation fears. Crude's gains also sparked speculation that the Soviet Union, which exports oil to European countries, might soon have more money to spend on grain imports, said Joel Karlin, a grain-market analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Karlin said unseasonably cool overnight temperatures in the Midwest revived concerns about the possibility of early frost damage to late-planted soybeans, which added further support. After the close, the Agriculture Department released weekly crop-progress statistics, showing slight deterioration in the condition of the soybean crop and slight improvemet in the corn crop's condition, although both crops remained in mostly good to excellent shape. Crop development continued to lag far behind the normal pace, a function of the heavy spring rains that delayed planting in some areas. A National Weather Service forecast for cooler and dryer than normal weather in the Midwest during the first half of next week could add to worries about the crops, analysts said. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 2\ cents higher with September at $2.82\ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 5 cents higher with September at $2.54\ a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 2} cents higher with September at $1.16} a bushel; soybeans were 6\ cents to 13 cents higher with August at $5.95\ a bushel. Slack demand and lower cash prices weighed on cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; most pork futures advanced, paced by powerful gains in pork bellies, reflecting strengthening demand. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .35 cent lower with August at 76.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .40 cent lower with August at 88.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .03 cent lower to .82 cent higher with August at 58.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with August at 50.55 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost more ground Monday against all major foreign currencies except the Japanese yen amid speculation that recent signs of economic weakness will lead to lower U.S. interest rates. But the decline was tempered by uncertainties about Iraq's occupation of Persian Gulf neighbor Kuwait. Those worries made traders reluctant to push the dollar lower because of the possibility that a military outbreak could send investors in search of the perceived safety of the currency. Gold prices climbed, benefiting from its status as a haven against international turmoil and a hedge against inflation. The dollar moved sharply lower as trading resumed in the United States, pushing the dollar toward its lowest level in 2{ years against the German mark. But the dollar later recovered somewhat as rumors swirled about what may happen overnight in the Persian Gulf. ``This is all emotional trading,'' said Liliana Nealon, first vice president at the New York office of the Union Bank of Switzerland. She said traders expect interest rates to fall in the United States in the wake of last week's unemployment report that indicated the economy may be headed toward a recession, increasing chances that the Federal Reserve would encourage lower interest rates. But she said they are fearful that an eruption of new military action in the Persian Gulf would drive the dollar higher because investors view it as the safest to hold during international turmoil. President Bush said Monday he was ``ruling out nothing at all,'' including a military blockade to choke off Iraqi trade, in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week. The invasion has led to sharply higher oil prices around the world, and triggered a big drop Monday in world stock prices. The dollar gained against the Japanese yen, largely because the Japanese economy is seen as vulnerable to oil price hikes since Japan depends almost entirely on imported oil. By the end of trading in New York, the dollar had risen to 150.35 yen, up from 149.925 yen late Friday. Earlier, the dollar rose to a closing 149.50 yen in Tokyo from 149.35 yen on Friday. In London, it rose to 149.55 yen. But the dollar lost ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8725 from $1.85375 late Friday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8725 from $1.8570 late Friday. It also dropped against the German mark, falling to 1.57875 marks from 1.5935 marks late Friday. That approached the lowest level for the dollar since it hit an intraday low of 1.5615 marks Jan. 4, 1988. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.3310 Swiss francs, down from 1.3505; 5.2890 French francs, down from 5.3415; 1,154.50 Italian lire, down from 1,166.00; and 1.14955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15125. Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5762 German marks, down from 1.5920; 1.3315 Swiss francs, down from 1.3505; 5.2863 French francs, down from 5.3345; 1.7760 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7945; 1,154.00 Italian lire, down from 1,164.90, and 1.1490 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1510. Selected midday dollar rates in New York included: 1.5770 German marks, 1.3255 Swiss francs, 1,150.00 Italian lire and 1.15125 Canadian dollars. Gold prices moved higher in what analysts said reflected the uncertain international state. Gold is often seen as a haven in troubled times, and is also seen as offering a hedge against inflation. On New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $7.30 an ounce to $384.70. At Republic National Bank in New York, an ounce of gold was quoted at $384 an ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, up $6.75 from late Friday. Gold rose in London to $382.50 a troy ounce, up from $379.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to $382.00 an ounce, up from $378.00 late Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.20 to close at $378.58 an ounce. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery rose to $4.892 an ounce, up from $4.842 an ounce last Friday. Silver bullion rose in London to $4.91 a troy ounce, up from $4.87 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Complaint Alleges Shearson Agent Squandered Widow's Money
DOC.TEXT: A Massachusetts official filed a complaint Monday against a Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. agent accusing him of squandering the life savings of a 90-year-old widow. A complaint filed by Secretary of State Michael J. Connolly's office alleges that George Prebola, a Shearson vice president and registered agent based in Boston, conducted unsuitable and highly speculative trading with money invested by Mary Dillon of Walpole, Mass., who was on a fixed income. Connolly's office is seeking to have Prebola's license revoked and to have Prebola and Shearson return the money they made from her investments. Steven Kaigen, a Shearson spokesman in New York, said the matter had been settled privately in May between Shearson and lawyers for Dillon's granddaughter, Bernadette Carty. He said the firm had had no previous problems with Prebola. ``We will work with the commonwealth of Massachusetts to resolve the matter,'' Kaigen said. The complaint alleged that Prebola engaged in dishonest and unethical conduct that resulted in Dillon losing almost all of her initial investment of $150,000. From the initial investment, Prebola earned commissions of about $87,000 and Shearson earned interest charged on margin debts of about $36,000, the complaint alleges. Dillon, who has since died, sold her house when her husband died and sought to invest the proceeds, said Marty Meehan, a deputy secretary of state. According to the complaint, Carty sought an investor in April 1985 to invest her grandmother's money and provide her with a secure income. Prebola assured Carty that Dillon's funds would be safely and profitably invested, the complaint alleges. But in 1986 and 1987, Prebola changed Dillon's investment objective from a conservative investment strategy of ``appreciation with safety,'' to ``speculative,'' the complaint alleged. The complaint also alleges that on several occasions Prebola altered Dillon's personal account information to make her look like a younger, more experienced investor. ``The pattern of trading conducted in the Dillon accounts by Prebola was clearly unsuitable for a 90-year-old woman on a fixed income,'' Connolly said in a statement. Meehan said that by October 1987 Dillon's money was gone. The complaint also alleges that Shearson failed to properly supervise Prebola, allowing him to conduct improper trading in Dillon's accounts, failing to recognize the excessive, disproportionate commissions and margin interest generated in her accounts, and not enforcing its own compliance procedures and guidelines.

DOC.HEAD: Say Industrialized World Should Use Emergency Reserves
With AM-Iraq-Consumers Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House energy subcommittee called Monday on the Bush administration, in coordination with Japan and Europe, to start pumping oil from emergency government reserves to halt the price spiral brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The Strategic Petroleum Reserve has to be used to make sure shortages don't show up ..., to short the market and protect the consumer,'' said Rep. Philip R. Sharp, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on energy and power. Just before it adjourned Saturday, Congress extended Bush's authority to begin drawing upon the 587-million-barrel U.S. reserve stored in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast while it is on vacation for the rest of August. Sharp, D-Ind., said a flooding of market with government reserves from emergency stockpiles in the United States, Europe and Japan could stem rapidly escalating oil prices on the world market. Since Thursday, the price the West Texas intermediate crude has jumped to more than $28 a barrel as of the close of trading Monday, the highest level in five years. An embargo or blockade of oil from Kuwait and Iraq by cutting off pipelines in Turkey and Saudi Arabia, as advocated by the Bush administration, would put further upward pressure on prices. Currently, between 3.5 million to 4.5 million barrels of oil per day _ about 15 percent of the world's supply _ move through those pipelines and via tankers passing through the Straits of Hormuz. The Energy Department has the capacity to pump a maximum 3 million barrels a day from its emergency reserve _ a roughly 200-day supply. A more likely scenario, according to government and private experts, would be to pump between 1 million and 2 million barrels per day from the U.S. reserve in coordination with similar draws from allies' government reserves. Deputy Energy Secretary Henson Moore said last week the Bush administration has no intention to use the reserve only to stop an increase in oil prices. ``The Strategic Petroleum Reserve is not designed as a pricing mechanism,'' he told reporters last Thursday. ``It was designed as a reserve of needed oil in this country, not to set prices.'' The administration of Bush's predecessor, Ronald Reagan, had reached agreements with energy ministers in Japan and the European Community in the middle 1980s to coordinate early draws of their respective reserves if a disruption in world supplies set off a price spiral. The reserve was established as as rainy-day stockpile in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. It has been tapped only once before, in a congressionally ordered 1985 test drawdown of 2 million barrels auctioned off to oil companies. Meanwhile, lawmakers hastily scheduled hearings for Tuesday on what they said was price gouging by the oil companies, wholesalers and service station dealers. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., said oil companies have gone on ``a feeding frenzy'' despite near-record stockpiles on hand. ``The oil companies are playing the old game, heads they win, tails you lose,'' he said. Bryan scheduled a hearing before the Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee, with industry figures, federal regulators and consumer advocates invited to testify. Seventeensenators signed onto a letter circulated by Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., asking Bush to establish an Emergency Oil Price Task Force to focus public scrutiny on the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf's Impact on the Markets At a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief rundown on how the rapidly changing events in the Persian Gulf rippled through the markets Monday and affected other business and economic news:

Panicky traders scoured the world for oil because they feared shortages, and pushed the price to the highest levels in five years. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of key West Texas Intermediate crude jumped $3.56 a barrel to settle at $28.05. Prices for refined products such as heating oil and gasoline also surged dramatically.

The impact of rising oil prices on the already weak U.S. economy pummeled Wall Street again, where stocks tumbled and the widely watched Dow Jones industrial average took the worst one-day spill since the October 1989 ``minicrash.'' The index of 30 blue-chip stocks ended down 93.31 points, or 3.32 percent, at 2,716.34. In the bond market, a sensitive barometer of the economy's health, most prices fell sharply and interest rates rose on fears of higher inflation. But those same fears strengthened the price of gold, historically considered a safe haven investment. The dollar weakened against most other key currencies.

From airport ticket counters to gas pumps nationwide, consumers began paying for the uncertainty in the oil market. Pan American World Airways became the second major carrier after Northwest to jack up prices because of rising fuel costs. Gasoline prices at service stations were up as much as 14 cents a gallon from levels prior to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait last week, provoking cries of price gouging. Several states said they would investigate alleged profiteering. In Washington, the chairman of a House energy subcommittee called on the Bush administration to tap emergency government oil reserves created after the 1970s Arab oil-price shocks in order to halt the latest price spiral.

Many economists speculated that the Federal Reserve Board would lower short-term interest rates soon to stimulate the economy and forestall a recession caused by the new blow of higher oil prices. Some suggested the central bank will nudge interest rates lower through its influence over the federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans to banks.

DOC.HEAD: Western Union Management, Communications Workers Face Contract Deadline
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for Western Union Corp. and representatives of 2,500 unionized workers wrangled over wages and health benefits Monday as the contract's scheduled midnight expiration approached. Ballots in a strike-authorization vote were being counted late Monday, said Dan J. Backstead, president of the Communications Workers of America's United Telegraph Workers Bargaining Council. The CWA has been pushing for higher wage increases. The union also opposes the company's plan to shift some medical premiums to workers and add part-time employees. Negotiations between the union and Western Union traditionally go to the last day of a contract, said company spokesman Warren Bechtel. The union opposed the company's offer of a 2.5 percent annual wage increase over two years, but have not countered with another offer, Beckstead said late Monday in a telephone interview from the negotiating site in Virginia Beach, Va. Western Union is based in Upper Saddle River. Neither Bechtel nor Beckstead would provide specific details about how the insurance costs would be shared, but Bechtel said the company proposed union employees' payments match those made by non-union workers. The union similarly resisted the company's proposals to merge the duties of operators and customer relations clerks and to increase the number of part-time employees not entitled to benefits under the union contract. The company was prepared to use management and 1,000 recently trained temporary workers to keep operating in the event of a walkout, Bechtel said. For most of its 140 years, Western Union held a monopoly on telegram service in the United States. In recent years Western Union has diversified into other communications businesses. Union workers last struck Western Union in 1985, for 10 days. A 1971 labor dispute took 57 days to settle and another in 1952 stretched on for 53 days, Beckstead said.

DOC.HEAD: Mercedes-Benz Again Tops in Sales Satisfaction
With BC-Power Survey-List
DOC.TEXT: For the fourth year in a row, Mercedes-Benz owners rated their car-buying experiences higher than any other make, the J.D. Power & Associates group said Monday. In their first two years covered in the annual survey by the Agoura Hills, Calif.-based market research organization, Toyota Motor Corp.'s Lexus and Nissan Motor Corp.'s Infiniti divisions received high marks. Customers were asked about their experiences in buying their cars, including the appearance and product knowledge of the salesperson and preparation of the car before delivery. The organization surveyed more than 26,000 owners of 1990-model cars bought about 90 days before the survey. Infiniti cars came in second and Lexus was fourth. General Motors Corp.'s Cadillac Division held down third place. In fifth place was GM's Buick Division. The organization releases the rankings only for those cars consumers judge to be average or above. Full copies of the reports are given to people who subscribe at a cost of hundreds of dollars a year. Automakers frequently use results of the Power studies in their advertising. In its monthly Power Report, which announced the results of the new survey, the group said its own index showed that overall customer satisfaction with salespeople and dealers rose slightly from last year. Roundin out the top 10 in the latest Power sales survey were: Lincoln at No. 6, Oldsmobile No. 7, Mercury and Jaguar tied for No. 8, and BMW 10th.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Moves To Reduce Costs With Hiring Freeze, Some Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp., struggling with slumping earnings, has begun a cost-cutting program that includes a hiring freeze and layoffs of up to 40 people, the company said Monday. Lotus, the Cambridge-based software company, has a workforce of 3,100. In the past, Lotus has occasionally closed small divisions, but employees were generally absorbed elsewhere. Susan Yeomans, director of investor relations, said Monday that Lotus has instituted a freeze in some areas in which the company is consolidating and reorganizing. Lotus has merged some sales and marketing functions and plans to eliminate positions where there is redundancy, Yeomans said. Lotus plans to add employees in other areas. David Bayer, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco who follows Lotus, said the freeze comes as no surprise. Lotus reported that earnings more than doubled in the second quarter to $23.5 million, or 54 cents a share on revenue of $175.2 million. But Bayer said he expects earnings to slow in the third quarter. ``I expect them to be profitable, just a lower level of profits,'' Bayer said. ``Clearly they're going to have a decrease in revenues.''

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Jolts Financial Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf, In early ..., after 9th graf pvs, In oil-dependent ..., to UPDATE with early Tokyo market; PICK UP 10th graf pvs, In the ...
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices leaped to their highest levels in nearly five years, and the Dow Jones industrial average took its biggest dive since last October as the financial markets continued to wrestle Monday with the Persian Gulf crisis. The dollar also fell sharply against most currencies in foreign exchange, shedding its historical role as a safe haven during times of political turmoil. Money flowed instead into Treasury bills, among the most secure short-term investments available. ``We have a selling panic going on in the stock and bond markets and a flight to quality to T bills,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``When investors are nervous they tend to pull back.'' On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average _ the best-known barometer of the stock market _ slid 93.31 points to close at 2,716.34, after slipping as much as 105 points earlier in the day. The plunge _ the biggest since last October's ``mini-crash'' _ tripped so-called ``circuit breakers'' designed by the nation's financial markets to cushion market declines in stocks and stock index futures. Declining issues far outpaced advances among stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Monday's drop extended a week-long slide in the market that has erased just just over 200 points from the Dow average. In oil-dependent Japan, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 28,599.53 points, down 916.23 points, or 3.1 percent. In Britain, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index dropped 64.4 points, or 2.9 percent, to 2,220.2. In early trading Tuesday, the Nikkei was down another 457.28 points, or 1.6 percent, at 28,142.25. In the United States, traders blamed the rout on continued worries that sharply higher oil prices, stemming from Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait last week, could trigger higher inflation and push the nation into a recession. ``The economy is in pretty bad shape now. This could make things worse,'' Yardeni said. Oil prices continued their upward trend Monday, with no end in sight. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate soared $3.56 to settle at $28.05 a 42-gallon barrel. It was the highest level for the the benchmark grade of U.S. crude since August 1985, when the price reached $28.08 per barrel. Among refined petroleum products, wholesale unleaded gasoline jumped 9.34 cents to 81.52 cents a gallon. Wholesale home heating oil was up 8.97 cents to 75.55 cents. Market observers said that if the United States and its allies move aggressively to end the conflict in the Middle East, the economic impact may be minimal. But if allowed to linger for weeks, the crisis could erode business confidence, resulting in job layoffs or lower production, the ingredients for a recession. ``We're in the hands of a very, very unpredictable ruthless madman running Iraq, so most people's investment portfolios are being held hostage to what (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein does next,'' Yardeni said. Part of the nation's economic future also hinges on the Federal Reserve's credit policies, economists said. ``The policy options were not good even without thinking about what hostilities lie on the horizon,'' said Robert A. Brusca, chief financial economist for Nikko Securities Co. International. ``The Fed has these conflicting signals.'' A move by the Fed to lower interest rates could stimulate the economy, but it could also further aggravate the inflation outlook. Speculation that the Fed will cut rates helped push the dollar lower against all major currencies, except the Japanes yen. Among the dollar's biggest drop was against the German mark, where it slipped to 2{-year lows. Interest rate concerns, coupled with worries about oil prices, contributed to Monday's drop in the bond market. Investors, unwilling to lock their money into anything long range, sold long-term Treasury bonds. The government's bellwether 30-year issue, for instance, plunged about 2{ points, or $25 per $1,000 face amount. The drop was far less dramatic in shorter-term bonds and notes. Also hurting bonds were concerns about the budget deficit and how it might be affected by the Mideast turmoil. ``With higher oil prices you won't have an energy tax (as lawmakers have discussed) ... and you won't see cuts in defense spending,'' said Maury Harris, chief economist for PaineWebber Inc.
